chunks.title: A Snow White Christmas
chunks.chunk:
Title: A Snow White Christmas
0. A Snow White Christmas is a Christmas animated television special produced by Filmation and telecast December 19, 1980, on CBS.
1. It is a sequel to the fairy tale" Snow White", unrelated to Filmation's other sequel to" Snow White" titled" Happily Ever After"( 1990).
2. The film's plot revolves around the return of the Wicked Queen, who is unexpectedly brought back to life during Christmas and casts an evil spell that freezes the entire land.
3. Only the young Snow White, the daughter of the original Snow White, manages to escape and take refuge with the seven giants with her dwarf friend.
4. It is now up to the giants to defeat the Queen forever and save the kingdom.

chunks.chunk:

2. Released by 20th Century Fox, this was the trio's take on the classic fairy tale" Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs".
3. The film was retitled Snow White and the Three Clowns in Great Britain.
4. This was Walter Lang ‘s final directing film before his retirement.
5. Olympic gold medalist figure skater Carol Heiss starred as Snow White, who must flee her home after The Evil Queen, her evil stepmother, wishes her to be dead.
6. Seeking refuge in the cottage of the seven dwarfs, she accidentally meets the Stooges, who are house sitting for them while they are away.

question: Which film came out first, Blind Shaft or The Mask Of Fu Manchu?

chunks.title: Blind Shaft
chunks.chunk:
Title: Blind Shaft
0. Blind Shaft is a 2003 film about a pair of brutal con artists operating in the illegal coal mines of present- day northern China.
1. The film was written and directed by Li Yang( 李杨), and is based on Chinese writer Liu Qingbang's short novel" Shen MuSacred Wood").

chunks.title: The Mysterious Dr. Fu Manchu
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Mysterious Dr. Fu Manchu
0. The Mysterious Dr. Fu Manchu is a 1929 American pre-Code drama film directed by Rowland V. Lee and starring Warner Oland as Dr. Fu Manchu.
1. It was the first Fu Manchu film of the talkie era.
2. Since this was during the transition period to sound, a silent version was also released in the United States.

chunks.title: The Mask of Fu Manchu
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Mask of Fu Manchu
0. The Mask of Fu Manchu is a 1932 pre-Code adventure film directed by Charles Brabin.
1. It was written by Irene Kuhn, Edgar Allan Woolf and John Willard based on the 1932 novel of the same name by Sax Rohmer.
2. Starring Boris Karloff as Fu Manchu, and featuring Myrna Loy as his depraved daughter, the movie revolves around Fu Manchu's quest for the golden sword and mask of Genghis Khan.
3. Lewis Stone plays his nemesis.
4. Dr. Petrie is absent from this film.

chunks.title: The Castle of Fu Manchu
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Castle of Fu Manchu
0. The Castle of Fu Manchu( also known as The Torture Chamber of Dr. Fu Manchu and also known by its German title Die Folterkammer des Dr. Fu Man Chu) is a 1969 film and the fifth and final Dr. Fu Manchu film with Christopher Lee portraying the title character.

chunks.title: The Brides of Fu Manchu
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Brides of Fu Manchu
0. The Brides of Fu Manchu is a 1966 British/ West German Constantin Film co-production adventure crime film based on the fictional Chinese villain Dr. Fu Manchu, created by Sax Rohmer.
1. It was the second film in a series, and was preceded by" The Face of Fu ManchuThe Vengeance of Fu Manchu" followed in 1967," The Blood of Fu Manchu" in 1968, and" The Castle of Fu Manchu" in 1969.
2. It was produced by Harry Alan Towers for Hallam Productions.
3. Like the first film, it was directed by Don Sharp, and starred Christopher Lee as Fu Manchu.
4. Nigel Green was replaced by Douglas Wilmer as Scotland Yard detective Nayland Smith.
5. The action takes place mainly in London, where much of the location filming took place.

chunks.title: Les Trottoirs de Bangkok
chunks.chunk:
Title: Les Trottoirs de Bangkok
0. Les Trottoirs de Bangkok( English:" The Sidewalks of Bangkok", also known as" Bangkok Interdit") is a 1984 erotic thriller film directed by Jean Rollin.
1. The film was inspired by the 1932 Boris Karloff classic" The Mask of Fu Manchu".
2. In contrast to Rollin's usual themes of vampires, dream- like atmosphere and crumbling châteaus," Les Trottoirs des Bangkok" mixes themes of adventure, crime and mystery with comic book dialogue, while still featuring naked women and sex, which his films were known for.

chunks.title: The Face of Fu Manchu
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Face of Fu Manchu
0. The Face of Fu Manchu is a 1965 thriller film directed by Don Sharp and based on the characters created by Sax Rohmer.
1. It stars Christopher Lee as the eponymous villain, a Chinese criminal mastermind, and Nigel Green as his pursuing rival Nayland Smith, a Scotland Yard detective.
2. The film was a British- West German co-production, and was the first in a five- part series starring Lee and produced by Harry Alan Towers for Constantin Film, the second of which was" The Brides of Fu Manchu" released the next year, with the final entry being" The Castle of Fu Manchu" in 1969.
3. It was shot in Technicolor and Techniscope, on- location in County Dublin, Ireland.

chunks.title: The Mask of the Gorilla
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Mask of the Gorilla
0. The Mask of the Gorilla is a 1958 French action film directed by Bernard Borderie.

chunks.title: The Blood of Fu Manchu
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Blood of Fu Manchu
0. The Blood of Fu Manchu, also known as Fu Manchu and the Kiss of Death, Kiss of Death, Kiss and Kill( U.S. title) and Against All Odds( original U.S. video title), is a 1968 British adventure crime film directed by Jesús Franco, based on the fictional Asian villain Dr. Fu Manchu created by Sax Rohmer.
1. It was the fourth film in a series, and was preceded by" The Vengeance of Fu Manchu The Castle of Fu Manchu" followed in 1969.
2. It was produced by Harry Alan Towers for Udastex Films.
3. It starred Christopher Lee as Dr. Fu Manchu, Richard Greene as Scotland Yard detective Nayland Smith, and Howard Marion- Crawford as Dr. Petrie.
4. The movie was filmed in Spain and Brazil.
5. Shirley Eaton appears in a scene that she claimed she was never paid for; apparently, the director Jesús Franco had inserted some stock footage of her from one of her films(" The Girl from Rio"( 1968)) into the film without telling her.
6. She only found out years later that she had been in a Fu Manchu film.

chunks.title: The Return of Dr. Fu Manchu
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Return of Dr. Fu Manchu
0. The Return of Dr. Fu Manchu is a 1930 American pre-Code film directed by Rowland V. Lee.
1. It is the second of three films starring Warner Oland as the fiendish Fu Manchu, who returns from apparent death in the previous film," The Mysterious Dr. Fu Manchu"( 1929), to seek revenge on those he holds responsible for the death of his wife and child.

chunks.title: Etan Boritzer
chunks.chunk:
Title: Etan Boritzer
0. Etan Boritzer( born 1950) is an American writer of children ’s literature who is best known for his book" What is God?" first published in 1989.
1. His best selling" What is?" illustrated children's book series on character education and difficult subjects for children is a popular teaching guide for parents, teachers and child- life professionals.
2. Boritzer gained national critical acclaim after" What is God?" was published in 1989 although the book has caused controversy from religious fundamentalists for its universalist views.
3. The other current books in the" What is?" series include
4. What is Love?,
5. What is Death?,
6. What is Beautiful?,
7. What is Funny?,
8. What is Right?,
9. What is Peace?,
10. What is Money?,
11. What is Dreaming?,
12. What is a Friend?,
13. What is True?,
14. What is a Family?,
15. What is a Feeling?"
16. The series is now also translated into 15 languages.
17. Boritzer was first published in 1963 at the age of 13 when he wrote an essay in his English class at Wade Junior High School in the Bronx, New York on the assassination of John F. Kennedy.
18. His essay was included in a special anthology by New York City public school children compiled and published by the New York City Department of Education.
19. Boritzer now lives in Venice, California and maintains his publishing office there also.
20. He has helped numerous other authors to get published through" How to Get Your Book Published!" programs.
21. Boritzer is also a yoga teacher who teaches regular classes locally and guest- teaches nationally.
22. He is also recognized nationally as an erudite speaker on" The Teachings of the Buddha."

chunks.title: David Lynch
chunks.chunk:
Title: David Lynch
0. David Keith Lynch (born January 20, 1946) is an American filmmaker, painter, musician, actor, and photographer.
1. He is best known for films such as "Eraserhead" (1977), "Blue Velvet" (1986) and "Mulholland Drive" (2001), often regarded by critics as among the best films of their respective decades, and for his successful 1990–91 television series "Twin Peaks", which led to him being labeled "the first popular Surrealist" by noted film critic Pauline Kael.
2. A recipient of an Academy Honorary Award in 2019, he has received three Academy Award nominations for Best Director, and has won France's César Award for Best Foreign Film twice, as well as the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival and a Golden Lion award for lifetime achievement at the Venice Film Festival.
3. He has been described by "The Guardian" as "the most important director of this era", while AllMovie called him "the Renaissance man of modern American filmmaking".
4. Born to a middle-class family in Missoula, Montana, Lynch spent his childhood traveling around the United States before he studied painting at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts in Philadelphia, where he first made the transition to producing short films.
5. He moved to Los Angeles, where he produced his first motion picture, the surrealist horror film "Eraserhead" (1977).
6. After "Eraserhead" became a success on the midnight movie circuit, Lynch was employed to direct the biographical film "The Elephant Man" (1980), from which he gained mainstream success.
7. He was then employed by the De Laurentiis Entertainment Group and proceeded to make two films: the science-fiction epic "Dune" (1984), which proved to be a critical and commercial failure, and then a neo-noir mystery film "Blue Velvet" (1986), which stirred controversy over its violence but later grew in critical reputation.
8. Next, Lynch created his own television series with Mark Frost, the popular murder mystery entitled "Twin Peaks" (1990–1991).
9. He also created a cinematic prequel,  (1992), a road film "Wild at Heart" (1990) and a family film "The Straight Story" (1999) in the same period.
10. Turning further towards surrealist filmmaking, three of his subsequent films operated on dream logic non-linear narrative structures: "Lost Highway" (1997), "Mulholland Drive" (2001), and "Inland Empire" (2006).
11. Meanwhile, Lynch embraced the Internet as a medium, producing several web-based shows, such as the animated "DumbLand" (2002) and the surreal sitcom "Rabbits" (2002).
12. Lynch and Frost reunited for a third season of "Twin Peaks", airing in on Showtime in 2017.
13. Lynch co-wrote and directed every episode, as well as reprising his role as Gordon Cole.
14. Lynch's other artistic endeavours include: his work as a musician, encompassing three studio albums—"BlueBOB" (2001), "Crazy Clown Time" (2011) and "The Big Dream" (
15. 2013)—as well as music and sound design for a variety of his films; painting and photography; writing three books—"Images" (1994), "Catching the Big Fish" (2006), and "Room to Dream" (2018); and directing several music videos and advertisements, including the Dior promotional film "Lady Blue Shanghai" (2006).
16. An avid practitioner of Transcendental Meditation (TM), Lynch founded the David Lynch Foundation in 2005, which sought to fund the teaching of TM in schools and has since widened its scope to other at-risk populations, including the homeless, veterans and refugees.
17. In 2019, he received an Academy Honorary Award; his first Oscar win.

chunks.title: Ronnie Rocket
chunks.chunk:
Title: Ronnie Rocket
0. Ronnie Rocket is an unfinished film project written by David Lynch, who also intended to direct it.
1. Begun after the success of Lynch's 1977 film "EraserheadRonnie Rocket" was shelved after Lynch felt he would be unable to find financial backing for the project.
2. He instead sought out an existing script on which to base his next film, settling on what would become 1980's "The Elephant Man".
3. "Ronnie Rocket" was to feature many of the elements which have since come to be seen as Lynch's hallmarks; including industrial art direction, 1950s popular culture and physical deformity.
4. The script featured a three-foot tall man with control over electricity; Lynch first met Michael J. Anderson when tentatively casting for this role, and later cast him in "Twin Peaks" and "Mulholland Drive" as a result.

question: Who is Charles Bretagne Marie De La Trémoille's paternal grandfather?
answer: Charles Armand René de La Trémoille

chunks.title: Charles Armand René de La Trémoille
chunks.chunk:
Title: Charles Armand René de La Trémoille
0. Charles Armand René de La Trémoille (14 January 1708, in Paris – 23 May 1741),
1. 6th duc de Thouars, was the son of Charles Louis Bretagne de La Trémoille and his wife, Marie Madeleine Motier de la Fayette.
2. La Trémoille was a French soldier and president of the States of Brittany.
3. He joined the military at a young age and became a colonel of the Champagne regiment at the age of eighteen.
4. Later, he became governor of Île-de-France.
5. He distinguished himself in the battle of Guastalla, in Italy, and was named shortly thereafter sergeant of the armies of the king.
6. La Trémoille was the author of some works and was elected a member of the Académie française on 13 February 1738.
7. On 29 January 1725 he married his cousin Marie Hortense de La Tour d'Auvergne, the daughter of Marie Armande Victoire de la Trémoïlle (1677–1717) and Emmanuel-Théodose de La Tour d'Auvergne, duc de Bouillon (1668–1730).
8. Marie Hortense, like her husband was a granddaughter of Charles Belgique Hollande de La Trémoille.
9. From this union was born a son:
10. Jean Bretagne Charles de La Trémoille and a daughter who died in infancy.

Prince Charles Bretagne Marie de La Trémoille (24 March 1764 – 10 November 1839), 8th Duke of Thouars, 7th Duke of La Trémoïlle, 10th prince de Tarente, 14th prince de Talmond and 14th Count of Laval, was a French aristocrat and soldier; he was the son of Jean Bretagne Charles de La Trémoille and his wife Princess Marie-Maximilienne of Salm-Kyrburg.

chunks.title: Henri Charles de La Trémoille
chunks.chunk:
Title: Henri Charles de La Trémoille
0. Henri Charles de La Trémoille( 17 December 1620 – 14 September 1672) was a French military commander.
1. He the son of Henry de La Trémoille, duc of Thouars and of La Trémoille, and his wife, Marie de La Tour d'Auvergne.
2. In 1628, La Trémoille's father, Henri III of Trémoïlle, converted himself and his children to Catholicism, but La Trémoille's mother convinced him to reconvert to Protestantism when he reached the age of majority.
3. In 1638, he joined the army of his uncle, Frederick Henry, Prince of Orange.
4. In 1648, he married the Calvinist Émilie of Hesse- Kassel, the daughter of William V of Hesse- Kassel( or Hesse- Cassel).
5. They had five children, including Charles Belgique, his heir, and Charlotte Amélie de la Trémoille.
6. In October 1651, during the Fronde, he came out against Cardinal Mazarin and supported Condé openly.
7. As a result, in 1656 he was imprisoned in Amiens.
8. La Trémoille's mother obtained his release after several months of imprisonment.
9. He was then relegated in Poitou then turned over to serve in Holland.
10. In 1668, he returned from Holland to manage the affairs of the duchy of Thouars, his father being weakened by the gout, and he again re-converted to Catholicism, taking away the children from his wife who fled to the Netherlands.
11. He died two years before his father in 1672; it was thus his elder son, Charles, who succeeded as the fourth duke of Thouars.

chunks.title: Claude de La Trémoille
chunks.chunk:
Title: Claude de La Trémoille
0. Claude de La Trémoille, 2nd Duke of Thouars (1566 – 25 October 1604) was a sixteenth-century French nobleman of the La Tremoille family.
1. He was the son of Louis III de La Trémoille and his wife, Jeanne de Montmorency.
2. King Henry IV of France had been friendly with La Trémoille when he was King of Navarre, but kept him in a subordinate position once he became King of France, preferring La Trémoille's cousin, Henry de La Tour d'Auvergne, the Viscount of Turenne.
3. In 1587, La Trémoille converted to Protestantism.
4. He fought for Henry IV at the battle of Coutras and also at Ivry, and was rewarded by elevation to the peerage, as Duke of Thouars, in 1595.
5. This new title, however, made La Trémoille lose more money than it earned him.
6. In 1598, Turenne proposed to his sister-in-law Charlotte-Brabantine to marry La Trémoille.
7. Thanks to her relations with the houses of Orange and Bouillon, Charlotte-Brabantine played an important part in the French Protestant diplomacy.
8. They had four children: Henry; Charlotte, who married James Stanley, Earl of Derby; Élisabeth (1601–1604); and Frédéric (1602–1642) comte de Laval.
9. In 1602, Charlotte-Brabantine dissuaded her husband from engaging in the conspiracy of Biron and encouraged him to lend allegiance to the king.
10. He died in 1604.

chunks.title: Ioan S. Nenițescu
chunks.chunk:
Title: Ioan S. Nenițescu
0. Ioan S. Nenițescu (April 11, 1854–February 23, 1901) was a Romanian poet and playwright.
1. Born in Galați, his parents were Ștefan Vasiliu, a manual laborer, and his wife Elisabeta ("née" Zaharia).
2. After completing the Alexandru Ioan
3. I commercial school in his native town
4. , he finished high school, passing the exit examination at Iași.
5. He also audited courses at Iași University's literature faculty.
6. Nenițescu attended an officers' school, volunteered in the Romanian War of Independence and was wounded at Grivitsa.
7. He then studied at the philosophy faculty of Berlin University, taking a doctorate in 1887 at Leipzig University with a thesis on Baruch Spinoza.
8. He worked as a schoolteacher and inspector in Bucharest.
9. He traveled south of the Danube, a trip that resulted in an ample "ethnic and statistical study of the AromaniansDe la românii din Turcia Europeană", 1895).
10. He sat in the Assembly of Deputies for his native Covurlui County, and also served as prefect of Tulcea County in the Dobruja region.
11. Nenițescu's first work appeared in the Galați newspaper "Gardistul civic".
12. A member of "Junimea", he published numerous poems in its organ "Convorbiri Literare".
13. He also contributed to "AlbinaAmicul copiilorRevista nouăRomânul literarȘezătoarea" and "Ziarul presei".
14. While in Bucharest from 1884 to 1888, he published "Țara nouă" magazine, mainly submitting articles on pedagogy, ethics and sociology.
15. His first book was the 1880 poetry volume "Flori de primăvară", followed by "Șoimii de la Războieni" (1882) and "Pui de lei" (1891).
16. Of the plays he wrote, the only one he published was "Radu de la Afumați" (1897).
17. In 1896, Nenițescu was elected a corresponding member of the Romanian Academy.
18. He died in Buzău.
19. His son Ștefan also became a poet.

chunks.title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu
chunks.chunk:
Title: Ștefan I. Nenițescu
0. Ștefan I. Nenițescu (October 8, 1897–October 1979) was a Romanian poet and aesthetician.
1. Born in Bucharest, his parents were the poet Ioan S. Nenițescu and his wife Elena ("née" Ștefan).
2. He attended Sapienza University of Rome from 1920, as well as the literature and philosophy department of Bucharest University.
3. At first an assistant professor of aesthetics, he later became an associate professor at Bucharest.
4. He served as press secretary and later economic adviser to the Romanian legation in The Hague.
5. Nenițescu's first publication was a 1915 article about William Shakespeare that appeared in "Noua revistă română".
6. His first book of poetry, "Denii" (1919), was followed by "Vrajă" (1923) and "Ode italice" (1925).
7. His single volume of theatre was "Trei mistere" (1922).
8. From 1924, he wrote for "Gândirea", and was a founding member of Romania's PEN Club.
9. He also contributed poetry and art criticism to "Convorbiri LiterareIdeea europeanăVremeaUniversul literarViața RomâneascăAdevărul" and "Arta plastică".
10. In 1925, Nenițescu published a treatise, "Istoria artei ca filosofie a istoriei".
11. He translated from Benedetto Croce ("Aesthetic", 1922) and Niccolò Machiavelli ("The Mandrake", 1926).
12. Initially, Nenițescu's poetry was discursive and religious, in line with the "Gândirist" current.
13. His verse became progressively more hermetic, as can be seen in the anthology volume
14. "Ani" (1973).
15. Including texts published in the 1940s and '50s, it reveals the intellectualized lyric verse of an eminently classical nature.

chunks.title: Ottawa High School and Junior High School

Title: Ottawa High School and Junior High School
0. The Ottawa High School and Junior High School, located at 526 and 506 S. Main St. respectively, are the historic former high school and junior high school in Ottawa, Kansas.
1. The high school was built in 1917, while the junior high school was built from 1927 to 1928; an enclosed hallway connecting the two buildings was built with the junior high school.
2. The high school was the first school in Ottawa to be built solely as a high school and the eighth school built in Ottawa.
3. George P. Washburn& Son designed the high school in the Collegiate Gothic style.
4. When the junior high school was constructed ten years later, the firm, by then known as Washburn& Stookey, designed the building in the same style as the high school.
5. In 1966, a new high school was built for the upper three classes of students; the freshman class moved to the building in 1976, and the old high school and junior high school became a middle school.
6. The two buildings were connected by a multi-purpose room in the same year.
7. The middle school later vacated the building.
8. The school was added to the National Register of Historic Places on October 6, 2000.

0. Fernando Fernández Gómez (28 August 1921 – 21 November 2007) better known as Fernando Fernán-Gómez was a Spanish actor, screenwriter, film director, theater director and member of the Royal Spanish Academy for seven years.
1. He was born in Argentina while his mother, Spanish actress Carola Fernán-Gómez, was making a tour in Latin America.
2. He would later use her surname for his stage name when he moved to Spain in 1924.
3. After the Spanish Civil War he began to study law but interrupted his studies to work in theater.
4. In 1942 he began to act in movies but also continued working on plays.
5. He formed his own theater company and received awards for directing and writing.
6. In the 1950s he began to direct movies, including the film of his novel, "El viaje a ninguna parte".
7. He received praise for his 1958 comedy "La vida por delante", which led to a sequel, "La vida alrededor".
8. In 1977, he won the Silver Bear for Best Actor at the 27th Berlin International Film Festival for his role in "The Anchorite".
9. He won the award again at the 35th Berlin International Film Festival in 1985 for his role in "Stico" and finally the Honorary Golden Bear at the 55th Berlin International Film Festival in 2005.
10. Having been very much in demand during the 1970s and 1980s, the 1990s was a less active period for him, but towards the end of his life, he enjoyed something of a revival, featuring in three major projects: "Todo sobre mi madrePlenilunio", and a starring role in the hit "La lengua de las mariposas".
11. He married María Dolores Pradera in 1945; they divorced in 1959.
12. He married Emma Cohen in 2000.
13. Fernando Fernán Gómez died in Madrid on 21 November 2007 from a heart failure.
14. As he was a lifelong anarchist, his coffin was covered in a black and red anarchist flag.

chunks.title: Antiochus X Eusebes
chunks.chunk:
Title: Antiochus X Eusebes
0. Antiochus X Eusebes Philopator (–92 or 88 BC) was a Hellenistic Seleucid monarch who reigned as the King of Syria between 95 BC and 92 BC or 89/88 BC (224 SE (Seleucid year)).
1. He was the son of Antiochus IX and perhaps his Egyptian wife Cleopatra IV.
2. He lived in a period during which there was a general disintegration of Seleucid Syria characterized by civil wars, foreign interference by Ptolemaic Egypt and incursions by the Parthians.
3. Antiochus IX was killed in 95BC at the hands of Seleucus VI, the son of his half-brother and rival Antiochus VIII.
4. Antiochus X then went to the city of Aradus where he declared himself king.
5. He avenged his father by defeating Seleucus VI, who was eventually killed.
6. Antiochus X did not enjoy a stable reign as he had to face three of Seleucus VI's brothers,
7. Antiochus XI, Philip I and Demetrius III.
8. Antiochus XI defeated AntiochusX and expelled him from the capital Antioch in 93 BC.
9. A few months later, AntiochusX regained his position and killed Antiochus XI.
10. This led to both Philip I and Demetrius III becoming involved.
11. The civil war continued but its final outcome is uncertain due to the contradictions between different ancient historians' accounts.
12. AntiochusX married his stepmother, Antiochus IX's widow Cleopatra Selene, and had several children with her, including a future king Antiochus XIII.
13. The death of Antiochus X is shrouded in mystery.
14. The year of his demise is traditionally given by modern scholars as 92 BC, but other dates are also possible including the year 224 SE (89/88BC).
15. The most reliable account of his end is that of the first century historian Josephus, who wrote that AntiochusX marched east to fight off the Parthians who were attacking a queen called Laodice; the identity of this queen and who her people were continues to be debated.
16. Other accounts exist:
17. the ancient Greek historian Appian has AntiochusX defeated by the Armenian king Tigranes II and losing his kingdom; the third century historian Eusebius wrote that AntiochusX was defeated by his cousins and escaped to the Parthians before asking the Romans for help in having him reinstated on the throne.
18. Modern scholars prefer the account of Josephus and question practically every aspect of the versions presented by other ancient historians.
19. Numismatic evidence shows that AntiochusX was succeeded in Antioch by Demetrius III, who controlled the capital in SE (88/87 BC).

chunks.title: The Mattei Affair
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Mattei Affair
0. The Mattei Affair is a 1972 film directed by Francesco Rosi.
1. It depicts the life and mysterious death of Enrico Mattei, an Italian businessman who in the aftermath of World War II managed to avoid the sale of the nascent Italian oil and hydrocarbon industry to US companies and developed them in the Eni, a state- owned oil company which rivaled the' seven sisters' for oil and gas deals in northern African and Middle Eastern countries.
2. The film shared the" Grand Prix" with" The Working Class Goes to Heaven" at the 1972 Cannes Film Festival.
3. Italian star Gian Maria Volonté was the leading actor in both films.
4. The film is an innovative hybrid of documentary and fiction, representing Francesco Rosi ’s concept of cine- inchieste( film investigation).
5. The flashback structure shows the influence of" Citizen Kane" and Rosi ’s" Salvatore Giuliano"( 1962).
6. Rosi remains faithful to his neo-realist roots with on- location shooting and non-professional actors.
7. The film is interspersed with footage of the director trying to find his friend, the investigative journalist Mauro De Mauro, who disappeared while doing research for the film.
8. He was killed by the Sicilian Mafia, but like the death of Mattei, De Mauro ’s case was never solved.

chunks.title: Daniel Hobbins
chunks.chunk:
Title: Daniel Hobbins
0. Daniel Hobbins is a Professor of History at the University of Notre Dame and an American historian specializing in Medieval France.
1. He has also written in the American Historical Review.
2. In this article, Hobbins writes on Jean Gerson.
3. Although his recent research involves Gerson, Dr. Hobbins' most significant work is" The Trial of Joan of Arc".
4. Published scholarly reviews have been universally positive.
5. For example, Wendy Maier of Oakton Community College writes that this" text is suitable for students, scholars, and anyone with an interest in Joan of Arc."
6. Other reviews note the significance of the book as being the" first translation of the trial transcripts in fifty years!"
7. Larissa Juliet Taylor, a professor at Colby College, says
8. " The entire scholarly community will welcome two new books that offer English translations of many Johannine sources -- Hobbins' trial translation and introduction, reviewed here, ..."
9. The reviewer thinks that Hobbins' book will be a useful for the classroom, because other editions of the trial transcripts are inadequate in various ways — not enough notes, bad OCR, etc.
10. If this reviewer is correct, Hobbins' book will probably be in use in many college courses.
11. Taylor's review ends:" Daniel Hobbins has provided an extraordinary service to the scholarly and educational community with this outstanding new translation of the Latin trial compilation.
12. Equally important, his critical introduction and notes stand alongside the most valuable recent contributions to scholarship on Joan of Arc."
13. Another positive reviewer refers to the book as" excellent" and" informative."
14. The reviewer asks why" do we need Hobbins' new English translation?"
15. The reasons given in this review by Susan Tiefenbrun are that Hobbins' book is" more reliable" and" more convenient."
16. He" gave guest lectures on Joan of Arc at Bowling Green State University( October 17) and at Ohio Northern University( October 23".
17. He is the recipient of the Nina Maria Gorrissen Prize and Fellow at the American Academy in Berlin for Fall 2011.

chunks.title: Louis II, Grand Duke of Baden

Title: Louis II, Grand Duke of Baden
0. Louis II, Grand Duke of Baden( 15 August 1824 – 22 January 1858) was the son of Leopold I, Grand Duke of Baden and Sophie of Holstein- Gottorp, Princess of Sweden.
1. Louis succeeded his father as Grand Duke of Baden on 24 April 1852.
2. His brother Frederick acted as regent, because Louis suffered from mental illness.
3. However, in 1856, Frederick became grand duke as well.
4. He was also an honorary citizen of Karlsruhe.

chunks.chunk:

0. Prince Karl Vladimir Ernst Heinrich of Leiningen( 2 January 1928 – 28 September 1990) was the younger son of Karl, 6th Prince of Leiningen( 1898 – 1946) and Grand Duchess Maria Kirillovna of Russia.
1. Maria was the daughter of Princess Victoria Melita of Edinburgh and Saxe- Coburg- Gotha and Cyril Vladimirovich, Grand Duke of Russia.
2. As such, Karl was a great- great- grandson of both Queen Victoria of Great Britain and Emperor Alexander II of Russia( as Victoria Melita and Cyril Vladimirovich were both grandchildren of Alexander II).

chunks.title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
chunks.chunk:
Title: Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha
0. Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha , later Grand Duchess Victoria Feodorovna of Russia (25 November 1876 – 2 March 1936) was the third child and second daughter of Alfred, Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, and Grand Duchess Maria Alexandrovna of Russia.
1. She was a granddaughter of Queen Victoria of the United Kingdom and Emperor Alexander II of Russia.
2. Born a British princess, Victoria spent her early life in England and lived in Malta for three years, where her father was serving in the Royal Navy.
3. In 1889 the family moved to Coburg, where Victoria's father became the reigning duke in 1893.
4. In her teens Victoria fell in love with her maternal first cousin Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia, but the disapprobation of marriage between first cousins of his faith, Orthodox Christianity, discouraged their romance.
5. Bowing to family pressure, Victoria married her paternal first cousin, Ernest Louis, Grand Duke of Hesse and by Rhine in 1894, following the wishes of their grandmother, Queen Victoria.
6. Their marriage was a failure.
7. Victoria scandalized the royal families of Europe when she divorced her husband in 1901.
8. The couple's only child, Princess Elisabeth of Hesse and by Rhine, died of typhoid fever in 1903.
9. Victoria married Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich in 1905.
10. They wed without the formal approval of Britain's King Edward VII, required by the Royal Marriages Act 1772, and in defiance of Tsar Nicholas II.
11. In retaliation, the Tsar stripped Kirill of his offices and honours, also initially banishing the couple from Russia.
12. They had two daughters and settled in Paris before being allowed to visit Russia in 1909.
13. In 1910 they moved to Russia, where Nicholas recognized her as Grand Duchess Victoria Feodorovna.
14. After the fall of the Russian monarchy in 1917, they escaped to Finland (then part of the Russian Empire) where she gave birth to her only son.
15. In exile they lived for some years among her relatives in Germany, and from the late 1920s on an estate they bought in Saint-Briac.
16. In 1926, Kirill proclaimed himself emperor in exile and Victoria supported her husband's claims.
17. Victoria died after suffering a stroke while visiting her daughter Maria in Amorbach.

chunks.title: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia
chunks.chunk:
Title: Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia
0. Grand Duke Andrei Vladimirovich of Russia ((14 May 1879 – 30 October 1956) was a son of Grand Duke Vladimir Alexandrovich of Russia, a grandson of Emperor Alexander II and a first cousin of Nicholas II, Russia’s last Tsar.
1. In 1900, he began an affair with the famous ballerina Mathilde Kschessinska, becoming the third grand duke to fall for her.
2. Grand Duke Andrei followed a military career and graduated from the Alexandrovskaya Military Law academy in 1905.
3. He occupied different military positions during the reign of Tsar Nicholas II, but with no particular distinction.
4. He became senator in 1911 and was appointed Major General in the Russian Army in 1915.
5. He took part in World War I, but was away from real combat spending most of the conflict at Russia's headquarters or in idle time in Saint Petersburg.
6. In February 1917, shortly before the fall of the Russian monarchy, Grand Duke Andrei left Saint Petersburg to join his mother in Kislovodsk.
7. He remained in the Caucasus for the next three years.
8. After the October Revolution he was briefly arrested along with his brother, Grand Duke Boris, but they escaped.
9. He departed revolutionary Russia in March 1920, being the last grand duke to leave for exile.
10. In 1921, he married his longtime mistress Mathilde Kschessinska and recognized her son as his.
11. The couple lived in the South of France until 1929 when they moved permanently to Paris, where Kschessinska opened a ballet school.
12. After World War II, Grand Duke Andrei lived under reduced circumstances.
13. Until his death at age 77, he was the last surviving Russian grand duke born in Imperial Russia.

chunks.title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia
chunks.chunk:
Title: Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia
0. Grand Duke Kirill Vladimirovich of Russia, ("Kirill Vladimirovich Romanov"; – 12 October 1938) was a son of Grand Duke Vladimir Alexandrovich of Russia, a grandson of Emperor Alexander II and a first cousin of Nicholas II, Russia’s last Tsar.
1. Grand Duke Kirill followed a career in the Russian navy serving during twenty years in the Naval Guards.
2. He took part in the Russo-Japanese War, barely surviving the sinking of the battleship at Port Arthur in April 1904.
3. In 1905, he married his paternal first cousin, Princess Victoria Melita of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha.
4. They wed in defiance of Tsar Nicholas II prohibition.
5. In retaliation, the Tsar stripped Kirill of his offices and honors, also initially banishing the couple from Russia.
6. They had two daughters and settled in Paris before being allowed to visit Russia in 1909.
7. In 1910 they moved to Russia, where Nicholas II recognized their marriage.
8. During World War I, Grand Duke Kirill was appointed Commander of the Naval Depot of the Guards in 1915 and in 1916, he achieved the rank of rear Admiral in the Imperial Navy.
9. During the February Revolution of 1917, Kirill marched to the Tauride Palace at the head of the Naval Guards swearing allegiance to the Russian Provisional Government.
10. During the rule of the provisional governmental in the summer 1917, Kirill escaped to Finland where his wife gave birth to the couple's only son.
11. In exile they lived for some years among his wife's relatives in Germany, and from the late 1920s on an estate they bought in Saint-Briac.
12. With the murder of his cousins Tsar Nicholas II and Grand Duke Michael, Kirill assumed the headship of the Imperial Family of Russia and, as next in line to the throne as the Guardian of the Throne in 1924.
13. Kirill proclaimed himself emperor in exile in 1926.
14. He worked for the restoration of the monarchy from exile for the rest of his life, but his claims were contested by some factions of the monarchy movement in a division that continues until today.
15. He wrote a book of memoirs, "My Life in Russia's Service", published after his death.
16. His granddaughter, Grand Duchess Maria Vladimirovna, is the current claimant to the headship of the House of Romanov.

chunks.title: Princess Irene of Hesse and by Rhine
chunks.chunk:
Title: Princess Irene of Hesse and by Rhine
0. Princess Irene of Hesse and by Rhine(" Irene Luise Marie Anne, Princess of Hesse and by Rhine", 11 July 1866 – 11 November 1953) was the third child and third daughter of Princess Alice of the United Kingdom and Louis IV, Grand Duke of Hesse and by Rhine.
1. Her maternal grandparents were Queen Victoria and Prince Albert of Saxe- Coburg and Gotha.
2. Her paternal grandparents were Prince Charles of Hesse and by Rhine and Princess Elizabeth of Prussia.
3. She was the wife of Prince Henry of Prussia, a younger brother of Wilhelm II, German Emperor and her first cousin.
4. The SS" Prinzessin Irene", a liner of the North German Lloyd was named after her.
5. Her siblings included Princess Victoria of Hesse and by Rhine, wife of Prince Louis of Battenberg, Grand Duchess Elizabeth Feodorovna of Russia, wife of Grand Duke Sergei Alexandrovich of Russia, Ernest Louis, Grand Duke of Hesse and by Rhine, and Empress Alexandra Feodorovna of Russia, wife of Tsar Nicholas II of Russia.
6. Like her younger sister, the empress, Irene was a carrier of the hemophilia gene, and Irene would lose her sisters Alix and Elisabeth in Russia to the Bolsheviks.

chunks.title: Beat Girl
chunks.chunk:
Title: Beat Girl
0. Beat Girl is a 1960 British teen exploitation film directed by Edmond T. Gréville.
1. The film was released in the United States under the title Wild for Kicks.
2. The title character of "Beat Girl" was played by starlet Gillian Hills, who later went on to have numerous small roles in 1960s and 1970s films, such as "Blowup" and "A Clockwork Orange", and became a successful ye-ye singer in France.
3. "Beat Girl" marked the first film roles of British pop idol Adam Faith and actor Peter McEnery, although it was not released until after other films featuring Faith ("Never Let Go") and McEnery ("Tunes of Glory") had already come out.
4. The film also features Christopher Lee and Nigel Green as strip joint operators, and Oliver Reed in a small role as one of the "beat" youth.
5. The original music was composer John Barry's first film commission, and was performed by the John Barry Seven and Orchestra, Adam Faith, and Shirley Anne Field.
6. The "Beat Girl" soundtrack was the first British soundtrack album to be released on a vinyl LP, and it reached number 11 on the UK Albums Chart, paving the way for the release of other film soundtrack albums.

chunks.title: Fleetwood Sheppard
chunks.chunk:
Title: Fleetwood Sheppard
0. Fleetwood Sheppard (sometimes spelled as "Shepphard,Sheppheard," and "Sheppeard") (1 January 1634 – 25 August 1698) was a British courtier and literary wit who was instrumental in the courts of Charles II of England and William of Orange.
1. He was an educated man known for his lively wit and honesty, and he was an important figure in the poetry of the 1680s and 1690s.
2. He was born in Oxfordshire, attended Magdalen Hall and Christ Church, Oxford, gaining the Bachelor of Arts in 1654 and Master of Arts in 1657.
3. When all persons attaining an M.A. were required to join the Church of England, King Charles intervened and said that Sheppard had a background in civil law (having studied at Gray's Inn) and was "not prepared to take orders, he being a person of much ability" (Ellis 255).
4. Instead, Sheppard became a courtier.
5. He was introduced to Nell Gwynn and became one of her favourite companions, along with Charles Sackville, Lord Buckhurst (later Earl of Dorset).
6. He would remain one of Dorset's closest friends throughout his life.
7. While satirists and gossips (such as Anthony á Wood) said that Sheppard spent his time as "a debauchee and atheist, a grand companion," others suggested that he was a fundamentally honest man who was always interested in a good joke.
8. He became one of Charles II's dining companions, and when Nell Gwynn gave birth to a male child, he was made the steward of Gwynn's household.
9. This prompted a satirist to accuse him of being the best paid pimp in the land.
10. There is little truth to this charge, however, as Sheppard was not paid by the crown for his services, except for two grants of £200.
11. Dorset and Sheppard went to Paris together.
12. Additionally, Dorset would travel out to meet Sheppard when the latter went out to the country.
13. Whether he and Dorset got in trouble in Paris for some scandalous behaviour, as Wood suggests, or not, it is true that Sheppard lived a very active life.
14. He was stabbed beneath the eye while separating Henry Bulkeley and George Etheridge in a quarrel in a tavern.
15. Sheppard was not liked by James II, and Sheppard did not like James, either.
16. When Charles II died, Sheppard went into retirement.
17. However, when William came to the throne, Sheppard was back at court and back in favour.
18. Dorset was made the chamberlain of the royal household, and that gave him a great many places to dispense in patronage.
19. For this, he employed Sheppard.
20. Sheppard received the proceeds from those wishing to purchase places, and he received the favours of those wishing a good word to be placed on their behalf.
21. At the same time, Sheppard was a favourite of the new Queen's, and John Oldmixon said that he made the Queen "very merry."
22. In "A New Way of Selling Places at Court" in 1712, Jonathan Swift would say that Fleetwood Sheppard sold places that did not exist and named successors for posts that were not vacant, that he enriched himself greatly.
23. In 1690 he was made a gentleman usher to the king.
24. In 1694 he was knighted, became a gentleman usher to the black rod in the House of Lords, and was inducted as a knight of the garter.
25. Sheppard was a patron of many poets and one of those who discovered others.
26. He was one of the ones, for example, who "discoveredParadise Lost" when Buckhurst bought it from a small stall at a fair.
27. He was also present when Matthew Prior was discovered reading Horace as a tap puller in a bar and sent to school to cultivate his talents.
28. He was also one of the main supports of Robert Gould, as well as John Oldmixon.
29. He may have embraced the Puritan cause around 1695, and some of his old friends were disaffected by this change.
30. Charles Gildon, Thomas Rymer, and John Dennis dedicated volumes of literary criticism to Sheppard, and John Wilmot, 2nd Earl of Rochester regarded Sheppard as the only critic he needed for his verses.
31. In his last years, Sheppard was reported dead several times before he died.
32. In 1694, Lord Godolphin heard a report that Sheppard had died, but Sheppard himself responded, saying that he was alive, but that he had suffered from "the stone" for twelve to fourteen years.
33. In December 1697, he was again reported as dead.
34. In July 1698, he was "again" reported as dead.
35. He did die shortly afterward, but in 1768 a joking "Annual Register" announced that Sheppard was still alive, in good health, and 120 years old.

0. When the Raven Flies( original) is a 1984 Icelandic- Swedish adventure film written and directed by Hrafn Gunnlaugsson.

2. The film was selected as the Icelandic entry for the Best Foreign Language Film at the 57th Academy Awards, but was not accepted as a nominee.
3. In 2016, online newspaper Kjarninn voted it as the best Icelandic film of all time.
4. Although mainly a tale of personal revenge," When the Raven Flies" bears a clear resemblance to the classic Akira Kurosawa film" Yojimbo", sharing common plot events, characters and action sequences.
5. Gunnlaugsson also drew inspiration from the Sagas of Icelanders and aimed to deconstruct the Viking stereotypes, replacing them with more authentic portrayals of the Viking era.
6. " When the Raven Flies" is the first film of the" Raven Trilogy"( also known as the" Viking Trilogy") that consists of three Viking films:" When the Raven Flies"( 1984, usually known as simply" The Raven" or" Revenge of the Barbarians In the Shadow of the Raven"( 1987, original Icelandic title:" Í skugga hrafnsins") and" Embla"( 1991, original Icelandic title:" Hvíti víkingurinn"), which is a director's cut of" The White Viking".

chunks.title: Eric Mueller

Title: Eric Mueller
0. Eric C. Mueller (born November 6, 1970) is a former Olympic and National team rower, representing the United States at the 1996 and 2000 Olympics.
1. He was born in Kansas City, Missouri.
2. Mueller, one of the most successful men's rowers in Wisconsin history, begins his third season as the Badgers' freshmen coach.
3. Mueller returns to Madison for the second time as an assistant coach.
4. He spent 1998–99 as the assistant varsity coach, before leaving to train for the 2000 Olympic Summer Games in Sydney, Australia.
5. During his previous stint, he was responsible for the Badgers' small boats and led them to four gold medals and one silver medal at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association national championships.
6. The result helped Wisconsin begin a four-year run as winners of the Ten Eyck Trophy as national team points champion.
7. Since his return, the UW freshmen have improved from a bottom six national finish in the year before his joining the program to a return to the national grand finals.
8. As a rower, Mueller secured three letters at Wisconsin while a member of the varsity eight from 1991–93.
9. At national championships during his career, the boat placed sixth, once, and ninth, twice.
10. A Cedarburg, native
11. , Mueller earned a bachelor's degree in mechanical engineering from Wisconsin in 1994.
12. Following his Badger career, Mueller went on to win an Olympic silver medal in the men's quadruple sculls in 1996 in Atlanta.
13. He also placed fifth at the 2000 Olympics with the men's four.
14. U.S. national team member in 1995, ‘96, ‘00, ‘01 and ‘02
15. , he was part of the men's eight champion at the 2002 World Cup in Lucerne, Switzerland, and finished third at the 2002 World Championships in Seville, Spain.
16. His men's four took fourth at the 2001 World Championships, while his men's eight was a bronze medalist at the 2000 World Cup, again in Lucerne.
17. He also won a bronze medal with the men's quadruple sculls in Lucerne at the 1996 World Cup.

chunks.title: Luigi Torchi
chunks.chunk:
Title: Luigi Torchi
0. Luigi Torchi invented the first direct multiplication machine in 1834.
1. This was also the second key- driven machine in the world, following that of James White( 1822).
2. Very little is known about the inventor and the machine.
3. We only know that he was a carpenter; his machine was awarded of a gold metal from the Imperial- regio istituto lombardo di scienze, lettere e arti in Milan in 1834.
4. A document of such occasion provides the known details of the machine, where a second document shows a drawing of the machine itself.
5. However, no detailed documents about how it worked are known to exist.
6. The machine was exhibited in Brera between 1834 and 1837; it was later found by Giovanni Schiaparelli in bad conditions.
7. After that, are not known further information about the machine.

chunks.title: Charles Redheffer
chunks.chunk:
Title: Charles Redheffer
0. Charles Redheffer was an American inventor who claimed to have invented a perpetual motion machine.
1. First appearing in Philadelphia, Redheffer exhibited his machine to the public, charging high prices for viewing.
2. When he applied to the government for more money, a group of inspectors were sent to examine the machine.
3. It was discovered the machine was actually powered by a device Redheffer claimed was powered by the machine.
4. Redheffer moved to New York City and set up a similar scam after rebuilding his machine.
5. However, an engineer detected that it was a fake by listening to its unsteady motions at an exhibition.
6. He discovered that the machine was operated by a man using a crank in a room on the floor above.
7. Redheffer returned to Philadelphia.
8. He later claimed to have created another machine, but refused to demonstrate it to anyone.
9. He managed to get a patent for his machine in 1820, but after this his fate is unknown.

2. Loy was born in Cagliari, Sardinia: his father was Guglielmo Loy- Donà, a lawyer issue from a distinguished Sardinian- Venetian family, and his mother was the noblewoman Donna Anna Sanjust of the Marquesses of Neoneli.
3. Rosetta Loy, an Italian novelist, is his sister- in- law.
4. He became famous for introducing in Italy the candid camera with his show" Specchio segreto"( Secret mirror) in 1965.
5. His 1962 film" The Four Days of Naples" was nominated for two Academy Awards.
6. It also won the FIPRESCI Prize at the 3rd Moscow International Film Festival in 1963.
7. His 1971 film" Detenuto in attesa di giudizio" was entered into the 22nd Berlin International Film Festival.
8. The star, Alberto Sordi, won the Silver Bear for Best Actor award.
9. He specialized in comedy films such as" Padre di famiglia" but he also shot film dealing with social themes(" Detenuto in attesa di giudizio" and" Sistemo l' America e torno").
10. Loy died at Fregene, near Rome, in 1995.

chunks.title: Marie Zéphyrine of France
chunks.chunk:
Title: Marie Zéphyrine of France
0. Marie Zéphyrine of France (26 August 1750 – 2 September 1755) was a French princess, the daughter of Louis, Dauphin of France, and Maria Josepha of Saxony.
1. Marie Zéphyrine, known as "Madame Royale" or "la Petite Madame", was born at the Palace of Versailles and was named after St Zephyrinus, on whose feast day she was born.
2. Her birth was greeted with caution; in the previous two years, Maria Josepha had suffered stillbirths and her health was of a fragile nature.
3. Louis XV, on the other hand, had hoped for a grandson.
4. Marie Isabelle de Rohan served as Marie Zéphyrine's governess.
5. Marie Zéphyrine died at Versailles due to an attack of convulsions, in the early hours of the morning of 2 September, having been baptised just days before by the Abbot of Chabannes.
6. She was not officially mourned; a French princess could only be mourned if she was over the age of 7.
7. She was buried at the Royal Basilica of Saint Denis outside the capital of Paris.

1. He had a younger brother, Philippe, who died as a toddler.
2. As a son of the king, Louis was a "fils de France".
3. As heir apparent, he became Dauphin of France.
4. However, he died before ascending to the throne.
5. Three of his sons became kings of France:
6. Louis XVI (reign: 1774–1792), Louis XVIII (reign: 1814–1815; 1815–1824) and Charles X (reign: 1824–1830).

chunks.title: Stefan Nemanja
chunks.chunk:
Title: Stefan Nemanja
0. Stefan Nemanja (Serbian Cyrillic: Стефан Немања, ; 1113 – 13 February 1199) was the Grand Prince (Veliki Župan) of the Serbian Grand Principality (also known as Raška, lat. "
1. Rascia") from 1166 to 1196.
2. A member of the Vukanović dynasty, Nemanja founded the Nemanjić dynasty, and is remembered for his contributions to Serbian culture and history, founding what would evolve into the Serbian Empire, as well as the national church.
3. According to the Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts, Nemanja is also among the most remarkable Serbs for his literary contributions and altruistic attributes.
4. In 1196, after three decades of warfare and negotiations which consolidated Serbia while distinguishing it from both Western and Byzantine spheres of influence, Nemanja abdicated in favor of his middle son Stefan Nemanjić, who became the first King of Serbia.
5. Nemanja ultimately went to Mount Athos, where he became a monk and took the name of Symeon, joining his youngest son (later known as Saint Sava), who had already become the first archbishop of the Serbian Orthodox Church.
6. Together with his son Sava, Nemanja restored the Hilandar Monastery at Mount Athos from 1198–1199, and issued the "Charter of Hilandar".
7. The monastery later became the cradle of the Serbian Orthodox Church.
8. The Serbian Orthodox Church canonized Stefan Nemanja shortly after his death under the name Saint Simeon
9. the Myrrh-streaming (Свети Симеон Мироточиви) after numerous miracles.

question: Was Şemsettin Baş or Gwenc'Hlan Le Scouëzec born first?

chunks.title: Gwenc'hlan
chunks.chunk:
Title: Gwenc'hlan
0. Gwenc'hlan is the cognomen of a legendary 6th century Breton druid and bard called Kian, the subject and purported author of a Breton song called" Diougan Gwenc'hlan"( Gwenc'hlan's prophecy), published by Hersart de la Villemarqué in his 1839 anthology" Barzaz Breiz".
1. In this song, Gwenc'hlan is imprisoned after having his eyes gouged out for refusing to convert to Christianity, sings out that he is n't afraid to die and makes a prophecy wherein he will be avenged.
2. The motive of the blinded prisoner is reminiscent of the historical fate of Boethius.
3. One Gwenc'hlan or Guinclaff around 1450 wrote a" chant royal", or" Dialogue between King Arthur and Gwenc'hlan", quoted by Dom Le Pelletier and Gregory of Rostrenen.
4. The poem was rediscovered in 1924.
5. The Breton used by this Gwenc'hlan is already deeply pervaded by French.
6. The legend of the 6th century bard is largely a creation of de la Villemarqué's, but he may have based his account on the 15th century author, as well as on other traditional Breton tales.
7. He quotes 6th to 12th century Welsh poems attributed to the bards Aneurin, Taliesin and Llywarch Hen as his sources.

chunks.title: Per Vari Kerloc'h
chunks.chunk:
Title: Per Vari Kerloc'h
0. Per Vari Kerloc'h( born 1952) is the current Grand Druid of the" Goursez Breizh"( founded in 1899).
1. He was born at Douarnenez, in the western part of Brittany.
2. The Grand Druid is appointed for life( Kerloc'h succeeded his predecessor Gwenc'hlan Le Scouëzec), whereas the Welsh and Cornish equivalents are now elected every three years.
3. Kerloc'h has been a middle manager and trade union representative with La Poste.
4. He is a native Breton speaker and a fluent speaker of Cornish.
5. His bardic name is" Morgan".
6. Per Vari Kerloc'h was welcomed at the Welsh National Eisteddfod in Cardiff(" Kerdiz" in Breton) in 2008.
7. An article in English published in the newspaper" Connexion" explains that after 2 years as a disciple, it is possible to become an Ovate, Bard or Druid, as in Wales.
8. This is different from Gorseth Kernow which has one order, Bards, and a Grand Bard who is elected for just one 3- year period.
9. " Goursez Breizh" has members who are Christian, Jewish or atheist; on the principle that anyone living in Brittany is Breton.
10. However there are hopes that a younger new leader, rooted in Breton language culture will refocus the" Goursez" on Breton cultural matters as was the original intent of the movement.

chunks.title: T. V. Chandran
chunks.chunk:
Title: T. V. Chandran
0. T. V. Chandran( born 23 November 1950) is an Indian film director, screenwriter, and actor, predominantly working in Malayalam cinema.
1. Born in a Malayali family in Telicherry, Chandran worked as a Reserve Bank of India employee before entering into the film industry.
2. He started his film career as an assistant director to P. A. Backer.
3. He also acted the lead role in Backer's highly acclaimed political drama" Kabani Nadi Chuvannappol"( 1975).
4. He made his directorial debut with the unreleased feature" Krishnan Kutty"( 1981), and followed this with the Tamil film" Hemavin Kadhalargal"( 1985).
5. Chandran came into prominence after" Alicinte Anveshanam"( 1989), which was nominated for the Golden Leopard at the Locarno International Film Festival.
6. This was followed with" Ponthan Mada"( 1993), his most famous film to- date.
7. Chandran is most known for his art- house films which have references to history and undertones of politics and feminism.
8. He is also known for his trilogy on 2002 Gujarat riots, consisting of" Kathavasheshan"( 2004)," Vilapangalkappuram"( 2008) and" Bhoomiyude Avakashikal"( 2012).
9. Other highly acclaimed films include" Mangamma"( 1997)," Dany"( 2001) and( 2003).
10. Chandran is widely regarded as one of the finest directors in Indian cinema and is widely credited with having revolutionised parallel cinema with his complex- structured art- house films.
11. Chandran has won several film awards including six National Film Awards and ten Kerala State Film Awards.
12. In addition to these, he is a recipient of a number of awards at various International film festivals.

chunks.title: Bhoomiyude Avakashikal
chunks.chunk:
Title: Bhoomiyude Avakashikal
0. Bhoomiyude Avakashikal
1. ( English:" The Inheritors of the Earth") is a 2012 Malayalam feature film written and directed by T. V. Chandran.
2. The film stars Kailash in the lead role along with Sreenivasan and Mythili who play pivotal supporting roles.
3. The film was produced by Anand Kumar under the banner of Yes Cinema and it was mainly shot in Nelliyampathi, Ottappalam and Shoranur in Kerala.
4. " Bhoomiyude Avakashikal" is the third and last installment of T. V. Chandran's trilogy on 2002 Gujarat riots.
5. The first one was," Kathavasheshan"( 2004), it was followed by" Vilapangalkkappuram"( 2008).
6. The narratives of all these films begin on the same day, 28 February 2002, that is, on the day after the Godhra train burning in Gujarat.
7. " Bhoomiyude Avakashikal" tells the story of Mohanachandran Nair, who is driven away from Ahmadabad following the Gujarat riots and who eventually loses his job and even his identity and ultimately lands up in a secluded house in Kerala, in the company of insects and animals with whom he shares his thoughts, concerns, doubts and frustrations.
8. The film was shot digitally to reduce costs as it was required to film several insects and animals in their natural habitat.
9. The film premiered at the 43rd International Film Festival of India on 27 November 2012.
10. It was also an official selection for the International Film Festival of Kerala.

chunks.title: Tchan Fou-li
chunks.chunk:
Title: Tchan Fou-li

chunks.title: Asfar ibn Kurduya
chunks.chunk:
Title: Asfar ibn Kurduya
0. Asfar ibn Kurduya( also spelled Kurdawayh, Kardawayh and Kurdawaih), was a Daylamite officer who served the Buyid dynasty.
1. Asfar is first mentioned during the reign of the Buyid ruler Adud al- Dawla, as one of the most prominent officers of the Empire.
2. After the death of Adud al- Dawla in 983, the Buyid Empire was thrown into civil war; the Empire was disputed between his two sons Samsam al- Dawla and Sharaf al- Dawla.
3. Samsam al- Dawla ruled Iraq, while Sharaf al- Dawla ruled Fars and Kerman.
4. In 986, Asfar rebelled against Samsam al- Dawla, and changed his allegiance to Sharaf al- Dawla.
5. However, Asfar quickly changed his mind, and declared allegiance to the latter's other brother Abu Nasr Firuz Kharshadh, who was shortly given the" laqab" of" Baha' al- Dawla."
6. However, Samsam al- Dawla, with the aid of Fuladh ibn Manadhar, suppressed the rebellion, and imprisoned Baha al- Dawla.
7. After this event, Asfar is no longer mentioned.

chunks.title: 'Adud al-Dawla
chunks.chunk:
Title: 'Adud al-Dawla
0. Fannā (Panāh) Khusraw , better known by his laqab of ʿAḍud al-Dawla ("Pillar of the [Abbasid] Dynasty")
1. (September 24, 936 – March 26, 983) was an emir of the Buyid dynasty, ruling from 949 to 983, and at his height of power ruling an empire stretching from Makran as far to Yemen and the shores of the Mediterranean Sea.
2. He is widely regarded as the greatest monarch of the dynasty, and by the end of his reign was the most powerful ruler in the Middle East.
3. The son of Rukn al-Dawla, Fanna Khusraw was given the title of Adud al-Dawla by the Abbasid caliph in 948 when he was made emir of Fars after the death of his childless uncle
4. Imad al-Dawla, after which Rukn al-Dawla became the senior emir of the Buyids.
5. In 974 Adud al-Dawla was sent by his father to save his cousin Izz al-Dawla from a rebellion.
6. After defeating the rebel forces, he claimed the emirate of Iraq for himself, and forced his cousin to abdicate.
7. His father, however, became angered by this decision and restored Izz al-Dawla.
8. After the death of Adud al-Dawla's father, his cousin rebelled against him, but was defeated.
9. Adud al-Dawla became afterwards the sole ruler of the Buyid dynasty and assumed the ancient Iranian title of Shahanshah ("King of Kings").
10. When Adud al-Dawla became emir of Iraq, the capital city, Baghdad, was suffering from violence and instability owing to sectarian conflict.
11. In order to bring peace and stability to the city, he ordered the banning of public demonstrations and polemics.
12. At the same time, he patronized a number of Shia scholars such as al-Mufid, and sponsored the renovation of a number of important Shia shrines.
13. In addition, 'Adud al-Dawla is credited with sponsoring and patronizing other scientific projects during his time.
14. An observatory was built by his orders in Isfahan where Azophi worked.
15. Al-Muqaddasi also reports that he ordered the construction of a great dam between Shiraz and Estakhr in 960.
16. The dam irrigated some 300 villages in Fars province and became known as "Band-e Amir" (Dam of the emir).
17. Among his other major constructions was the digging of the Haffar channel, that joined the Karun river to the Shatt al-Arab river (the confluence of the Tigris and the Euphrates).
18. The port of Khorramshahr was built on the Haffar, at its joining point with the Shatt al-Arab.

chunks.title: Ali ibn Kama
chunks.chunk:
Title: Ali ibn Kama
0. Ali ibn Kama, the uncle of the Buyid ruler Rukn al- Dawla and the latter's other brothers Mu'izz al- Dawla and Imad al- Dawla, was a Buyid military officer who became prominent among the Buyids of Jibal, and was greatly honored among his Daylamite kinsmen.
1. At the death of Imad al- Dawla in 949, Ali was appointed as the viceroy of Ray by Rukn al- Dawla, who went to Shiraz to secure the succession of his son there, Adud al- Dawla.
2. Meanwhile, the Samanids used this opportunity to invade the territories of Rukn al- Dawla, forcing Ali to flee from Jibal.
3. In ca. 959, a battle ensured between Ali and the Ziyarid prince Bisutun, which resulted in a Buyid victory.
4. In 966, Ali and Rukn al- Dawla defeated a large force of" ghazis" who had arrived from Khorasan.
5. Rukn al- Dawla later died in 976 and was succeeded by his son Fakhr al- Dawla, who had Ali executed.

chunks.title: Aziz al-Dawla
chunks.chunk:
Title: Aziz al-Dawla
0. ʿ Azīz al- Dawla Abū Shujāʿ Fātik al- Waḥīd ī ibn ʿ Abd Allāh al- Rūmī, better known simply as Aziz al- Dawla( d. 1022), was the first Fatimid governor of Aleppo in 1016/ 17–1022.
1. An ethnic Armenian, Aziz al- Dawla started his political career as a trusted" ghulam"( military slave) of Manjutakin al- Azizi, the Fatimid governor of Damascus during the reign of Caliph al- Hakim( 996–1021).
2. The latter appointed Aziz al- Dawla governor of Aleppo, which experienced prosperity during his rule.
3. By 1020, Aziz al- Dawla was acting independently of al- Hakim's authority by issuing coins in his name and having his political sovereignty declared in Friday prayers.
4. When al- Hakim sent an army to force Aziz al- Dawla into submission, the latter appealed for Byzantine support but canceled the appeal when al- Hakim mysteriously disappeared in early 1021.
5. Afterward, the Fatimid court attempted to reconcile with Aziz al- Dawla, who nonetheless moved to secure his rule by building a well- fortified palace at the foot of the Aleppo's citadel.
6. In July 1022, Aziz al- Dawla was murdered in his sleep by one of his" ghulams"( slave soldier) in a plot devised by another of his" ghulams", Abu'l- Najm Badr, with likely backing from al- Hakim's virtual successor, Sitt al- Mulk.
7. Badr briefly succeeded Aziz al- Dawla as governor but was arrested three months later.

chunks.title: Ziyar ibn Shahrakuya
chunks.chunk:
Title: Ziyar ibn Shahrakuya
0. Ziyar ibn Shahrakuya( also spelled Shahrakawayh), was a high- ranking Gilaki military officer who served the Buyids.
1. Ziyar was the son of Shahrakawayh, the son of Harusindan, the maternal uncle of the Ziyarid ruler Mardavij.
2. Ziyar had a cousin, who married the Buyid ruler Adud al- Dawla, and bore him one son named Abu Kalijar Marzuban.
3. During that period, Ziyar, along with a Daylamite officer named Fuladh ibn Manadhar, dominated the Buyid court of Baghdad.
4. After the death of Adud al- Dawla in 983, the Buyid Empire was thrown into civil war; the Empire was disputed between his two sons Abu Kalijar Marzuban( who took the name Samsam al- Dawla) and Sharaf al- Dawla.
5. The Turkic soldiers of Iraq shortly betrayed Samsam al- Dawla, and went towards to the court of Sharaf al- Dawla.
6. However, Ziyar managed to make most of them change their mind and stay loyal to Samsam al- Dawla.
7. In 987, Sharaf al- Dawla marched towards Baghdad and deposed Samsam al- Dawla.
8. He then imprisoned Fuladh and had Ziyar executed.

chunks.title: Taj al-Dawla
chunks.chunk:
Title: Taj al-Dawla
0. Abu'l-Husain Ahmad , better known by his "laqab" of Taj al-Dawla
1. (Arabic: تاج الدولة،, "Crown of the Dynasty"), was the Buyid ruler of Khuzestan during the 980s.
2. He was the son of 'Adud al-Dawla.

chunks.title: Safiyy al-Dawla
chunks.chunk:
Title: Safiyy al-Dawla
0. Ṣafiyy al- Dawla Muḥammad
1. ibn ʿ Ali ibn Jaʾfar ibn Falāh was the Fatimid governor of Aleppo between October 1022 and April 1023.
2. He was specifically assigned to govern the city, while the citadel of Aleppo was assigned to a separate governor, the eunuch Yumn al- Dawla Sa'adat.
3. This marked the first time the Fatimids appointed separate rulers for the city and citadel of Aleppo since they gained direct control over the city in October 1016.
4. Safiyy al- Dawla belonged to the Kutama, a militant Berber group that played a major role in the Fatimid military, and he was the grandson of the Fatimid general Ja'far ibn Fallah.
5. He was bestowed with the title" ṣafiyy al- dawla"( chosen of the State).
6. Safiyy al- Dawla and Yumn al- Dawla were appointed to Aleppo to replace Abu'l- Najm Badr.
7. Nothing is known about their reign and Safiyy al- Dawla was dismissed in April 1023, and succeeded by Sanad al- Dawla Hasan.

question: Who was born later, D'Arcy Coulson or Thomas William Adams?

chunks.title: Thomas William Adams
chunks.chunk:
Title: Thomas William Adams
0. Alfred Albert Thomas William Adams( 24 June 1842 – 1 June 1919), known as Thomas William Adams, was a New Zealand farmer, forester, churchman and educationalist.
1. He was born in Graveley, Cambridgeshire, England on 24 June 1842.
2. In 1862 he emigrated to New Zealand on the" African".
3. He bought of virgin tussock land at Greendale in Canterbury in 1865 and converted them to farmland.
4. The area prospered over the next few years as more farmers developed land.
5. Adams married Lucy Pannett in 1867 and they had a daughter the following year.
6. Lucy drowned in 1869.
7. Adams married her sister Harriet in 1872, and they had five sons and three daughters together.
8. Adams was a pioneer in planting trials, obtaining seeds from correspondents around the world, keeping records and publishing the results.
9. He started planting trees in 1868 for shelter and fuel, and by 1908 had created an arboretum of 800 species.
10. His recommendation of" Pinus radiata" and other pines influenced early New Zealand forestry.
11. In 1913 he was a member of the Royal Commission on Forestry, and in 1918 he became a lifetime member of the New Zealand Forestry League.
12. For 40 years, Adams taught Sunday school at Greendale, which began by teaching local children to read.
13. He was instrumental in the formation of the Greendale day school in 1872, and served on the North Canterbury Education Board from 1892 to 1918, serving as chairman from 1897 to 1905.
14. He was also a governor of Canterbury College( now University of Canterbury) from 1897 until his death.
15. He was the first secretary of the Canterbury Baptist Association, and later its president.
16. Adams died at Greendale on 1 June 1919 and was buried there.
17. His will left £ 2000 and of land to Canterbury College to be used for a school of forestry.
18. Harriet died 15 January 1934 and was buried with him.
19. The school of forestry opened in 1924, and about 1975 a T.W. Adams Scholarship was set up to support postgraduate forestry students.

chunks.title: Gordon Persons
chunks.chunk:
Title: Gordon Persons
0. Seth Gordon Persons( February 5, 1902 – May 29, 1965) was an American Democratic politician who was the 43rd Governor of Alabama from 1951 to 1955.
1. He was born and died in Montgomery, Alabama.
2. The Dauphin Island Bridge south of Mobile is formally named for him.
3. The Gordon Persons Building is a six floor, 60,000 square foot state government office building in Montgomery.
4. Persons built a successful business running electrical lines in rural Alabama( benefiting from Rural Electrification Administration contracts); in addition to financial gain, he also won considerable popularity.
5. When running for office in 1950, Persons gained notoriety by touring the state in a helicopter( prompting one opponent to dub him" the man from Mars").
6. He won the Democratic nomination by defeating a crowded field that included former governor Chauncey Sparks.
7. In office, his notable accomplishments included abolishing flogging in Alabama's prisons, advocating for the establishment of Alabama Public Television, and imposing speed limits on state highways.
8. Persons largely accomplished his goal of having four years of" no fighting," maintaining a truce among the various wings of the state Democratic Party.
9. At the end of his term, Persons ordered the National Guard into Phenix City following the assassination of Attorney- General- elect Albert Patterson.
10. After leaving office as governor, Persons never sought statewide public office again, although he did make an unsuccessful run for circuit judge late in life.
11. Persons was an alumnus of Auburn University, though he attended for only one year.
12. While at Auburn, Persons served as president of a student organization( known as the" Boxcar Reds and Boxcar Blacks") that traveled to away football games.

chunks.title: Lucio Fulci
chunks.chunk:
Title: Lucio Fulci
0. Lucio Fulci( 17 June 1927 – 13 March 1996) was an Italian film director, screenwriter, producer, and actor.
1. Although he worked in a wide array of genres through a career spanning nearly five decades, including comedy, spaghetti western, adventure, science fiction and erotica, he garnered an international cult following for his giallo and horror films.
2. His most notable films include the" Gates of Hell" trilogy —" City of the Living Dead"( 1980)," The Beyond"( 1981), and" The House by the Cemetery"( 1981) —as well as" Massacre Time"( 1966)," One on Top of the Other"( 1969)," A Lizard in a Woman's Skin"( 1971)," Do n't Torture a Duckling"( 1972)," White Fang"( 1973)," Four of the Apocalypse"( 1975)," Sette note in nero"( 1977)," Zombi 2"( 1979)," Contraband"( 1980)," The Black Cat"( 1981)," The New York Ripper"( 1982)," Murder Rock"( 1984), and" A Cat in the Brain"( 1990).
3. Because of the high level of visceral graphic violence present in many of his films, especially" Zombi 2" and" The Beyond", Fulci is frequently referred to as" The Godfather of Gore", a title also given to Herschell Gordon Lewis.
4. Fulci was in his young adult years a politically active radical for the Italian Communist Party.

3. Robert Altman's film" Gosford Park", set in 1932, features a( fictional) character who produces the Chan films for Fox and claims to be in England doing research for" Charlie Chan in London".

chunks.title: Layne Tom Jr.

0. Layne Tom Jr.( June 19, 1927 – January 14, 2015) was an American actor.
1. He holds the sole distinction of having played three different Charlie Chan sons: as Charlie Chan Jr. in" Charlie Chan at the Olympics"( 1937), as Tommy Chan in" Charlie Chan in Honolulu"( 1938), and in 1940's" Charlie Chan's Murder Cruise" as Willie Chan, Chan's number seven son.
2. He also appeared with child star Shirley Temple in" Stowaway"( 1936) as an uncredited Chinese Boy in the Musical Band.
3. He was credited as Mako with Dorothy Lamour, Jon Hall, and C. Aubrey Smith in" The Hurricane( 1937)", and as an uncredited extra in" San Francisco"( 1936) with stars Clark Gable, Jeanette MacDonald, and Spencer Tracy.
4. After he got out of the Navy when World War II ended, he turned down a five- year movie contract with Monogram Pictures to go to college instead to become an architect.
5. He only returned to show business to film two documentaries about Charlie Chan: and" Legacy of Charlie Chan" as himself.
6. His daughter Kiana Tom is a television host, star of" Kiana's Flex Appeal" fitness series and one of the most widely recognized fitness experts in the world.

chunks.title: Adam Baal Shem
chunks.chunk:
Title: Adam Baal Shem
0. According to Hasidic legend, Adam Baal Shem of Ropczyce was a rabbi and mystic who first introduced the movement of Hasidism.
1. The leadership of the movement was later handed down from Rabbi Adam to Rabbi Yisrael ben Eliezer, the Baal Shem Tov.
2. The exact identity of Rabbi Adam is unknown.
3. Since the name Adam was rare among European Jewry, Gershom Scholem considers it to be a pseudonym for Heshel Zoref( died 1700).
4. According to Aryeh Kaplan, others identify this Adam with Rabbi David Moshe Abraham( whose initials are Adam) of Troyes or with Adam Zerweiker.
5. Kaplan also writes that it may be an anonym to protect the subject's identity.
6. According to Rabbi Yosef Yitzchak Schneersohn, Rabbi Adam was a disciple of Rabbi Yoel Baal Shem of Zamość, who in turn was a disciple of Rabbi Eliyahu Baal Shem of Worms.
7. According to the" Shivhei HaBesht", Rabbi Adam found manuscripts in a cave, containing hidden secrets of the Torah.
8. Rabbi Adam asked in a dream to whom should he hand down the manuscripts?
9. He was answered to hand them down to Rabbi Israel ben Eliezer of the city of Okopy.
10. Before his death, he commanded his only son, who was an eminent scholar, to search for the city with that name and hand the manuscripts to Israel ben Eliezer.
11. After Rabbi Adam died, his son traveled until he arrived at Okopy, where he married the daughter of a wealthy man and eventually gave the manuscripts to the Baal Shem Tov.

chunks.title: Christophe Honoré
chunks.chunk:
Title: Christophe Honoré
0. Christophe Honoré (born 10 April 1970) is a French writer and film director.
1. Honoré was born in Carhaix, Finistère.
2. After moving to Paris in 1995, he wrote articles in "Les Cahiers du Cinéma".
3. He started writing soon after.
4. His 1996 book "Tout contre LéoClose to Leo") talks about HIV and is aimed at young adults; he made it into a film in 2002.
5. He wrote other books for young adults throughout the late 1990s.
6. His first play, "Les Débutantes", was performed at Avignon's Off Festival in 1998.
7. In 2005, he returned to Avignon to present "Dionysos impuissant" in the "In" Festival, with Joana Preiss and Louis Garrel playing the leads.
8. A well-known director, he is considered an "auteur" in French cinema.
9. His 2006 film "Dans Paris" has led him to be considered by French critics as the heir to the Nouvelle Vague cinema.
10. In 2007, "Les Chansons d'amour" was one of the films selected to be in competition at the 2007 Cannes Film Festival.
11. Honoré is openly gay, and some of his movies or screenplays (among them "Les Filles
12. ne savent pas nagerDix-sept fois Cécile Cassard" and "Les Chansons d'amour") deal with gay or lesbian relations.
13. Honoré has been the screenwriter for some of Gaël Morel's films.
14. He has also directed Louis Garrel in five different films.

1. He was the second son of Sir Arthur Gore, 2nd Baronet and Elizabeth Annesley, and younger brother of Arthur Gore, 1st Earl of Arran.
2. He sat in the House of Commons of Ireland, as a Member of Parliament for Mayo from 1751 to 1760, and for Sligo County from 1765 to 1768.

chunks.title: Sir Arthur Gore, 2nd Baronet
chunks.chunk:
Title: Sir Arthur Gore, 2nd Baronet
0. Sir Arthur Gore, 2nd Baronet( c. 1685 – 10 February 1742) was an Irish politician and baronet.
1. He was the son of Paul Gore, himself son of Sir Arthur Gore, 1st Baronet, and his wife Anne Gore, daughter of Sir John Gore.
2. Gore succeeded his grandfather as baronet in 1697.
3. He was High Sheriff of Mayo in 1711 and Member of Parliament( MP) in the Irish House of Commons.
4. Gore represented Ballynakill from 1703 to 1713 and then for Donegal Borough until 1715.
5. Subsequently, he sat for Mayo until 1741.
6. Gore was married to Elizabeth Annesley, daughter of Maurice Annesley.
7. They had eight children, four daughters and four sons.
8. Gore was succeeded in the baronetcy by his eldest son Arthur, who later was raised to the Peerage of Ireland as 1st Earl of Arran.
9. Of his daughters, Anne married John Browne, 1st Earl of Altamont and Elizabeth married James Cuffe( died 1762).

1. He was the son of Robert Bruce, 2nd Earl of Elgin, and Lady Diana Grey.
2. His maternal grandparents were Henry Grey, 1st Earl of Stamford, and Lady Anne Cecil, daughter of William Cecil, 2nd Earl of Exeter.
3. His" Memoirs", which were not published until long after his death, are a valuable source for English history in the last quarter of the seventeenth century.
