chunks.title: Arthur Gore, 1st Earl of Arran
chunks.chunk:
Title: Arthur Gore, 1st Earl of Arran
0. Arthur Gore, 1st Earl of Arran PC (Ire) (1703 – 17 April 1773), known as Sir Arthur Gore, 3rd Baronet from 1741 to 1757 and as Viscount Sudley from 1758 to 1762, was an Irish politician.
1. Arran was the son of Sir Arthur Gore, 2nd Baronet, and Elizabeth Annesley, and was educated at Trinity College, Dublin.
2. In 1727 he was elected to the Irish House of Commons for Donegal Borough, a seat he held until 1758.
3. He was also High Sheriff of Wexford in 1738 and was admitted to the Irish Privy Council in 1748.
4. In 1758 he was raised to the Peerage of Ireland as Baron Saunders, of Deeps in the County of Wexford, and Viscount Sudley, of Castle Gore in the County of Mayo.
5. In 1762 he was further honoured when he was created Earl of Arran, of the Arran Islands in the County of Galway.
6. This was the third occasion that the title Earl of Arran had been created in the Peerage of Ireland.
7. His sister Anne married John Browne, the 1st Earl of Altamont in December 1729.
8. Lord Arran married Jane Saunders, daughter of Richard Saunders (a grandson of the MP Henry Whitfield), in 1731.
9. They had three sons and two daughters.
10. He died in April 1773 and was succeeded in his titles by his eldest son Arthur.

Title: James Hamilton, Duke of Châtellerault
0. James Hamilton, Duke of Châtellerault, 2nd Earl of Arran( – 22 January 1575) was a regent for Mary, Queen of Scots.

Title: James Stewart, Earl of Arran
0. Captain James Stewart, Earl of Arran( died 1595) was created Earl of Arran by the young King James VI, who wrested the title from James Hamilton, 3rd Earl of Arran.
1. He rose to become Lord Chancellor of Scotland and was eventually murdered in 1595.

chunks.title: John Evans-Freke, 6th Baron Carbery
chunks.chunk:
Title: John Evans-Freke, 6th Baron Carbery
0. John Evans- Freke, 6th Baron Carbery( 11 November 1765 – 12 May 1845), styled Sir John Evans- Freke, 2nd Baronet between 1777 and 1807, was an Anglo- Irish politician and peer.
1. He was the son of Sir John Freke, 1st Baronet.
2. In 1777 he succeeded to his father's baronetcy.
3. He served in the Irish House of Commons as the Member of Parliament for Donegal Borough between 1783 and 1790.
4. He then represented Baltimore from 1790 to 1800.
5. On 4 March 1807 he succeeded his first cousin once removed, John Evans, as Baron Carbery, and in 1824 was elected to the House of Lords as an Irish representative peer.
6. On 25 January 1783 he married his cousin, Lady Catherine Charlotte Gore, the third daughter of Arthur Gore, 2nd Earl of Arran.
7. He died without surviving male issue, and was succeeded in his titles by his nephew, George Evans- Freke.

chunks.title: Arthur Gore, 2nd Earl of Arran
chunks.chunk:
Title: Arthur Gore, 2nd Earl of Arran
0. Arthur Saunders Gore, 2nd Earl of Arran KP, PC (Ire)
1. (25 July 1734 – 8 October 1809) styled The Honourable Arthur Gore from 1758 to 1762 and Viscount Sudley from 1762 to 1773, was an Irish peer and politician.
2. Arran was the eldest son of Arthur Gore, 1st Earl of Arran, and Jane Saunders.
3. He was elected to the Irish House of Commons for Donegal Borough in 1759, a seat he held until 1761 and again from 1768 to 1774 and also represented Wexford County between 1761 and 1768.
4. In 1773 he succeeded his father as second Earl of Arran and entered the Irish House of Lords.
5. Arran was also appointed High Sheriff of County Wexford in 1757 and High Sheriff of Mayo in 1765.
6. He was admitted to the Irish Privy Council in 1771 and in 1783 he was invested as one of the original sixteen Knights of the Order of St Patrick.

chunks.title: Philip Gore, 4th Earl of Arran
chunks.chunk:
Title: Philip Gore, 4th Earl of Arran
0. Philip Yorke Gore, 4th Earl of Arran( 23 November 1801 – 25 June 1884), known as Philip Gore until 1837, was an Anglo- Irish peer and diplomat.
1. Born at Dublin Castle, Arran was the eldest son of Colonel the Hon. William John Gore, second son of Arthur Gore, 2nd Earl of Arran, and his wife Caroline, daughter of Sir Thomas Hales, 4th Baronet.
2. In 1820 Gore was sent as attaché to the British embassy in Stockholm, was transferred to Paris in 1825 and to Lisbon a year later.
3. In 1828 he was promoted to secretary of legation in Buenos Aires where he was" chargé d'affaires" 1832 –34.
4. He succeeded his uncle Arthur as earl in 1837 and was made a Knight of the Order of St Patrick in 1841.
5. Lord Arran married Elizabeth Marianne Napier, second daughter of Sir William Francis Patrick Napier, in 1838.
6. They had two sons and three daughters.
7. He died in June 1884, aged 82, and was succeeded in his titles by his eldest son Arthur.
8. Lady Arran died in 1899.

6. Between 1847 and 1859 he also served as Lord-Lieutenant of Buteshire.
7. Crichton-Stuart married Hannah, daughter of William Tighe, MP, in 1818.
8. Their son James also represented Cardiff in the House of Commons.
9. Crichton-Stuart died in September 1859, aged 65.
10. His wife survived him by thirteen years and died in June 1872.

chunks.title: Douglas Leiterman
chunks.chunk:
Title: Douglas Leiterman
0. Douglas Leiterman (1927 – 19 December 2012) was a Canadian television producer.
1. He was born in 1927 in South Porcupine, Ontario.
2. During the early 1950s, he attended the University of British Columbia for a Bachelor of Arts degree, while also working as a "Vancouver Province" reporter.
3. He had a brother, cinematographer Richard Leiterman, and a sister, Elaine Campbell, who was married to producer Norman Campbell.
4. His sister Phyllis, a teacher and poet, was married to acclaimed film director Allan King.
5. He had a sister Mary, a teacher and founder of a school, who was married to renowned Ibiza architect and artist Rolph Blakstad.
6. He attended Harvard University in 1954 on a Nieman Fellowship.
7. Leiterman had five children with his first wife, Mary.
8. He toured Eastern Europe with Mary in 1955.
9. In 1968 he divorced Mary and married Beryl Fox, who had worked for him at CBC, and had one daughter.
10. Leiterman got his start in journalism in British Columbia, before becoming a correspondent on Parliament Hill in Ottawa for the Southam News Service.
11. His television credits include "This Hour Has Seven Days" which he co-produced with Patrick Watson from 1964 to 1966.
12. It was the second most popular CBC program.
13. After that series was cancelled, Leiterman joined CBS to provide advice for the development of the "60 Minutes" series.
14. He produced a special "Sixteen in Webster Grove" for CBS.
15. He produced other series such as "The Fabulous Sixties" and "Here Come the Seventies" (CTV, 1969-1972).
16. He produced documentaries for the United Nations and a nature film documentary series.
17. He founded WIred CIty Communications, a cable company in Toronto, in the 1970s.
18. He founded Motion Picture Guarantors Inc., in the 1970s in Canada and The Motion PIcture Bond Company Ltd., in the 1980s, the second largest completion bond company in the world for motion pictures.
19. He operated both companies internationally and bonded such films as "Peter The Great" and TV series such as "Baywatch".
20. He sold MPB to AIG in the early 2000s.
21. Leiterman died at his winter residence in Vero Beach, Florida on 19 December 2012.
22. He was survived by his partner of 50 years, documentary filmmaker Beryl Fox and their daughter and three of his daughters from his first marriage.
23. He was predeceased by his first wife Mary and two of their five children, Mark and Lisa.

chunks.title: Alexandre Gaydamak
chunks.chunk:
Title: Alexandre Gaydamak
0. Alexandre "Sacha" Gaydamak (born May 1976 in France) is a French and Israeli businessman.
1. A member of the wealthy Gaydamak family, he is the only son of Arcadi Gaydamak.
2. In January 2006 he announced that he was following his father into association football club ownership by becoming co-owner of English Premier League club Portsmouth F.C. with Milan Mandarić.
3. His father was the owner of Israeli side Beitar Jerusalem.
4. In July 2006 Alexandre Gaydamak became the sole owner of Portsmouth, although Mandarić remained at the club as non-executive chairman until later that year.
5. Gaydamak owns a Luxembourg-based company, Belvia SARL and a British Virgin Islands company, Devondale Investments, which owned Portsmouth F.C.
6. On 21 July 2009, Gaydamak agreed to sell Portsmouth F.C. to Sulaiman Al Fahim in principle, and therefore stepped down from the board.
7. He remained the owner of the club until the details of the sale had been finalised on 8 June 2009.
8. Gaydamak has been alleged to have asset stripped Portsmouth F.C. before this sale and yet still retains a claim, said to be £32,000,000, against the club as a creditor despite the huge debts at the club.
9. Investigations into these allegations are ongoing.
10. On 22 October 2010 Gaydamak's business acumen came into question after reports of him demanding a payment from his former club Portsmouth for an apparent £2.5million.
11. It seems that he was unsure that his unpaid debt would be repaid.
12. The case was made more embarrassing after Portsmouth F.C had received confirmation several times from Gaydamak himself that the terms were agreed and that he was a secured creditor meaning that not only would be paid in full, but he would also be paid before many unsecured creditors who are set to only receive 20% of any debt.

chunks.title: Henry IV of France
chunks.chunk:
Title: Henry IV of France
0. Henry IV (read as ; 13 December 1553 – 14 May 1610), also known by the epithet Good King Henry or Henry the Great, was King of Navarre (as Henry III) from 1572 and King of France from 1589 to 1610.
1. He was the first monarch of France from the House of Bourbon, a cadet branch of the Capetian dynasty.
2. He was assassinated in 1610 by François Ravaillac, a fanatical Catholic, and was succeeded by his son Louis XIII.
3. The son of Antoine de Bourbon, Duke of Vendôme and Jeanne d'Albret, the Queen of Navarre, Henry was baptised as a Catholic but raised in the Protestant faith by his mother.
4. He inherited the throne of Navarre in 1572 on his mother's death.
5. As a Huguenot, Henry was involved in the French Wars of Religion, barely escaping assassination in the St. Bartholomew's Day massacre.
6. He later led Protestant forces against the royal army.
7. He and his predecessor Henry III of France were direct descendants of Saint-King Louis IX.
8. Henry III belonged to the House of Valois, descended from Philip III of France, elder son of Saint Louis; Henry IV belonged to the House of Bourbon, descended from Robert, Count of Clermont, younger son of Saint Louis.
9. As Head of the House of Bourbon, Henry was "first prince of the blood".
10. Upon the death of his brother-in-law and distant cousin Henry III in 1589, Henry was called to the French succession by the Salic law.
11. He initially kept the Protestant faith (the only French king to do so) and had to fight against the Catholic League, which denied that he could wear France's crown as a Protestant.
12. To obtain mastery over his kingdom, after four years of stalemate, he found it prudent to abjure the Calvinist faith.
13. As a pragmatic politician (in the parlance of the time, a "politique"), he displayed an unusual religious tolerance for the era.
14. Notably, he promulgated the Edict of Nantes (1598), which guaranteed religious liberties to Protestants, thereby effectively ending the Wars of Religion.
15. Considered a usurper by some Catholics and a traitor by some Protestants, Henry became target of at least 12 assassination attempts.
16. An unpopular king among his contemporaries, Henry gained more status after his death.
17. He was admired for his repeated victories over his enemies and his conversion to Catholicism.
18. The "Good King Henryle bon roi Henri") was remembered for his geniality and his great concern about the welfare of his subjects.
19. An active ruler, he worked to regularise state finance, promote agriculture, eliminate corruption and encourage education.
20. During his reign, the French colonization of the Americas truly began with the foundation of the colony of Acadia and its capital Port-Royal.
21. He was celebrated in the popular song "Vive le roi Henri" (which later became an anthem for the French monarchy during the reigns of his successors) and in Voltaire's "Henriade".

chunks.title: Barthold A. Butenschøn Sr.
chunks.chunk:
Title: Barthold A. Butenschøn Sr.
0. Hans Barthold Andresen Butenschøn( 27 December 1877 – 28 November 1971) was a Norwegian businessperson.
1. He was born in Kristiania as a son of Nils August Andresen Butenschøn and Hanna Butenschøn, and grandson of Nicolay Andresen.
2. Together with Mabel Anette Plahte( 1877 – 1973, a daughter of Frithjof M. Plahte) he had the son Hans Barthold Andresen Butenschøn Jr. and was through him the father- in- law of Ragnhild Butenschøn and grandfather of Peter Butenschøn.
3. Through his daughter Marie Claudine he was the father- in- law of Joakim Lehmkuhl, through his daughter Mabel Anette he was the father- in- law of Harald Astrup( a son of Sigurd Astrup) and through his daughter Nini Augusta he was the father- in- law of Ernst Torp.
4. He took commerce school and agricultural school.
5. He was hired in the family company N. A. Andresen& Co, and became a co-owner in 1910.
6. He eventually became chief executive officer.
7. The bank changed its name to Andresens Bank in 1913 and merged with Bergens Kreditbank in 1920.
8. The merger was dissolved later in the 1920s.
9. He was also a landowner, owning Nedre Skøyen farm and a lot of land in Enebakk.
10. He chaired the board of Nydalens Compagnie from 1926, having not been a board member before that.
11. He also chaired the supervisory council of Forsikringsselskapet Viking and Nedre Glommen salgsforening, and was a supervisory council member of Filharmonisk Selskap.
12. He was a member of the gentlemen's club SK Fram since 1890, and was proclaimed a lifetime member in 1964.
13. He was buried in Enebakk.

chunks.title: Werner, Count of Valenciennes
chunks.chunk:
Title: Werner, Count of Valenciennes
0. Werner( Garnier, Warin)( died 973), Count of Valenciennes and Count of Hesbaye and Zülpich, brother of Renaud, Count of Mons.
1. His parentage is unknown.
2. In 953, Reginar III was defeated by King Lothair and Archbishop Bruno, and banished to Bavaria.
3. At that time, Werner became the successor of Rudolf as Count of Hesbaye, Werner, is referred to as count in a charter confirmed by Bruno.
4. Before 966, it appears that at least some of Rudolf's property was confiscated and placed under Werner.
5. After the disgrace of Count Reginar III, Godfrey I, Duke of Lower Lorraine, received the County of Hainaut, which included the cities of Mons and Valenciennes.
6. After the death of Godfrey, Amaury became Count of Valenciennes, while Richer assumed the countship of Mons.
7. After the death of Amaury, Emperor Otto I appointed Werner as the Count of Valenciennes.
8. Returning from exile in 973, the sons of Reginar III, Reginar IV, Count of Mons, and Lambert I, Count of Louvain, killed both Werner and his brother Renaud at the battle of Peronne.
9. Werner had no known children.

Title: Lambert II, Count of Lens
0. Lambert II, Count of Lens( died 1054) was a French nobleman.
1. He was likely born circa 1030.
2. This would put his death age at about 24 years old.
3. He was the son of Eustace I, Count of Bologne and of Maud of Louvain( daughter of Lambert I of Louvain).
4. he married Adelaide of Normandy, Countess of Aumale, daughter of Robert I, Duke of Normandy and sister of William the Conqueror.
5. Adelaide was the widow of Enguerrand II, Count of Ponthieu who died in 1053.
6. Lambert and Adelaide had a daughter, Judith of Lens, although Lambert would scarcely have seen her; he was killed at the battle of Lille in 1054.
7. Lambert was supporting Baldwin V, Count of Flanders against Henry III, Holy Roman Emperor when he was killed in battle.
8. His widow, Adelaide, married thirdly, Odo, Count of Champagne.

chunks.title: Sigramnus, Count of Hesbaye

Title: Sigramnus, Count of Hesbaye
0. Sigramnus (Sigrand), was the Count of Hesbaye.
1. Sigramnus became Count of Hesbaye by virtue of his marriage to the daughter of Lambert, Count of Hesbaye.
2. The dates of his rule are unknown but are believed to be between that of Lambert’s son and grandson, and so it was perhaps an interim position until the latter became of age.
3. The only knowledge available on Sigramnus is through his son, the Bishop of Metz, and grandson Ingerman of Hesbaye, father of Ermengard, wife of Louis the Pious.
4. Sigramnus is known to have been an early supporter of Charles Martel, even before the Battle of Amblève.
5. Sigramnus married , daughter of Lambert, Count of Hesbaye.
6. They had three children:
Previous histories have portrayed Sigramnus as the husband of the daughter of Charles Martel, but this has been largely discredited.
7. Sigramnus was succeeded by his nephew Cancor as Count of Hesbaye.

chunks.title: Reginar III, Count of Hainaut
chunks.chunk:
Title: Reginar III, Count of Hainaut
0. Reginar III (c. 920 – 973) was a Count of Hainaut from approximately 940 until his exile in 958.
1. He was the son of Reginar II, Count of Hainaut.
2. He took part in the rebellion of his uncle Gilbert, Duke of Lorraine.
3. When Gilbert was killed in 939, Regnier had to pledge fealty to King Otto the Great.
4. He then allied himself with King Louis IV of France, but King Otto sent duke Hermann of Swabia to quell the rebels in 944.
5. Otto appointed Conrad the Red as duke of Lotharingia, who tried to diminish the power of Reginar.
6. However, when Conrad rose against Otto, Reginar supported him.
7. In an anarchic situation, Reginar appropriated the dowry of Gerberga of Saxony, Otto's sister and mother of the French king, and also church property.
8. In 953, Bruno, Archbishop of Cologne, who had also been appointed duke of Lotharingia, restored order and defeated Reginar.
9. As Reginar refused to submit, he was exiled to Bohemia, where he died.

chunks.title: Carlos Saura
chunks.chunk:
Title: Carlos Saura
0. Carlos Saura Atarés( born 4 January 1932) is a Spanish film director, photographer and writer.
1. Along with Luis Buñuel and Pedro Almodóvar, he is counted among the Spain ’s three most renowned filmmakers.
2. He has a long and prolific career that spans over half a century.
3. Several of his films have won many international awards.
4. Saura began his career in 1955 making documentary shorts.
5. He quickly gained international prominence when his first feature- length film premiered at Cannes Film Festival in 1960.
6. Although he started filming as a neorealist, Saura quickly switched to films encoded with metaphors and symbolism in order to get around the Spanish censors.
7. In 1966, he was thrust into the international spotlight when his film" La Caza" won the Silver Bear at the Berlin International Film Festival.
8. In the following years, he forged an international reputation for his cinematic treatment of emotional and spiritual responses to repressive political conditions.
9. By the 1970s, Saura was the best known filmmaker working in Spain.
10. His films employed complex narrative devices and were frequently controversial.
11. He won Special Jury Awards for" La Prima Angélica"( 1973) and" Cría Cuervos"( 1975) in Cannes; and an Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film nomination in 1979 for" Mama Cumple 100 Años".
12. In the 1980s, Saura was in the spotlight for his Flamenco trilogy –" Bodas de SangreCarmen" and" El Amor Brujo," in which he combined dramatic content and flamenco dance forms.
13. His work continued to be featured in worldwide competitions and earned numerous awards.
14. He received two nominations for Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film, for" Carmen"( 1983) and" Tango"( 1998).
15. His films are sophisticated expression of time and space fusing reality with fantasy, past with present, and memory with hallucination.
16. In the last two decades of the 20th century, Saura has concentrated on works uniting music, dance and images.

chunks.title: John E. Blakeley
chunks.chunk:
Title: John E. Blakeley
0. John E. Blakeley
1. ( 1 October 1888 – 20 February 1958) was a British film producer, director and screenwriter, the founder of Mancunian Films.
2. Born in Ardwick, Manchester, son of James Blakeley( born c. 1862; Manchester), and Margaret Quirk( born c. 1861; Glasgow, Scotland), he was of Lancashire( Church of England) descent on his father's side of the family and Irish Catholic on his mother's.
3. His father had become an early film distributor in 1908 after previous work as a travelling draper.
4. Blakeley joined his father's business and soon came to understand the tastes of the emerging cinema audiences in the northern industrial towns.
5. By the 1930s, the younger Blakeley was making films starring the idols of northern music hall comedy: George Formby, Frank Randle and Sandy Powell.
6. Initially relying on London studios, rising costs encouraged him to found the Mancunian Film Studios in his hometown in 1947, on £ 70,000 capital.
7. The studios produced a sequence of profitable films, often on shoestring budgets, until Blakeley's retirement in 1953.
8. He died in Stockport aged 69.

2. Amadeus VII was known for his hospitality, for he would entertain people of all stations and never turned a person from his table without a meal.
3. He married Bonne of Berry, daughter of John, Duke of Berry, who was the younger brother of Charles V of France.
4. They had three children:
Upon his death at age 29 from tetanus, controversy arose because of his will.
5. Amadeus VII left the important role of guardian of his son and heir, Amadeus VIII, to his own mother, a sister of the powerful Duke de Bourbon, instead of following the tradition of appointing the child's mother, who was a daughter of the equally powerful Duke de Berry.
6. It took three months of negotiations to restore peace in the family.

chunks.title: Control engineering
chunks.chunk:
Title: Control engineering
0. Control engineering or control systems engineering is an engineering discipline that applies automatic control theory to design systems with desired behaviors in control environments.
1. The discipline of controls overlaps and is usually taught along with electrical engineering at many institutions around the world.
2. The practice uses sensors and detectors to measure the output performance of the process being controlled; these measurements are used to provide corrective feedback helping to achieve the desired performance.
3. Systems designed to perform without requiring human input are called automatic control systems( such as cruise control for regulating the speed of a car).
4. Multi-disciplinary in nature, control systems engineering activities focus on implementation of control systems mainly derived by mathematical modeling of a diverse range of systems.

chunks.title: Alfred Hitchcock
chunks.chunk:
Title: Alfred Hitchcock
0. Sir Alfred Joseph Hitchcock,( 13 August 1899 – 29 April 1980) was an English film director and producer, widely regarded as one of the most influential and extensively studied filmmakers in the history of cinema.
1. Known as" the Master of Suspense", he directed over 50 feature films in a career spanning six decades, becoming as well known as any of his actors thanks to his many interviews, his cameo roles in most of his films, and his hosting and producing of the television anthology" Alfred Hitchcock Presents"( 1955 – 1965).
2. His films garnered a total of 46 Oscar nominations and six wins.
3. Born in Leytonstone, Essex, Hitchcock entered the film industry in 1919 as a title card designer after training as a technical clerk and copy writer for a telegraph- cable company.
4. He made his directorial debut with the silent film" The Pleasure Garden"( 1925).
5. His first successful film,( 1927), helped to shape the thriller genre, while his 1929 film," Blackmail", was the first British.
6. Two of his 1930s thrillers," The 39 Steps"( 1935) and" The Lady Vanishes"( 1938), are ranked among the greatest British films of the 20th century.
7. By 1939 Hitchcock was a filmmaker of international importance, and film producer David O. Selznick persuaded him to move to Hollywood.
8. A string of successful films followed, including" Rebecca"( 1940)," Foreign Correspondent"( 1940)," Suspicion"( 1941)," Shadow of a Doubt"( 1943), and" Notorious"( 1946).
9. " Rebecca" won the Academy Award for Best Picture, although Hitchcock himself was only nominated as Best Director; he was also nominated for" Lifeboat"( 1944) and" Spellbound"( 1945), although he never won the Best Director Academy Award.
10. The" Hitchcockian" style includes the use of camera movement to mimic a person's gaze, thereby turning viewers into voyeurs, and framing shots to maximise anxiety and fear.
11. The film critic Robin Wood wrote that the meaning of a Hitchcock film" is there in the method, in the progression from shot to shot.
12. A Hitchcock film is an organism, with the whole implied in every detail and every detail related to the whole."
13. After a brief lull of commercial success in the late 1940s, Hitchcock returned to form with" Strangers on a Train"( 1951) and" Dial M For Murder"( 1954).
14. By 1960 Hitchcock had directed four films often ranked among the greatest of all time:" Rear Window"( 1954)," Vertigo"( 1958)," North by Northwest"( 1959), and" Psycho"( 1960) with the first and last of these garnering him Best Director nominations.
15. In 2012," Vertigo" replaced Orson Welles's" Citizen Kane"( 1941) as the British Film Institute's greatest film ever made based on its world- wide poll of hundreds of film critics.
16. By 2018 eight of his films had been selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry, including his personal favourite," Shadow of a Doubt"( 1943).
17. He received the BAFTA Fellowship in 1971, the AFI Life Achievement Award in 1979 and was knighted in December that year, four months before he died.

0. Marius is a 1931 French drama film directed by Alexander Korda.

4. The restored film was also given a limited re-release in the United States by Janus Films on 4 January 2017, first premiering at Film Forum.
5. The film was made by Korda for the French subsidiary of Paramount Pictures.
6. A separate Swedish- language version" Längtan till havet" by John W. Brunius was also released in 1931 and a German- language version" The Golden Anchor", also directed by Korda, was released the following year.

1. Both the screenplay and the successful stage play on which it was based were written by English playwright Frederick Knott.
2. The play premiered in 1952 on BBC Television, before being performed on stage in the same year in London's West End in June, and then New York's Broadway in October.
3. Originally intended to be shown in dual- strip polarized 3- D, the film played in most theatres in ordinary 2- D due to the loss of interest in the 3- D process( the projection of which was difficult and error- prone) by the time of its release.

0. Sir Alexander Korda( born Sándor László Kellner, 16 September 1893 – 23 January 1956) was a British film producer and director and screenwriter, who founded his own film production studios and film distribution company.
1. Born in Hungary, where he began his career, he worked briefly in the Austrian and German film industries during the era of silent films, before being based in Hollywood from 1926 to 1930 for the first of his two brief periods there( the other was during World War II).
2. The change led to a divorce from his first wife, the Hungarian film actress María Corda, who was unable to make the transition from silent films to" talkies" because of her strong Hungarian accent.
3. From 1930, Korda was active in the British film industry, and soon became one of its leading figures.
4. He was the founder of London Films and, post-war, the owner of British Lion Films, a film distribution company.
5. Korda produced many outstanding classics of the British film industry, including" The Private Life of Henry VIIIRembrandtThings To Come The Thief of Baghdad" and" The Third Man".
6. In 1942, Korda became the first filmmaker to receive a knighthood.

chunks.title: The Princess Bride (film)

Title: The Princess Bride (film)
0. The Princess Bride is a 1987 American fantasy adventure comedy film directed and co-produced by Rob Reiner, starring Cary Elwes, Robin Wright, Mandy Patinkin, Chris Sarandon, Wallace Shawn, André the Giant, and Christopher Guest.
1. Adapted by William Goldman from his 1973 novel" The Princess Bride", it tells the story of a farmhand named
2. Westley, accompanied by companions befriended along the way, who must rescue his true love Princess Buttercup from the odious Prince Humperdinck.
3. The film essentially preserves the novel's narrative style by presenting the story as a book being read by a grandfather( Peter Falk) to his sick grandson( Fred Savage).
4. The film was first released in the United States on September 25, 1987, and was well- received by critics at the time, but was only a modest box office success.
5. Over time, particularly with the introduction of the Internet, the film has become a cult classic.
6. The film is number 50 on the Bravo's" 100 Funniest Movies", number 88 on The American Film Institute's( AFI)" AFI's 100 Years ... 100 Passions" list of the 100 greatest film love stories, and 46 in Channel 4's 50 Greatest Comedy Films list.

chunks.title: Prince Constantine Constantinovich of Russia
chunks.chunk:
Title: Prince Constantine Constantinovich of Russia
0. Prince Constantine Constantinovich of Russia(" Константин Константинович"; 1 January 1891 – 18 July 1918), nicknamed Kostya by the family, was the fourth child of Grand Duke Constantine Constantinovich of Russia by his wife Grand Duchess Elizabeth Mavrikievna of Russia.
1. The Prince was a silent, shy person who fancied theatre and was educated in the Corps des Pages, a military academy in Saint Petersburg.
2. He served in the army during the First World War.
3. A priest who met him at the front, Hegumen Seraphim, wrote:" He was an extremely modest officer of the Guard of the Izmaylovsky Regiment, much beloved by officers and soldiers alike; along with them he was a brave soldier who distinguished himself.
4. I personally remember seeing him in the trenches among the soldiers, risking his life."
5. After seeing the happiness of his two elder siblings, John and Tatiana, Konstantin was keen to start his own family.
6. He fancied the Tsar's oldest daughter, Olga, but was also keen on Princess Elisabeth of Romania.
7. Elisabeth's grandmother, the former Grand Duchess Maria Alexandrovna of Russia, wrote to her daughter, the Crown Princess Marie of Romania in 1911, saying," The young Kostya is seized now with terror that she will be snatched away, as he says, before he has even made her acquaintance.
8. The young man seems really quite nice, is much liked in his regiment, and they have really been very well brought up.
9. This one is full of life ... if you have nothing against this youth coming on a passing visit, will you telegraph to me."
10. However, the request was denied on political grounds, as Prince John was married to Helen of Serbia, and Konstantin never did find the marriage he longed for.
11. In March 1918 he was exiled to the Urals by the Bolsheviks and murdered in a mineshaft near Alapayevsk, along with his brothers Prince John Constantinovich and Prince Igor Konstantinovich, his cousin Prince Vladimir Pavlovich Paley and other relatives and friends.
12. His body was eventually buried in the Russian Orthodox Church cemetery in Beijing, which was destroyed in 1986 to build a park.

chunks.chunk:
Title: Theodoric the Great
0. Theodoric the Great (454 – 30 August 526), also spelled Theoderic or called Theodoric the Amal , was king of the Ostrogoths (471–526), and ruler of the independent Ostrogothic Kingdom of Italy between 493–526, regent of the Visigoths (511–526), and a patrician of the Roman Empire.
1. As ruler of the combined Gothic realms, Theodoric controlled an empire stretching from the Atlantic Ocean to the Adriatic Sea.

chunks.title: Audofleda
chunks.chunk:
Title: Audofleda
0. Audofleda was a Gothic queen.
1. She was the sister of Clovis I, King of the Franks.
2. She married Theoderic the Great, King of the Ostrogoths (471–526), around 493 AD (exact date unknown).
3. Theoderic sent an embassy to Clovis to request the marriage.
4. This political move allied Theoderic with the Franks, and by marrying his daughters off to the kings of the Burgundians, the Vandals, and the Visigoths, he allied himself with every major 'Barbarian' kingdom in the West.
5. Audofleda was a pagan prior to her marriage, and was baptised at the time of her wedding by an Arian bishop.
6. Theoderic and Audofleda had one daughter, Amalasuntha, who ruled the Ostrogoths from 526 until 534.

0. Saint Rumbold( or" RumoldRomuold") was an Irish or Scottish Christian missionary, although his true nationality is not known for certain.
1. He was martyred near Mechelen by two men, whom he had denounced for their evil ways.
2. Saint Rumbold's feast day is celebrated by the Roman Catholic Church, and Western Rite Orthodox Churches, on 24 June; and it is celebrated in Ireland on 3 July.
3. He is the patron saint of Mechelen, where St. Rumbold's Cathedral possesses an elaborate golden shrine on its high altar, containing relics attributed to the saint.
4. It is rumoured that his remains are buried inside the cathedral.
5. Twenty- five paintings in the choir illustrate his life.

chunks.chunk:
Title: Jessamine (band)
0. Jessamine was an American post- rock band, that recorded three albums for Kranky records between 1994 and 1998, and a number of singles for other record labels.
1. These singles were later collected by the band on a self- released compilation album in 1997 entitled" Another Fictionalized History".
2. Their single" Cellophane" was a minor college radio hit in the band's native Seattle, getting frequent airplay on KCMU( now KEXP).
3. The band's sound was influenced by the works of Krautrock bands such as Can and Neu!, and their first album also bore some sonic resemblance to the sounds of early 1990s bands from the UK shoegaze scene.
4. This mesh of krautrock, shoegaze, drone, space- rock, and experimental electronica helped the band forge a unique sound, which helped them stand apart from other active bands in the Seattle scene that were more grunge, metal, or indie- rock based.
5. Their success in solidifying a unique sound however did not translate to album sales, and the band remained a relatively obscure act, with a small cult following.
6. The band split in 1998, and Ritter and Brown recorded together as Fontanelle for a couple more years.

chunks.title: John Lennon
chunks.chunk:
Title: John Lennon
0. John Winston Ono Lennon (born John Winston Lennon, 9 October 19408 December 1980) was an English singer, songwriter and peace activist who gained worldwide fame as the founder, co-lead vocalist, and rhythm guitarist of the Beatles.
1. His songwriting partnership with Paul McCartney remains the most successful in history.
2. In 1969, he started the Plastic Ono Band with his second wife, Yoko Ono.
3. After the Beatles disbanded in 1970, Lennon continued as a solo artist.
4. Born in Liverpool, Lennon became involved in the skiffle craze as a teenager.
5. In 1957, he formed his first band, the Quarrymen, which evolved into the Beatles in 1960.
6. He was initially the group's de facto leader, a role gradually ceded to McCartney.
7. Starting in 1967, Lennon's lyrics began to espouse a pacifist message, and some of his songs were soon adopted as anthems by the anti-war movement and the larger counterculture.
8. From 1968 to 1972, he produced more than a dozen records with Ono, including a trilogy of avant-garde albums, his first solo LP "John Lennon/Plastic Ono Band", and the international top 10 singles "Give Peace a ChanceInstant Karma!Imagine" and "Happy Xmas (War Is Over)".
9. Lennon was known for the rebellious nature and acerbic wit in his music, writing, drawings, on film and in interviews.
10. He was controversial through his political and peace activism.
11. After moving to New York City in 1971, his criticism of the Vietnam War resulted in a three-year attempt by the Nixon administration to deport him.
12. In 1975, Lennon disengaged from the music business to raise his infant son Sean, and in 1980, returned with the Ono collaboration "Double Fantasy".
13. He was shot and killed in the archway of his Manhattan apartment building three weeks after the album's release.
14. By 2018, Lennon's solo equivalent album sales had exceeded 72 million units worldwide.
15. In 2002, Lennon was voted eighth in a BBC poll of the 100 Greatest Britons, and in 2008, "Rolling Stone" ranked him the fifth-greatest singer of all time.
16. In 1987, he was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame.
17. Lennon was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame twice, as a member of the Beatles in 1988 and as a solo artist in 1994.

chunks.title: Giant in My Heart

Title: Giant in My Heart
0. " Giant in My Heart" is a song by Canadian recording artist Kiesza from her debut studio album," Sound of a Woman"( 2014).
1. It was released by record label Lokal Legend as the second single from the album on August 8, 2014.
2. The song was co-written by Kiesza and Rami Samir Afuni, and produced by the latter.
3. " Giant in My Heart" is an electropop and house track sung in an emotive falsetto tone and features a combination of scat- singing, a pounding 808 and softer synth- led sections.
4. Lyrically, the song focuses on subjects of love lost and the aftermath of a breakup.
5. " Giant in My Heart" garnered positive reviews from contemporary music critics, who commended the song for its sonic similarities with Kiesza's debut single" Hideaway" and the singer's strong vocal performance.
6. It was a commercial success, debuting at number four on the UK Singles Chart, number one on the UK Dance Chart and selling 33,414 copies in its first week.
7. " Giant in My Heart" marked Kiesza's second consecutive top five single in the United Kingdom and has also had success in Germany and Belgium where it peaked at numbers 11 and 12 respectively.
8. The song was accompanied by a short film music video directed by producer Afuni in New York City.
9. The clip premiered on July 1, 2014 and was acclaimed by several critics.
10. It features a frustrated male office worker living a double life as a crossdresser.
11. Kiesza has performed" Giant in My Heart" on American television show" Jimmy Kimmel Live!", and the song has been covered by English singer Florrie.

question: Who is Maria Luisa Of Savoy's father-in-law?

chunks.title: Princess Maria Luisa of Savoy (1729–1767)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Princess Maria Luisa of Savoy (1729–1767)
0. Maria Luisa of Savoy (Maria Luisa Gabriella; 25 March 1729 – 22 June 1767) was a princess of Savoy.

chunks.title: Maria Luisa, Duchess of Lucca
chunks.chunk:
Title: Maria Luisa, Duchess of Lucca
0. Maria Luisa of Spain  (6 July 1782 – 13 March 1824) was a Spanish infanta, daughter of King Charles IV and his wife, Maria Luisa of Parma.
1. In 1795, she married her first cousin Louis, Hereditary Prince of Parma.
2. She spent the first years of her married life at the Spanish court where their first child, Charles, was born.
3. In 1801 the Treaty of Aranjuez made her husband King of Etruria, a kingdom created from the former Duchy of Tuscany in exchange for the renunciation of the Duchy of Parma.
4. They arrived in Florence, the capital of the new kingdom, in August 1801.
5. During a brief visit to Spain in 1802, Maria Luisa gave birth to her second child.
6. Her husband's reign in Etruria was marred by his ill health.
7. He died in 1803, at the age of 30, following an epileptic crisis.
8. Maria Luisa acted as regent for their son.
9. During her government in Florence, she tried to gain the support of her subjects, but her administration of Etruria was cut short by Napoleon Bonaparte, who forced her to leave with her children in December 1807.
10. As part of the Treaty of Fontainebleau, Napoleon incorporated Etruria to his domains.
11. After a futile interview with Napoleon in Milan, Maria Luisa looked for refuge in exile with her family in Spain.
12. The Spanish court was deeply divided and a month after her arrival the country was thrown into unrest when a popular uprising, known as the Mutiny of Aranjuez, forced Maria Luisa's father to abdicate in favor of her brother Ferdinand VII.
13. Napoleon invited father and son to Bayonne, France, with the excuse of acting as a mediator, but gave the kingdom to his brother Joseph.
14. Napoleon called the remaining members of the Spanish royal family to France and at their departure on 2 May 1808, the citizens of Madrid rose up against the French occupation.
15. In France, Maria Luisa was reunited in exile with her parents.
16. She was the only member of the Spanish royal family to directly oppose Napoleon.
17. After her secret plan to escape was discovered, Maria Luisa was separated from her son and placed with her daughter as prisoners in a Roman convent.
18. Maria Luisa, mostly known as the Queen of Etruria during her lifetime, regained her freedom in 1814 at the fall of Napoleon.
19. In the following years she continued to live in Rome, hoping to recover her son's former domains.
20. To put forward her case she wrote a book of memoirs, but was disappointed when the Congress of Vienna (1814–15) compensated her not with Parma, but with the smaller Duchy of Lucca, which had been carved out of Tuscany.
21. As a consolation she was allowed to retain the honors of a queen.
22. Initially reluctant to accept this accord, Maria Luisa did not take the government of Lucca until December 1817.
23. As a reigning duchess of Lucca, she disregarded the constitution imposed by the Congress of Vienna.
24. While spending time in her palace in Rome, she died of cancer at the age of 41.

chunks.title: Philip V of Spain
chunks.chunk:
Title: Philip V of Spain
0. Philip V (19 December 1683 – 9 July 1746) was King of Spain from 1 November 1700 to his abdication in favour of his son Louis on 14 January 1724, and from his reaccession of the throne upon his son's death, 6 September 1724 to his own death on 9 July 1746.
1. Before his reign, Philip occupied an exalted place in the royal family of France as a grandson of King Louis XIV.
2. His father, Louis, Grand Dauphin, had the strongest genealogical claim to the throne of Spain when it became vacant in 1700.
3. However, since neither the Grand Dauphin nor Philip's older brother, Louis, Duke of Burgundy, could be displaced from their place in the succession to the French throne, the Grand Dauphin's maternal uncle (Philip's granduncle)
4. King Charles II of Spain named Philip as his heir in his will.
5. It was well known that the union of France and Spain under one monarch would upset the balance of power in Europe, such that other European powers would take steps to prevent it.
6. Indeed, Philip's accession in Spain provoked the 13-year War of the Spanish Succession, which continued until the Treaty of Utrecht forbade any future possibility of unifying the French and Spanish crowns while confirming his accession to the throne of Spain.
7. Philip was the first member of the French House of Bourbon to rule as King of Spain.
8. The sum of his two reigns, 45 years and 21 days, is the longest in modern Spanish history.

question: Which film came out first, Repeated Absences or She Wore A Yellow Ribbon?

chunks.title: Fort Apache (film)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Fort Apache (film)
0. Fort Apache is a 1948 American western film directed by John Ford and starring John Wayne and Henry Fonda.
1. The film was the first of the director's" cavalry trilogy" and was followed by" She Wore a Yellow Ribbon"( 1949) and" Rio Grande"( 1950), both also starring Wayne.
2. The screenplay was inspired by James Warner Bellah's short story" Massacre"( 1947).
3. The historical sources for" Massacre" have been attributed both to George Armstrong Custer and the Battle of Little Bighorn and to the Fetterman Fight.
4. The film was one of the first to present an authentic and sympathetic view of the Native Americans.
5. In his review of the DVD release of" Fort Apache" in 2012," New York Times" movie critic
6. Dave Kehr called it" one of the great achievements of classical American cinema, a film of immense complexity that never fails to reveal new shadings with each viewing ... among the first pro-Indian westerns" that portrays the Native Americans with" sympathy and respect".
7. The film was awarded the Best Director and Best Cinematography awards by the Locarno International Film Festival of Locarno, Switzerland.
8. Screenwriter Frank S. Nugent was nominated for best screenplay by the Writers Guild of America.

chunks.title: She Wore a Yellow Ribbon
chunks.chunk:
Title: She Wore a Yellow Ribbon
0. She Wore a Yellow Ribbon is a 1949 Technicolor Western film directed by John Ford and starring John Wayne.
1. The Oscar- winning film was the second of Ford's Cavalry trilogy films, along with" Fort Apache"( 1948) and" Rio Grande"( 1950).
2. With a budget of$ 1.6 million, the film was one of the most expensive Westerns made up to that time.
3. It was a major hit for RKO.
4. The film takes its name from" She Wore a Yellow Ribbon", a popular US military song that is used to keep marching cadence.
5. The film was shot on location in Monument Valley utilizing large areas of the Navajo reservation along the Arizona- Utah state border.
6. Ford and cinematographer Winton Hoch based much of the film's imagery on the paintings and sculptures of Frederic Remington.
7. The film won the Academy Award for Best Cinematography, Color in 1950.
8. It was also nominated as 1950's Best Written American Western( which the Writers Guild of America awarded to" Yellow Sky").

chunks.title: Thorvald Stoltenberg

Title: Thorvald Stoltenberg
0. Thorvald Stoltenberg (8 July 1931 – 13 July 2018) was a Norwegian politician.
1. His ancestors stemmed from Tønsberg.
2. He served as Minister of Defence (1979–81) and Minister of Foreign Affairs (1987–1989 and 1990–1993) in two Labour governments.
3. From 1989 to 1990 served as Norwegian Ambassador to the UN.
4. In 1990 he became the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, but served only one year before rejoining the Norwegian government.
5. In 1992, Stoltenberg, together with nine Baltic Ministers of Foreign Affairs and an EU commissioner, founded the Council of the Baltic Sea States (CBSS) and the EuroFaculty.
6. In 1993 appointed Special Representative of the UN Secretary-General for the former Yugoslavia and UN Co-Chairman of the Steering Committee of the International Conference on the former Yugoslavia.
7. Thorvald Stoltenberg was also the UN witness at the signing of Erdut Agreement.
8. In 2003 he was appointed Chairman of the Board of International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance (International IDEA).
9. Between 1999 and 2008 he was President of the Norwegian Red Cross, the only president to serve three terms.
10. He is also a member of the Trilateral Commission, and holds a seat on their Executive Committee.
11. At the local level, Stoltenberg was elected to the Oslo City Council in 2015.
12. Stoltenberg was born in Oslo.

0. William III (1224 – 6 June 1251) was the lord of Dampierre from 1231 and count of Flanders from 1247 until his death.
1. He was the son of William II of Dampierre and Margaret II of Flanders.
2. Margaret inherited Flanders and Hainault in 1244 and immediately the War of the Succession of Flanders and Hainault began between William and his brothers, the Dampierre claimants, and the children of Margaret's first marriage to Bouchard of Avesnes.
3. Margaret favoured William and declared him her heir.
4. In 1246, Louis IX of France intervened to arbitrate the conflict and declared Flanders to William and Hainault to John I of Avesnes.
5. Margaret officially invested William as count in 1247.
6. In November of that year, William married Beatrice of Brabant, daughter of Henry II, Duke of Brabant and Marie of Hohenstaufen.
7. They had no children.
8. Meanwhile, the fight continued over Namur between the Dampierres and the Avesnes.
9. On 19 May 1250, peace was signed.
10. On 6 June the next year, William died at a tournament in Trazegnies.
11. The war began anew with Guy, William's younger brother, taking up Flanders and the Dampierre claim.

chunks.title: Lee Mantle
chunks.chunk:
Title: Lee Mantle
0. Lee Mantle( December 13, 1851 November 18, 1934) was a United States Senator from Montana.
1. Born in Birmingham, England, his mother converted to Mormonism and immigrated to the United States with her children; they settled at Salt Lake City, Utah in 1864.
2. Upon arriving in Utah Territory and facing evidence that Mormon men were practicing polygamy, Mantle's mother came to believe that she had been deceived by the Mormon missionaries and she and her children renounced the LDS Church.
3. Mantle attended a village school and moved to Idaho Territory in 1870, where he was a telegraph operator and stage agent.
4. He moved to Butte, Montana in 1877 and became agent of the Wells- Fargo Express Co.
5. He established the Inter Mountain, a daily Republican newspaper, in 1881 and served as alderman the same year.
6. He was a member of the Territorial house of representatives in 1882, 1884, and 1888, and served as speaker in 1888; he was mayor of Butte in 1892 and many times chairman of local and State conventions.
7. Lee Mantle was appointed to the U.S. Senate to fill the vacancy in the term commencing March 4, 1893, caused by the failure of the legislature to elect, but was not seated; he was then elected as a Republican to fill the vacancy and served from January 16, 1895 to March 3, 1899.
8. In 1896, he switched parties and joined the Silver Republican Party.
9. He was an unsuccessful candidate for renomination in 1899, and organized and became chairman of the Silver Republican Party of Montana in 1896, but returned to the Republican Party in 1900.

chunks.title: Juan Carlos I of Spain
chunks.chunk:
Title: Juan Carlos I of Spain
0. Juan Carlos I( Juan Carlos Alfonso Víctor María de Borbón y Borbón- Dos Sicilias, born 5 January 1938) is a member of the Spanish royal family who reigned as King of Spain from November 1975 until his abdication in June 2014.
1. Juan Carlos is the grandson of Alfonso XIII, the last king of Spain before the abolition of the monarchy in 1931 and the subsequent declaration of the Second Spanish Republic.
2. Juan Carlos was born in Rome, Italy, during his family's exile.
3. " Generalísimo" Francisco Franco took over the government of Spain after his victory in the Spanish Civil War in 1939, yet in 1947 Spain's status as a monarchy was affirmed and a law was passed allowing Franco to choose his successor.
4. Juan Carlos's father, Juan, was the third son of King Alfonso, who had renounced his claims to the throne in January 1941.
5. Juan was seen by Franco to be too liberal and in 1969 was bypassed in favour of Juan Carlos as Franco's successor as head of state.
6. Juan Carlos spent his early years in Italy and came to Spain in 1947 to continue his studies.
7. After completing his secondary education in 1955, he began his military training and entered the General Military Academy at Zaragoza.
8. Later, he attended the Naval Military School, the General Academy of the Air, and finished his tertiary education at the University of Madrid.
9. In 1962, Juan Carlos married Princess Sophia of Greece and Denmark in Athens.
10. The couple had two daughters and a son together: Elena, Cristina, and Felipe.
11. Due to Franco's declining health, Juan Carlos first began periodically acting as Spain's head of state in the summer of 1974.
12. Franco died in November the following year and Juan Carlos became king on 22 November 1975, two days after Franco's death, the first reigning monarch since 1931; although his exiled father did not formally renounce his claims to the throne in favor of his son until 1977.
13. Expected to continue Franco's legacy, Juan Carlos, however, soon after his accession introduced reforms to dismantle the Francoist regime and begin the Spanish transition to democracy.
14. This led to the approval of the Spanish Constitution of 1978 in a referendum, which re-established a constitutional monarchy.
15. In 1981, Juan Carlos played a major role in preventing a coup that attempted to revert Spain to Francoist government in the King's name.
16. In 2008, he was considered the most popular leader in all Ibero- America.
17. Hailed for his role in Spain's transition to democracy, the King and the monarchy's reputation began to suffer after controversies surrounding his family arose, exacerbated by an elephant- hunting trip he undertook during a time of financial crisis in Spain.
18. In 2014, Juan Carlos, citing personal reasons, abdicated in favour of his son, who acceded to the throne as Felipe VI.

Juan Carlos Salazar actually began his singing career by accident.
3. While in high school he was selected to play the “cuatro” for a fellow student who was to represent their school in a nationwide singing competition.
4. Three days before the big event, the singer developed an acute case of laryngitis.
5. Too late to retire the school from the contest, the principal searched desperately for a replacement.
6. The only student that knew the song was Juan Carlos.
7. At the age of 16, without ever taking a singing lesson, Juan Carlos walked to the center of the stage and trembling all over sang the song.
8. Upsetting all the favorites, Juan Carlos won first prize and national recognition.
9. Juan Carlos is an accomplished performer with over twenty years of experience.
10. He has performed internationally to “standing room only crowds” and in intimate settings in Venezuela, Dominican Republic, San Diego (CA), Miami, Orlando, Gainesville and Tampa (FL), Denver and Fort Collins (CO), San Juan (PR), Madrid (Spain), Bonn and Stuttgart (Germany), Brussels (Belgium), The Hague (Netherlands), Paris (France), London (England), Zurich and Berna (Switzerland).
11. Since 2009 he lives currently in Orlando, Florida State.

1. She died while covering the siege of Homs in Syria.
2. After her death, Stony Brook University established the Marie Colvin Center for International Reporting in her honor.
3. Her family also established the Marie Colvin Memorial Fund through the Long Island Community Foundation, which strives to give donations in Marie's name in honor of her humanitarianism.
4. In July 2016, lawyers representing Colvin's family filed a civil action against the government of the Syrian Arab Republic claiming they had obtained proof that the Syrian government had directly ordered her assassination, leading to a judge finding the Syrian government guilty of her assassination in early 2019, awarding Colvin's family $302 million in damages.

chunks.title: Namie Amuro
chunks.chunk:
Title: Namie Amuro
0. Born in Naha, Okinawa, Japan, Amuro debuted as the lead singer of the idol group Super Monkey's when she was 14 years old.
1. Despite early sales disappointments, she ventured into modeling and acting, attracting domestic attention with the group's best-selling single
2. "Try Me (Watashi o Shinjite)".
3. She signed to Avex Trax in 1995 and debuted as a solo artist with the single "Body Feels Exit".
4. Her 1996 studio album, "Sweet 19 Blues," sold over 3 million copies, setting the record at the time for the biggest selling album by a female artist in Japan and the highest selling album debut in the world (currently ranked #15 in the world's largest first week album sales).
5. One of the singles from her album "Concentration 20" (1997), "Can You Celebrate?", is the best-selling single by a solo female artist in Japanese music history.
6. From 1999, Amuro partnered with international musicians and producers on her records, beginning with "Genius 2000" (2000).
7. In the early 2000s, Amuro's music evolved from pop to R&B, and Amuro saw a decline in sales.
8. "Play" (2007), her eighth studio album, heralded a period of commercial resurgence.
9. She continued to experiment musically, moving to electronic dance music and English language songs with follow-up records "Uncontrolled" (2012) and "Feel" (2013).
10. She subsequently released her eleventh studio album, "Genic" (2015) and a compilation album, "Finally" (2017).
11. Amuro is noted within the Japanese entertainment industry, and the wider Western music industry, for "producing" and managing her own career.
12. Aside from music, she has appeared in various advertisement campaigns in Japan and founded her own management company, Stella88, and her own record label, Dimension Point.
13. Having sold more than 36 million records in Japan, Amuro is recognized as one of the best-selling artists in Japan by Oricon.
14. Since her solo debut, she has top 10 singles for 23 consecutive years (#1 for solo artist).
15. All of her albums are at least certified Platinum, and her debut solo album, "Sweet 19 Blues", was the best selling album in Japan.
16. She is the only artist in Japan selling million albums in her teens, 20s, 30s and 40s.
17. Furthermore, her last album, "Finally", topped the Year-End album charts of both Oricon and Billboard Japan for two consecutive years (The first and only artist in the Japanese Music Industry to do so).
18. Amuro has frequently been noted for her live performances at music award ceremonies and she is the recipient of World Music Awards, Japan Record Awards, Japan Gold Disc Awards, and MTV Video Music Awards Japan among many others.
19. On September 16, 2018, Amuro officially retired from the music and entertainment business.

chunks.title: List of The Dillinger Escape Plan band members
chunks.chunk:
Title: List of The Dillinger Escape Plan band members
0. The Dillinger Escape Plan is an American mathcore band from Morris Plains, New Jersey.
1. Formed in 1997, the group originally featured vocalist Dimitri Minakakis, lead guitarist Ben Weinman, rhythm guitarist Derek Brantley, bassist Adam Doll and drummer Chris Pennie, although Brantley left after only two shows.
2. The remaining four members recorded the band's self-titled debut EP in 1997, before John Fulton replaced Brantley for the subsequent tour and 1998's "Under the Running Board".
3. Shortly after the second EP's release, Fulton left the band due to "creative differences", and in early 1999 Doll was forced to cease involvement due to a spinal injury suffered in a road traffic accident.
4. As a result, Weinman performed all guitars and bass on the band's full-length debut album "Calculating Infinity", released in 1999.
5. Following the release of "Calculating Infinity", Brian Benoit replaced Fulton and Jeff Wood took Doll's place; Wood left the band in 2000 due to the ongoing effects of a gunshot wound to the head sustained in 1992, and was replaced by Liam Wilson.
6. In April 2001, it was announced that Minakakis had decided to leave The Dillinger Escape Plan to pursue "non-music related endeavors", with the band briefly placed on hiatus.
7. The vocalist was replaced later in the year by Greg Puciato, who was chosen from "over one hundred" singers who auditioned by submitting a recording of "43% Burnt" to the band.
8. In between the departure of Minakakis and the addition of Puciato, the band recorded the EP
9. "Irony Is a Dead Scene" with Faith No More and
10. Mr. Bungle vocalist Mike Patton, which was released in 2002.
11. In 2004, the band released its first album with Puciato on vocals, "Miss Machine".
12. Later in the year, Benoit suffered nerve damage in his left hand which affected his ability to play guitar; after attempting to continue, he was forced to leave the band in April 2005 and was replaced by James Love.
13. During a tour in 2006, tensions arose between Weinman and Pennie, with the guitarist briefly leaving the band citing "undisclosed personal reasons".
14. Pennie eventually left the band in 2007 to join Coheed and Cambria, with Gil Sharone replacing him for the band's third album "Ire Works".
15. Also in 2007, guitarist Jeff Tuttle was added to the band due to Love's unavailability.
16. By the beginning of 2009, Sharone had left the band and been replaced by Billy Rymer. "
17. Option Paralysis" was released in 2010, which marked Tuttle's first contribution to the band (he performed additional vocals, with Weinman recording all guitars).
18. The guitarist later left the band in August 2012 to attend film school.
19. Love rejoined the band as Tuttle's replacement, although was not featured on the 2013 album "
20. One of Us Is the Killer".
21. After a brief hiatus, Love was replaced by Kevin Antreassian in 2015.
22. The band released "Dissociation" in 2016, which was presented as the group's final album before embarking on an indefinite hiatus the following year.
23. In the liner notes of "Dissociation" the band listed everyone who was a member or a part of the band in some other way or another.
24. The list states "
25. The Dillinger Escape Plan is: Billy Rymer, Greg Puciato, Liam Wilson, Benjamin Weinman, Kevin Antreassian, Dimitri Minakakis, Adam Doll, Brian Benoit, Chris Pennie, Tom Apostolopoulos, Jeff Wood, John Fulton, Jeff Tuttle, Mike Patton, Thomas Bouaziz, Kevin Hilliard, Gil Sharone, James Love, Jessica Curreri, Steve Evetts, Talmadge Cook, Ryan Downey, Jeff Geisser, Brian Montouri, Paul D'Elia, Chris Tropea, Asian Steve, Timothy Connors, Matt Rosenblum, Reid Ferris, Marc Schapiro, And all the other fearless soldiers who have graced the stage with us over the past 20 years."

0. Anthony David Weiner (born September 4, 1964) is an American former Democratic congressman, convicted felon who represented from January 1999 until June 2011.

2. Weiner resigned from Congress in June 2011 after an incident in which a sexually suggestive photo that he sent to a woman via Twitter was captured and publicized.
3. On May 19, 2017, Weiner pleaded guilty to another, unrelated sexting charge of transferring obscene material to a minor, and was sentenced to 21 months in prison, ordered to pay a $10,000 fine, and was required to permanently register as a sex offender.
4. Weiner began serving his federal prison sentence in November 2017.
5. He was released from prison in February 2019, and released from halfway house custody in May 2019.

7. He was a member of the New York City Council from 1992 to 1998 and a congressional aide to U.S. Representative Chuck Schumer from 1985 to 1991.

chunks.title: Place of birth
chunks.chunk:
Title: Place of birth
0. The place of birth( POB) or birthplace is the place where a person was born.
1. This place is often used in legal documents, together with name and date of birth, to uniquely identify a person.
2. As a general rule with respect to passports, the place of birth is determined to be the country that currently has" sovereignty" over the actual place of birth, regardless of when the birth actually occurred.
3. The place of birth is not necessarily the place where the parents of the new baby live.
4. If the baby is born in a hospital in another place, that place is the place of birth.
5. In many countries, this also means that the government requires that the birth of the new baby is registered in the place of birth.
6. Some countries place less or no importance on the place of birth, instead using alternative geographical characteristics for the purpose of identity documents.
7. For example, Sweden has used the concept of" födelsehemortdomicile of birth") since 1947.
8. This means that the domicile of the baby's mother is the registered place of birth.
9. The location of the maternity ward or other physical birthplace is considered unimportant.
10. Similarly, Switzerland uses the concept of" Heimatortlieu d'origineluogo d'origineplace of origin" in German, French and Italian respectively).
11. A child born to Swiss parents is automatically assigned the place of origin of the parent with the same last name, so the child either gets their mother's or father's place of origin.
12. A child born to one Swiss parent and one foreign parent acquires the place of origin of their Swiss parent.
13. In a Swiss passport and identity card, the holder's place of origin is stated, not their place of birth.
14. In some countries( primarily in the Americas), the place of birth automatically determines the nationality of the baby, a practice often referred to by the Latin phrase" jus soli".
15. Almost all countries outside the Americas instead attribute nationality based on the nationality( ies) of the baby's parents( referred to as" jus sanguinis").
16. There can be some confusion regarding the place of birth if the birth takes place in an unusual way: when babies are born on an airplane or at sea, difficulties can arise.
17. The place of birth of such a person depends on the law of the countries involved, which include the nationality of the plane or ship, the nationality( ies) of the parents and/ or the location of the plane or ship( if the birth occurs in the territorial waters or airspace of a country).
18. Some administrative forms may request the applicant's" country of birth".
19. It is important to determine from the requester whether the information requested refers to the applicant's" place of birth" or" nationality at birth".
20. For US citizens born abroad who under the US Constitution acquire US citizenship at the time of birth, the nationality at birth will be USA( American), while the place of birth would be the country in which the actual birth takes place.

0. Caterina Sforza (1463 – 28 May 1509) was an Italian noblewoman along with the Countess of Forlì and Lady of Imola, firstly with her husband Girolamo Riario, and after his death as a regent of her son Ottaviano.
1. Caterina was the illegitimate daughter of Galeazzo Maria Sforza, Duke of Milan and Lucrezia, the wife of the courtier Gian Piero Landriani, a close friend of the Duke.
2. She was raised in the refined Milanese court.
3. The descendant of a dynasty of noted condottieri, from an early age, Caterina distinguished herself through her bold and impetuous actions taken to safeguard her possessions from possible usurpers and to defend her dominions from attack, when they were involved in political intrigues.
4. In her private life Caterina was devoted to various activities, including experiments in alchemy and a love of hunting and dancing.
5. She had many children, but
6. only the youngest, Captain Giovanni dalle Bande Nere, inherited his mother's forceful, militant personality.
7. Caterina's resistance to Cesare Borgia meant she had to face his fury and imprisonment.
8. Once she gained her freedom in Rome, she led a quiet life in Florence.
9. In the final years of her life, she confided to a monk: "Se io potessi scrivere tutto, farei stupire
10. il mondoIf
11. I could write everything that happened, I would shock the world").

chunks.title: Gustaf Molander
chunks.chunk:
Title: Gustaf Molander
0. Gustaf Harald August Molander (18 November 1888 – 19 June 1973) was a Swedish actor and film director.
1. His parents were director Harald Molander, Sr.
2. (1858–1900) and singer and actress Lydia Molander, "née" Wessler, and his brother was director Olof Molander (1892–1966).
3. He was the father of director and producer Harald Molander from his first marriage to actress Karin Molander and father to actor Jan Molander from his second marriage to Elsa Fahlberg (1892-1977).
4. Gustaf Molander was born in Helsingfors (now Helsinki) in the Grand Duchy of Finland (in the Russian Empire), where his father was working at the Swedish Theatre.
5. He studied in the school of the Royal Dramatic Theatre in Stockholm 1907–1909, acted at the Swedish theatre in Helsingfors 1909–1913, and then at the Royal Dramatic Theatre from 1913–1926.
6. The last years there he headed the school; his students included Greta Garbo.
7. Molander wrote several screenplays for Victor Sjöström and Mauritz Stiller, and was helped by the latter to get employment as a director for Svensk Filmindustri, where he worked 1923–1956.
8. All in all, he directed sixty-two films.
9. He often worked with Gösta Ekman, and his films include "Intermezzo" (1936), which became Ingrid Bergman's breakthrough and paved her way to America, where she starred in the 1939 Hollywood remake of the film.

chunks.title: Stephen Van Rensselaer
chunks.chunk:
Title: Stephen Van Rensselaer
0. Stephen Van Rensselaer III( November 1, 1764 January 26, 1839) was a New York landowner, businessman, militia officer, and politician.
1. A graduate of Harvard University, at age 21, Van Rensselaer took control of Rensselaerswyck, his family's manor.
2. He developed the land by encouraging tenants to settle it, and granting them perpetual leases at moderate rates, which enabled the tenants to use more of their capital to make their farms and businesses productive.
3. Active in politics as a Federalist, Van Rensselaer served in the New York State Assembly and New York State Senate, and as Lieutenant Governor of New York.
4. After the demise of the Federalist Party, Van Rensselaer was a John Quincy Adams supporter, and served in the United States House of Representatives for one partial term and three full ones.
5. Van Rensselaer was a supporter of higher education; he served on the board of trustees for several schools and colleges, and was the founder of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.
6. He was also a civic activist and philanthropist, and was a founder of Albany's public library and the city's Institute of History& Arts.
7. Long active in the militia, Van Rensselaer attained the rank of major general; he commanded troops on the New York- Canada border during the War of 1812, but resigned his commission after defeat at the Battle of Queenston Heights.
8. After Van Rensselaer's 1839 death, efforts by his sons to collect past due lease payments led to the Anti-Rent War, and the break up and sale of the manor.
9. As the heir to and then owner of one of the largest estates in New York, Van Rensselaer's holdings made him the tenth richest American of all time, based on the ratio of his fortune to contemporary GDP.

chunks.title: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Kiliaen van Rensselaer (merchant)
0. Kiliaen van Rensselaer (1586 – buried 7 October 1643) was a Dutch diamond and pearl merchant from Amsterdam who was one of the founders and directors of the Dutch West India Company, being instrumental in the establishment of New Netherland.
1. He was one of the first patroons, but the only one to become successful.
2. He founded the Manor of Rensselaerswyck in what is now mainly New York's Capital District.
3. His estate remained throughout the Dutch and British colonial era and the American Revolution as a legal entity until the 1840s.
4. Eventually, that came to an end during the Anti-Rent War.
5. Van Rensselaer was the son of Hendrick Kiliaensz van Rensselaer, a soldier from Nijkerk in the "States army of the duke of Upper Saxony", and Maria Pafraet, descendant of a well-known printers' dynasty.
6. To keep from risking his life in the army like his father, he apprenticed under his uncle, a successful Amsterdam jeweler.
7. He too became a successful jeweler and was one of the first subscribers to the Dutch West India Company upon its conception.
8. The concept of patroonships may have been Kiliaen van Rensselaer's; he
was likely the leading proponent of the Charter of Freedoms and Exemptions, the document that established the patroon system.
9. His patroonship became the most successful to exist, making full use of his business tactics and advantages, such as his connection to the Director of New Netherland, his confidantes at the West India Company, and his extended family members who were eager to emigrate to a better place to farm.
10. Van Rensselaer married twice and had at least eleven children.
11. When he died sometime after 1642, two succeeded him as patroons of Rensselaerswyck.
12. Van Rensselaer had a marked effect on the history of the United States.
13. The American Van Rensselaers all descend from Kiliaen's son Jeremias and the subsequent Van Rensselaer family is noted for being a very powerful and wealthy influence in the history of New York and the Northeastern United States, producing multiple State Legislators, Congressmen, and two Lieutenant Governors in New York.

chunks.title: Round table (discussion)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Round table (discussion)
0. Round table is a form of academic discussion.
1. Participants agree on a specific topic to discuss and debate.
2. Each person is given equal right to participate, as illustrated by the idea of a circular layout referred to in the term round table.
3. Round- table discussions, together with houses of hospitality and agronomic universities, is one of the key elements of the Catholic Worker Movement, as formulated by Peter Maurin, one of the co-founders of the movement.
4. Round table discussions are also a common feature of political talk shows.
5. Talk shows such as" Washington Week" and" Meet the Press" have roundtables of reporters or pundits.
6. Most of these are done around a table in a studio, but occasionally they report in split- screen from remote locations.
7. Some sports shows, such as ESPN's" Around the Horn", employ the round table format.
8. The round table method is still highly used to this day.

chunks.title: Round table (furniture)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Round table (furniture)
0. A round table is a table which has no" head" and no" sides", and therefore no one person sitting at it is given a privileged position and all are treated as equals.
1. The idea stems from the Arthurian legend about the Knights of the Round Table in Camelot.
2. Today, round tables are often used at conferences involving many parties.
3. The most famous modern round table was the one used for talks between the Communist government and Solidarity in Poland in 1989; see: Polish Round Table Agreement.
4. Hence, the term" round table" is also used figuratively to refer to a peaceful way of achieving a compromise solution.

chunks.title: East German Round Table
chunks.chunk:
Title: East German Round Table
0. Round table primarily refers to the Central Round Table(" Zentraler Runder Tisch"), a series of meetings during the Peaceful Revolution in East Germany in late- 1989 and early- 1990.
1. The Round table first convened in East Berlin on 7 December 1989, the day after Egon Krenz had resigned as the head of the Socialist Unity Party( SED) government.
2. This Round Table, modeled after the Polish Round Table convened in April 1989, was initiated by the group Democracy Now.
3. " Round table" was to be understood in a methaphoric sense, meaning that the participants were on a par with each other.
4. Physically, the table was rectangular( unlike the Polish model which was literally round).
5. It was set up as a forum in which members of East German government- aligned organizations( such as the so- called bloc parties, trade unions, etc.) came together with representatives of the new citizens ’ movements( such as Democracy Now, Democratic Awakening, and New Forum) to discuss and advance reforms in the German Democratic Republic( East Germany), advising the executive until free elections could be held.
6. There were 39 representatives at the Central Round Table, 33 of whom were entitled to vote.
7. Seventeen of them represented new oppositional groups and political parties, and sixteen were from political parties and organizations that had been part of the communist- dominated East German government.
8. Three, representing women, consumers and environmentalists, had observer status.
9. The final three members were the moderators, all clergymen, from the Protestant, Catholic and Methodist churches, who did not have a vote.
10. At first most participants hoped to reform the East German government and thus retain the country ’s independence, but as popular opinion moved towards rapid unification with West Germany, these hopes were dashed.
11. The Round Table's first three meetings, held on 7, 18 and 22 December 1989, took place in the Protestant church's Bonhoeffer House near Friedrichstraße in Berlin- Mitte.
12. Because popular interest created a need for more space, from the fourth meeting on 27 December to the sixteenth and final meeting on 12 March 1990, the Round Table met in the conference building of the SED- dominated Council of Ministers in Ossietzky St. near Schönhausen Palace in Berlin- Pankow.
13. During the first meeting the Round Table decided to dissolve the" Office for National Security"( the organization that succeeded the Stasi), to hold free elections for the East German Parliament(" Volkskammer") on 6 May 1990( in January the election was preponed to 18 March 1990), and to draft a new constitution, a project that was completed by a subcommittee and presented on 4 April 1990, but never discussed by the newly elected" Volkskammer".
14. Modeled after this Central Round Table, many local round tables were set up in cities and towns across East Germany.
15. In general they continued to exist until the May 6, 1990 local elections constituted new local governments.

2. He was also a prominent environmental activist.
3. Matthiessen's nonfiction featured nature and travel, notably "The Snow Leopard" (1978) and American Indian issues and history, such as a detailed and controversial study of the Leonard Peltier case, "
4. In the Spirit of Crazy Horse" (1983).
5. His fiction was adapted for film: the early story "Travelin' Man" was made into "The Young One" (1960) by Luis Buñuel and the novel "At Play in the Fields of the Lord" (1965) into the 1991 film of the same name.
6. In 2008, at age 81, Matthiessen received the National Book Award for Fiction for "Shadow Country", a one-volume, 890-page revision of his three novels set in frontier Florida that had been published in the 1990s.
7. According to critic Michael Dirda, "No one writes more lyrically [than Matthiessen] about animals or describes more movingly the spiritual experience of mountaintops, savannas, and the sea."
8. Matthiessen was treated for acute leukemia for more than a year.
9. He died on April 5, 2014, three days before publication of his final book, the novel "In Paradise" on April 8.
