1. He was a son of the Frankish statesman Pepin of Herstal and Pepin's mistress, a noblewoman named Alpaida.
2. Charles successfully asserted his claims to power as successor to his father as the power behind the throne in Frankish politics.
3. Continuing and building on his father's work, he restored centralized government in Francia and began the series of military campaigns that re-established the Franks as the undisputed masters of all Gaul.
4. According to a near-contemporary source, the "Liber Historiae Francorum", Charles was "a warrior who was uncommonly  effective in battle".
5. Much attention has been paid to his success in defeating an Arab invasion in Aquitaine at the Battle of Tours.
6. Alongside his military endeavours, Charles has been traditionally credited with a seminal role in the development of the Frankish system of feudalism.
7. At the end of his reign, Charles divided Francia between his sons, Carloman and Pepin.
8. The latter became the first king of the Carolingian dynasty.
9. Charles' grandson, Charlemagne, extended the Frankish realms, and became the first emperor in the West since the fall of Rome.

chunks.title: The Thirty Nine Steps (1978 film)

Title: The Thirty Nine Steps (1978 film)
0. The Thirty Nine Steps is a British 1978 thriller film directed by Don Sharp, with screenplay by British playwright Michael Robson, based on the novel" The Thirty- Nine Steps" by John Buchan.
1. It was the third film version of the 1915 novel.
2. This version of Buchan's tale starred Robert Powell as Richard Hannay, Karen Dotrice as Alex, John Mills as Colonel Scudder, and a host of other well- known British actors in smaller parts.
3. It is generally regarded as the closest to the novel, being set before the Great War.
4. The early events and overall feel of the film bear much resemblance to Buchan's original story, albeit with a few changes such as the re-casting of Scudder as a more immediately sympathetic character and the introduction of a love interest.
5. It also introduces a different meaning for the" thirty- nine steps", although unlike its filmed predecessors it returns to Buchan's original notion of being an actual staircase.
6. It is known for the Big Ben sequence near the end, inspired by the film" My Learned Friend"( 1943), starring Will Hay, although this is its most fundamental deviation from Buchan's original story, which reaches its culmination in a coastal location in Kent.
7. Powell later reprised the role in the ITV series" Hannay" which ran for 13 episodes from 1988 to 1989.

chunks.title: Takhir Sabirov
chunks.chunk:
Title: Takhir Sabirov
0. Takhir Sabirov( December 21, 1929 – May 30, 2002) is a Tajik film director, actor, screenwriter, art director, and one of the most notable figures of the Tajik cinema.
1. He is known as the" founding father" of the" One Thousand and One Nights" dynasty of the film industry due to his creation of the' Scheherazade' trilogy.
2. He is also known by his formal name Takhir Mukhtorovich Sabirov.
3. His mother" Mastona Sobir Zoda" was the daughter of Duke" Sobir- kaloni Tura-zoda" of Samarkand( now part of the Samarqand Province, Uzbekistan), from the Duchy of Greater Khorasan, known as" Tura- zoda", who were eminent members of Central Asia's Aristocracy.
4. Takhir was the youngest of five children.
5. He was married twice and has two sons and three daughters.
6. He completed the Performing Arts discipline at the Tashkent State Art Institute of Theatrical Arts in Tashkent, Uzbekistan.
7. In 1951, he then continued further by obtaining his Directorial discipline under faculty of Yuri Zavadsky at The Russian Academy of Theatre Arts( GITIS) in Moscow, Russia.
8. His first film," Roh"( 1955)
9. ( Russian title:" Дорога") produced by Mosfilm initiated him into the film industry, but the role of" Yodgor" in" Dokhunda"( 1956) sparked his career and was followed by several successful roles.
10. His directorial debut was in" Vaqti zangirii pisar rasid"( Russian title:" Sinu para jinitsa", 1959), which was the first comedy musical motion picture in the Cinema of Tajikistan.
11. With his films he introduced the Tajik film industry onto international scenebasis with his nomination in International film festivals.
12. His film" Margi Sudkhur"( Russian title:" Smert' Rostovshika", 1966) was nominated at the International Film Festival of Asia and Africa in 1968.
13. His trilogy of" New Tales of ScheherazadeAnother Night of Scheherazade" and" The Last Night of Scheherazade" that were based on the Arabic folktale" One Thousand and One Nights" had made a great impact in the Cinema of Tajikistan by opening it to European audiences and borders.
14. The Scheherazade trilogies were among one of the first Tajik film productions that achieved distribution beyond Russian( former USSR) borders, placing Tajik film on the map of International Film Festivals.
15. Not only has he directed and co-written the Scheherazade trilogies, but also starred as King Shahryar( Sultan); which coincidentally is more true to his own lineage of royalty.
16. He became a cultural icon gaining more acknowledgement and respect.
17. Regardless of the obstacles he had faced in his lifetime, he never stopped filming.
18. He is known in the Tajik film industry as one of the major film directors of his time.
19. He broadened his entertainment field as he established entrepreneurial joint venture" Movarounnahr Joint Venture" as an Art Director.
20. Although he was involved in many fields of the film industry, he always had time to instruct and inspire students and apprentices.
21. In 1999, he was part of the judging committee in the 21st( XXI) Moscow International Film Festival.
22. He became the first Tajik film director to be honored with the position of a film judge.
23. In 2002, he was an honorary guest at the 55th( LV) Cannes Film Festival.
24. Even in his seventy years of age he was involved in film production.
25. However, on May 30, 2002 he died with his film" Khoja Kamoli Khujandi" still in production.
26. In 2003, a street," Takhir Sabirov Street" was named after his death for his contributions in the Cinema of Tajikistan( Tajikfilm, Tajik Film Studio).

1. Bank was cast in fifty episodes of" Leave It to Beaver" between January 24, 1958, until the series finale on May 30, 1963.
2. Thereafter, he was cast as Clarence Rutherford in 101 episodes of the series sequel," The New Leave It to Beaver", which aired on cable television from 1985 to 1989.
3. Beginning in 1973, Bank became a bond broker in his native Los Angeles.
4. His autobiography," Call Me Lumpy: My Leave It To Beaver Days and Other Wild Hollywood Life," was published in 1997.
5. Bank died of cancer on April 13, 2013, in Rancho Mirage, California, one day after his 71st birthday.
6. He was survived by his third wife, Rebecca, four daughters, and five grandchildren.
7. He is interred at Hillside Memorial Park Cemetery in Culver City, California.

0. Henry II( 1103 – 1123) was the Margrave of Meissen and the Saxon Ostmark( as" Lusizensis marchio": margrave of Lusatia) from his birth until his death.
1. He was the posthumous son of Margrave Henry I and Gertrude of Brunswick, daughter of Egbert I of Meissen.
2. He was by inheritance also Count of Eilenburg.
3. He was the second Meissener margrave of the House of Wettin.
4. He was initially under the regency of his great uncle Thimo.
5. He died young and without children in 1123.
6. His lands were inherited by his half- sister Richenza of Northeim.
7. He left a widow, Adelaide, daughter of Lothair Udo III, Margrave of the Nordmark.
8. The succession to the marches was disputed after his death.

chunks.title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
chunks.chunk:
Title: Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
0. Odo( or Hodo) I( also" Huodo" or" Huoto")( c. 930 – 13 March 993) was margrave in the Saxon Eastern March of the Holy Roman Empire from 965 until his death.
1. Odo was, if the onomastics are correct, a son( or maybe a nephew) of Christian( d. 950), a Saxon count in the Nordthüringgau and Schwabengau of Eastphalia.
2. Count Christian, probably a scion of the Billung dynasty, had married Hidda( d. 970), a sister of Gero, margrave of the vast" marca Geronis" in the lands settled by Polabian Slavs.
3. From 945 he also ruled over the adjacent gau of Serimunt beyond the Saale river.
4. In 965, Margrave Gero died and his great" marca Geronis" was divided into five smaller marches.
5. Count Thietmar, a known son of Hidda, and Odo inherited large parts of his march:
6. Odo received the so- called" marca Orientalis" or Eastern March, stretching from the Gau Serimunt in the west up to the remotest outposts on the Bóbr river in the east, while Thietmar appeared as margrave of southern Meissen after 970.
7. Both are buried at Nienburg Abbey, a foundation of Thietmar and his brother Archbishop Gero of Cologne, which too provides evidence of their probable relationship.
8. As a young man, Margrave Odo had shared the tutorship of Otto's son( later Otto II) with the boy's step- uncle William, Archbishop of Mainz.
9. Archbishop William taught literature and culture; Margrave Odo taught war and legal customs.
10. Odo spent the first years of his rule subduing the Slavic tribes settling in the eastern parts of the Saxon Ostmark.
11. He held comital rights in the gau of Nizizi, comprising the lands between the Mulde, Elbe and Black Elster rivers, and appeared with the title" marchio"( margrave) only in 974, though he had held further marcher territories( officially as a county) since 965.
12. In that same year( 974), Odo was made Count in the Saxon Nordthüringgau, still rivalling with Margrave Thietmar.
13. Odo is chiefly known for his quarrels with the Polish duke Mieszko I.
14. The West Slavic Polans had established a state east of the Saxon marches and, aiming to advance into the Pomeranian lands north of the Warta river, had reached an agreement with late Margrave Gero and Emperor Otto I: Mieszko's ducal title was confirmed and the Polans paid a recurring tribute to the emperor, which was collected by Margrave Odo.
15. The medieval chronicler Thietmar of Merseburg, apparently quite gladly, relates that Odo's reputation with Mieszko was such that the duke of Poland" would not have dared while wearing his fur coat to enter a house where he knew the margrave to be, or to remain seated when the margrave stood up."
16. When in 972 the Polans again marched for the Baltic trade centre of Wolin, they entered into open conflict with Odo.
17. The margrave, intending to compel Mieszko to pay tribute for the Pomeranian territory between the Oder and Warta rivers, invaded that region.
18. Aged Emperor
19. Otto, engaged in the marriage of his son
20. Otto II with Princess Theophanu at far- off
21. Rome, ordered them to cease until he himself could arbitrate their dispute.
22. However, Odo attacked Mieszko's forces and was defeated on 24 June at the Battle of Cedynia.
23. The belligerents reconciled at the Imperial Diet in Quedlinburg one year later.
24. In 983, Odo took part in the attempts to suppress the Great Slav Rising of the Polabian Lutici tribes, but was not able to prevent the loss of the Saxon Northern March.
25. He also failed to succeed Thietmar in the Margraviate of Meissen in 979.
26. Odo left a son, Siegfried( d. 1030), who became a monk at Nienburg, but left the monastery on his father's death to claim his inheritance.
27. He did however not prevail against Thietmar's son Gero II, who became Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark in 993.
28. Siegfried again appeared as a count from 1015, when he claimed the Saxon Ostmark from Gero's son Thietmar IV and allied with Duke Mieszko II of Poland in the German- Polish War.
29. Thietmar IV prevailed with the support by Emperor Henry II, but lost the eastern parts of his march to Mieszko II in the 1018 Peace of Bautzen.

Title: Gero II, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark
0. Gero II (c. 975 – 1 September 1015 at Krosno Odrzańskie) was the eldest son of Thietmar, Margrave of Meissen, and Schwanehilde (Suanhild), daughter of Herman, Duke of Saxony.
1. He was therefore probably a grandson of Hidda and Christian of Thuringia and named for his great uncle Gero the Great.
2. He succeeded his probable uncle, Hodo, as Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark including Mark Lausitz (Lusatia) in 993 upon the death of margrave of Lusatia Hodo or Odo I, Margrave of the Saxon Ostmark.
3. Gero was created Count of Hassegau in 992, just a year before becoming margrave.
4. He died in his territory in battle with a Polish army of Boleslaw I in Gau Diadesi and was buried in his family's monastery of Nienburg.
5. He was survived by his wife Adelaide (Athelheidhe) and one son, Thietmar, who succeeded him.

5. Eddy is also the uncle of Jo Planckaert and the father of Francesco Planckaert.
6. After the 2016 Paris-Roubaix, Planckaert declared that second-placed Tom Boonen should have made a deal with eventual winner Matthew Hayman in order to fix the race and let Boonen win.

chunks.chunk:
Title: Owen Lloyd George, 3rd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor

chunks.title: David Lloyd George
chunks.chunk:
Title: David Lloyd George
0. David Lloyd George, 1st Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor, (17 January 1863 – 26 March 1945) was a British statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom between 1916 and 1922.
1. He was the final Liberal to hold the post.
2. Lloyd George was born in Manchester to Welsh parents.
3. His father—a schoolmaster—died in 1864 and he was raised in Wales by his mother and her shoemaker brother, whose Liberal politics and Baptist faith strongly influenced Lloyd George; the same uncle helped the boy embark on a career as a solicitor after leaving school.
4. Lloyd George became active in local politics, gaining a reputation as an orator and a proponent of a Welsh blend of radical Liberalism which championed nonconformism and the disestablishment of the Anglican church in Wales, equality for labourers and tenant farmers, and reform of landownership.
5. In 1890, he narrowly won a by-election to become the Member of Parliament for Caernarvon Boroughs, in which seat he remained for fifty-five years.
6. Lloyd George served in Henry Campbell-Bannerman's cabinet from 1905.
7. After H. H. Asquith succeeded to the premiership in 1908, Lloyd George replaced him as Chancellor of the Exchequer.
8. To fund extensive welfare reforms, he proposed taxes on land ownership and high incomes in the "People's Budget" (1909), which the Conservative-dominated House of Lords rejected.
9. The resulting constitutional crisis was only resolved after two elections in 1910 and the passage of the Parliament Act 1911.
10. His budget was then enacted alongside the National Insurance Act 1911 which helped to establish the modern welfare state.
11. In 1913, he was embroiled in the Marconi scandal but he remained in office and struggled to impose Irish Home Rule until the outbreak of the First World War in 1914 suspended its implementation.
12. As wartime Chancellor, Lloyd George strengthened the country's finances and forged agreements with trade unions to maintain production.
13. In 1915, Asquith formed a Liberal-led wartime coalition with the Conservatives and Labour.
14. Lloyd George became Minister of Munitions and rapidly expanded production.
15. In 1916, he was appointed Secretary of State for War but was frustrated by his limited power and clashes with the military establishment over strategy.
16. Amid stalemate on the Western Front, confidence in Asquith's leadership waned.
17. He was forced to resign in December 1916; Lloyd George succeeded him as Prime Minister, supported by the Conservatives and some Liberals.
18. He centralised authority through a smaller war cabinet, a new Cabinet Office and his "Garden Suburb" of advisers.
19. To combat food shortages he implemented the convoy system, established rationing, and stimulated farming.
20. After supporting the disastrous French Nivelle Offensive in 1917, he had to reluctantly approve Field Marshal Haig's plans for the Battle of Passchendaele which resulted in huge casualities with little strategic benefit.
21. Against the views of his commanders, he was finally able to see the Allies brought under one command in March 1918.
22. The war effort turned to their favour that August and was won in November.
23. In the aftermath, he and the Conservatives maintained their coalition with popular support following the December 1918 "Coupon" election.
24. His government had extended the franchise to all men and some women earlier in the year.
25. Lloyd George was a major player in Paris Peace Conference of 1919 but the situation in Ireland worsened that year, erupting into the Irish War of Independence which lasted until Lloyd George negotiated independence for the Irish Free State in 1921.
26. At home he initiated reforms to education and housing but trade union militancy entered record levels, the economy became depressed in 1920 and unemployment rose; spending cuts followed (1921–22) and he was embroiled in a scandal over the sale of honours and the Chanak Crisis in 1922.
27. Bonar Law won backbench support for the Conservatives to contend the next election alone.
28. Lloyd George resigned; with his party split between his and Asquith's supporters, his faction won less than 60 seats in the 1922 election.
29. The next year the pair reunited to oppose Stanley Baldwin's tariff proposal which he put to the country.
30. The Liberals made gains in 1923 but remained third after the Conservatives and Labour, propping up a Labour minority government; they never regained their status as second party and, when the Labour government fell, went down to just over 40 seats in 1924 under Asquith.
31. Lloyd George led the Liberals from 1926 to 1931, putting forward innovative proposals for public works; this failed to convert into seats in 1929 and from 1931 he was a marginalised and mistrusted figure heading a small rump of breakaway Liberals opposed to the National Government.
32. He declined an offer to serve in Winston Churchill's War Cabinet in 1940 and was raised to the peerage in 1945, shortly before his death.
33. Lloyd George has often been ranked highly among modern British prime ministers, but his legacy remains complicated and controversial.
34. Scholars have praised his welfare reforms and his efforts to mobilise and lead Britain to victory during the First World War, but he has also been criticised for adopting a "presidential" style of leadership, for distrusting his own commanders during the war, and for his strategic failures and involvement in various scandals.
35. His legacies over Ireland and the Treaty of Versailles are also controversial.
36. In the post-war period, he arguably alienated many of the workers he had earlier championed, helping to swell Labour's popular support at the Liberals' expense (not helped by his conflicts with Asquithian Liberals after 1916).

chunks.title: A. J. Sylvester
chunks.chunk:
Title: A. J. Sylvester
0. Albert James Sylvester( 24 November 1889 – 27 October 1989) served as Principal Private Secretary to British statesman David Lloyd George from 1923 until Lloyd George's death in March 1945.
1. A native of Harlaston, Staffordshire, Sylvester served as private secretary to the Secretary to the Committee of Imperial Defence, 1914 – 1921, to the Secretary of the War Cabinet and the Cabinet, 1916 – 1921, to the Secretary of the Imperial War Cabinet, 1917, to the British Secretary of the Paris Peace Conference, 1919, and to three successive Prime Ministers, 1921- 3: Lloyd George, Bonar Law and Stanley Baldwin.
2. He ran Lloyd George's private office in London.
3. After Lloyd George's death, A. J. Sylvester earned his living as a member of Lord Beaverbrook's staff from 1945 until 1948, and spent a further year as unpaid assistant to the Liberal Party leader, Clement Davies.
4. In 1947, he published" The Real Lloyd George", based on his diaries.
5. In 1949, he retired from political life, and moved to a farm at Corsham, Wiltshire, England, where he served as JP.
6. His ambition to publish a full- scale autobiography, upon which he was actively engaged in extreme old age, never came to fruition.
7. His papers provide an insight into the life of Lloyd George after his fall from power in 1922.

chunks.title: Richard Lloyd George, 2nd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor
chunks.chunk:
Title: Richard Lloyd George, 2nd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor
0. Richard Lloyd George, 2nd Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor (15 February 1889 – 1 May 1968) was a British soldier and peer in the peerage of the United Kingdom, a member of the House of Lords from 1945 until his death.
1. The son of the Liberal prime minister David Lloyd George by his first wife, Margaret Owen, Lloyd George was educated at Portmadoc School and Christ's College, Cambridge, graduating BA in 1910.
2. During the First World War he was commissioned into the Royal Engineers and rose to the rank of Major.
3. He became an associate member of the Institution of Civil Engineers and served in the British Army again during the Second World War.
4. On 7 April 1917 Lloyd George married Roberta McAlpine (1898–1966), a daughter of Sir Robert McAlpine, 1st Baronet.
5. They had two children, Valerie Davidia (1918–2000) and Owen (1924–2010), before being divorced in 1933.
6. In 1935 Lloyd George married secondly Winifred Emily Peedle, a daughter of Thomas W. Peedle.
7. Valerie became the wife of the academic and broadcasting executive, Sir Goronwy Daniel.
8. On 1 January 1945 his father was created Earl Lloyd-George of Dwyfor, and he gained the courtesy title of Viscount Gwynedd.
9. Less than three months later, on 26 March 1945, his father died of cancer and he inherited his peerage, unusually becoming the first member of the family to sit in the House of Lords, as David Lloyd George had been too ill to do so.
10. He wrote a biography of his mother, "Dame Margaret", and of his father, "Lloyd George".

chunks.title: Frances Stevenson
chunks.chunk:
Title: Frances Stevenson
0. Frances Lloyd George, Countess Lloyd- George of Dwyfor,( 7 October 1888 – 5 December 1972) was the mistress, personal secretary, confidante and second wife of British Prime Minister David Lloyd George.
1. Frances Louise Stevenson was born in London.
2. She was the daughter of a Lowland Scottish father and a mother of mixed French and Italian extraction.
3. She was educated at Clapham High School, where in the fifth form she had made friends with Mair, Lloyd George's oldest daughter, and then at Royal Holloway College where she studied Classics.
4. In July 1911, Lloyd George, then Chancellor of the Exchequer, hired Stevenson as a governess for his youngest daughter Megan.
5. Lloyd George and Stevenson were soon attracted to each other.
6. Although Stevenson, who wanted a conventional marriage and many children, hesitated about becoming the mistress of a married man, she agreed to become Lloyd George's personal secretary on his terms, which included a sexual relationship, in 1913.
7. She was created a Commander of the Order of the British Empire in the 1918 New Year Honours and accompanied Lloyd George to the Paris Peace Conference of 1919.
8. The delegates were under the impression she was still just his secretary.
9. Stevenson chose the location and supervised the construction of Lloyd George's house Bron- y- de in Churt, Surrey.
10. She also arranged and collated Lloyd George's extensive archive of personal and political papers so that he could write his" War Memoirs".
11. After having had two abortions, Stevenson gave birth to a daughter, Jennifer, in 1929.
12. Stevenson had been having an affair with Thomas Tweed, a novelist and Liberal Party official.
13. Stevenson encouraged Lloyd George to believe the child was his, but it is more likely that her father was Tweed.
14. Two years after Lloyd George's wife Margaret died, Stevenson married Lloyd George on 23 October 1943 despite the disapproval of Lloyd George's children from his first marriage.
15. Less than 18 months later, Lloyd George died on 26 March 1945.
16. As Dowager Countess Lloyd- George of Dwyfor, she lived at Churt for the rest of her life, devoting her time to her family, charitable activities, perpetuating the memory of Lloyd George and writing.
17. Her memoir" The Years That Are Past" was published in 1967, and her diary of her life with Lloyd George was published in 1971.

chunks.title: Boris Nemtsov
chunks.chunk:
Title: Boris Nemtsov
0. Boris Yefimovich Nemtsov (9 October 195927 February 2015) was a Russian physicist and liberal politician.
1. Nemtsov was one of the most important figures in the introduction of capitalism into the Russian post-Soviet economy.
2. He had a successful political career in the 1990s under President Boris Yeltsin.
3. From 2000 until his death, he was an outspoken critic of Vladimir Putin.
4. Nemtsov was assassinated on 27 February 2015, beside his Ukrainian partner Anna Duritskaya, on a bridge near the Kremlin in Moscow, with four shots fired from the back.
5. In the weeks before his death, Nemtsov expressed fear that Putin would have him killed.
6. In late June 2017, five Chechen men were found guilty by a jury in a Moscow court for agreeing to kill Nemtsov in exchange for 15 million rubles (US$253,000); neither the identity nor whereabouts of the person who hired them is known.
7. Nemtsov criticized Putin's government as an increasingly authoritarian, undemocratic regime, highlighting widespread embezzlement and profiteering ahead of the Sochi Olympics, and Russian political interference and military involvement in Ukraine.
8. After 2008, Nemtsov published in-depth reports detailing the corruption under Putin, which he connected directly with the President.
9. As part of the same political struggle, Nemtsov was an active organizer of and participant in Dissenters' Marches, Strategy-31 civil actions and rallies "For Fair Elections".
10. At the time of the assassination, Nemtsov was in Moscow helping to organize a rally against the Russian military intervention in Ukraine and the Russian financial crisis.
11. At the same time, Nemtsov was working on a report demonstrating that Russian troops were fighting alongside pro-Russian rebels in eastern Ukraine, which the Kremlin had been denying, and was unpopular externally but also in Russia.
12. Nemtsov was the first governor of the Nizhny Novgorod Oblast (1991–97).
13. Later he worked in the government of Russia as Minister of Fuel and Energy (1997),
14. Vice Premier of Russia and Security Council member from 1997 to 1998.
15. In 1998, he founded the Young Russia movement.
16. In 1998, he co-founded the coalition group Right Cause and in 1999, he co-formed Union of Right Forces, an electoral bloc and subsequently a political party.
17. Nemtsov was also a member of the Congress of People's Deputies (1990), Federation Council (1993–97) and State Duma (1999–2003).
18. He also served as Vice Speaker of the State Duma and the leader of parliamentary group Union of Right Forces.
19. After a 2008 split in the Union of Right Forces, he co-founded Solidarnost.
20. In 2010, he co-formed the coalition "For Russia without Lawlessness and Corruption", which was refused registration as a party.
21. Beginning in 2012, Nemtsov was co-chair of the Republican Party of Russia – People's Freedom Party (RPR-PARNAS), a registered political party.
22. At the time of his death, Nemtsov was one of the leaders of the Solidarnost ("Solidarity")
23. opposition movement, an elected member of the regional parliament of Yaroslavl Oblast, and co-chair of the RPR-PARNAS, which is a member of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats, a Pan-European political party.
24. After Nemtsov's murder, Serge Schmemann of "The New York Times" paid tribute to him in an article headlined "A Reformer Who Never Backed Down."
25. Schmemann wrote: "Tall, handsome, witty and irreverent, Mr. Nemtsov was one of the brilliant young men who burst onto the Russian stage at that exciting moment when Communist rule collapsed and a new era seemed imminent.
26. "
27. Julia Ioffe of "The New York Times" described Nemtsov after his death as "a powerful, vigorous critic of Vladimir Putin", who was "a deeply intelligent, witty, kind and ubiquitous man" who "seemed to genuinely be everyone's friend".

chunks.title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
chunks.chunk:
Title: PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament
0. The annual PGA Tour Qualifying Tournament, also known as Qualifying School or Q-School, was historically the main method by which golfers earned PGA Tour playing privileges, commonly known as a Tour card.
1. Beginning in 2013, Q-School grants privileges only for the Korn Ferry Tour, the PGA Tour's official developmental circuit.
2. The first tournament was played in 1965.
3. In several early years (1968–69, 1975–81), two separate tournaments were played, one in the spring and one in the fall.
4. The format of the tournament has changed several times, ranging from a 72-hole tournament to a 144-hole tournament.
5. The current format (in place since 1982) is 108 holes over six days in late November and early December.
6. Before 2013, the top 25 players and ties earned their tour cards.
7. The next set of fifty finishers earned full Korn Ferry Tour cards.
8. The remaining participants received conditional Korn Ferry Tour status.
9. The 2012 Qualifying Tournament was the last to grant playing privileges for the PGA Tour.
10. On March 20, 2012, the tour announced radical changes to its season structure and qualifying process, and announced further details on July 10 of that year.
11. The 2013 season ended with The Tour Championship in September, and the 2014 season began the following month.
12. Since then, the Qualifying Tournament only grants playing privileges for the Korn Ferry Tour (known as the Nationwide Tour at the time of the March 2012 announcement).
13. A new series of three tournaments known as the Korn Ferry Tour Finals, held in September, grants 50 PGA Tour cards to a field consisting of the top 75 on the Korn Ferry Tour money list and the golfers placed 126 to 200 on the PGA Tour's FedEx Cup points list.
14. The top 25 on the Korn Ferry Tour money list before the Finals receive PGA Tour cards, with total money earned in the Finals determining the remaining 25 card earners.

chunks.title: WinCo Foods Portland Open
chunks.chunk:
Title: WinCo Foods Portland Open
0. The WinCo Foods Portland Open is a golf tournament on the Korn Ferry Tour.
1. It was first played in August 2014 at Witch Hollow at Pumpkin Ridge in North Plains, Oregon, a suburb of Portland.
2. Northwest-based supermarket chain WinCo Foods was named as the title sponsor in June 2013.
3. Since its inception, the Portland Open has become the last regular season event on the Korn Ferry Tour.
4. The event gives players one last chance to place in the Top 25 on the money list to earn a PGA Tour card or play their way into the top 75 to retain full Korn Ferry Tour privileges and earn a chance at a PGA Tour card via the Korn Ferry Tour Finals.

chunks.title: Korn Ferry Tour Championship
chunks.chunk:
Title: Korn Ferry Tour Championship
0. The Korn Ferry Tour Championship presented by United Leasing & Finance is the year-end golf tournament of the Korn Ferry Tour.
1. It has been played at a variety of courses; starting in 2019 it will be played at Victoria National Golf Club in Newburgh, Indiana as part of a 10 year deal.
2. Since the 2008 edition, the purse has been $1,000,000, with the winner receiving $180,000.
3. The format of the tournament is stroke play at 18 holes for four days, a total of 72 holes.
4. Originally, the field consisted of the top 60 players on the money list, all attempting to be among the 25 to earn PGA Tour cards.
5. Since 2013, it has been part of the Korn Ferry Tour Finals and the field consists of the top 75 players from the Korn Ferry Tour money list and the non-exempt players ranked 126 to 200 on the PGA Tour's money list at the start of the Finals.
6. Beginning in 2013, 50 PGA Tour cards will be awarded after the event.
7. It is considered the flagship event of the Korn Ferry Tour, with twenty OWGR points to the winner, compared to sixteen for other Finals events and fourteen for regular season tournaments.

2. Although Eleanor is often referred to as the Grand Duchess of Tuscany, she predeceased the creation of the Grand Duchy of Tuscany.

chunks.title: Pietro de' Medici
chunks.chunk:
Title: Pietro de' Medici
0. Don Pietro de' Medici( 3 June 1554 – 25 April 1604) was the youngest son of Cosimo I de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany and Eleonora di Toledo.
1. Early in 1571 he went to Rome and in the spring of 1575 he went to Venice.
2. In 1571 he married his first cousin Eleonora di Garzia di Toledo, whom he accused of adultery and strangled with a dog leash in July 1576 at the Villa Medici at Cafaggiolo.
3. He also had her supposed lover Bernardino Antinori imprisoned and killed.
4. At the end of 1577, he went for the first of many stays at the Spanish court.
5. He remained in Spain until the end of 1578.
6. During this visit he gained a reputation as a spendthrift and a rake.
7. He left Tuscany in October 1579 to bring Italian troops to Spain and lead them during the mission to Portugal.
8. He stayed in Lisbon until the end of 1582 when he returned to Spain where his presence is documented in 1583 and 1584.
9. His correspondence proves that he had serious money problems.
10. He came to Italy in July 1584 to ask his brothers to cover his debts, incurring their disapproval for living with a woman with a questionable reputation.
11. The Medici court tried to arrange a marriage for Pietro.
12. In July 1586 he went back to Spain, where he continued to accumulate debts.
13. He came back to Italy in November 1587 after Francesco I de' Medici's death and stayed until September 1589, when he went back to Spain.
14. His marriage to Dona Beatriz de Lara, daughter of Manuel de Menezes, the Portuguese Duke of Vila Real, in 1593 did little to stabilize him economically and emotionally.
15. Pietro continued to see his lover Antonia de Carvajal who gave him five children out of wedlock.
16. He also had an illegitimate son with Maria della Ribera.
17. He kept writing to his brother Ferdinando I de' Medici, asking for a portion of the family fortune to cover his debts.
18. In 1596 he came to Italy to appeal in vain to the Pope to side with him in the controversy.
19. Pietro died, deeply in debt, before turning 50.
20. After his death his illegitimate children were all brought to Florence to be cared for by the Medici.
21. Pietro was buried in the Monasterio de la Santissima Trinidad in Madrid.
22. His corpse was later brought to Florence by Cosimo II de' Medici.

1. (March 1553 – 10 July 1576), more often known as "Leonora" or "Dianora", was the daughter of García Álvarez de Toledo, 4th Marquis of Villafranca, Duke of Fernandina.
2. Leonora was born in Florence, where she was brought up by
3. Cosimo I de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany and his wife Eleanor of Toledo, her aunt and namesake.
4. Betrothed to their son Pietro at the age of 15, she blossomed under the wing of Pietro's older sister, the artistic patron Isabella, into a vivacious and witty beauty.
5. Her marriage, like Isabella's, was not a success, and she followed her mentor's example of taking lovers.
6. For this reason, Pietro had her brought in 1576 to the country retreat of Cafaggiolo, where he strangled her to death with a dog leash.
7. Cosimo's successor, Francesco I, tacitly approved the murder, and Pietro was never brought to justice for it.
8. Until recently, little was known of Leonora di Garzia di Toledo, and she was not identified as the sitter of several portraits of her.
9. The facts of her life have emerged from the growing scholarship on Isabella de' Medici, with whom she has much in common.
10. In the view of art historian Gabrielle Langdon, "Her story is valuable in revealing attitudes and legalities attendant on the lives and decorum of women in the early-modern Italian court".

chunks.title: Éric Rohmer
chunks.chunk:
Title: Éric Rohmer
0. Jean Marie Maurice Schérer or Maurice Henri Joseph Schérer, known as Éric Rohmer (21 March 192011 January 2010), was a French film director, film critic, journalist, novelist, screenwriter, and teacher.
1. Rohmer was the last of the post-World War II French New Wave directors to become established.
2. He edited the influential film journal, "Cahiers du cinéma", from 1957 to 1963, while most of his colleagues—among them Jean-Luc Godard and François Truffaut—were making the transition from film critics to filmmakers and gaining international attention.
3. Rohmer gained international acclaim around 1969 when his film "My Night at Maud's" was nominated at the Academy Awards.
4. He won the San Sebastián International Film Festival with "Claire's Knee" in 1971 and the Golden Lion at the Venice Film Festival for "The Green Ray" in 1986.
5. Rohmer went on to receive the Venice Film Festival's Career Golden Lion in 2001.
6. After Rohmer's death in 2010, his obituary in "The Daily Telegraph" described him as "the most durable filmmaker of the French New Wave", outlasting his peers and "still making movies the public wanted to see" late in his career.

chunks.title: Shear strength (discontinuity)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Shear strength (discontinuity)
0. The shear strength of a discontinuity in a soil or rock mass may have a strong impact on the mechanical behavior of a soil or rock mass.
1. The shear strength of a discontinuity is often considerably lower than the shear strength of the blocks of intact material in between the discontinuities, and therefore influences, for example, tunnel, foundation, or slope engineering, but also the stability of natural slopes.
2. Many slopes, natural and man-made, fail due to a low shear strength of discontinuities in the soil or rock mass in the slope.
3. The deformation characteristics of a soil or rock mass are also influenced by the shear strength of the discontinuities.
4. For example, the modulus of deformation is reduced, and the deformation becomes plastic( i.e. non-reversible deformation on reduction of stress) rather than elastic( i.e. reversible deformation).
5. This may cause, for example, larger settlement of foundations, which is also permanent even if the load is only temporary.
6. Furthermore, the shear strength of discontinuities influences the stress distribution in a soil or rock mass.

0. Mohammed Ahmed Al-Modiahki (born June 1, 1974) is a chess Grandmaster.
1. He was the first player in Qatar to earn the title of grandmaster, and is the country's highest ranked player.
2. He was awarded the trophy of the "Player of the Century within the Arab Countries".
3. Al-Modiahki has participated in nine Chess Olympiads in 1988, 1990, 1992, 1994, 1996, 1998, 2000, 2002 and 2006 with an overall record of (+60,=28,-21).
4. At the 32nd Chess Olympiad in 1996 and he won the gold medal for his individual performance on the first board, scoring 8/10.
5. A performance which he repeated at the 33rd Chess Olympiad in 1998, this time with 7.5/8.
6. In 1994 and 2002, his individual performance earned him the bronze medal.
7. He played four times in the knock out stages of the FIDE World Chess Championships in Las Vegas (1999), New Delhi (2000), Moscow (2002) and Libya 2004.
8. He won the Arab Chess Championship on four occasions: in 1994, 1997, 2000 and 2002 (shared with Hichem Hamdouchi).
9. Other victories include the Agadir Open in Morocco, Andorra Open (1999), the open tournament in Tunis (1997) and shared first places at the Goodricke Open in India (1995) and Benasque Open in Spain (1997).
10. In 2001, he married Grandmaster Zhu Chen, who now also plays for Qatar.
11. In October 2003, he achieved his maximum FIDE rating of 2588.

chunks.title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
chunks.chunk:
Title: Gideon Johnson Pillow
0. Gideon Johnson Pillow (June 8, 1806 – October 8, 1878) was an American lawyer, politician, speculator, slaveowner, United States Army major general of volunteers during the Mexican–American War and Confederate brigadier general in the American Civil War.
1. Before his military career, Pillow practiced law and was active in Democratic Party politics.
2. He was a floor leader in support of the nomination of fellow-Tennessean James K. Polk at the 1844 Democratic National Convention.
3. In 1847, Pillow was commissioned a brigadier general of volunteers to serve in the Mexican–American War, and was later promoted to major general.
4. He performed reasonably well, and was wounded that year at Cerro Gordo and Chapultepec.
5. However, controversy arose when, in a series of letters, Pillow tried to take what was perceived by some as undue credit for American victories at the expense of his commander, Major General Winfield Scott.
6. Pillow was court-martialed for insubordination, but with President Polk's assistance, the court-martial was reduced to a court of inquiry, which in 1848 exonerated Pillow.
7. After the war, Pillow served as a delegate to the Nashville Convention of 1850, where he supported compromise.
8. He remained active in supporting the Democratic Party.
9. At the start of the Civil War in 1861, Pillow supported secession, and was commissioned a brigadier general in the Confederate Army in July.
10. Pillow received the thanks of the Confederate Congress for driving off the Union force at the Battle of Belmont, Missouri.
11. Pillow controversially failed to exploit a temporary break through of Union lines by his troops which might have allowed the Confederate garrison of Fort Donelson to escape at the Battle of Fort Donelson on February 15, 1862.
12. The next night, before the surrender of the fort, Brigadier General John B. Floyd passed overall command of the fort to Pillow, who in turn passed it to Brigadier General Simon Buckner.
13. Floyd and Pillow managed to personally escape with a few aides before Buckner surrendered the remaining garrison to the Union Army of Brigadier General Ulysses S. Grant.
14. These actions sent his military career and reputation into decline.
15. Pillow commanded a brigade at the Battle of Stones River in 1863, where he performed poorly, and was among the few generals in the army to praise the leadership of commanding General Braxton Bragg.
16. Removed from combat duty, he worked mainly in recruiting assignments through the remainder of the war.
17. Bankrupt after the war, Pillow recovered financially and resumed a successful legal career.
18. He died near Helena, Arkansas in 1878; initially buried in Helena, Pillow was later reinterred at Elmwood Cemetery in Memphis.

chunks.title: Holm Jølsen
chunks.chunk:
Title: Holm Jølsen
0. Holm Pedersen Jølsen (6 December 1833 – 1 August 1906) was a Norwegian industrial pioneer and plant owner.
1. He was born near the village Rælingen in Akershus, Norway.
2. In 1859 he took over the family farm Ekeberg in the parish of Enebakk ("Ekeberg gård i Enebakk").
3. In 1866, he established Jølsens Tændstikfabrik, which developed into one of the larger match factory in Norway in the 1870s, with about 300 employees.
4. In 1886, the factory was re-located from Ekebergdalen to Bryn in Aker.
5. In 1887 he established Enebak Cellulosefabrik, which was one of the first pulp mills in Norway.
6. Following a large fire in 1893, Jølsen was bankrupt.
7. Holm Jølsen was married to Pauline Lovise Holmsen (1836–1903).
8. Their daughter Ragnhild Jølsen (1875-1908) was the subject of the book "Drømmen og hjulet" written by Jens Bjørneboe and published in 1964.

chunks.title: Richard N. Palmer
chunks.chunk:
Title: Richard N. Palmer
0. Richard N. Palmer( born May 27, 1950) is an Associate Justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court.
1. Palmer was born in Hartford, Connecticut.
2. Palmer received his Bachelor of Arts Phi Beta Kappa, from Trinity College in Hartford in 1972.
3. He went on to receive the Juris Doctor with high honors from the University of Connecticut School of Law, in 1977.
4. Following law school, Palmer clerked for Judge Jon O. Newman, then of the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut.
5. After practicing privately with Shipman and Goodman, Palmer was as an Assistant United States Attorney in the U.S. Attorney's Office for the District of Connecticut, interrupted briefly by a stint in the firm of Chatigny and Palmer.
6. In 1991, Palmer served as the United States Attorney in Connecticut, and subsequently became Chief State's Attorney for the State of Connecticut.
7. On March 17, 1993, he was sworn in as an Associate Justice of the Connecticut Supreme Court.
8. On October 10, 2008, Palmer wrote the majority opinion for the Connecticut Supreme Court case" Kerrigan v. Commissioner of Public Health", granting marriage rights to same- sex couples in Connecticut, striking down a law passed in 2005 granting civil union rights to them.

question: Which film was released first, The Beginning Or The End or Hold Back The Night?

chunks.title: The Beginning or the End
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Beginning or the End
0. The Beginning or the End is a 1947 American docudrama film about the development of the atomic bomb in World War II, directed by Norman Taurog, starring Brian Donlevy and Hume Cronyn, and released by Metro- Goldwyn- Mayer.
1. The film dramatizes the creation of the atomic bomb in the Manhattan Project and the bombing of Hiroshima.
2. The film originated in October 1945 as a project of actress Donna Reed and her high school science teacher, Edward R. Tompkins, who was a chemist at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory.
3. Bob Considine wrote the treatment, which was sent to MGM script writers.
4. The title was supplied by President Harry S. Truman.
5. At the time there was a legal requirement that permission be obtained to depict living well- known public figures.
6. Many refused, but others, such as J. Robert Oppenheimer, co-operated.
7. Major General Leslie R. Groves, Jr., the director of the Manhattan Project, was hired as a consultant for$ 10,000.
8. Although the filmmakers put considerable effort into historical accuracy, particularly in details, the film is known for some key distortions of history.
9. An entirely fictional sequence was added in which Truman agonizes over whether to authorize the attack; anti-aircraft shells are shown bursting around the" Enola Gay" on its bombing run over Hiroshima; and it is said that leaflets were dropped on Hiroshima for ten days in advance of the mission warning the citizens of the forthcoming raid.
10. The film received generally mixed reviews, and was a box office disappointment.

chunks.title: George I of Greece
chunks.chunk:
Title: George I of Greece
0. George I (Greek:
1. Γεώργιος Α΄, Geórgios I; 24 December 1845 – 18 March 1913) was King of Greece from 1863 until his assassination in 1913.
2. Originally a Danish prince, he was born in Copenhagen, and seemed destined for a career in the Royal Danish Navy.
3. He was only 17 years old when he was elected king by the Greek National Assembly, which had deposed the unpopular former king Otto.
4. His nomination was both suggested and supported by the Great Powers: the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, the Second French Empire and the Russian Empire.
5. He married the Russian grand duchess Olga Constantinovna of Russia in 1867, and became the first monarch of a new Greek dynasty.
6. Two of his sisters, Alexandra and Dagmar, married into the British and Russian royal families.
7. King Edward VII and Tsar Alexander III were his brothers-in-law, and King George V, Tsar Nicholas II, King Christian X of Denmark and King Haakon VII of Norway were his nephews.
8. George's reign of almost 50 years (the longest in modern Greek history) was characterized by territorial gains as Greece established its place in pre-World War
9. I Europe.
10. Britain ceded the Ionian Islands peacefully in 1864, while Thessaly was annexed from the Ottoman Empire after the Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878).
11. Greece was not always successful in its territorial ambitions; it was defeated in the Greco-Turkish War (1897).
12. During the First Balkan War, after Greek troops had captured much of Greek Macedonia, George was assassinated in Thessaloniki.
13. Compared with his own long tenure, the reigns of his successors Constantine, Alexander, and George II proved short and insecure.

2. Lord Bernard was to be created Earl of Lichfield by King Charles I for his actions at the first and second battles of Newbury and Naseby but died of injuries received leading a sortie against besieging Parliamentary forces in the Battle of Rowton Heath in September 1645, before the patent could be implemented.
3. The titles of Baron Newbury and Earl of Lichfield were instead created in December 1645 for his six- year- old nephew, Charles Stewart( 1639 – 1672), the son of Bernard's elder brother George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny, who had been killed at the Battle of Edgehill in 1642.
4. His brother John was also killed in the war.

1. On the death of his father, James Fitz- James Stuart, in 1738, he inherited his titles of Duke of Berwick and Duke of Liria and Xerica( he also possessed many other titles in both Spain and England.)
2. His mother was Spanish, and on her side he was a direct descendant of explorer Christopher Columbus.

chunks.title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
chunks.chunk:
Title: George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny
0. George Stewart (or Stuart), 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny (17 July 1618 – 23 October 1642) was a Scottish nobleman and Royalist commander in the English Civil War.
1. He was the son of Esmé Stewart, 3rd Duke of Lennox, and his wife Katherine Clifton, 2nd Baroness Clifton, and the brother of James Stewart, 1st Duke of Richmond and 4th Duke of Lennox, and of the Royalist commander Lord Bernard Stewart.
2. Stewart, his older brother Henry, and younger brother Ludovic were brought up at Aubigny in France as Roman Catholics under the charge of their paternal grandmother, the old Duchess-Dowager, Katherine de Balsac.
3. Stewart's father, the Duke of Lennox, died in 1624, and Stewart became a ward of his cousin, King Charles I of England.
4. He inherited the Lordship of Aubigny at the age of 14 on the death of his elder brother Henry in 1632.
5. By 1633, he was a student at the Collège de Navarre, part of the University of Paris, and he did homage to Louis XIII of France for the lordship of Aubigny on 5 August 1636, shortly after his eighteenth birthday.
6. Later that year he moved to England.
7. In 1638 he secretly married Katherine Howard, the daughter of Theophilus Howard, 2nd Earl of Suffolk, and Elizabeth Home, without her father's consent, offending his guardian the king.
8. The portrait of Stewart by Anthony van Dyck, now in the National Portrait Gallery, London, may have been painted to mark his marriage; the Latin inscription can be translated
9. "Love is stronger than I am" which may allude to his conflicting loyalties.
10. His younger brothers Lords John and Bernard are shown in a still more famous double Van Dyck portrait in the National Gallery, London - the iconic image of Cavaliers.
11. They were also both killed in the Civil War.
George Stewart and Katherine Howard had two children:
12. He fought with the French against the Spanish in the Battle of Montjuïc (1641).
13. As civil war loomed in England, Stewart joined the forces of King Charles at York where he was knighted on 18 April 1642 along with his brother Bernard.
14. He was mortally wounded in the first pitched battle of the war at Edgehill on Sunday 23 October 1642, aged 24.
15. He was buried in Christ Church Cathedral, Oxford.
16. The lordship of Aubigny passed to his next brother, Ludovic, on his death.
17. His widow remarried James Levingston, 1st Earl of Newburgh and had one further child Elizabeth.
18. They were suspected in 1648 of plotting to rescue Charles I and on the discovery of the supposed plot fled to the Netherlands where Katherine died in 1650.

chunks.title: Charles Lennox, 3rd Duke of Richmond
chunks.chunk:
Title: Charles Lennox, 3rd Duke of Richmond
0. Field Marshal Charles Lennox, 3rd Duke of Richmond, 3rd Duke of Lennox, 3rd Duke of Aubigny,( 22 February 1735 – 29 December 1806), styled Earl of March until 1750, was a British Army officer and politician.
1. He associated with the Rockingham Whigs and rose to hold the post of Southern Secretary for a brief period.
2. He was noteworthy for his support for the colonists during the American Revolutionary War, his support for a policy of concession in Ireland and his advanced views on the issue of parliamentary reform.
3. He went on to be a reforming Master- General of the Ordnance first in the Rockingham ministry and then in the ministry of William Pitt.

2. With his youngest brother, Lord Bernard Stewart, he embarked on a three- year tour of the continent in 1639, before returning to join the King ’s cause in the Civil War as a General.
3. He was killed at the Battle of Cheriton near Alresford, Essex, on 29 March 1644.
4. Only one of his brothers, Lodovic, survived the war to see the restoration of the monarchy in 1660.

chunks.title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
chunks.chunk:
Title: Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond
0. Charles Stewart, 3rd Duke of Richmond, 6th Duke of Lennox KG (7 March 1639December 1672) was the only son of George Stewart, 9th Seigneur d'Aubigny and Katherine Howard, daughter of Theophilus Howard, 2nd Earl of Suffolk.
1. He was the grandson of Esmé Stewart, 3rd Duke of Lennox.
2. On 10 December 1645 he was created Baron Stuart of Newbury, Berkshire, and Earl of Lichfield, titles conferred on him "to perpetuate the titles which were intended to have been conferred on his uncle" Lord Bernard Stewart, youngest son of the Duke of Lennox, who had been killed in the Battle of Rowton Heath in the English Civil War in September of that year.
3. In January 1658, Charles Stewart went into exile in France, and took up his residence in the house of his uncle, Ludovic, seigneur d'Aubigny.
4. In the following year he fell under the displeasure of The Protectorate's Council of State, and warrants were issued for seizing his person and goods.
5. Charles Stewart married, firstly, Elizabeth Rogers, after June 1659.
6. He married, secondly, Margaret Banaster (widow of William Lewis) on 31 March 1662.
7. He married, thirdly, Frances Teresa Stewart, granddaughter of Walter Stewart, 1st Lord Blantyre, in March 1667.
8. This last marriage was famous, as Frances Stewart, known at court as "Le Belle Stuart" had been desired by Richmond's cousin, King Charles II, as a mistress.
9. Charles Stewart returned to England with Charles II in 1660, and sat in the Convention Parliament, showing great animosity towards the supporters of the Commonwealth.
10. On the death of his 10-year-old cousin Esmé Stewart on 10 August 1660, Charles Stewart succeeded as third Duke of Richmond and sixth Duke of Lennox.
11. In that same year he was created Hereditary Great Chamberlain of Scotland, Hereditary Great Admiral of Scotland, and Lord-Lieutenant of Dorset.
12. On 15 April 1661 he was invested with the Order of the Garter.
13. On the death of his uncle, Ludovic Stuart, he succeeded him as 12th Seigneur D'Aubigny, for which title he did homage by proxy to Louis XIV of France on 11 May 1670.
14. In July 1667, on the death of his cousin, Mary Butler, countess of Arran, he became Baron Clifton, and on 4 May 1668 he was made lord lieutenant and vice admiral of Kent jointly with the Earl of Winchilsea.
15. In 1671 he was sent as ambassador to the Danish court to persuade Denmark to join England and France in a projected attack on the Dutch.
16. While there he died (by drowning) in 1672, aged 33 at Elsinore, without issue, and his titles became extinct, with the exception of Baron Clifton, which passed with most of his property to his sister Katherine, Lady O'Brien.
17. His wife, however, had had the Lennox estates granted to her for life.
18. He was buried on 20 September 1673 at Westminster Abbey.
19. The titles Duke of Richmond, Duke of Lennox and Earl of March, were resurrected for Charles II's illegitimate son by Louise de Kérouaille, Charles Lennox, 1st Duke of Richmond and Lennox, in 1675.

4. What is Love?,
5. What is Death?,

8. What is Right?,
9. What is Peace?,

11. What is Dreaming?,
12. What is a Friend?,
13. What is True?,
14. What is a Family?,
15. What is a Feeling?"
16. The series is now also translated into 15 languages.
17. Boritzer was first published in 1963 at the age of 13 when he wrote an essay in his English class at Wade Junior High School in the Bronx, New York on the assassination of John F. Kennedy.
18. His essay was included in a special anthology by New York City public school children compiled and published by the New York City Department of Education.
19. Boritzer now lives in Venice, California and maintains his publishing office there also.
20. He has helped numerous other authors to get published through" How to Get Your Book Published!" programs.
21. Boritzer is also a yoga teacher who teaches regular classes locally and guest- teaches nationally.

chunks.title: Place of birth
chunks.chunk:
Title: Place of birth
0. The place of birth( POB) or birthplace is the place where a person was born.
1. This place is often used in legal documents, together with name and date of birth, to uniquely identify a person.
2. As a general rule with respect to passports, the place of birth is determined to be the country that currently has" sovereignty" over the actual place of birth, regardless of when the birth actually occurred.
3. The place of birth is not necessarily the place where the parents of the new baby live.
4. If the baby is born in a hospital in another place, that place is the place of birth.
5. In many countries, this also means that the government requires that the birth of the new baby is registered in the place of birth.
6. Some countries place less or no importance on the place of birth, instead using alternative geographical characteristics for the purpose of identity documents.
7. For example, Sweden has used the concept of" födelsehemortdomicile of birth") since 1947.
8. This means that the domicile of the baby's mother is the registered place of birth.
9. The location of the maternity ward or other physical birthplace is considered unimportant.
10. Similarly, Switzerland uses the concept of" Heimatortlieu d'origineluogo d'origineplace of origin" in German, French and Italian respectively).
11. A child born to Swiss parents is automatically assigned the place of origin of the parent with the same last name, so the child either gets their mother's or father's place of origin.
12. A child born to one Swiss parent and one foreign parent acquires the place of origin of their Swiss parent.
13. In a Swiss passport and identity card, the holder's place of origin is stated, not their place of birth.
14. In some countries( primarily in the Americas), the place of birth automatically determines the nationality of the baby, a practice often referred to by the Latin phrase" jus soli".
15. Almost all countries outside the Americas instead attribute nationality based on the nationality( ies) of the baby's parents( referred to as" jus sanguinis").
16. There can be some confusion regarding the place of birth if the birth takes place in an unusual way: when babies are born on an airplane or at sea, difficulties can arise.
17. The place of birth of such a person depends on the law of the countries involved, which include the nationality of the plane or ship, the nationality( ies) of the parents and/ or the location of the plane or ship( if the birth occurs in the territorial waters or airspace of a country).
18. Some administrative forms may request the applicant's" country of birth".
19. It is important to determine from the requester whether the information requested refers to the applicant's" place of birth" or" nationality at birth".
20. For US citizens born abroad who under the US Constitution acquire US citizenship at the time of birth, the nationality at birth will be USA( American), while the place of birth would be the country in which the actual birth takes place.

chunks.title: Henry St John, 18th Baron St John of Bletso
chunks.chunk:
Title: Henry St John, 18th Baron St John of Bletso
0. Henry Beauchamp Oliver St John, 18th Baron St John of Bletso DL (24 June 1876 – 17 October 1920) was an English peer.
1. He was the eldest son of Beauchamp St John, 17th Baron St John of Bletso, and his wife Helen Thornton.
2. He was educated at Wellington College and Magdalene College, Cambridge.
3. On 26 July 1901, he was made a Deputy Lieutenant of Bedfordshire.
4. Henry became the 17th Lord St John on the death of his father in 1912, and inherited Melchbourne Park.
5. He was a JP for Bedfordshire and described as Church of England Conservative.
6. He owned about and gave his interests as county pursuits and county business.
7. He died unmarried at the age of 44 and was succeeded by his younger brother, Moubray.

chunks.title: St Andrew St John, 15th Baron St John of Bletso
chunks.chunk:
Title: St Andrew St John, 15th Baron St John of Bletso

chunks.title: John St John, 12th Baron St John of Bletso
chunks.chunk:
Title: John St John, 12th Baron St John of Bletso
0. John St John of Northwood, 12th Baron St John of Bletso( 15 November 1725 – 20 April 1767) was a British peer.
1. St John was the eldest son of John St John, 11th Baron St John of Bletso and his wife Elizabeth Crowley, daughter of Sir Ambrose Crowley of Greenwich.
2. He was educated at Winchester College and at New College, Oxford.
3. He inherited the title of Baron St John of Bletso on the death of his father in 1757.
4. St John died at the age of 41 at Nice but was buried at Bletsoe.
5. St John married Susanne Louise Simond, the daughter of Peter Simond, a wealthy French Huguenot merchant in London.
6. She brought £ 20,000 to the marriage.
7. Their eldest son, John Peter died aged just three and St John was succeeded in the barony successively by his second son Henry and his third son St Andrew.
8. His widow died at Bath, Somerset in 1805 at the age of 80.

chunks.title: Oliver St John, 3rd Baron St John of Bletso
chunks.chunk:
Title: Oliver St John, 3rd Baron St John of Bletso
0. Oliver St John, 3rd Baron St John of Bletso( c. 1540–1618) was an English politician who sat in the House of Commons from 1588 until 1596 when he inherited the peerage as Baron St John of Bletso.
1. St John was a son of Oliver St John, 1st Baron St John of Bletso, and Agnes Fisher.
2. He was High Sheriff of Bedfordshire in 1585.
3. In 1588 he was elected Member of Parliament for Bedfordshire.
4. He was High Sheriff of Bedfordshire again in 1589 and was re-elected MP for Bedfordshire in 1593.
5. He succeeded to the barony on the death of his brother John without male issue on 23 October 1596.
6. He was Lord Lieutenant of Huntingdonshire from April 1597 until his death.
7. St John married Dorothy Reid, daughter of Sir John Rede or Reid, of Odington, Gloucestershire.
8. They had eight sons and seven daughters:
9. His eldest son Oliver inherited the Barony and became Earl of Bolingbroke.
10. Of his remaining sons, John and Dudley died young, while the remaining five all became Members of Parliament.

chunks.title: Henry St John, 13th Baron St John of Bletso
chunks.chunk:
Title: Henry St John, 13th Baron St John of Bletso
0. Henry Beauchamp St John, 13th
1. Baron St John of Bletso
2. ( 2 August 1758- 18 December 1805) was a British peer.
3. St John was born at Woodford, Northamptonshire, the eldest son of John St John, 12th Baron St John of Bletso, and his wife Susanna Simond, daughter of Peter Simond, merchant of London.
4. He succeeded his father as 13th Baron in 1767.
5. He was at a private school at Easton, near Stamford, and was admitted at St John's College, Cambridge, on 15 October 1776.
6. He was awarded MA in 1778.
7. St John died at the age of 47 after a long illness.
8. St John married Emma Maria Elizabeth Whitbread, daughter of Samuel Whitbread of Cardington, Bedfordshire, on 2 December 1780.
9. She brought £ 30,000 to the marriage.
10. His son St John died aged seven in March 1791 at Exeter and he was succeeded in the barony by his brother Andrew.

chunks.title: Beauchamp St John, 17th Baron St John of Bletso
chunks.chunk:
Title: Beauchamp St John, 17th Baron St John of Bletso
0. Beauchamp Moubray St John, 17th Baron St John of Bletso (4 December 1844 – 10 May 1912) was an English peer.
1. St John was born at Melchbourne, the second son of St Andrew St John, 15th Baron St John of Bletso and his wife Eleanor Hussey.
2. He served in the Highland Light Infantry until 1867.
3. He inherited the title Baron St John of Bletso on the death of his brother in 1887 without male heir to become the 17th Baron, and moved to Melchbourne Park, Bedfordshire.
4. He served as Lord Lieutenant of Bedfordshire from 1905 to 1912.
5. St John married Helen Charlotte Thornton in 1869 and had a very large family.
6. His eldest son Henry succeeded to the title, followed by his second son Mowbray.
7. His daughter Edith married George Lawson Johnston, 1st Baron Luke.
8. Helen died in 1909 and Beauchamp married, secondly, in 1911, to Ethel Susan Lutley (died 1945), daughter of John H. Lutley of Brockhampton Park, Hereford.

chunks.title: Oliver St John, 1st Baron St John of Bletso
chunks.chunk:
Title: Oliver St John, 1st Baron St John of Bletso
0. Oliver St John of Bletsoe, 1st Baron St John of Bletso( c. 1522 – 21 April 1582) was an English peer.
1. He was the son of Sir John St John( born 1498) of Bletsoe and Spelsbury and his first wife Margaret, the daughter of Sir William Waldegrave.
2. His paternal great- great- great- grandfather Sir Oliver St John of Bletsoe, Spelsbury and Lydiard Tregoze( d. 1437) was the husband of Margaret Beauchamp of Bletso, great- great- granddaughter of Roger de Beauchamp, who was summoned to Parliament as Baron Beauchamp of Bletso from 1363 to 1379.
3. Since then that title had not been assumed, although St John was considered to be the line of heir.
4. On 13 January 1559 he was raised to the peerage himself as Baron St John of Bletso, in the county of Bedfordshire.

chunks.title: Andrew St John, 21st Baron St John of Bletso
chunks.chunk:
Title: Andrew St John, 21st Baron St John of Bletso
0. Lieutenant Colonel Andrew Beauchamp St John, 21st Baron St John of Bletso TD( 23 August 1918 – 11 February 1978) was an English peer.
1. He was the third son of Rowland Tudor St John( third son of Beauchamp St John, 17th Baron St John of Bletso) and Katherine Madge Lockwood( second daughter of Sir Frank Lockwood).
2. He was educated at Wellington and joined the Bank of England in 1937.
3. He served in the Indian Army in World War II, and was later was a Lt- Colonel in the Royal Artillery( TA), commanding the Tower Hamlets Regiment( TA) from 1951 to 1954.
4. He was awarded the Territorial Decoration.
5. After the war he was living at Old Deer Park Gardens Richmond with his parents, and in 1955 married Katherine Berg, daughter of Alfred Berg.
6. He emigrated to South Africa in 1957 where he joined Syfret's Trust Company in Cape Town.
7. He became the 21st Baron St John on the death of his cousin in 1976 but only lived to enjoy it for one year.

chunks.title: John St John, 11th Baron St John of Bletso
chunks.chunk:
Title: John St John, 11th Baron St John of Bletso
0. John St John, 11th Baron St John of Bletso( died 24 June 1757) was an English peer.
1. The son of Andrew St John and his wife Jane Blois, daughter of William Blois of Cockfield Hall, Suffolk, he was a nephew of Paulet St John, 8th Baron St John of Bletso and succeeded his brother Rowland St John, 10th Baron St John of Bletso to the family title in 1722.
2. Lord St John married Elizabeth Crowley( the daughter of Ambrose Crowley) at Greenwich on 6 March 1725.
3. Their children included: British comedian and actor Alexander Armstrong is a direct descendant of Lord St John.

chunks.title: John St John, 20th Baron St John of Bletso
chunks.chunk:
Title: John St John, 20th Baron St John of Bletso
0. John Moubray
1. Russell St John, 20th
2. Baron St John of Bletso TD( 3 August 1917 – 13 April 1976) was an English peer.
3. The only son of Moubray St John, 19th Baron St John of Bletso and his wife Evelyn, John St John became the 20th Baron Lord St John of Bletso on the death of his father in 1934.
4. He was living at a hotel in Dublin and died unmarried in 1976, aged 58, and the title passed to a distant cousin.

chunks.title: The Falcon Out West

Title: Joseph H. Lewis
0. Joseph H. Lewis( April 6, 1907 – August 30, 2000) was an American B-movie film director whose stylish flourishes came to be appreciated by auteur theory- espousing film critics in the years following his retirement in 1966.
1. In a 30- year directorial career, he helmed numerous low- budget westerns, action pictures and thrillers and is remembered for original mysteries" My Name Is Julia Ross"( 1945) and" So Dark the Night"( 1946) as well as his most- highly regarded feature, 1950's" Gun Crazy", which spotlighted a desperate young couple( Peggy Cummins and John Dall) who embark on a deadly crime spree.

chunks.title: The Falcon's Brother
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Falcon's Brother
0. The Falcon's Brother is a 1942 American crime drama film in which George Sanders, who had been portraying" The Falcon" in a series of films, appears with his real- life brother Tom Conway; with Sanders handing off the series to Conway, who would play the new Falcon in nine subsequent films.
1. Jane Randolph was featured in a supporting role.
2. " The Falcon's Brother", the only one to feature two Falcons, was directed by Stanley Logan.

chunks.title: The Falcon in Mexico
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Falcon in Mexico
0. The Falcon in Mexico is a 1944 film directed by William Berke and stars Tom Conway in his recurring role as a suave amateur sleuth, supported by Mona Maris and Martha Vickers.
1. Conway would play the Falcon seven more times before RKO retired the franchise in 1946.
2. " The Falcon in Mexico" was the ninth of 16 films in the Falcon detective series.
3. The film features many second unit sequences filmed in Mexico and Brazil; the latter scenes from Orson Welles's aborted film" It's All True".

chunks.title: His Last Haul
chunks.chunk:
Title: His Last Haul
0. His Last Haul is a 1928 American silent crime drama film directed by Marshall Neilan and starring Tom Moore, Seena Owen and Alan Roscoe.
1. Under a woman's guidance, a criminal attempts to reform.

chunks.title: The Falcon Takes Over
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Falcon Takes Over
0. The Falcon Takes Over( also known as The Falcon Steps Out), is a 1942 black- and- white mystery film directed by Irving Reis.
1. The B film was the third, following" The Gay Falcon" and" A Date with the Falcon"( 1941), to star George Sanders as the character Gay Lawrence, a gentleman detective known by the sobriquet the Falcon.

chunks.title: The Falcon and the Co-eds
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Falcon and the Co-eds
0. The Falcon and the Co-eds is a 1943 film under the direction of William Clemens, and produced by Maurice Geraghty, the same team that had worked on" The Falcon in Danger"( 1943) and would stay together for the next film in the Falcon series.
1. " The Falcon and the Co-eds" was the seventh of 16 in the Falcon series.
2. The story and screenplay was by Ardel Wray, a frequent collaborator with Val Lewton in his RKO horror series, who added supernatural elements to the proceedings.
3. As he had in the past three Falcon films, Tom Conway played the suave amateur sleuth, this time backed up by a bevy of young starlets, including Jean Brooks, Rita Corday and Amelita Ward.

chunks.title: The Falcon in San Francisco
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Falcon in San Francisco
0. The Falcon in San Francisco is a 1945 American crime and mystery film directed by Joseph H. Lewis and stars Tom Conway, Rita Corday and Edward Brophy, who played the recurring role of" Goldie" Locke.
1. The film was the 11th in The Falcon series of detective films, and the eighth featuring Conway as the amateur sleuth.
2. " The Falcon in San Francisco" was the final film in the series produced by Maurice Geraghty, after which budgets were reduced and location shooting largely abandoned.

question: Who is Edward De Vere, 17Th Earl Of Oxford's paternal grandfather?
answer: John de Vere, 15th Earl of Oxford

chunks.title: John de Vere, 16th Earl of Oxford
chunks.chunk:
Title: John de Vere, 16th Earl of Oxford
0. John de Vere, 16th Earl of Oxford (1516 – 3 August 1562) was born to John de Vere, 15th Earl of Oxford and Elizabeth Trussell, daughter of Edward Trussell.
1. He was styled Lord Bolebec 1526 to 1540 before he succeeded to his father's title.

chunks.title: Aubrey de Vere, 10th Earl of Oxford
chunks.chunk:
Title: Aubrey de Vere, 10th Earl of Oxford
0. Aubrey de Vere, 10th Earl of Oxford( c. 1338 – 15 February 1400) was the third son of John de Vere, 7th Earl of Oxford and Maud de Badlesmere, daughter of Bartholomew de Badlesmere, 1st Lord Badlesmere.
1. Aubrey de Vere had three brothers, John, Thomas, and Robert, and three sisters.
2. Margaret, Maud and Elizabeth.
3. His eldest brother, John, married the daughter of Hugh Courtenay, Earl of Devon, but died in 1350 in his father's lifetime.
4. Another brother, Robert, also died in his father's lifetime.
5. Aubrey de Vere's third brother, Thomas, succeeded his father as 8th Earl of Oxford, and was in turn succeeded by his only son, Robert de Vere, 9th Earl of Oxford, who died in 1392 without issue, leaving Aubrey de Vere to inherit the earldom.
6. In 1360 Aubrey de Vere was made steward of the royal forest of Havering in Essex.
7. In 1367 was retained to' abide for life' with the Black Prince, with a substantial allowance.
8. He was knighted, made constable of Wallingford Castle in 1375 and also given the honours of Wallingford and St. Valery, though he gave up Wallingford in 1378 for Hadleigh Castle.
9. Edward III used him as an ambassador in seeking peace with France.
10. In 1381, de Vere became a Chamberlain of the Royal Household and member of the privy council.
11. In 1388 his nephew, Robert de Vere, Duke of Ireland and 9th Earl of Oxford was deemed a traitor, causing Aubrey to lose his post of chamberlain.
12. However, after Robert ’s death in 1392, the king gave Aubrey the title of Earl of Oxford allowing him to take a seat in parliament.
13. Aubrey ’s son, Richard became the 11th Earl of Oxford on his death.
14. An administrator of Aubrey de Veer appears as William Tasburgh, of Raylegh, parson, in 1401.

chunks.title: Bernard Mordaunt Ward
chunks.chunk:
Title: Bernard Mordaunt Ward
0. Bernard Mordaunt Ward (20 January 1893 – 12 October 1945) was a British author and third-generation soldier most noted for his support of the Oxfordian theory of Shakespeare authorship and writing the first documentary biography of Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford.

1. Bridget was brought up by her maternal grandfather, the powerful statesman William Cecil, 1st Baron Burghley.
2. She was also styled Lady Norris of Rycote and Viscountess Thame.
3. She married Francis Norris, 1st Earl of Berkshire; however, the marriage was not a success, and they separated in 1606.

2. She served as a Maid of Honour to Queen Elizabeth before her marriage.

chunks.title: Robert de Vere, 5th Earl of Oxford

0. Robert de Vere, 5th Earl of Oxford( c. 1220 – 1296) was the son and heir of Hugh de Vere, 4th Earl of Oxford, and chamberlain to Queen Eleanor.

chunks.title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
chunks.chunk:
Title: Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford
0. Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford (12 April 155024 June 1604) was an English peer and courtier of the Elizabethan era.
1. Oxford was heir to the second oldest earldom in the kingdom, a court favourite for a time, a sought-after patron of the arts, and noted by his contemporaries as a lyric poet and court playwright, but his volatile temperament precluded him from attaining any courtly or governmental responsibility and contributed to the dissipation of his estate.
2. Since the 1920s he has been among the most popular alternative candidates proposed for the authorship of Shakespeare's works.
3. De Vere was the only son of John de Vere, 16th Earl of Oxford, and Margery Golding.
4. After the death of his father in 1562, he became a ward of Queen Elizabeth and was sent to live in the household of her principal advisor, Sir William Cecil.
5. He married Cecil's daughter, Anne, with whom he had five children.
6. De Vere was estranged from her for five years after he refused to acknowledge her first child as his.
7. De Vere was a champion jouster and travelled widely throughout Italy and France.
8. He was among the first to compose love poetry at the Elizabethan court, and he was praised as a playwright,
9. though none of the plays known as his survive.
10. A stream of dedications praised de Vere for his generous patronage of literary, religious, musical, and medical works, and he patronised both adult and boy acting companies, as well as musicians, tumblers, acrobats and performing animals.
11. He fell out of favour with the Queen in the early 1580s and was exiled from court after impregnating one of her maids of honour, Anne Vavasour, which instigated violent street brawls between de Vere's retainers and her uncles.
12. De Vere was reconciled to the Queen in 1583, but all opportunities for advancement had been lost.
13. In 1586, the Queen granted de Vere a £1,000 annuity to relieve his financial distress caused by his extravagance and selling off his income-producing lands for ready money.
14. After his wife's death, he married Elizabeth Trentham, one of the Queen's maids of honour, with whom he had an heir, Henry de Vere.
15. He died in 1604, having spent the entirety of his inherited estates.

chunks.title: Margery Golding
