chunks.title: Alexander Carl Otto Westphal
chunks.chunk:
Title: Alexander Carl Otto Westphal
0. Alexander Carl Otto Westphal (18 May 1863, Berlin – 9 January 1941, Bonn) was a German neurologist and psychiatrist.
1. He was the son of the psychiatrist Carl Friedrich Otto Westphal (1833–1890) and Clara Mendelssohn and the grandson of Otto Carl Friedrich Westphal.
2. Alexander Westphal studied at Heidelberg and Berlin, receiving his doctorate at Berlin in 1888.
3. He then became an assistant to Wilhelm Heinrich Erb (1840-1921) in Heidelberg and to Heinrich Curschmann (1846-1910) in Leipzig.
4. In 1892 he became the head physician of the department for nervous diseases at the Berlin Charité under Friedrich Jolly (1844-1904), subsequently qualifying in the fields psychiatry and neurology (1894).
5. In 1902 he accepted an invitation to the University of Greifswald as an associate professor, and two years later relocated to the University of Bonn as full professor.
6. Westphal made contributions towards the literature involving diabetes insipidus, leukaemia and pseudoleukaemia, as well as a variety of topics in psychiatry and neurology.
7. He is eponymously associated with the "Westphal-Pilcz sign" (neurotonic pupillary reaction), a medical indicator named in conjunction with Polish neurologist Jan Pilcz (1870-1931).
8. He also produced a compilation of a complete edition of his father's scientific works.
9. He trained a number of significant scientists, including Otto Lowenstein (1889-1965), with whom he was co-author of "Experimentelle und klinische Studien zur Physiologie
10. und Pathologie
11. der Pupillenbewegungen, mit besonderer Berücksichtigung der Schizophrenie" (part of the series, "Abhandlungen aus
12. der Neurologie, Psychiatrie, Psychologie und ihren Grenzgebieten".

4. Westphal was married to Karoline Friederike Heine, the daughter of a wealthy banker.

chunks.title: Place of birth
chunks.chunk:
Title: Place of birth
0. The place of birth( POB) or birthplace is the place where a person was born.
1. This place is often used in legal documents, together with name and date of birth, to uniquely identify a person.
2. As a general rule with respect to passports, the place of birth is determined to be the country that currently has" sovereignty" over the actual place of birth, regardless of when the birth actually occurred.
3. The place of birth is not necessarily the place where the parents of the new baby live.
4. If the baby is born in a hospital in another place, that place is the place of birth.
5. In many countries, this also means that the government requires that the birth of the new baby is registered in the place of birth.
6. Some countries place less or no importance on the place of birth, instead using alternative geographical characteristics for the purpose of identity documents.
7. For example, Sweden has used the concept of" födelsehemortdomicile of birth") since 1947.
8. This means that the domicile of the baby's mother is the registered place of birth.
9. The location of the maternity ward or other physical birthplace is considered unimportant.
10. Similarly, Switzerland uses the concept of" Heimatortlieu d'origineluogo d'origineplace of origin" in German, French and Italian respectively).
11. A child born to Swiss parents is automatically assigned the place of origin of the parent with the same last name, so the child either gets their mother's or father's place of origin.
12. A child born to one Swiss parent and one foreign parent acquires the place of origin of their Swiss parent.
13. In a Swiss passport and identity card, the holder's place of origin is stated, not their place of birth.
14. In some countries( primarily in the Americas), the place of birth automatically determines the nationality of the baby, a practice often referred to by the Latin phrase" jus soli".
15. Almost all countries outside the Americas instead attribute nationality based on the nationality( ies) of the baby's parents( referred to as" jus sanguinis").
16. There can be some confusion regarding the place of birth if the birth takes place in an unusual way: when babies are born on an airplane or at sea, difficulties can arise.
17. The place of birth of such a person depends on the law of the countries involved, which include the nationality of the plane or ship, the nationality( ies) of the parents and/ or the location of the plane or ship( if the birth occurs in the territorial waters or airspace of a country).
18. Some administrative forms may request the applicant's" country of birth".
19. It is important to determine from the requester whether the information requested refers to the applicant's" place of birth" or" nationality at birth".
20. For US citizens born abroad who under the US Constitution acquire US citizenship at the time of birth, the nationality at birth will be USA( American), while the place of birth would be the country in which the actual birth takes place.

chunks.title: Taddea Malaspina
chunks.chunk:
Title: Taddea Malaspina
0. Taddea Malaspina( 1505-?) was an Italian marchesa.
1. She was the mistress of Alessandro de' Medici, Duke of Florence from the early 1530s to about 1537 and was likely the mother of at least two of his children, Giulio di Alessandro de' Medici and Giulia de' Medici.
2. Giulio de' Medici was associated with the Malaspina family at different points throughout his life.
3. Taddea was the younger daughter of Alberico Malaspina, sovereign marquis of Massa, and Lucrezia d' Este.
4. She married Count Giambattista Boiardo di Scandiano.
5. After his death and the death of her father, Malaspina lived with her mother in Florence and had a number of lovers, including Alessandro.
6. Her sister Ricciarda inherited the title after their father's death.
7. Through Ricciarda's marriage, the family was related to Pope Innocent VIII.
8. Ricciarda was probably also one of Alessandro de' Medici's lovers.
9. In a portrait of Alessandro by Pontormo, dated to about 1534, the Duke, dressed in black, draws the profile of a woman in silverpoint.
10. The portrait may have been a gift for Malaspina.
11. The Chiesa della Madonna del Carmine and the Santa Chiara monastic complex in Massa, now in the Italian province of Massa Carrara, were built on Taddea Malaspina's order; they still stand.

chunks.title: Angela de' Rossi
chunks.chunk:
Title: Angela de' Rossi
0. Angela Paola de' Rossi
1. ( 1506- 11 November 1573) was an Italian noblewoman.
2. She was born to Troilo I de' Rossi and Bianca Riario in San Secondo Parmense.
3. Her first husband was Vitello Vitelli and her second was Alessandro Vitelli, both from the Vitelli family.
4. She died in Città di Castello.

chunks.title: Alessandro Vitelli
chunks.chunk:
Title: Alessandro Vitelli
0. Alessandro Vitelli (1500 - 1554) was an Italian condottiero in the service of the Holy Roman Empire, the Papal States and the Grand Duchy of Tuscany.
1. He was an illegitimate son of Paolo Vitelli and the second husband of Angela de' Rossi.
2. He also became count of Montone, count of Citerna and lord of Amatrice.
3. He was born in Città di Castello and died in Citerna.

chunks.title: Catherine de' Medici
chunks.chunk:
Title: Catherine de' Medici
0. Catherine de' Medici (13 April 1519 – 5 January 1589), was an Italian noblewoman who was queen consort of France from 1547 until 1559, by marriage to King Henry II, and Queen mother of kings Francis II, Charles IX and Henry III from 1559 to 1589.
1. The years during which her sons reigned have been called "the age of Catherine de' Medici" as she had extensive, if at times varying, influence in the political life of France.
2. She was born in Florence to Lorenzo de’ Medici, Duke of Urbino and Madeleine de La Tour d'Auvergne.
3. In 1533, at the age of fourteen, Catherine married Henry, second son of King Francis I and Queen Claude of France.
4. Catherine's marriage was arranged by her uncle Pope Clement VII.
5. Henry excluded Catherine from participating in state affairs and instead showered favors on his chief mistress, Diane de Poitiers, who wielded much influence over him.
6. Henry's death thrust Catherine into the political arena as mother of the frail 15-year-old King Francis II.
7. When he died in 1560, she became regent on behalf of her 10-year-old son King Charles IX and was granted sweeping powers.
8. From 1560 to 1563, she ruled France as regent for her son Charles IX, King of France.
9. After Charles died in 1574, Catherine played a key role in the reign of her third son, Henry III.
10. He dispensed with her advice only in the last months of her life (he would outlive her by seven months).
11. Catherine's three sons reigned in an age of almost constant civil and religious war in France.
12. The problems facing the monarchy were complex and daunting but Catherine was able to keep the monarchy and the state institutions functioning even at a minimum level.
13. At first, Catherine compromised and made concessions to the rebelling Calvinist Protestants, or Huguenots, as they became known.
14. She failed, however, to grasp the theological issues that drove their movement.
15. Later she resorted, in frustration and anger, to hard-line policies against them.
16. In return, she came to be blamed for the excessive persecutions carried out under her sons' rule, in particular for the St. Bartholomew's Day massacre of 1572, in which thousands of Huguenots were killed in Paris and throughout France.
17. Some historians have excused Catherine from blame for the worst decisions of the crown, though evidence for her ruthlessness can be found in her letters.
18. In practice, her authority was always limited by the effects of the civil wars.
19. Her policies, therefore, may be seen as desperate measures to keep the Valois monarchy on the throne at all costs, and her patronage of the arts as an attempt to glorify a monarchy whose prestige was in steep decline.
20. Without Catherine, it is unlikely that her sons would have remained in power.
21. According to Mark Strage, one of her biographers, Catherine was the most powerful woman in 16th-century Europe.

chunks.title: Francis II of France
chunks.chunk:
Title: Francis II of France
0. Francis II (19 January 1544 – 5 December 1560) was King of France from 1559 to 1560.
1. He was also King consort of Scotland as a result of his marriage to Mary, Queen of Scots, from 1558 until his death in 1560.
2. He ascended the throne of France at the age of fifteen after the accidental death of his father, Henry II, in 1559.
3. His short reign was dominated by the first stirrings of the French Wars of Religion.
4. Although the royal age of majority had been set at fourteen, his mother, Catherine de' Medici, entrusted the reins of government to his wife's uncles from the House of Guise, staunch supporters of the Catholic cause.
5. They were unable to help Catholics in Scotland against the progressing Scottish Reformation, however, and the Auld Alliance was dissolved.
6. Francis was succeeded by two of his brothers in turn, both of whom were also unable to reduce tensions between Protestants and Catholics.

chunks.title: J. Frank Dalton
chunks.chunk:
Title: J. Frank Dalton
0. John Frank Dalton( March 8, 1848 August 15, 1951) was a man who, in the last few years( 1948- 1951) of his long life, publicly claimed to be the famous outlaw Jesse James.
1. However, most professional historians believe that Dalton was merely a Jesse James impostor, and that the real Jesse James was killed by Robert" Bob" Ford on April 3, 1882, in a house Jesse was renting located at 1318 Lafayette Street in St. Joseph, Missouri.
2. With the death of Jesse James in 1882, and the subsequent death of his( Dalton's) wife Julia Ellen Groshon during childbirth in 1886, Dalton abandoned his children and began roaming the countryside.
3. In the 1930s and 1940s he appeared in Independence County, Arkansas, telling tales of being Jesse James, and on other occasions he told tales of being the famous Western lawman John Franklin" Frank" Dalton( June 8, 1859- November 27, 1887), thus earning himself a meal.
4. By the 1940s he was in Oklahoma and Texas, where his uncle lived and he had relatives.
5. It was in Texas that he first claimed he was the same Frank Dalton who historians believe had been killed in 1887.
6. When it was proved that he was n't the original Frank Dalton( 1859- 1887), in April, 1948- in Lawton, Oklahoma- he took up being Jesse James instead.
7. Dalton was allegedly 100 years old at the time of his first public appearance as Jesse James- at Lawton, Oklahoma in April – May, 1948.
8. Like the real Jesse James, Dalton apparently had been a pro-Confederate guerrilla in Missouri during the Civil War.
9. However, Dalton's account of himself as Jesse James did not hold up under questioning from Jesse James' surviving relatives.
10. Nevertheless, several people of note, such as journalist/ novelist Robert Ruark, were convinced that J. Frank Dalton was the famous outlaw Jesse Woodson James.
11. To many people's surprise, Dalton did appear to have many of the unique body marks/ body features which the real Jesse James was rumored to have.
12. These body features included: seven bullet wounds, a rope burn around his neck, a collapsed lung, a damaged fingertip, and severely burned feet.
13. On September 5, 1949, Rudi Turilli and Lester B. Dill( the general manager and owner, respectively, of Meramec Caverns, near Stanton, Missouri) hosted a reunion at Meramec Caverns for Dalton and his last- remaining old- time friends, in celebration of Dalton's/ Jesse James' supposed 102nd birthday.
14. J. Frank Dalton died on August 15, 1951, in Granbury, Texas, and his death certificate was recorded with the name of the man he claimed to be.
15. His gravestone in Granbury Cemetery also has that claimed identity recorded on it.

chunks.title: David Lean
chunks.chunk:
Title: David Lean
0. Sir David Lean (25 March 190816 April 1991) was an English film director, producer, screenwriter and editor.
1. Widely considered as one of the most influential directors of all time, Lean was mostly famous for his large-scale epics such as "The Bridge on the River Kwai" (1957), "Lawrence of Arabia" (1962), "Doctor Zhivago" (1965) and "A Passage to India" (1984).
2. He also directed adaptations of Charles Dickens novels "Great Expectations" (1946) and "Oliver Twist" (1948), and the romantic drama "Brief Encounter" (1945).
3. Originally a film editor in the early 1930s, Lean made his directorial debut with 1942's "In Which We Serve", which was the first of four collaborations with Noël Coward.
4. Beginning with "Summertime" in 1955, Lean began to make internationally co-produced films financed by the big Hollywood studios; in 1970, however, the critical failure of his film "Ryan's Daughter" led him to take a fourteen-year break from filmmaking, during which he planned a number of film projects which never came to fruition.
5. In 1984 he had a career revival with "A Passage to India", adapted from E. M. Forster's novel; it was an instant hit with critics but proved to be the last film Lean would direct.
6. Lean's affinity for pictorialism and inventive editing techniques has led him to be lauded by directors such as Steven Spielberg, Stanley Kubrick, Martin Scorsese, and Ridley Scott.
7. Lean was voted 9th greatest film director of all time in the British Film Institute "Sight & SoundDirectors' Top Directors" poll in 2002.
8. Nominated seven times for the Academy Award for Best Director, which he won twice for "The Bridge on the River Kwai" and "Lawrence of Arabia", he has seven films in the British Film Institute's Top 100 British Films (with three of them being in the top five) and was awarded the AFI Life Achievement Award in 1990.

14. What is a Family?,
15. What is a Feeling?"

18. His essay was included in a special anthology by New York City public school children compiled and published by the New York City Department of Education.
19. Boritzer now lives in Venice, California and maintains his publishing office there also.
20. He has helped numerous other authors to get published through" How to Get Your Book Published!" programs.
21. Boritzer is also a yoga teacher who teaches regular classes locally and guest- teaches nationally.
22. He is also recognized nationally as an erudite speaker on" The Teachings of the Buddha."

chunks.title: Gourmaëlon
chunks.chunk:
Title: Gourmaëlon
0. Gourmaëlon or Wrmaelon( died 913/ 4), was the Count of Cornouaille and" de facto" ruler of Brittany from 907 – c. 914.
1. As ruler of Brittany he was considered" Prince de Bretagne" in some chronicles and histories.
2. His actual history is among the least well documented of the early medieval rulers of Brittany.
3. His reputed time of rule coincides with a dramatic increase in Viking invasions that ultimately led up to the Viking Occupation of Brittany that began after his death.
4. He is believed to have been named Count of Cornouaille by Alan I, King of Brittany near the end of his reign in 907.
5. After Alan I's death in 907 he disputed the right of Alan's heirs to rule Brittany and fought for the control of the kingdom, albeit without claiming the title king.
6. His life and activities are sparsely recorded in historical documents save for several donations to the Breton churches of the day.
7. In a donation to the monastery of Plélan in 910 he is identified as ruler of Brittany.
8. At Redon in 913 he is identified as" Count Gourmaelon, the Breton monarch."
9. He is understood to have died in 913( or 914) in a battle with invading Vikings.
10. No subsequent ruler of Brittany is recorded in histories or chronicles of the period until the return of Alan II, Duke of Brittany, known as Alan Barbetorte, from England c. 937–938.

1. She was the daughter of Odo II, Count of Blois and Ermengarde of Auvergne.

2. She was the daughter and heir of Jacques de Dinan( d. 1444), lord of Beaumanoir and chamberlain at the court of Brittany, and Catherine de Rohan.
3. Sh was also the heir of her paternal uncle Bertrand de Dinan( d. 1444), Marshall of Bretagne, Lord of Montafilant, Chateaubriant and Huguetières.
4. She was abducted by and forced to marry Gilles of Brittany, brother of Francis I, Duke of Brittany and Peter II, Duke of Brittany, in 1444.
5. She was widowed in 1450, when her spouse was imprisoned and died on the instigation of Arthur de Montauban, who wished to marry her.
6. By the help of Françoise d'Amboise, she married Guy XIV de Laval in 1451.
7. In 1488, she was appointed governess to Anne of Brittany and her sister Isabelle.
8. She played an active role on the political marriage arrangements surrounding Anne.
9. In 1494, she remarried the noble Jean de Proisy.

chunks.title: Etan Boritzer
chunks.chunk:
Title: Etan Boritzer
0. Etan Boritzer( born 1950) is an American writer of children ’s literature who is best known for his book" What is God?" first published in 1989.
1. His best selling" What is?" illustrated children's book series on character education and difficult subjects for children is a popular teaching guide for parents, teachers and child- life professionals.
2. Boritzer gained national critical acclaim after" What is God?" was published in 1989 although the book has caused controversy from religious fundamentalists for its universalist views.
3. The other current books in the" What is?" series include
4. What is Love?,
5. What is Death?,
6. What is Beautiful?,
7. What is Funny?,
8. What is Right?,
9. What is Peace?,
10. What is Money?,
11. What is Dreaming?,
12. What is a Friend?,
13. What is True?,
14. What is a Family?,
15. What is a Feeling?"
16. The series is now also translated into 15 languages.
17. Boritzer was first published in 1963 at the age of 13 when he wrote an essay in his English class at Wade Junior High School in the Bronx, New York on the assassination of John F. Kennedy.
18. His essay was included in a special anthology by New York City public school children compiled and published by the New York City Department of Education.
19. Boritzer now lives in Venice, California and maintains his publishing office there also.
20. He has helped numerous other authors to get published through" How to Get Your Book Published!" programs.
21. Boritzer is also a yoga teacher who teaches regular classes locally and guest- teaches nationally.
22. He is also recognized nationally as an erudite speaker on" The Teachings of the Buddha."

chunks.title: Eiludd Powys
chunks.chunk:
Title: Eiludd Powys
0. Eiludd Powys was an early 7th-century King of Powys.
1. One theory asserts that when Manwgan ap Selyf came to the throne in 613 he was a young boy, which led to an invasion of Powys by Eluadd ap Glast
2. (alias Eiludd Powys), the erstwhile King of Dogfeiling.
3. The usurper probably managed to hold the throne for some thirty years or more before he was killed fighting the Northumbrians, possibly at the Battle of Maes Cogwy (Oswestry) in 642.
4. The Dogfeiling dynasty was finally crushed by the Saxons around 656.
5. He was more likely the son or younger brother of Selyf "Sarffgadau" ap Cynan Garwyn.
6. It is not known which he is as there are two accounts one in the Jesus College Ms.20
7. that makes him the son of Selyf and brother of Manwgan whereas the Harleian Ms. 3859 makes him the brother of Selyf Sarffgadau, he could be either as it is not unheard of that a brother succeeds in absence of a mature heir (see Rhyddfedd Frych), as well as the eldest being overlooked as successor by their father
8. (see Gruffydd ap Llywelyn Fawr and Dafydd ap Llywelyn).
9. But what is interesting is a reference to the descendants of Selyf, serpents of Battle by the Powysian Court Poet Cynddelw Brydydd Mawr and that he specifically during this time of the 12th Century worked for the Powysian Royal family and then after their fall, went to work under Gwynedd and then later Powys Wenwynwyn.

chunks.title: Beli ap Eiludd
chunks.chunk:
Title: Beli ap Eiludd
0. Beli ap Eiludd was a 7th- century King of Powys.
1. Some theories assert that he was in fact the son of Manwgan ap Selyf who regained power after Eiludd Powys was killed at the battle of Battle of Maes Cogwy in 642.
2. It is more likely however that as the genealogies state he was the son of Eiludd who was either the son or brother of Selyf, the former being the most likely due to a surviving reference from Cynddelw painting the Mathrafal dynasty as being descendants of Selyf.
3. It was also likely if Eiludd Powys fought at Maes Cogwy alongside Elfan Powys and Cynddylan, Beli would have been the King whom Heledd ran to for protection.

chunks.title: Free Expression Tunnel
chunks.chunk:
Title: Free Expression Tunnel
0. The Free Expression Tunnel is the longest, widest, and most heavily used pedestrian tunnel under the railroad tracks at North Carolina State University in Raleigh, North Carolina (also goes under Yarbrough Drive).
1. The special aspect of the tunnel is that anyone is permitted to decorate its walls, ceiling, and floor.
2. The tunnel connects NCSU's North Campus with the Central Campus and provides the most direct route from The Brickyard to the Central Campus residence halls.
3. Clubs, fraternities, sororities, and other organizations often paint the tunnel to promote events and amateur artists paint to express themselves and to promote freedom of speech.
4. A retaining wall just outside the tunnel's south entrance is also open for free expression.
5. The "service tunnel" itself was constructed in 1939 as a Public Works Administration project.
6. The tunnel was first painted in 1968, when it was painted red and white to celebrate the military veterans of North Carolina
7. Fans of other universities' sports teams often come to the Free Expression Tunnel before and sometimes after big athletic events to paint the tunnel with their teams' athletic colors as part of a prank.
8. Carolina Tar Heel fans have a long history of doing this prank as well as fans from East Carolina University.
9. The tunnel is subject to flooding during massive torrential rains.
10. Waters rose to a height of 60 inches after a storm in July 2003.
11. For the Spring 2005-2006 semester, the Free Expression Tunnel was closed for repairs and the installation of handicap ramps.
12. The tunnel reopened in the winter of 2006 with a re-dedication ceremony, which unveiled a new plaque at the tunnel's north entrance expressing the brief history of the tunnel and its purpose.
13. Prior to the renovations, the space available for free expression was much larger at both ends.
14. On November 5, 2008 racist, threatening graffiti directed at (then) President-elect Barack Obama was found in the tunnel.
15. Because of the threats against Obama, the Secret Service was among those called to investigate.
16. The four students responsible were identified, and admitted to the act, stating that it was protected by their First Amendment right to free speech; however the North Carolina chapter of the NAACP has called for their expulsion.
17. Since February 2010, there has been an ongoing tradition of a weekly freestyle cypher, every Monday night around 11pm.
18. Local artists and students alike gather at the tunnel to freestyle, beatbox, sing, play instruments, recite poetry, and network.
19. More photos of the tunnel and the free expression art can be seen at the tunnel's Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/FreeX.NCSU
20. The video below is an example of what people can do in the tunnel.

chunks.title: Black Rock Tunnel
chunks.chunk:
Title: Black Rock Tunnel
0. The Black Rock Tunnel is an active rail road tunnel of the old Reading Railroad.
1. The 1835 tunnel was the third rail tunnel constructed in the United States, and is the third oldest still in use.
2. The tunnel is also notable as being the first for which shafts were sunk during construction.
3. The tunnel is cut through a hill in Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, United States.
4. The tunnel and line are now owned by Norfolk Southern as part of its Harrisburg Line.
5. The Black Rock Tunnel was constructed between 1835 and 1837 and opened in 1838.
6. W. Hasell Wilson was the resident engineer in charge.
7. The tunnel was originally long, wide, and high.
8. The tunnel passes below the top of the hill.
9. A then- unique feature of the tunnel's construction was the sinking of six, diameter shafts, tangent to the tunnel cross section.
10. These shafts were spaced at intervals to correct errors in the tunnel alignment.
11. Construction of the tunnel cost an estimated$ 178,992.
12. Noted local miner, geologist and palaentologist Charles M. Wheatley examined the rock excavated from the tunnel and identified many previously unknown fossilized species, some of which now bear his name.
13. In 1858 and 1859 the Black Rock and Flat Rock Tunnels were widened to accommodate the wider rolling stock from the Lebanon Valley Branch.
14. The spacing between the tracks was increased from to.
15. The widening of the tunnel was the first project to employ electric detonation of multiple explosive charges.
16. The northern end of the tunnel is high on a steep bank of the Schuylkill River so the rail line makes a dramatic transition from tunnel to bridge.
17. The ends of the Black Rock Tunnel are located at and.

0. Ferdinand IV August Carl Joseph Johannes Nepomuk Thaddeus, count of Limburg Styrum Zu Illereichen,( 24 September 1785- 5 December 1800) was sovereign lord of the immediate lordship of Gemen.

2. At the age of 13, when his grandfather Karl Josef of Limburg Stirum died, he inherited the immediate lordship of Gemen along with the associated seat on the Bench of Counts of Westphalia in the Imperial Diet.
3. He also inherited the fortress of Simontornya in Hungary.
4. With his death at the age of 15, the Gemen- branch of the House of Limburg Stirum became extinct.
5. Historians assume that the Styrum- branch of the House of Limburg Stirum took over his seat in the Imperial Diet.
6. Gemen went to Reichsfreiherr Aloys von Boineburg- Bömelberg Zu Erolsheim.

chunks.title: Kenneth Branagh

Title: Kenneth Branagh
0. Sir Kenneth Charles Branagh (born 10 December 1960) is a Northern Irish actor, director, film producer and screenwriter.
1. Branagh trained at the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London; in 2015 he succeeded Richard Attenborough as its president.
2. He has both directed and starred in several film adaptations of William Shakespeare's plays, including "Henry V" (1989) (for which he was nominated for the Academy Awards for Best Actor and Best Director), "Much Ado About Nothing" (1993), "Othello" (1995), "Hamlet" (1996) (for which he was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay), "Love's Labour's Lost" (2000), and
3. "As You Like It" (2006).
4. Branagh has starred in numerous other films and television series including "Fortunes of War" (1987), Woody Allen's " Celebrity" (1998), "Wild Wild West" (1999), as the voice of Miguel in "The Road to El Dorado" (2000), as SS leader Reinhard Heydrich in "Conspiracy" (2001), "Shackleton" (2002), "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets" (2002), "Warm Springs" (2005), as Major General Henning von Tresckow in "Valkyrie" (2008), "The Boat That Rocked" (2009), "Wallander" (2008–2016), "
5. My Week with Marilyn" (2011) as Sir Laurence Olivier (Academy Award nomination for Best Supporting Actor), and as Royal Navy Commander Bolton in the action-thriller "Dunkirk" (2017).
6. He has directed such films as "Dead Again" (1991), in which he also starred, "Swan Song" (1992)
7. (Academy Award nominated for Best Live Action Short Film), "Mary Shelley's Frankenstein" (1994) in which he also starred, "The Magic Flute" (2006), "Sleuth" (2007), the Marvel superhero film
8. "Thor" (2011), the action thriller  (2014) in which he also co-stars, the live-action adaptation of Disney's "Cinderella" (2015), and the mystery drama adaptation of Agatha Christie's "Murder on the Orient Express" (2017), in which he also starred as Hercule Poirot.
9. He narrated the series "Cold War" (1998), the BBC documentary miniseries "Walking with Dinosaurs" (1999) (as well as "The Ballad of Big AlWalking with Beasts" (2001) and "Walking with Monsters" (2005).
10. Branagh has been nominated for five Academy Awards, five Golden Globe Awards, and has won three BAFTAs, and two Emmy Awards.
11. He was appointed a Knight Bachelor in the 2012 Birthday Honours and was knighted on 9 November 2012.
12. He was made a Freeman of his native city of Belfast in January 2018.

chunks.title: Íñigo Vélez de Guevara, 8th Count of Oñate
chunks.chunk:
Title: Íñigo Vélez de Guevara, 8th Count of Oñate 0. Íñigo Vélez de Guevara (1597–1658), 8th Count of Oñate was a Spanish political figure. 1. He was the son of Íñigo Vélez de Guevara, 7th Count of Oñate and Catalina Vélez. 2. His younger brother was Beltrán, Viceroy of Sardinia. 3. He was Spanish ambassador in London and Rome.
4. He played an important role in crushing the Neapolitan revolt of 1647 led by Masaniello. 5. Oñate was the eventual vanquisher of the "Neapolitan Republic" and commissioned the Fontana della Sellaria to commemorate his victory. 6. He later served as viceroy of the Kingdom of Naples (from 1648) (see List of Spanish Viceroys of Naples), where he repulsed a French attack during the Franco-Spanish War (1635).
7. At his return in Spain he was made State Councilor and received the title of Marqués de Guevara. 8. He married Antonia Manrique de la Cerda and had two daughters:

chunks.title: Luis Vélez de Guevara
chunks.chunk:
Title: Luis Vélez de Guevara
0. Luis Vélez de Guevara( born Luis Vélez de Santander)
1. ( 1 August 1579 – 10 November 1644) was a Spanish dramatist and novelist.
2. He was born at Écija and was of Jewish converso descent.
3. After graduating as a sizar at the University of Osuna in 1596, he joined the household of Rodrigo de Castro, Cardinal- Archbishop of Seville, and celebrated the marriage of Philip III in a poem signed Vélez de Santander, a name which he continued to use till some years later.
4. It seems he served as a soldier in Italy and Algiers, returning to Spain in 1602 when he entered the service of the count de Saldaña, and dedicated himself to writing for the stage.
5. He died at Madrid on 10 November 1644.
6. Velez de Guevara was the author of over four hundred plays, of which the best are" Reinar despues de morirLa Luna de la Sierra", and" El Diablo está en Cantillana".
7. The play" Más pesa el rey que la sangre", which translates into" The King weighs more than blood( kinship)" is based on the episode of the Reconquista in which the nobleman Alonso Pérez de Guzmán allows his son to be sacrificed, rather than surrender his King's possession of Tarifa.
8. However, Vélez de Guevara is most widely known as the author of" El diablo cojuelo"( 1641," The Lame Devil" or" The Crippled Devil"), a fantastic novel which suggested to Alain- René Lesage the idea for" Le Diable boiteux"( 1707).
9. The plot presents a rascal student that hides in an astrologer's mansard.
10. He frees a devil from a bottle.
11. As an acknowledgement the devil shows him the apartments of Madrid and the tricks, miseries and mischiefs of their inhabitants.
12. A similar theme was suggested by the magic lenses in" Los anteojos de mejor vista"( 1620 – 1625) by Rodrigo Fernández de Ribera.
13. Charles Dickens refers to" El Diablo cojuelo" in The Old Curiosity Shop, chapter thirty- three.

chunks.title: Eystein Glumra
chunks.chunk:
Title: Eystein Glumra
0. Eystein Glumra(" Eystein the Noisy" or" Eystein the Clatterer"; Modern Norwegian" Øystein Glumra") also known as Eystein Ivarsson, was reputedly a petty king on the west coast of Norway, during the 9th Century.
1. The" Heimskringla" saga states that Eystein Glumra was the father of Rognvald Eysteinsson and Sigurd Eysteinsson:" The first earl in the Orkney Islands was called Sigurd, who was a son of Eystein Glumra, and brother of Ragnvald earl of More.
2. After Sigurd, his son Guthorm was earl for one year.
3. After him Torf- Einar, a son of Ragnvald, took the earldom, and was long earl, and was a man of great power".
4. According to the" Orkneyinga Saga", Eystein Glumra was the son of Ivar the jarl of Uplanders and grandson of Halfdan the Old.
5. " Orkneyinga Saga" also named Eystein Glumra as the father of Rognvald Eysteinsson:" Heiti, Gorr ’s son, was father of Sveiði the sea-king,[ who was] the father of Halfdan the old,[ who was] the father of Ivar the Uplanders ’ earl,[ who was] the father of Eystein the noisy,[ who was] the father of earl Rognvald the mighty and wise in council".
6. Linnea Hartsuyker's books
7. The Half- drowned King and The Sea Queen cover the lives of Eystein's children.

0. Beltrán Vélez Ladrón de Guevara, 1st Marquis of Monreale (Sardinia) and 1st Marquis of Campo Real (Spain)
1. (died February 21, 1652) was a Spanish velez-noble noble-velez political figure.
2. He was the son of Iñigo Vélez de Guevara and Catalina de Guevara, 5th Countess of Oñate.
3. He married Catalina Vélez, 9th Countess of Oñate, daughter of his brother Íñigo Vélez de Guevara, 8th Count of Oñate.

chunks.title: Gene Fowler Jr.
chunks.chunk:
Title: Gene Fowler Jr.
0. Gene Fowler Jr.( 27 May 1917 – 11 May 1998), the eldest son of journalist and author Gene Fowler, was a prominent Hollywood film editor.
1. His work included films of Fritz Lang and Samuel Fuller and movies like Stanley Kramer's" It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World"( 1963), John Cassavetes'" A Child Is Waiting"( 1963) and" Hang' Em High"( 1968).
2. He was also the director of feature films as well as numerous television programs.
3. While the majority of his directorial work is regarded as minor efforts( Leonard Maltin lists only three of his seven features in his compendium), two of his films," I Was a Teenage Werewolf"( 1957) and" I Married a Monster from Outer Space"( 1958), have gained some critical attention in retrospect.

chunks.title: Yongle Emperor
chunks.chunk:
Title: Yongle Emperor
0. The Yongle Emperor (pronounced , ; 2 May 1360 – 12 August 1424) — personal name Zhu Di
1. (WG: Chu Ti) — was the third Emperor of the Ming dynasty, reigned from 1402 to 1424.
2. Zhu Di was the fourth son of the Hongwu Emperor, the founder of the Ming dynasty.
3. He was originally enfeoffed as the Prince of Yan  in May 1370, with the capital of his princedom at Beiping (modern Beijing).
4. Amid the continuing struggle against the Mongols of the Northern Yuan dynasty, Zhu Di consolidated his own power and eliminated rivals such as the general Lan Yu.
5. He initially accepted his father's appointment of his eldest brother Zhu Biao and then his nephew Zhu Yunwen as crown prince, but when Zhu Yunwen ascended the throne as the Jianwen Emperor and began executing and demoting his powerful uncles, Zhu Di found pretext for rising in rebellion against his nephew.
6. Assisted in large part by eunuchs mistreated by the Hongwu and Jianwen Emperors, who both favored the Confucian scholar-bureaucrats, Zhu Di survived the initial attacks on his princedom and drove south to launch the Jingnan Campaign against the Jianwen Emperor in Nanjing.
7. In 1402, he successfully overthrew his nephew and occupied the imperial capital, Nanjing, after which he was proclaimed Emperor and adopted the era name Yongle, which means "perpetual happiness".
8. Eager to establish his own legitimacy, Zhu Di voided the Jianwen Emperor's reign and established a wide-ranging effort to destroy or falsify records concerning his childhood and rebellion.
9. This included a massive purge of the Confucian scholars in Nanjing and grants of extraordinary extralegal authority to the eunuch secret police.
10. One favorite was Zheng He, who employed his authority to launch major voyages of exploration into the South Pacific and Indian Oceans.
11. The difficulties in Nanjing also led the Yongle Emperor to re-establish Beiping (present-day Beijing) as the new imperial capital.
12. He repaired and reopened the Grand Canal and, between 1406 and 1420, directed the construction of the Forbidden City.
13. He was also responsible for the Porcelain Tower of Nanjing, considered one of the wonders of the world before its destruction by the Taiping rebels in 1856.
14. As part of his continuing attempt to control the Confucian scholar-bureaucrats, the Yongle Emperor also greatly expanded the imperial examination system in place of his father's use of personal recommendation and appointment.
15. These scholars completed the monumental "Yongle Encyclopedia" during his reign.
16. The Yongle Emperor died while personally leading a military campaign against the Mongols.
17. He was buried in the Changling Tomb, the central and largest mausoleum of the Ming tombs located north of Beijing.

6. No further information survives about Fulco's work in Estonia, or whether he ever even got there.

chunks.title: Tivala
chunks.chunk:
Title: Tivala
0. Tivala (born 3rd-century BC), also referred to as Tivara, was a son of Maurya Emperor Ashoka from his second queen, Karuvaki.
1. He is the only son of Ashoka who is mentioned by name in his inscriptions, along with his mother, in the Queen Edict.
2. He was the favourite child of his father and probably the crown prince , being his mother the only wife of Ashoka living in the palace advising him on his matters.
3. Tivala is the only son of Ashoka whose existence is attested by historical evidence and who was a possible successor to his father.
4. However, it seems that Tivala may have predeceased Ashoka and thus could not succeed him as Emperor.
5. Tivala is also considered to have been a favourite child of his aging father.

chunks.title: Ashoka
chunks.chunk:
Title: Ashoka
0. Ashoka (Brāhmi: 𑀅𑀲𑁄𑀓, "Asoka", IAST: Aśoka)
1. sometimes Ashoka the Great, was an Indian emperor of the Maurya Dynasty, who ruled almost all of the Indian subcontinent from to 232 BCE.
2. The grandson of the founder of the Maurya Dynasty, Chandragupta Maurya, Ashoka promoted the spread of Buddhism across ancient Asia.
3. Considered by many to be one of India's greatest emperors, Ashoka expanded Chandragupta's empire to reign over a realm stretching from present-day Afghanistan in the west to Bangladesh in the east.
4. It covered the entire Indian subcontinent except for parts of present-day Tamil Nadu, Karnataka and Kerala.
5. The empire's capital was Pataliputra (in Magadha, present-day Patna), with provincial capitals at Taxila and Ujjain.
6. Ashoka waged a destructive war against the state of Kalinga (modern Odisha), which he conquered in about 260 BCE.
7. In about 263 BCE, he converted to Buddhism after witnessing the mass deaths of the Kalinga War, which he had waged out of a desire for conquest and which reportedly directly resulted in more than 100,000 deaths and 150,000 deportations.
8. He is remembered for the Ashoka pillars and edicts, for sending Buddhist monks to Sri Lanka and Central Asia, and for establishing monuments marking several significant sites in the life of Gautama Buddha.
9. Beyond the Edicts of Ashoka, biographical information about him relies on legends written centuries later, such as the 2nd-century CE "Ashokavadana"Narrative of Ashoka, a part of the "Divyavadana"), and in the Sri Lankan text "Mahavamsa"Great Chronicle).
10. The emblem of the modern Republic of India is an adaptation of the Lion Capital of Ashoka.
11. His Sanskrit name  means "painless, without sorrow" (the "a" privativum and "śokapain, distress").
12. In his edicts, he is referred to as ' (Pali ' or "the Beloved of the Gods"), and ' (Pali ' or "He who regards everyone with affection").
13. His fondness for his name's connection to the "Saraca asoca" tree, or "Ashoka tree", is also referenced in the "Ashokavadana".
14. In "The Outline of History" (1920),
15. H.G. Wells wrote, "Amidst the tens of thousands of names of monarchs that crowd the columns of history, their majesties and graciousnesses and serenities and royal highnesses and the like, the name of Ashoka shines, and shines, almost alone, a star."

question: Who is the paternal grandmother of King Kang Of Zhou?

chunks.title: Shu Yu of Tang
chunks.chunk:
Title: Shu Yu of Tang
0. Shu Yu of Tang, surname( 姓): Ji( 姬) given name( 名): Yu( 虞), and Ziyu( 子於), was the founder of the State of Tang during the early Zhou Dynasty( 1046 – 771 BC) of ancient China.
1. The State of Tang would later be renamed Jin by Shu Yu's son and successor, Xie.
2. He was the son of King Wu of Zhou and the younger brother of King Cheng of Zhou.
3. Shortly after the establishment of the Zhou Dynasty, King Wu of Zhou died.
4. His son, Prince Song, ascended the throne and became King Cheng of Zhou.
5. Since he was very young and too inexperienced to run the newly founded dynasty, his uncle, the Duke of Zhou, served as regent and handled all political affairs until King Cheng of Zhou became old enough to rule.
6. In the year that King Cheng of Zhou ascended the throne, the people of a land called Tang( 唐) rebelled, so the Duke of Zhou conquered them.
7. According to the Records of the Grand Historian, one day, King Cheng of Zhou was playing with his younger brother, Prince Yu. King Cheng of Zhou suddenly picked up a parasol tree leaf and gave it to Prince Yu.
8. Then he said playfully," Let this be a proof that I will make you a feudal lord."
9. Prince
10. Yu happily got the leaf and he then told this to the Duke of Zhou.
11. The Duke of Zhou thought that whatever the young King Cheng of Zhou said should not be taken lightly since he was the king.
12. The Duke of Zhou approached the young king and asked him if it were true.
13. The young king said that he was just joking with his brother.
14. Then the Duke of Zhou replied," A sovereign must not joke about the things he says and do as what he has said."
15. The young king thought it was reasonable and gave the recent conquered called Tang land, west of modern Yicheng County in Shanxi, to his brother, Prince Yu. Shu Yu's son and successor, Xie, moved the capital Jiang( 绛) nearer to the Jin River and renamed the state Jin.
16. Jinci was a shrine in Taiyuan dedicated to Shu Yu.
17. It is a major historical and cultural site protected at the national level in People's republic of China.

chunks.title: King Kang of Zhou
chunks.chunk:
Title: King Kang of Zhou
0. King Kang of Zhou  or King K’ang of Chou was the third sovereign of the Chinese Zhou Dynasty and son of the King Cheng of Zhou.
1. The dates of his reign are 1020-996 BC or 1005–978 BC.
2. King Kang followed his father King Cheng’s policy and expanded the Zhou territory in the North and in the West.
3. He also repressed a rebellion in the east.
4. Life prospered in the Zhou Dynasty under Kang’s rule.
5. His was succeeded by his son King Zhao of Zhou.

chunks.title: Duke Ding of Qi
chunks.chunk:
Title: Duke Ding of Qi
0. Duke Ding of Qi (reigned c. 10th century BC) was the second recorded ruler of the ancient Chinese state of Qi during the Western Zhou Dynasty.
1. His personal name was Lü Ji (呂伋) and
2. ancestral name was Jiang (姜).
3. According to classical Chinese texts such as the "Records of the Grand Historian" and "Zuo Zhuan", Duke Ding succeeded his father Lü Shang, Duke Tai of Qi, who was said to have been a centenarian.
4. Duke Ding supposedly served King Kang of Zhou along with other major vassal state rulers including Xiong Yi, viscount of Chu, Count Kang of Wey (衞康伯), Xie, Marquis of Jin and Boqin, Duke of Lu.
5. However, most modern historians believe Duke Ding was in fact the fifth-generation descendant of Duke Tai, and he could not have served King Kang of Zhou.
6. After Duke Ding died, he was succeeded by his son Duke Yǐ of Qi.

chunks.title: King Cheng of Zhou
chunks.chunk:
Title: King Cheng of Zhou
0. King Cheng of Zhou  or King Ch'eng of Chou was the second king of the Chinese Zhou Dynasty.
1. The dates of his reign are 1042-1021 BCE or 1042/35-1006 BCE.
2. His parents were King Wu of Zhou and Queen Yi Jiang (邑姜).
3. King Cheng was young when he ascended the throne.
4. His uncle, Duke of Zhou, fearing that Shang forces might rise again under the possible weak rule of a young ruler, became the regent and supervised government affairs for several years.
5. Duke of Zhou established the eastern capital at Luoyang, and later defeated a rebellion by Cheng
6. ’s
7. uncles Cai Shu, Guan Shu and Huo Shu.
8. King Cheng later stabilized Zhou Dynasty’s border by defeating several barbarian tribes along with the Duke of Zhou.

1. It was the fourth film in a series, and was preceded by" The Vengeance of Fu Manchu The Castle of Fu Manchu" followed in 1969.

chunks.title: Robert Florey
chunks.chunk:
Title: Robert Florey
0. Robert Florey( 14 September 1900 – 16 May 1979) was a French- American director, screenwriter, film journalist and actor.
1. Born as Robert Fuchs in Paris, he became an orphan at an early age and was then raised in Switzerland.
2. In 1920 he worked at first as a film journalist, then as an assistant and extra in featurettes from Louis Feuillade.
3. Florey moved to the United States in 1921.
4. As a director, Florey's most productive decades were the 1930s and 1940s, working on relatively low- budget fillers for Paramount and Warner Brothers.
5. His reputation is balanced between his avant- garde expressionist style, most evident in his early career, and his work as a fast, reliable studio- system director called on to finish troubled projects, such as 1939's" Hotel Imperial".
6. He directed more than 50 movies.
7. His most popular film is likely the first Marx Brothers feature" The Cocoanuts" of 1929, and his 1932 foray into Universal- style horror," Murders in the Rue Morgue" is regarded by horror fans as highly reflective of German expressionism.
8. In 2006, as his 1937 film" Daughter of Shanghai" was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry by the Library of Congress, Florey was called" widely acclaimed as the best director working in major studio B-films".

chunks.title: Right to know
chunks.chunk:
Title: Right to know
0. " Right to know", in the context of United States workplace and community environmental law, is the legal principle that the individual has the right to know the chemicals to which they may be exposed in their daily living.
1. It is embodied in federal law in the United States as well as in local laws in several states.
2. " Right to Know" laws take two forms: Community Right to Know and Workplace Right to Know.
3. Each grants certain rights to those groups.
4. The" right to know" concept is included in Rachel Carson's book" Silent Spring".
5. Environmental illness shares characteristics with common diseases.
6. For example, cyanide exposure symptoms include weakness, headache, nausea, confusion, dizziness, seizures, cardiac arrest, and unconsciousness.
7. Influenza and heart disease include the same symptoms.
8. Cyanide is one of the most toxic known substances, and failure to obtain proper disclosure is likely to lead to improper or ineffective medical diagnosis and treatment.
9. This can contribute to prolonged illness and death.

chunks.title: Ręce do góry
chunks.chunk:
Title: Ręce do góry
0. Ręce do góry (known in its subtitled English version as Hands Up!) is a Polish drama film directed by Jerzy Skolimowski.
1. It is the fourth of a series of semi-autobiographical films in which Skolimowski himself plays his "alter ego", Andrzej Leszczyc.
2. At the time it was banned in Poland, under the Communist regime, for 18 years because it depicted the Stalinist past.
3. The film was originally made in 1967 in monochrome by studio.
4. In a twenty-minute section (filmed in colour) added by Skolimowski in 1981 he explains how the original was withheld by Polish censors of the time, and that this was a principal cause of
5. his leaving his country; however following liberalisation in Poland, he was invited to resuscitate it.
6. The introduction includes, apart from some fictional apocalyptic passages, shots of Beirut ruined by the civil wars of the 1970s, where Skolimowski is working as an actor on Volker Schloendorff's German film "Die Fälschung (Circle of Deceit)", and also shots of London featuring demonstrations in favour of "Solidarnosc", Speaker's Corner, and an exhibition of Skolimowski's own paintings.
7. These sections include cameo roles by Bruno Ganz, David Essex, Mike Sarne and others.
8. Some of the music in this introduction is from the 1970 choral work "Kosmogonia" by the Polish composer Krzysztof Penderecki.
9. The original film is a surrealistic reunion of Leszczyc (who has apparently become a veterinary surgeon) and some of his student colleagues.
10. They refer to themselves by the makes of the cars they own
11. - Leszczyc owns a Zastawa, one owns a Wartburg, the others own more upmarket models such as an Opel Rekord or the Alfa Romeo owned by the unhappily married couple.
12. Supposedly taking speed (although it is later revealed the pills are a placebo), and carousing in the cattle truck of a freight train, the group offers various satirical sidelights on Polish society of the 1960s.
13. The characters also reflect that the truck may have been one of those in which the former generation were transported during World War II to the Nazi death camps.
14. The final credits show the actors as they are in 1981, with the exception of Bogumil Kobiela, who died in 1969.
15. The film was screened out of competition at the 1981 Cannes Film Festival.

chunks.title: Vivien Leigh
chunks.chunk:
Title: Vivien Leigh
0. Vivien Leigh , born Vivian Mary Hartley and styled as Lady Olivier after 1947 (5 November 1913 – 8 July 1967) was a British stage and film actress.
1. She won two Academy Awards for Best Actress, for her definitive performances as Scarlett O'Hara in "Gone with the Wind" (1939) and Blanche DuBois in the film version of "A Streetcar
2. Named Desire" (1951), a role she had also played on stage in London's West End in 1949.
3. She also won a Tony Award for her work in the Broadway musical version of "Tovarich" (1963).
4. After completing her drama school education, Leigh appeared in small roles in four films in 1935 and progressed to the role of heroine in "Fire Over England" (1937).
5. Lauded for her beauty, Leigh felt that her physical attributes sometimes prevented her from being taken seriously as an actress.
6. Despite her fame as a screen actress, Leigh was primarily a stage performer.
7. During her 30-year career, she played roles ranging from the heroines of Noël Coward and George Bernard Shaw comedies to classic Shakespearean characters such as Ophelia, Cleopatra, Juliet, and Lady Macbeth.
8. Later in life, she performed as a character actress in a few films.
9. At the time, the public strongly identified Leigh with her second husband, Laurence Olivier, who was her spouse from 1940 to 1960.
10. Leigh and Olivier starred together in many stage productions, with Olivier often directing, and in three films.
11. She earned a reputation for being difficult to work with, and for much of her adult life, she suffered from bipolar disorder, as well as recurrent bouts of chronic tuberculosis, which was first diagnosed in the mid-1940s and ultimately claimed her life at the age of 53.
12. Although her career had periods of inactivity, in 1999 the American Film Institute ranked Leigh as the 16th greatest female movie star of classic Hollywood cinema.

chunks.title: Sennedjem
chunks.chunk:
Title: Sennedjem
0. The Ancient Egyptian artisan Sennedjem lived in Set Maat( translated as" The Place of Truth"), contemporary Deir el- Medina, on the west bank of the Nile, opposite Thebes, during the reigns of Seti I and Ramesses II.
1. Sennedjem had the title" Servant in the Place of Truth".
2. He was buried along with his wife, Iyneferti, and family in a tomb in the village necropolis.
3. His tomb was discovered January 31, 1886.
4. When Sennedjem's tomb was found, in it there was regular furniture from his home, including a stool and a bed, which he actually used when he was alive.
5. His titles included Servant in the Place of Truth, meaning that he worked on the excavation and decoration of the nearby royal tombs.

chunks.title: Place of birth
chunks.chunk:
Title: Place of birth
0. The place of birth( POB) or birthplace is the place where a person was born.
1. This place is often used in legal documents, together with name and date of birth, to uniquely identify a person.
2. As a general rule with respect to passports, the place of birth is determined to be the country that currently has" sovereignty" over the actual place of birth, regardless of when the birth actually occurred.
3. The place of birth is not necessarily the place where the parents of the new baby live.
4. If the baby is born in a hospital in another place, that place is the place of birth.
5. In many countries, this also means that the government requires that the birth of the new baby is registered in the place of birth.
6. Some countries place less or no importance on the place of birth, instead using alternative geographical characteristics for the purpose of identity documents.
7. For example, Sweden has used the concept of" födelsehemortdomicile of birth") since 1947.
8. This means that the domicile of the baby's mother is the registered place of birth.
9. The location of the maternity ward or other physical birthplace is considered unimportant.
10. Similarly, Switzerland uses the concept of" Heimatortlieu d'origineluogo d'origineplace of origin" in German, French and Italian respectively).
11. A child born to Swiss parents is automatically assigned the place of origin of the parent with the same last name, so the child either gets their mother's or father's place of origin.
12. A child born to one Swiss parent and one foreign parent acquires the place of origin of their Swiss parent.
13. In a Swiss passport and identity card, the holder's place of origin is stated, not their place of birth.
14. In some countries( primarily in the Americas), the place of birth automatically determines the nationality of the baby, a practice often referred to by the Latin phrase" jus soli".
15. Almost all countries outside the Americas instead attribute nationality based on the nationality( ies) of the baby's parents( referred to as" jus sanguinis").
16. There can be some confusion regarding the place of birth if the birth takes place in an unusual way: when babies are born on an airplane or at sea, difficulties can arise.
17. The place of birth of such a person depends on the law of the countries involved, which include the nationality of the plane or ship, the nationality( ies) of the parents and/ or the location of the plane or ship( if the birth occurs in the territorial waters or airspace of a country).
18. Some administrative forms may request the applicant's" country of birth".
19. It is important to determine from the requester whether the information requested refers to the applicant's" place of birth" or" nationality at birth".
20. For US citizens born abroad who under the US Constitution acquire US citizenship at the time of birth, the nationality at birth will be USA( American), while the place of birth would be the country in which the actual birth takes place.

chunks.title: American Sniper
chunks.chunk:
Title: American Sniper
0. American Sniper is a 2014 American biographical war drama film directed by Clint Eastwood and written by Jason Hall.
1. It is loosely based on the memoir" American Sniper: The Autobiography of the Most Lethal Sniper in U.S. Military History"( 2012) by Chris Kyle, with Scott McEwen and Jim DeFelice.
2. The film follows the life of Kyle, who became the deadliest marksman in U.S. military history with 255 kills from four tours in the Iraq War, 160 of which were officially confirmed by the Department of Defense.
3. While Kyle was celebrated for his military successes, his tours of duty took a heavy toll on his personal and family life.
4. The film was produced by Eastwood, Robert Lorenz, Andrew Lazar, Bradley Cooper, and Peter Morgan.
5. It stars Cooper as Kyle and Sienna Miller as his wife Taya, with Luke Grimes, Jake McDorman, Cory Hardrict, Kevin Lacz, Navid Negahban, and Keir O'Donnell in supporting roles.
6. The world premiere was on November 11, 2014, at the American Film Institute Festival, followed by a limited theatrical release in the United States on December 25, 2014, and a wide release on January 16, 2015.
7. The film became a major success, with a worldwide gross of over$ 547 million, making it the highest- grossing film of 2014 in the United States($ 350 million), the highest- grossing war film of all time unadjusted for inflation, and Eastwood's highest- grossing film to date.
8. The film received mostly positive reviews, with praise for towards Cooper's lead performance and Eastwood's direction, although it attracted some controversy over its portrayal of both the War in Iraq and Chris Kyle.
9. At the 87th Academy Awards," American Sniper" received six nominations, including Best Picture, Best Adapted Screenplay, and Best Actor for Cooper, ultimately winning one award for Best Sound Editing.

chunks.title: Clint Eastwood
chunks.chunk:
Title: Clint Eastwood
0. Clinton Eastwood Jr.( born May 31, 1930) is an American actor, filmmaker, musician, and politician.
1. After achieving success in the Western TV series" Rawhide", he rose to international fame with his role as the Man with No Name in Italian filmmaker Sergio Leone's" Dollars" Trilogy of spaghetti Westerns during the 1960s and as antihero cop Harry Callahan in the five" Dirty Harry" films throughout the 1970s and 1980s.
2. These roles, among others, have made Eastwood an enduring cultural icon of masculinity.
3. For his work in the Western film" Unforgiven"( 1992) and the sports drama" Million Dollar Baby"( 2004), Eastwood won Academy Awards for Best Director and Best Picture, as well as receiving nominations for Best Actor.
4. Eastwood's greatest commercial successes have been the adventure comedy" Every Which Way But Loose"( 1978) and it s sequel, the action comedy" Any Which Way You Can"( 1980), after adjustment for inflation.
5. Other popular films include the Western" Hang' Em High"( 1968), the psychological thriller" Play Misty for Me"( 1971), the crime film" Thunderbolt and Lightfoot"( 1974), the Western" The Outlaw Josey Wales"( 1976), the prison film" Escape from Alcatraz"( 1979), the action film" Firefox"( 1982), the suspense thriller" Tightrope"( 1984), the Western" Pale Rider"( 1985), the war films" Where Eagles Dare"( 1968)," Kelly's Heroes"( 1970), and" Heartbreak Ridge"( 1986), the action thriller" In the Line of Fire"( 1993), the romantic drama" The Bridges of Madison County"( 1995), and the drama" Gran Torino"( 2008).
6. In addition to directing many of his own star vehicles, Eastwood has also directed films in which he did not appear, such as the mystery drama" Mystic River"( 2003) and the war film" Letters from Iwo Jima"( 2006), for which he received Academy Award nominations, the drama" Changeling"( 2008), and the South African biographical political sports drama" Invictus"( 2009).
7. The war drama biopic" American Sniper"( 2014) set box- office records for the largest January release ever and was also the largest opening ever for an Eastwood film.
8. Eastwood received considerable critical praise in France for several films, including some that were not well received in the United States.
9. Eastwood has been awarded two of France's highest honors: in 1994, he became a recipient of the Commander of the Ordre des Arts et des Lettres, and in 2007, he was awarded the Legion of Honour medal.
10. In 2000, Eastwood was awarded the Italian Venice Film Festival Golden Lion for lifetime achievement.
11. Since 1967, Eastwood's Malpaso Productions has produced all but four of his American films.
12. Elected in 1986, Eastwood served for two years as mayor of Carmel- by- the- Sea, California, a non-partisan office.

Title: Befikre
0. Befikre is a 2016 Indian Hindi- language romantic comedy- drama film written, directed, and produced by Aditya Chopra under his banner of Yash Raj Films.
1. It features Ranveer Singh and Vaani Kapoor in the lead roles.
2. The film was shot over a period of 50 days in Paris and Mumbai.
3. It released worldwide on 9 December 2016 to mixed reviews.
4. The film's songs has been composed by Vishal- Shekhar and produced by Mikey McCleary with Vishal- Shekhar.
5. McCleary also composed the background score of the movie.
6. This is Chopra's only directorial venture without Shah Rukh Khan in the lead role.

2. Morgan has served as an executive producer for films including "Identity ThiefKillers", and the "Poison Ivy" trilogy, and as a producer of "Spread" and "American Sniper".

chunks.title: Aditya Chopra
chunks.chunk:
Title: Aditya Chopra
0. Aditya Chopra( born 21 May 1971) is an Indian filmmaker.
1. His work as a director includes" Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge"( 1995)," Mohabbatein"( 2000)," Rab Ne Bana Di Jodi"( 2008) and" Befikre"( 2016).
2. He is also the current Chairman of India's multi-national film, media and entertainment conglomerate Yash Raj Films( YRF).
3. Chopra has written and produced a number of films under the banner such as" Veer- Zaara"( 2004)," Fanaa"( 2006)," Band Baaja Baaraat"( 2010)," Jab Tak Hai Jaan"( 2012), the" Dhoom series"( 2004, 2006& 2013)," Sultan"( 2016), the" Tiger series"( 2012& 2017) and" War"( 2019).
4. He has broken away from typecast through production of off- beat films such as" Kabul Express"( 2006)," Chak De! India"( 2007),( 2009)," Dum Laga Ke Haisha"( 2015) and" Hichki!"( 2018), that do not necessarily fit into the realm of" masala films".
5. Chopra is also the first to move towards a true film studio model through independent projects helmed by talent under his banner.
6. Major post-production work of the company is now carried out of YRF Studios( co- founded by his ex-wife Payal Khanna), where Chopra serves as Chief Executive.
7. He has produced ten films that have accumulated worldwide gross earnings of more than 200 crore, which is the most for an Indian film producer.
8. In December 2009, Chopra fought a hostile acquisition bid by Walt Disney, valued upwards of 2500 crore, to remain and continue purely as a domestic entity aided by the Tata Sons.
9. Apart from emerging as an equitable brand, his company has earned the status of a movie mogul through distribution networks spread across the globe, estimated to be net worth 7640 crore( FY17/18) by the NSE, thereby making it the biggest and most successful film production company in the history of Indian Cinema.
10. Having denied him admission into the NSD as a young applicant, the Directorate of Film Festivals eventually honored him with the National Award for his achievements in 1995, 2005, 2007 and 2015.
11. The Government of India appealed both Chopra and Mani Ratnam to focus on content created locally under its Make in India initiative, which was later followed by productions like" Daawat- e- Ishq"( 2014)," Meri Pyaari Bindu"( 2016)," Sui- Dhaaga"( 2018) and" Jayeshbhai Jordaar"( 2020) planned by his company.
12. In June 2018, he was awarded membership into The Academy by the Producers Guild of America.
13. Widely regarded as one of the most influential and powerful executives in Indian entertainment, Chopra has however rejected the publicity and fame that came with being Yash Chopra's son and the Chief Executive of Yash Raj Films.
14. He has remained extremely media -shy and a passive individual, battling constant reports of an alleged dysthymic disorder throughout his three- decade career, resulting in very few public photos of him being in existence.

His work for" Vanity Fair" included Pope Leo XIII, Giuseppe Garibaldi, Umberto I of Italy, William Henry Waddington, all in 1878, Charles Gounod, Giuseppe Verdi, Ernest Renan, Jules Grévy, Napoléon Joseph Charles Paul Bonaparte, Victor Hugo, Marshal MacMahon, Granier de Cassagnac, Louis Blanc, and Alexandre Dumas" fils", all in 1879.

chunks.title: Etan Boritzer

Title: Etan Boritzer
0. Etan Boritzer( born 1950) is an American writer of children ’s literature who is best known for his book" What is God?" first published in 1989.
1. His best selling" What is?" illustrated children's book series on character education and difficult subjects for children is a popular teaching guide for parents, teachers and child- life professionals.
2. Boritzer gained national critical acclaim after" What is God?" was published in 1989 although the book has caused controversy from religious fundamentalists for its universalist views.
3. The other current books in the" What is?" series include
4. What is Love?,
5. What is Death?,
6. What is Beautiful?,
7. What is Funny?,
8. What is Right?,
9. What is Peace?,
10. What is Money?,
11. What is Dreaming?,
12. What is a Friend?,
13. What is True?,
14. What is a Family?,
15. What is a Feeling?"
16. The series is now also translated into 15 languages.
17. Boritzer was first published in 1963 at the age of 13 when he wrote an essay in his English class at Wade Junior High School in the Bronx, New York on the assassination of John F. Kennedy.
18. His essay was included in a special anthology by New York City public school children compiled and published by the New York City Department of Education.
19. Boritzer now lives in Venice, California and maintains his publishing office there also.
20. He has helped numerous other authors to get published through" How to Get Your Book Published!" programs.
21. Boritzer is also a yoga teacher who teaches regular classes locally and guest- teaches nationally.
22. He is also recognized nationally as an erudite speaker on" The Teachings of the Buddha."

chunks.title: Prince Napoléon Bonaparte
chunks.chunk:
Title: Prince Napoléon Bonaparte
0. Napoléon Joseph Charles Paul Bonaparte (9 September 1822 – 17 March 1891), usually called Napoléon-Jérôme Bonaparte or Jérôme Bonaparte, was the second son of Jerome, King of Westphalia and his second wife Catharina of Württemberg.
1. An oustpoken liberal, he became the "de facto" head of the House of Bonaparte from 1879 to his death.
2. He wasn't considered a legitimate pretender to the throne by many Bonapartists, due to his fathers previous marriage without divorce.
3. They instead preferred his son Victor.
4. From the 1880s he was one of the stronger supporters of General Georges Boulanger, together with other monarchist forces.
5. As well as bearing the title of Prince Napoléon, given him by his cousin Emperor Napoleon III in 1852,
he was also 3rd Prince of Montfort, 1st Count of Meudon and Count of Moncalieri, following his marriage with Maria Clotilde of Savoy in 1859.
6. His popular nickname, Plon-Plon, stemmed from his difficulty in pronouncing his own name while still a child.

question: Where did William S. Burroughs Jr.'s father study?

chunks.title: William S. Burroughs Jr.
chunks.chunk:
Title: William S. Burroughs Jr.
0. William Seward Burroughs III (July 21, 1947 – March 3, 1981) was an American novelist, also known as William S. Burroughs Jr. and Billy Burroughs.
1. He bears the name of both his father and his great grandfather, William Seward Burroughs I, the original inventor of the Burroughs adding machine.
2. He wrote three novels, two of which were published as "Speed" (1970) and "Kentucky Ham" (1973).
3. His third novel, "Prakriti Junction," begun in 1977, was never completed, although extracts from it were included in his third and final published work "Cursed From Birth".
4. Burroughs Jr. underwent a liver transplant in 1976 after developing cirrhosis.
5. He died in 1981, at the age of 33, from alcoholism and liver failure.
6. Burroughs Jr. appears briefly in the 1983 documentary , about his father, in which he discusses his childhood, his liver problems, and his relationship with his family.
7. In the documentary, John Giorno calls him "the last beatnik."

chunks.title: William S. Burroughs
chunks.chunk:
Title: William S. Burroughs
0. William Seward Burroughs II (February 5, 1914 – August 2, 1997) was an American writer and visual artist.
1. Burroughs was a primary figure of the Beat Generation and a major postmodernist author whose influence is considered to have affected a range of popular culture as well as literature.
2. Burroughs wrote eighteen novels and novellas, six collections of short stories and four collections of essays.
3. Five books have been published of his interviews and correspondences.
4. He also collaborated on projects and recordings with numerous performers and musicians and made many appearances in films.
5. He was also briefly known by the pen name William Lee.
6. Burroughs created and exhibited thousands of paintings and other visual artworks, including his celebrated 'Gunshot Paintings'.
7. He was born into a wealthy family in St. Louis, Missouri, grandson of the inventor and founder of the Burroughs Corporation, William Seward Burroughs I, and nephew of public relations manager Ivy Lee.
8. Burroughs began writing essays and journals in early adolescence but did not begin publicizing his writing until his thirties.
9. He left home in 1932 to attend Harvard University, studied English, and anthropology as a postgraduate, and later attended medical school in Vienna.
10. In 1942 Burroughs enlisted in the U.S. Army to serve during World War II, but was turned down by the Office of Strategic Services and Navy, after which he picked up the drug addiction that affected him for the rest of his life, while working a variety of jobs.
11. In 1943, while living in New York City, he befriended Allen Ginsberg and Jack Kerouac, and out of their mutual influence grew the foundation of the Beat Generation, which was later a defining influence on the 1960s counterculture.
12. Much of Burroughs' work is semiautobiographical, primarily drawn from his experiences as a heroin addict, as he lived throughout Mexico City, London, Paris and the Tangier International Zone near Morocco, as well as from his travels in the South American Amazon.
13. His work also features frequent mystical, occult or otherwise magical themes – a constant preoccupation for Burroughs, both in fiction and in real life.
14. Burroughs killed his second wife, Joan Vollmer, in 1951 in Mexico City.
15. Burroughs initially claimed that he shot Vollmer while drunkenly attempting a "William Tell" stunt.
16. He later told investigators a different story: that he had been showing his pistol to friends, when it fell and hit the table, firing the bullet that killed Vollmer.
17. After Burroughs returned to the United States, he was convicted of manslaughter "in absentia", and received a two-year suspended sentence.
18. Burroughs found success with his confessional first novel, "Junkie" (1953), but he is perhaps best known for his third novel "Naked Lunch" (1959), a highly controversial work that was the subject of a court case after it was challenged as being in violation of the U.S. sodomy laws.
19. With Brion Gysin, he also popularized the literary cut-up technique in works such as The Nova Trilogy (1961–1964).
20. In 1983, Burroughs was elected to the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters, and in 1984 he was awarded the Ordre des Arts et des Lettres by France.
21. Jack Kerouac called Burroughs the "greatest satirical writer since Jonathan Swift", a reputation he owes to his "lifelong subversion" of the moral, political, and economic systems of modern American society, articulated in often darkly humorous sardonicism.
22. J. G. Ballard considered Burroughs to be "the most important writer to emerge since the Second World War", while Norman Mailer declared him "the only American writer who may be conceivably possessed by genius".
23. Burroughs created visual art throughout his lifetime, but never exhibited it until 1987, after the death of his friend and collaborator Brion Gysin.
24. For the next and last 10 years of his life, he presented his paintings and drawings at museums and galleries worldwide.
25. Burroughs had one child, William S. Burroughs Jr. (1947–1981), with his second wife Joan Vollmer.
26. William Burroughs died at his home in Lawrence, Kansas, after suffering a heart attack in 1997.

Title: Sobhuza I
0. Sobhuza I (also known as Ngwane IV, Somhlolo) (ca. 1780–1836) was king of Swaziland, from 1815 to 1836.
1. Born around 1780, his father was Ndvungunye (also known as "Zikodze"), and his mother was Somnjalose Simelane.
2. He was called Somhlolo, "the Wonder," upon his birth because his father Ndvungunye died as a result of being struck by lightning.
3. When Sobhuza was king, Lojiba Simelane instead of his mother Somnjalose was Queen Mother because Somnjalose was an "inhlanti" or support bride to Lojiba.
4. Somhlolo is a greatly revered king of Swaziland.
5. He had his first royal capital or kraal at Zombodze in the Shiselweni region, but moved it north to new Zombodze in central Swaziland.
6. Swazis celebrate Somhlolo Day every September 6 as their Independence Day and the national stadium is named Somhlolo stadium.
7. Sobhuza was succeeded by his son Mswati II and his wife Tsandzile Ndwandwe as Queen Mother after a short regency by Queen Lojiba Simelane.
8. Sobhuza by the time of his death a conquered a country claimed to be reaching modern day Barberton in the north, Carolina in the west, Pongola River in the south and Lubombo Mountains in the east.

2. Together with Mabel Anette Plahte( 1877 – 1973, a daughter of Frithjof M. Plahte) he had the son Hans Barthold Andresen Butenschøn Jr. and was through him the father- in- law of Ragnhild Butenschøn and grandfather of Peter Butenschøn.
3. Through his daughter Marie Claudine he was the father- in- law of Joakim Lehmkuhl, through his daughter Mabel Anette he was the father- in- law of Harald Astrup( a son of Sigurd Astrup) and through his daughter Nini Augusta he was the father- in- law of Ernst Torp.
4. He took commerce school and agricultural school.
5. He was hired in the family company N. A. Andresen& Co, and became a co-owner in 1910.
6. He eventually became chief executive officer.
7. The bank changed its name to Andresens Bank in 1913 and merged with Bergens Kreditbank in 1920.
8. The merger was dissolved later in the 1920s.
9. He was also a landowner, owning Nedre Skøyen farm and a lot of land in Enebakk.
10. He chaired the board of Nydalens Compagnie from 1926, having not been a board member before that.
11. He also chaired the supervisory council of Forsikringsselskapet Viking and Nedre Glommen salgsforening, and was a supervisory council member of Filharmonisk Selskap.
12. He was a member of the gentlemen's club SK Fram since 1890, and was proclaimed a lifetime member in 1964.

8. "It's Oh
9. So QuietArmy of Me", and "Hyperballad".
10. In 2004, Björk released her fifth studio album, "Medúlla", followed by her sixth studio album, "Volta", in May 2007.
11. Björk is reported to have sold between 20 and 40 million records worldwide .
12. She has won the 2010 Polar Music Prize from the Royal Swedish Academy of Music in recognition of her "deeply personal music and lyrics, her precise arrangements, and her unique voice.
13. "
14. Björk was included in "Time"'s 2015 list of the 100 most influential people in the world.
15. She was ranked both sixtieth and eighty-first in "Rolling Stone"
16. 's 100 greatest singers and songwriters lists respectively.
17. She has also won five BRIT Awards and has been nominated for 15 Grammy Awards.
18. Björk's ninth studio album, "Utopia", was released in November 2017 through One Little Indian Records.
19. Outside her music career, Björk starred in the 2000 Lars von Trier film "Dancer in the Dark", for which she won the Best Actress Award at the 2000 Cannes Film Festival, and was nominated for Academy Award for Best Original Song for
20. "I've Seen It All".
21. Her 2011 album "Biophilia" was marketed as an interactive app album with its own education program.
22. Björk has also been an advocate for environmental causes in her home country Iceland.
23. A full-scale retrospective exhibition dedicated to Björk was held at the New York Museum of Modern Art in 2015.
