chunks.title: Hunter (Björk song)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Hunter (Björk song)
0. "Hunter" is a song recorded by Icelandic musician Björk for her third studio album "Homogenic" (1997).
1. The lyrics explore the pressure Björk felt to write music after realising the workforce that depended on her, following the success she found as a solo artist with her previous studio albums.
2. The song was first performed at the 1997 Tibetan Freedom Concert and later included with the online promotional release of "Homogenic"; the track was subsequently released as the third single for the album as three different CD releases in October 1998.
3. A collaborative effort between Björk and Mark Bell, "Hunter" features a dark combination of strings and layered synths, a militaristic electronic beat, and enigmatic lyrics about the heading towards a mission.
4. Most music critics were enticed by "Hunter", which they declared one of the highlights of the "Homogenic" album.
5. The single charted poorly, peaking at number 44 on the UK Singles Chart and number 55 on the French Singles Chart.
6. The song was included in the compilation album "Greatest Hits" (2002), whose tracks were selected by fans through a survey.
7. The accompanying music video for "Hunter" was directed by longtime collaborator Paul White of Me Company and consists of a close-up of a bald Björk as she transforms into a "techno-bear" while singing.
8. Seeking to convey the music's fusion of organic and technological, the polar bear was animated in a non-naturalistic fashion; the bear also embodies the ferocious hunter the lyrics represent.
9. The song's video garnered acclaim from critics.
10. Björk has performed "Hunter" on " Later... with Jools Holland" and in five of her tours, the most recent being the Vulnicura Tour.

Title: Richard Beauchamp, 1st Earl of Worcester
0. Richard de Beauchamp, 1st Earl of Worcester, KCB (c. 1394 – c. 18 March 1421/1422) was an English peer.
1. The only son of William de Beauchamp, 1st Baron Bergavenny, he succeeded as 2nd Baron Bergavenny at the death of his father on 8 May 1411.
2. On 27 July 1411, he married Lady Isabel le Despenser, daughter of Thomas le Despenser, 1st Earl of Gloucester, and great-granddaughter of Edward III.
3. They had one child, Lady Elizabeth de Beauchamp, later 3rd Baroness Bergavenny, who married Sir Edward Neville, later 1st Baron Bergavenny.
4. He was joint Warden of the Welsh Marches in 1415, and a captain of lances and archers in Normandy in 1418.
5. In February 1420/1, he was created Earl of Worcester.
6. Worcester was mortally wounded on 18 March 1421/2 at the Siege of Meaux and died soon after.
7. His body was taken back to England and he was buried on 25 April 1422 at Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire.
8. His daughter inherited his estates and his barony of Bergavenny, although the castle and honour of Abergavenny were still held by her grandmother in dower.

0. William de Beauchamp, 1st Baron Bergavenny, KG
1. (c. 1343 – 8 May 1411) was an English peer.
2. Beauchamp was the fourth son of Thomas de Beauchamp, 11th Earl of Warwick, and Katherine Mortimer.
3. He served under Sir John Chandos during the Hundred Years' War, and was created a Knight of the Garter in 1376.
4. He served as Captain of Calais in 1383.
5. Upon the death of his first cousin once removed, John Hastings, 3rd Earl of Pembroke on 30 December 1389, William inherited the lordship of Abergavenny, including Abergavenny Castle.
6. He was summoned to Parliament on 23 July 1392 as "Willilmo Beauchamp de Bergavenny", by which he is held to have become Baron Bergavenny, a barony by writ.
7. In 1399, he was appointed Justiciar of South Wales and Governor of Pembroke.
8. He entailed the castle and Honour of Abergavenny on the issue male of his body, with remainder to his brother Thomas de Beauchamp, 12th Earl of Warwick and his heirs male; his wife enjoyed it in dower until her death in 1435.
9. Bergavenny died in 1411 and was buried at Black Friars, Hereford.

1. From 13 November 1750 to 1766 he was the Captain- General of the Netherlands, where he was known as the Duke of Brunswick or( to distinguish him from his eldest brother Charles, who succeeded to their father's title of Duke of Brunswick- Lüneburg) Duke of Brunswick- Wolfenbüttel.
2. Another brother was Duke Ferdinand of Brunswick who led the Allied Anglo- German army during the Seven Years' War.

chunks.title: Augustus William Lumley-Savile

Title: Augustus William Lumley-Savile
0. Augustus William Lumley- Savile, renamed Augustus William Savile in 1881,( 1829, London – 13 April 1887, Cannes) was an English landowner and Her Majesty's Assistant Master of the Ceremonies.
1. John Lumley- Savile, 8th Earl of Scarbrough was Augustus William Lumley- Savile's father.
2. Lord Scarbrough never married but engendered five natural children, four sons and one daughter.
3. The earl bequeathed the family estates to his second son Captain Henry Lumley( d. 1881), and on Captain Lumley's death the estates passed to Augustus William Lumley- Savile, who was the youngest of the four sons.
4. In 1883 the family estates consisted of 17,820 acres in Nottinghamshire and 16,000 acres in the West Riding of Yorkshire.
5. The principal residence was Rufford Abbey, near Ollerton.
6. In 1847 Augustus William Lumley- Saville matriculated at Corpus Christi College, Oxford.
7. On 23 November 1849 he became a cornet in a cavalry regiment, the 2nd Regiment of Life Guards.
8. In 1881 by royal licence he dropped the name of Lumley.
9. He served as Queen Victoria's assistant- master of ceremonies from 1881 until his death.
10. When Augustus William Savile died in 1887 the family estates were inherited by his brother John Lumley- Savile, who assumed the surname of Savile only.

chunks.title: William, Duke of Brunswick
chunks.chunk:
Title: William, Duke of Brunswick
0. William, Duke of Brunswick( 25 April 1806 – 18 October 1884), was ruling duke of the Duchy of Brunswick from 1830 until his death.
1. William was the second son of Frederick William, Duke of Brunswick- Lüneburg, and after the death of his father in 1815, was under the guardianship of King George IV of the United Kingdom.
2. He became a Prussian major in 1823.
3. When his brother, Charles, was deposed as ruling duke by a rebellion in 1830, William took over the government provisionally.
4. In 1831, a family law of the House of Guelph made William the ruling duke permanently.
5. William left most government business to his ministers, and he spent most of his time outside of his state at his possessions in Oels.
6. While William joined the Prussian- led North German Confederation in 1866, his relationship to Prussia was strained, since Prussia refused to recognize Ernest Augustus, Crown Prince of Hanover, his nearest male- line relative, as his heir, because of the Duke of Cumberland's claim to the throne of Hanover.
7. William died in 1884; he passed on his private possessions to the Duke of Cumberland.
8. His death caused a constitutional crisis for Brunswick that lasted until the accession of Ernest Augustus, Duke of Brunswick, the son of the Crown Prince of Hanover, in 1913.
9. William died unmarried, but had a number of illegitimate children.

chunks.title: Ernest Ferdinand, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg

1. He was Prince of Brunswick-Bevern and founder of the younger Brunswick-Bevern line.

chunks.title: Charles William Ferdinand, Duke of Brunswick
chunks.chunk:
Title: Charles William Ferdinand, Duke of Brunswick
0. Charles William Ferdinand, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg, Prince of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel (9 October 1735 – 10 November 1806) was the Prince of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel and Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg and a military leader.
1. His titles are usually shortened to Duke of Brunswick in English-language sources.
2. He succeeded his father as sovereign prince of the Principality of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel, one of the princely states of the Holy Roman Empire.
3. The duke was a cultured and benevolent despot in the model of Frederick the Great, and was married to Princess Augusta, a sister of George III of Great Britain.
4. He was also a recognized master of 18th century warfare, serving as a Field Marshal in the Prussian Army.
5. During the Napoleonic Wars, he was mortally wounded by a musket ball at the Battle of Jena–Auerstedt in 1806.

chunks.title: Augustus William, Duke of Brunswick-Bevern
chunks.chunk:
Title: Augustus William, Duke of Brunswick-Bevern
0. August Wilhelm, Duke of Brunswick-Bevern (1715 in Braunschweig1781 in Stettin), Prussian soldier, son of Ernest Ferdinand, Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg, was born in Braunschweig in 1715, and entered the Prussian army in 1731, becoming colonel of an infantry regiment in 1739.
1. He won great distinction at the battle of Hohenfriedberg as a major-general, and was promoted lieutenant-general in 1750.
2. Bevern was one of the most experienced and exact soldiers in the army of Frederick the Great.
3. He commanded a wing in the battle of Lobositz in 1756, and defeated the Austrians under Marshal Königsegg in a well-fought battle at Reichenberg on 21 April 1757.
4. He took part in the battles of Prague and Kolin and the retreat to Görlitz, and subsequently commanded the Prussians left behind by Frederick in the autumn of 1757 when he marched against the French.
5. Bevern conducted a defensive campaign against overwhelming numbers with great skill, but he soon lost the valuable assistance of General Winterfeldt, who was killed in a skirmish at Moys; and he was eventually brought to battle and suffered a heavy defeat at the battle of Breslau on 22 November.
6. He fell into the hands of the Austrians on the following morning, and remained prisoner for a year.
7. He was made general of infantry in 1759, and on 11 August 1762 inflicted a severe defeat at Reichenbach on an Austrian army endeavouring to relieve Schweidnitz.
8. Bevern retired, after the peace of Hubertusburg, to his government of Stettin, where he died in peace in 1781.

chunks.title: Frederick William, Duke of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel
chunks.chunk:
Title: Frederick William, Duke of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel
0. Frederick William, Duke of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel (9 October 1771 – 16 June 1815) was a German prince and Duke of Brunswick-Lüneburg and Oels.
1. Nicknamed "The Black Duke", he was a military officer who led the Black Brunswickers against French domination in Germany.
2. He briefly ruled the state of Brunswick-Wolfenbüttel from 1806 to 1807 and again from 1813 to 1815.

question: Who is the mother-in-law of Lollia Paulina?

chunks.title: Caligula
chunks.chunk:
Title: Caligula
0. Caligula (31 August 12 – 24 January 41 AD) was Roman emperor from 37 to 41 AD.
1. The son of the popular Roman general Germanicus and Augustus's granddaughter Agrippina the Elder, Caligula was born into the first ruling family of the Roman Empire, conventionally known as the Julio-Claudian dynasty.
2. Germanicus's uncle and adoptive father, Tiberius, succeeded Augustus as emperor of Rome in 14 AD.
3. Although he was born Gaius Caesar, after Julius Caesar, he acquired the nickname "Caligula" (
4. meaning "little [soldier's] boot", the diminutive form of "caliga") from his father's soldiers during their campaign in Germania.
5. When Germanicus died at Antioch in 19, Agrippina returned with her six children to Rome, where she became entangled in a bitter feud with Tiberius.
6. The conflict eventually led to the destruction of her family, with Caligula as the sole male survivor.
7. Untouched by the deadly intrigues, Caligula accepted an invitation in 31 to join the emperor on the island of Capri, where Tiberius had withdrawn five years earlier.
8. Following the death of Tiberius, Caligula succeeded his adoptive grandfather as emperor in 37.
9. There are few surviving sources about the reign of Caligula, although he is described as a noble and moderate emperor during the first six months of his rule.
10. After this, the sources focus upon his cruelty, sadism, extravagance, and sexual perversion, presenting him as an insane tyrant.
11. While the reliability of these sources is questionable, it is known that during his brief reign, Caligula worked to increase the unconstrained personal power of the emperor, as opposed to countervailing powers within the principate.
12. He directed much of his attention to ambitious construction projects and luxurious dwellings for himself, and initiated the construction of two aqueducts in Rome: the Aqua Claudia and the Anio Novus.
13. During his reign, the empire annexed the client kingdom of Mauretania as a province.
14. In early 41, Caligula was assassinated as a result of a conspiracy by officers of the Praetorian Guard, senators, and courtiers.
15. The conspirators' attempt to use the opportunity to restore the Roman Republic was thwarted, however.
16. On the day of the assassination of Caligula, the Praetorians declared Caligula's uncle, Claudius, the next Roman emperor.
17. Although the Julio-Claudian dynasty continued to rule the empire until the fall of his nephew Nero in 68, Caligula's death marked the official end of the Julii Caesares in the male line.

0. Gaza Ghetto: Portrait of a Family, 1948 – 1984 is a documentary film about the life of a Palestinian family living in the Jabalia refugee camp.
1. The film, created by Joan Mandell, Pea Holmquist, and Pierre Bjorklund in 1984 is believed to be the first documentary ever made in Gaza.
2. The film features Ariel Sharon, Binyamin Ben-Eliezer and soldiers on patrol" candidly discuss[ ing] their responsibilities."
3. In his book," An Accented Cinema: Exilic and Diasporic Filmmaking", Hamid Naficy describes the film as an" early important film" on the Palestinian refugee situation.
4. The film follows a refugee family from the Gaza Strip who visit the site of their former village, now a Jewish town in Israel.
5. As the grandfather and great- grandfather point out an orchard and sycamore fig that belonged to Muhammed Ayyub and Uncle Khalil, an Israeli resident appears and tells them to leave, claiming they need a permit to be there.
6. The mother tells him that," We work in Jaffa and Tel Aviv and that's not forbidden," to which he replies," Here it's forbidden."
7. Ted Swedenburg mentions his scene in" Memories of Revolt: The 1936- 1939 Rebellion and the Palestinian National PastWhile chasing the refugee family off, he asserts forcibly that the site is" his" home."

1. It is a film adaptation of Howard's Conan novel" The Hour of the Dragon", with the protagonist changed to the author's other barbarian hero Kull.
2. The storyline also bears similarities to two other Howard stories, the Kull story" By This Axe I Rule!" and the Conan story" The Phoenix on the Sword", which was actually a rewrite of the Kull story.
3. The film was originally intended to be the third Conan film," Conan the Conqueror".
4. The protagonist was changed due to Arnold Schwarzenegger's refusal to reprise his role as Conan and Sorbo's reluctance to redo a character already played.
5. Screenwriter Charles Edward Pogue has stated that he was extremely displeased with this film, feeling that his script was ruined by studio interference.

0. The National Council of Women of Canada (NCWC, , (CNFC)) is a Canadian advocacy organization based in Ottawa, Ontario aimed at improving conditions for women, families, and communities.

chunks.title: Henry Willoughby, 4th Baron Willoughby of Parham
chunks.chunk:
Title: Henry Willoughby, 4th Baron Willoughby of Parham
0. Henry Willoughby, 4th Baron Willoughby of Parham( 1612–1617) was an English peer of the House of Lords.
1. He was born in about November 1612, the son of William Willoughby, 3rd Baron Willoughby of Parham, and Frances Manners, daughter of John Manners, 4th Earl of Rutland.
2. On the death of his father in 1617, he succeeded as the 4th Baron Willoughby of Parham.
3. However, he did not enjoy the title long, dying in infancy on about 14 October 1617.
4. The barony was succeeded by his brother, Francis Willoughby.

chunks.title: Charles Willoughby, 10th Baron Willoughby of Parham
chunks.chunk:
Title: Charles Willoughby, 10th Baron Willoughby of Parham
0. Charles Willoughby, 10th Baron Willoughby of Parham was an English peer of the House of Lords.
1. He succeeded to the title in September 1678 on the death of John Willoughby, 9th Baron Willoughby of Parham.
2. Charles Willoughy was the male heir and descendant from the first creation of the barony that commenced with Sir William Willoughby 1st
3. Baron Willoughby of Parham in 1547 and was the last male heir of the eldest line.
4. Charles Willoughby married Marie daughter of Sir Beaumont Dixie, Bart of Bosworth.
5. He died without a male heir on 9 December 1679.
6. The first creation by letters patent stipulated the title must pass to heirs male of
7. Sir William Willoughby 1st
8. Baron Willoughby of Parham.
9. Charles Willoughby, 10th Baron Willoughby of Parham died without issue and left his estate to his niece Elizabeth, who had married James Bertie, 1st Earl of Abingdon.

chunks.title: William Willoughby, 6th Baron Willoughby of Parham
chunks.chunk:
Title: William Willoughby, 6th Baron Willoughby of Parham
0. William Willoughby, 6th Lord Willoughby (c. 1616 – 10 April 1673) was an English landowner and politician who sat in the House of Commons and later in the House of Lords.
1. In 1666 he inherited the peerage of Baron Willoughby of Parham, and from 1667 he served as Governor of Barbados (1667 – 1673).
2. Willoughby was the third son of William Willoughby, 3rd Baron Willoughby of Parham, and his wife Lady Frances Manners, daughter of John Manners, 4th Earl of Rutland.
3. He was educated at Eton College from 1623 to 1624.
4. In 1636 he travelled abroad in Italy.
5. He was a student of the Middle Temple in 1652.
6. In 1660 Willoughby was elected a Member of Parliament for Midhurst in the Convention Parliament.
7. He was commissioner for plantations from December 1660 until 1667.
8. On the death in 1666 of his brother Francis Willoughby, 5th Lord Willoughby of Parham, who died without a male heir, he succeeded to his hereditary peerage and to his seat in the House of Lords.
9. From 1667 until his death he was Governor of Barbados, revisiting England occasionally and retaining his other offices.
10. Willoughby died in Barbados in 1673, and his body was brought back to Lincolnshire, to be buried at Knaith.
11. Willoughby married Anne, daughter of Sir Philip Carey of Aldenham, Hertfordshire, by 1637.
12. They had a daughter, Frances, who married Charles Kirkhoven, 1st Earl of Bellomont.

chunks.title: Thomas Willoughby, 11th Baron Willoughby of Parham

Title: Thomas Willoughby, 11th Baron Willoughby of Parham
0. Thomas Willoughby, 11th Baron Willoughby of Parham( c.1602–1691/92) was an English peer of the House of Lords.
1. He was born in about 1602, son of Sir Thomas Willoughby and Mary Thornhaugh( Thornley), and grandson of Charles Willoughby, 2nd Baron Willoughby of Parham and Lady Margaret Clinton.

chunks.title: George Willoughby, 7th Baron Willoughby of Parham
chunks.chunk:
Title: George Willoughby, 7th Baron Willoughby of Parham
0. George Willoughby, 7th Baron Willoughby of Parham( 1638 – 1674) was an English peer of the House of Lords.
1. He was born at Belvoir Castle, Leicestershire, England on 18 March 1639, the son of William Willoughby, 6th Baron Willoughby of Parham and Anne Carey.
2. On 9 October 1666, he married Elizabeth Clinton, daughter of Henry Clinton and Jane Markham.
3. George and Elizabeth had three children:
4. John Willoughby, 8th Baron Willoughby of Parham, his successor; Anne, who died in infancy; and Elizabeth, who married Hon. James Bertie, son of James Bertie, 1st Earl of Abingdon.
5. On the death of his father in 1673, he succeeded as the 7th Baron Willoughby of Parham.
6. He died in Knaith, Lincolnshire, England in 1674, aged 35.

chunks.title: John Willoughby, 9th Baron Willoughby of Parham
chunks.chunk:
Title: John Willoughby, 9th Baron Willoughby of Parham
0. John Willoughby, 9th Baron Willoughby of Parham( 1643 – 1678) was an English peer of the House of Lords.
1. He was born in Stanstead Bury, near Stanstead Abbotts, Hertfordshire, England on 29 December 1643, the son of William Willoughby, 6th Baron Willoughby of Parham and Anne Carey.
2. He married Anne Bolterton( died circa 3 October 1683).
3. On the death of his nephew John in early 1678, he succeeded as the 9th Baron Willoughby of Parham.
4. However, a few months later he died without issue in September 1678.
5. The barony was succeeded by his younger brother, Charles Willoughby.

2. On the death of his father in 1674, he succeeded as the 8th Baron Willoughby of Parham.
3. However, he did not enjoy the title long, dying in early 1678.
4. The barony was succeeded by his uncle, John Willoughby.

chunks.title: Hugh Willoughby, 15th Baron Willoughby of Parham
chunks.chunk:
Title: Hugh Willoughby, 15th Baron Willoughby of Parham
0. Hugh, 15th Baron Willoughby of Parham( 1713 – 17 January 1765) was an English nobleman and hereditary peer of the House of Lords.
1. He was born in 1713, the eldest son of Charles Willoughby, 14th Baron Willoughby of Parham and Hester, daughter of Henry Davenport of Little Lever and Darcy Lever, near Bolton.
2. Hugh Willoughby's father died on 12 June 1715, aged 34, and the infant Hugh Willoughby became the 15th Baron Willoughby of Parham.
3. He could not take his seat in the House of Lords until he reached the age of 21.

chunks.title: Henry Willoughby, 16th Baron Willoughby of Parham
chunks.chunk:
Title: Henry Willoughby, 16th Baron Willoughby of Parham
0. Henry Willoughby, 16th Baron Willoughby of Parham( 1696 – 29 January 1775) was an English peer of the House of Lords.
1. On the death of Charles Willoughby, 10th Baron Willoughby of Parham, who died without male heir on 9 December 1679, the title should have passed to the descendants of Sir Ambrose Willoughby of Matson, younger brother of Charles Willoughby, 2nd Baron Willoughby of Parham who died in 1603.
2. The title instead passed to the family of Thomas Willoughby, who became the 11th baron.
3. Sir Ambrose Willoughby had two sons, Edward and Richard.
4. Edward's son was Henry, who emigrated to the Colony of Virginia in 1676, then one of the Thirteen Colonies, whose whereabouts were unknown.
5. Henry died in Hull Creek, Virginia on 26 November 1685, aged 59.
6. His son, also Henry, was then aged 20.
7. Henry married Elizabeth, daughter of William Pigeon of Stepney, with whom he had a son who was also named Henry.
8. Henry Willoughby had twice been master of the Company of Brewers in London, a Justice of the Peace and colonel of the 2nd Regiment of Militia of the Tower Hamlets.
9. Henry Willoughby married Susannah, daughter Robert Gresswell of Middlesex and had a daughter, Elizabeth who married John Halsey of Tower Hill.
10. Henry Willoughby first petitioned for his seat in the House of Lords in 1733, his case was not heard.
11. His petition was accepted after the death of Hugh Willoughby, 15th Baron Willoughby of Parham and he took his seat on 25 April 1767 to become the 16th baron.
12. Henry Willoughby died on 29 January 1775, aged 79, without male heir and the title passed to his nephew.

question: Who is George Fitzroy, 1St Duke Of Northumberland's stepmother?

chunks.title: Charles II of England
chunks.chunk:
Title: Charles II of England
0. Charles II (29 May 1630 – 6 February 1685) was king of England, Scotland, and Ireland.
1. He was king of Scotland from 1649 until his deposition in 1651, and king of England, Scotland and Ireland from the 1660 Restoration of the monarchy until his death.
2. Charles II was the eldest surviving child of Charles I of England, Scotland and Ireland and Henrietta Maria of France.
3. After Charles I's execution at Whitehall on 30 January 1649, at the climax of the English Civil War, the Parliament of Scotland proclaimed Charles II king on 5 February 1649.
4. However, England entered the period known as the English Interregnum or the English Commonwealth, and the country was a "de facto" republic led by Oliver Cromwell.
5. Cromwell defeated Charles II at the Battle of Worcester on 3 September 1651, and Charles fled to mainland Europe.
6. Cromwell became virtual dictator of England, Scotland and Ireland.
7. Charles spent the next nine years in exile in France, the Dutch Republic and the Spanish Netherlands.
8. A political crisis that followed the death of Cromwell in 1658 resulted in the restoration of the monarchy, and Charles was invited to return to Britain.
9. On 29 May 1660, his 30th birthday, he was received in London to public acclaim.
10. After 1660, all legal documents stating a regnal year did so as if he had succeeded his father as king in 1649.
11. Charles's English parliament enacted laws known as the Clarendon Code, designed to shore up the position of the re-established Church of England.
12. Charles acquiesced to the Clarendon Code even though he favoured a policy of religious tolerance.
13. The major foreign policy issue of his early reign was the Second Anglo-Dutch War.
14. In 1670, he entered into the Treaty of Dover, an alliance with his cousin King Louis XIV of France.
15. Louis agreed to aid him in the Third Anglo-Dutch War and pay him a pension, and Charles secretly promised to convert to Catholicism at an unspecified future date.
16. Charles attempted to introduce religious freedom for Catholics and Protestant dissenters with his 1672 Royal Declaration of Indulgence, but the English Parliament forced him to withdraw it.
17. In 1679, Titus Oates's revelations of a supposed Popish Plot sparked the Exclusion Crisis when it was revealed that Charles's brother and heir presumptive, James, Duke of York, was a Catholic.
18. The crisis saw the birth of the pro-exclusion Whig and anti-exclusion Tory parties.
19. Charles sided with the Tories, and, following the discovery of the Rye House Plot to murder Charles and James in 1683, some Whig leaders were executed or forced into exile.
20. Charles dissolved the English Parliament in 1681, and ruled alone until his death in 1685.
21. He was received into the Catholic Church on his deathbed.
22. Charles was one of the most popular and beloved kings of England, known as the "Merry Monarch", in reference to both the liveliness and hedonism of his court and the general relief at the return to normality after over a decade of rule by Cromwell and the Puritans.
23. Charles's wife, Catherine of Braganza, bore no live children, but Charles acknowledged at least twelve illegitimate children by various mistresses.
24. He was succeeded by his brother James.

chunks.title: Dorothy Granger
chunks.chunk:
Title: Dorothy Granger
0. Dorothy Karolyn Granger( November 21, 1911 – January 4, 1995) was an American actress best known for her roles in short subject comedies in Hollywood.
1. She was also the stepmother of film maker and former record producer Anthony J. Hilder.

chunks.title: George FitzRoy, 1st Duke of Northumberland
chunks.chunk:
Title: George FitzRoy, 1st Duke of Northumberland
0. Lieutenant-General George FitzRoy, 1st Duke of Northumberland, KG, PC (28 December 1665 – 28 June 1716) was the third and youngest illegitimate son of King Charles II of England; his mother was Barbara Villiers, Countess of Castlemaine (also known as Barbara Villiers, Duchess of Cleveland).
1. On 1 October 1674, he was created Earl of Northumberland, Baron of Pontefract (Yorkshire) and Viscount Falmouth (Cornwall).
2. On 6 April 1683, he was created Duke of Northumberland.
3. The first Duke of Northumberland was born at Merton College, Oxford.
4. In 1682, he was employed on secret service in Venice.
5. Upon his return to England in 1684, he was elected (10 January) and installed (8 April) Knight of the Garter.
6. That summer, he served as a volunteer on the side of the French at the Siege of Luxembourg.
7. In 1687, Northumberland commanded the 2nd Troop of Horse Guards.
8. A year later, he was appointed a lord of His Majesty's bedchamber.
9. In 1701, he was appointed Constable of Windsor Castle, in 1710 Lord Lieutenant of Surrey, and in 1712, he became Lord Lieutenant of Berkshire as well.
10. In 1703, he succeeded the Earl of Oxford as Colonel of the Royal Regiment of Horse.
11. Seven years later, on 10 January 1710, he became Lieutenant-General.
12. On 7 April 1713, he was sworn into the Privy Council and as Chief Butler of England.
13. In March 1686, Northumberland married Catherine Wheatley, the daughter of a poulterer, Robert Wheatley of Bracknell in Berkshire.
14. Catherine was the widow of Thomas Lucy of Charlecote Park, a captain in the Royal Horse Guards.
15. Soon after the marriage, Northumberland and his brother, Henry FitzRoy, 1st Duke of Grafton, allegedly attempted to privately convey her abroad to an English convent in Ghent, Belgium.
16. After the death of Catherine in 1714, Northumberland remarried to Mary Dutton, the sister of Captain Mark Dutton.
17. The Duke lived at Frogmore House at Windsor in Berkshire, but died suddenly aged 50 at Epsom on 28 June 1716.
18. He had no legitimate offspring.
19. Mary died at Frogmore House in 1738.

chunks.chunk:
Title: Louis IV, Count of Chiny
0. Louis IV the Young( 1173- 7 October 1226), Count of Chiny from 1189 to 1226, son of Louis III, Count of Chiny, and Sophie.
1. Louis was the last of the first dynasty of Counts of Chiny.
2. Having no son, he prepared his eldest daughter Jeanne as his successor.
3. Louis marked his reign by issuing the first postage stamp in the county.
4. He succeeded as count in 1189 when his father died on the Third Crusade, but was under the supervision of his mother and uncle Thierry, Lord of Mellier, because of his young age.
5. He likely participated in the Albigensian Crusade, where he died in Cahors.
6. He married Matilda of Avesnes, widow of Nicolas IV, Lord of Rumigny, and daughter of James, Lord of Avesnes and Conde, and Adele, Lady of Guise.
7. They had three children: Isabelle was referred to as Madame de Florenville during the in 1285, hosted by Louis' grandson Louis V, successor Count of Chiny, Upon Louis ’ death, his daughter Jeanne became Countess of Chiny until her marriage to Arnold IV, when he became the first Count of Chiny of the second dynasty as Arnold II.
8. Louis IV was also a direct paternal descendant of Charlemagne.

0. Louis I (murdered September 29, 1025), Count of Chiny (987-1025) and Count of Verdun (as Louis) (1024-1025), son of Otto I, Count of Chiny, and an unknown mother.
Upon Otto’s death, Louis became the second Count of Chiny.
1. Virtually nothing is known about his rule in Chiny.
2. In 1024, Reginbert, the Bishop of Verdun, appointed Louis as Count of Verdun when Count Herman of Ename, son of Godfrey the Prisoner, retired to a monastery.
3. Herman's nephew, Godfrey the Bearded, coveted the position, and Gothelo (Herman’s brother and Godfrey’s father) invaded the city and murdered Louis.
4. Louis married Adelaide (d. after 1025), of unknown parentage.
5. They had two children:
Louis’ son Louis II assumed the position of Count of Chiny after his father’s death, and Godfrey the Bearded was appointed Count of Verdun.

Title: Louis II, Count of Chiny
0. Louis II (d. before 1066), Count of Chiny (1025–1066), son of Louis I, Count of Chiny and Verdun, and Adélaïde de Saint Varme.
1. He left very few traces in history and nothing is known about his reign.
2. Louis was married to Sophie.
3. They had two children:
Legend has it that Louis held hunting parties in his huge game park.
4. Here, Thibault of Champagne established a hermitage and found a source of holy springs, and Louis built a shrine to the spring's healing powers.
5. The shrine became famous, with many pilgrims who came to implore the grace of Saint-Thibault.
6. Later, monks from Calabria, Italy, founded a monastery nearby at Orval at the invitation of Louis’ son Arnold.
7. Upon Louis' death, his son Arnold became Count of Chiny.

chunks.title: Otto I, Count of Chiny
chunks.chunk:
Title: Otto I, Count of Chiny
0. Otto I (Eudes) (d. 987), Count of Chiny, perhaps son of Adalbert I the Pious, Count of Vermandois, and Gerberge of Lorraine.
1. Although he probably did not use the title, Otto is regarded as the first Count of Chiny.
2. Historically, an Otto of Vermandois is mentioned in a charter of 958 alongside his father, the Count of Vermandois.
3. His name and that of his brother Ludolfe show a Germanic ancestry of the kings of the family of Saxony, which is indeed the case, as his mother is Gerberge of Lorraine, niece of Emperor Otto I (her mother being daughter to Henry the Fowler).
4. He was reported as a quarrelsome lord who threatened Hainaut and Cambrésis (the region around Cambrai).
5. In 971, an Otto erected a fortress in Warcq, in the Ardennes, and attacked his neighbors, including Adalbero, Archbishop of Reims.
6. He is mentioned as having imperial ancestry.
7. This and a number of other facts prompted the historian Léon Vanderkindere to hypothesize that these two Ottos were in fact a single historical figure.
8. His wife’s name is unknown.
9. It is possible that she was from Ardennes, a relative of Wigeric of Lotharingia and Cunigunda of France, granddaughter of Louis the Stammerer.
10. This could explain the name of his son and the appointment of the latter as Count of Verdun in 1024.
11. Otto and his wife had one child:
Upon his death, Otto was succeeded as Count of Chiny by his son Louis.

chunks.title: John the Fearless
chunks.chunk:
Title: John the Fearless
0. John the Fearless (28 May 1371 – 10 September 1419) was Duke of Burgundy (the second of the Valois dynasty) as John I from 1404 until his death.
1. A scion of the royal house of France, he played an important role in French affairs during the early 15th century, in particular the struggles to rule the country for the mentally ill King Charles VI (his first cousin) and the Hundred Years' War with England.
2. His rash, unscrupulous, and violent political dealings contributed to the eruption of the Armagnac–Burgundian Civil War in France, and culminated in his assassination in 1419.
3. The involvement of Charles, the heir to the French throne, in his assassination, prompted John's son and successor Philip to seek an alliance with the English, thereby bringing the Hundred Years' War to its final phase.

chunks.title: Henry, son of Robert I of Burgundy
chunks.chunk:
Title: Henry, son of Robert I of Burgundy
0. Henry of Burgundy (c. 1035 – January 27, 1070/1074), called the Gallant ("le Damoiseau"), was the eldest surviving son and heir of Robert I, Duke of Burgundy, second son of Robert II of France, and his wife, Helie of Semur, granddaughter of Henry I, Duke of Burgundy.
1. Little is known about his life.
2. He died shortly before his father and was never duke himself.
3. The name of Henry's wife is not known, though both Sibylla and Clémence have been suggested.
4. The first of these derives from an undated obituary from Besançon, Sainte-Etienne, naming "Sibilla, mater ducus Burgundie" (Sibylla, mother of the Duke of Burgundy), it being reasoned that since she is not called duchess, she must have been married to the sole father of a duke who was not a duke himself, Henry.
5. However, it has been argued by Jean Richard that this is a reference to Sibylla of Burgundy, Duchess of Burgundy, mother of the then-ruling duke, Hugh II.
6. Richard proposed based on the name's repeated use among the descendants of her son Odo I, Duke of Burgundy that she may have been named Clémence, although Odo's wife had a sister, Clementia of Burgundy, who could have been the inspiration for its use among their descendants.
7. Based on the use of the byname "Borel" by Odo I, genealogist Szabolcs de Vajay proposed that his mother was the daughter of Berenguer Ramon I, Count of Barcelona and his third wife, Guisle of Lluca, and hence granddaughter of Ramon Borrell, Count of Barcelona, although there is no documentary evidence that this was the case.
8. Henry's wife died on or after July 6, 1074.

2. He went on to make some of the most innovative early sound films in France, before going abroad to work in the UK and USA for more than a decade.

chunks.title: Henry III of England
chunks.chunk:
Title: Henry III of England
0. Henry III (1 October 1207 – 16 November 1272), also known as Henry of Winchester, was King of England, Lord of Ireland, and Duke of Aquitaine from 1216 until his death.
1. The son of King John and Isabella of Angoulême, Henry assumed the throne when he was only nine in the middle of the First Barons' War.
2. Cardinal Guala declared the war against the rebel barons to be a religious crusade and Henry's forces, led by William Marshal, defeated the rebels at the battles of Lincoln and Sandwich in 1217.
3. Henry promised to abide by the Great Charter of 1225, which limited royal power and protected the rights of the major barons.
4. His early rule was dominated first by Hubert de Burgh and then Peter des Roches, who re-established royal authority after the war.
5. In 1230, the King attempted to reconquer the provinces of France that had once belonged to his father, but the invasion was a debacle.
6. A revolt led by William Marshal's son, Richard Marshal, broke out in 1232, ending in a peace settlement negotiated by the Church.
7. Following the revolt, Henry ruled England personally, rather than governing through senior ministers.
8. He travelled less than previous monarchs, investing heavily in a handful of his favourite palaces and castles.
9. He married Eleanor of Provence, with whom he had five children.
10. Henry was known for his piety, holding lavish religious ceremonies and giving generously to charities; the King was particularly devoted to the figure of Edward the Confessor, whom he adopted as his patron saint.
11. He extracted huge sums of money from the Jews in England, ultimately crippling their ability to do business, and as attitudes towards the Jews hardened, he introduced the Statute of Jewry, attempting to segregate the community.
12. In a fresh attempt to reclaim his family's lands in France, he invaded Poitou in 1242, leading to the disastrous Battle of Taillebourg.
13. After this, Henry relied on diplomacy, cultivating an alliance with Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor.
14. Henry supported his brother Richard of Cornwall in his bid to become King of the Romans in 1256, but was unable to place his own son Edmund Crouchback on the throne of Sicily, despite investing large amounts of money.
15. He planned to go on crusade to the Levant, but was prevented from doing so by rebellions in Gascony.
16. By 1258, Henry's rule was increasingly unpopular, the result of the failure of his expensive foreign policies and the notoriety of his Poitevin half-brothers, the Lusignans, as well as the role of his local officials in collecting taxes and debts.
17. A coalition of his barons, initially probably backed by Eleanor, seized power in a coup d'état and expelled the Poitevins from England, reforming the royal government through a process called the Provisions of Oxford.
18. Henry and the baronial government enacted a peace with France in 1259, under which Henry gave up his rights to his other lands in France in return for King Louis IX recognising him as the rightful ruler of Gascony.
19. The baronial regime collapsed but Henry was unable to reform a stable government and instability across England continued.
20. In 1263, one of the more radical barons, Simon de Montfort, seized power, resulting in the Second Barons' War.
21. Henry persuaded Louis to support his cause and mobilised an army.
22. The Battle of Lewes occurred in 1264, where Henry was defeated and taken prisoner.
23. Henry's eldest son, Edward, escaped from captivity to defeat de Montfort at the Battle of Evesham the following year and freed his father.
24. Henry initially enacted a harsh revenge on the remaining rebels, but was persuaded by the Church to mollify his policies through the Dictum of Kenilworth.
25. Reconstruction was slow and Henry had to acquiesce to various measures, including further suppression of the Jews, to maintain baronial and popular support.
26. Henry died in 1272, leaving Edward as his successor.
27. He was buried in Westminster Abbey, which he had rebuilt in the second half of his reign, and was moved to his current tomb in 1290.
28. Some miracles were declared after his death; however, he was not canonised.

chunks.title: Edward I of England
chunks.chunk:
Title: Edward I of England
0. Edward I (17/18 June 1239 – 7 July 1307), also known as Edward Longshanks and the Hammer of the Scots , was King of England from 1272 to 1307.
1. Before his accession to the throne, he was commonly referred to as The Lord Edward.
2. The first son of Henry III, Edward was involved from an early age in the political intrigues of his father's reign, which included an outright rebellion by the English barons.
3. In 1259, he briefly sided with a baronial reform movement, supporting the Provisions of Oxford.
4. After reconciliation with his father, however, he remained loyal throughout the subsequent armed conflict, known as the Second Barons' War.
5. After the Battle of Lewes, Edward was hostage to the rebellious barons, but escaped after a few months and defeated the baronial leader Simon de Montfort at the Battle of Evesham in 1265.
6. Within two years the rebellion was extinguished and, with England pacified, Edward joined the Ninth Crusade to the Holy Land.
7. Edward was on his way home in 1272 when he was informed that his father had died.
8. Making a slow return, he reached England in 1274 and was crowned at Westminster Abbey on 19 August.
9. Edward spent much of his reign reforming royal administration and common law.
10. Through an extensive legal inquiry, he investigated the tenure of various feudal liberties, while the law was reformed through a series of statutes regulating criminal and property law.
11. Increasingly, however, Edward's attention was drawn towards military affairs.
12. After suppressing a minor rebellion in Wales in 1276–77, Edward responded to a second rebellion in 1282–83 with a full-scale war of conquest.
13. After a successful campaign, he subjected Wales to English rule, built a series of castles and towns in the countryside and settled them with English people.
14. Next, his efforts were directed towards Scotland.
15. Initially invited to arbitrate a succession dispute, Edward claimed feudal suzerainty over the kingdom.
16. The war that followed continued after Edward's death, even though the English seemed victorious at several points.
17. Simultaneously, Edward found himself at war with France (a Scottish ally) after the French king Philip IV had confiscated the Duchy of Gascony, which until then had been held in personal union with the Kingdom of England.
18. Although Edward recovered his duchy, this conflict relieved English military pressure against Scotland.
19. At the same time there were problems at home.
20. In the mid-1290s, extensive military campaigns required high levels of taxation, and Edward met with both lay and ecclesiastical opposition.
21. These crises were initially averted, but issues remained unsettled.
22. When the King died in 1307, he left to his son Edward II an ongoing war with Scotland and many financial and political problems.
23. Edward
24. I was a tall man (6'2") for his era, hence the nickname "Longshanks".
25. He was temperamental, and this, along with his height, made him an intimidating man, and he often instilled fear in his contemporaries.
26. Nevertheless, he held the respect of his subjects for the way he embodied the medieval ideal of kingship, as a soldier, an administrator and a man of faith.
27. Modern historians are divided on their assessment of Edward
28. I: while some have praised him for his contribution to the law and administration, others have criticised him for his uncompromising attitude towards his nobility.
29. Currently, Edward I is credited with many accomplishments during his reign, including restoring royal authority after the reign of Henry III, establishing Parliament as a permanent institution and thereby also a functional system for raising taxes, and reforming the law through statutes.
30. At the same time, he is also often criticised for other actions, such as his brutal conduct towards the Welsh and Scots, and issuing the Edict of Expulsion in 1290, by which the Jews were expelled from England.
31. The Edict remained in effect for the rest of the Middle Ages, and it was over 350 years until it was formally overturned under Oliver Cromwell in 1657.

chunks.title: Adela of Normandy
chunks.chunk:
Title: Adela of Normandy
0. Adela of Normandy, of Blois, or of England( c. 1067 – 8 March 1137), also known as in Roman Catholicism, was a daughter of William the Conqueror and Matilda of Flanders who later became the Countess of Blois, Chartres, and Meaux by marriage to Stephen II, Count of Blois.
1. Her husband greatly benefited from the increased social status and prestige that came with such a marriage.
2. She brought with her not only her bloodline, but a wedding gift of money and other movable goods from the prodigious store of Anglo- Norman wealth.
3. She was regent of Blois during the absence of her spouse in 1096 – 1100 and 1101 – 02, and during the minority of her son from 1102 until 1120.
4. Adela was the mother of Stephen, King of England and Henry of Blois, Bishop of Winchester.
5. The couple had ten children, though it is not certain if all were Adela's biological children.
6. It is only certain that she had five sons and might have had three or more daughters.

chunks.title: Alix of Brittany, Dame de Pontarcy
chunks.chunk:
Title: Alix of Brittany, Dame de Pontarcy
0. Alix of Brittany, Dame de Pontarcy, Countess of Blois (6 June 1243 – 2 August 1288), was a Breton noblewoman and a member of the House of Dreux as the eldest daughter of John I, Duke of Brittany.
1. She married John I, Count of Blois.
2. Alix was known for founding religious houses including the Monastery of La Guiche, where she was later buried.
3. Alix, named after her paternal grandmother, Alix of Thouars, was born on 6 June 1243 at the Château de Suscinio in Sarzeau, Morbihan, Brittany.
4. She was the eldest daughter of John I, Duke of Brittany and Blanche of Navarre, daughter of Theobald I of Navarre and Agnes of Beaujeu.
5. Alix held the title "Dame de Pontarcy" in her own right.
6. Sometime after a contract was signed on 11 December 1254, she married John I, Count of Blois of the House of Châtillon.
7. Thereafter she was styled Countess of Blois.
8. She brought as her dowry her titles of Pontarcy and de Brie-Comte-Robert, which had been named after her ancestor Robert I of Dreux.
9. The marriage produced one child, a daughter Jeanne, who was heiress to her father's title and estates.
10. In 1270, her husband was appointed Lieutenant General of France.
11. Through Alix's marriage to John, the Château de Brie-Comte-Robert passed to the Châtillon family.
12. Alix and John founded several religious houses including the Monastery of La Guiche near Blois in 1277.
13. She became a widow on 28 June 1279.
14. In 1287, the year before her own death, Alix travelled to Palestine.
15. From there she journeyed on to Syria, where she commissioned the erection of two barbican towers at Ptolemais.

chunks.title: Lolita (Leah LaBelle song)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Lolita (Leah LaBelle song)
0. "Lolita" is a song recorded by American singer Leah LaBelle.
1. It was released on May 7, 2013 through Epic.
2. The single was written by American songwriter Kelly Sheehan in collaboration with record producer Pharrell Williams.
3. Backed by synthesizers and a bass guitar, it is a midtempo funk, R&B, and pop song with disco influences.
4. Media commentators have suggested the song was inspired by Vladimir Nabokov's 1955 novel "Lolita", and noted that its lyrics greatly diverge from the source material.
5. "Lolita" was positively received by music critics, who praised its chorus, Williams' production, and LaBelle's vocal performance.
6. The single ranked number seven on the Dance Club Songs "Billboard" chart in the United States.
7. Internationally, it peaked at number 264 on the official Tophit airplay chart.
8. To promote "Lolita", LaBelle sang an acoustic version for "Rap-Up", and performed the original version at various venues, such as New York Fashion Week and the Club Skirts Dinah Shore Weekend.
9. Directed by Diane Martel, the single's accompanying music video features LaBelle as Lolita and shows how she seduces boys from her neighborhood.
10. The video received attention due to its focus on sexuality.
11. Welsh singer-songwriter Charlotte Church strongly criticized Martel's creation of sexually-explicit music videos, and Idolator selected the carwash scene as an instance in which the video emphasized sexuality.
12. Despite the criticism, LaBelle's performance garnered positive reviews.

6. and it is here that earned his reputation as an internationally respected trainer.

Ian Balding has had influence on many top class Thoroughbreds and race horses, amongst whom some are Mill Reef, Lochsong, Mrs Penny, Glint of Gold, Diamond Shoal, Gold and Ivory, Selkirk, Forest Flower, Dashing Blade, Robellino, Silver Fling, King of Clubs, Lochangel, Top Cees, Crystal Spirit, and Tagula.

question: Which film was released earlier, Anna-Liisa or Children Underground?

chunks.title: Children Underground
chunks.chunk:
Title: Children Underground
0. Children Underground is an American 2001 documentary film directed by Edet Belzberg.
1. In an effort to increase the Romanian work force, former communist leader Nicolae Ceaușescu outlawed contraception and abortion in 1966.
2. Thousands of unwanted children were placed in state orphanages where they faced terrible conditions.
3. With the fall of Communism, many children from the orphanages moved into the streets while others were runaways from impoverished families.
4. Today there are 20,000 children living in the streets while the resources for sheltering these homeless youths are severely limited.
5. " Children Underground" follows the story of five street children, aged eight to sixteen who live in a subway station in Bucharest, Romania.
6. The street kids are encountered daily by commuting adults, who pass them by in the station as they starve, swindle, and steal, all while searching desperately for a fresh can of paint to get high with.
7. Belzberg and her cameraman, Wolfgang Held, maintain their distance as the kids panhandle, fight and sleep on cardboard boxes, either on the train platforms or the public parks above ground, watching dispassionately as the youngsters inhale Aurolac, a noxious silver paint with intoxicating fumes, from plastic bags.
8. In a slightly uplifting coda, Belzberg and crew return a year later to find that a police who swept off the Victoriei has dispersed the children.
9. Some of them landed in state- funded homes, while others simply moved on to one of the many abandoned construction sites that dot the city.
10. Belzberg steers away from any discussion of the rampant sexual exploitation of these young children or the fact that one of the biggest dangers they face are STDs, including AIDS, but the urban hell she presents is shattering enough.
11. Homelessness is all too familiar to many inhabitants in the world's wealthiest cities, but rarely has the situation seemed so hopeless, or its victims so desperate.
12. One of the children director Belzberg follows is Cristina Ionescu.
13. At first, this child looked like a young man, but one later finds out that girls have to become tough and look boyish in order to survive.
14. This is also very apparent with another child named, Violeta' Macarena' Rosu, who is also a girl.
15. The nickname' Macarena' derives from the song" Macarena", her favorite.
16. Three other children, Mihai Tudose, and brother and sister Ana and Marian, are also profiled.
17. The film explores the lives of these children, who are shown fighting, abusing themselves, and becoming addicted to Aurolac.
18. The filmmakers follow Mihai to his family's home in the town of Constanța.
19. A similar scene films Ana and Marian as they visit their home, which is also outside Bucharest.

chunks.title: Dorado Airport
chunks.chunk:
Title: Dorado Airport
0. Dorado Airport or Dorado Beach Airport was a small single runway airport in Dorado, Puerto Rico.
1. Clara Livingston, at the time owner of the property, ordered the strip to be built, and her friend, Amelia Earhart, may have used the facility as well.
2. Later on, the United States military, during World War II, paved the runway.
3. Much later on, a large airline named Caribair (later overtaken by Eastern Air Lines), began flights there.
4. When Caribair became part of Eastern, flights to Dorado Airport were suspended.
5. During the mid 1960s, Dorado was served by Dorado Wings, a small airline that operated charter flights between Dorado Airport and Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport in San Juan.
6. The airline operated propeller airplanes.
7. In the early 1990s, the airport was officially closed.
8. In 1996, the parcel was rezoned and construction commenced of a master planned community: Dorado Beach East.
9. In memory of Dorado Airport and its founder, Ms. Clara Livingston, the developers built a children's playground themed with unique play airplanes, a hangar for activities, and a runway plaza.

chunks.title: Arnold Palmer Regional Airport
chunks.chunk:
Title: Arnold Palmer Regional Airport
0. Arnold Palmer Regional Airport is in Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania, two miles( 3 km) southwest of Latrobe and about southeast of Pittsburgh.
1. It was formerly" Westmoreland County Airport"; it was renamed in September 1999 for Arnold Palmer as part of his 70th birthday celebration.
2. Palmer learned to fly at the airport and the dedication ceremony included Governor Tom Ridge and a flyover of three A- 10s of the Pennsylvania Air National Guard.
3. Federal Aviation Administration records say the airport had 18,946 passenger boardings( enplanements) in calendar year 2008, 15,482 in 2009 and 6,978 in 2010.
4. The Federal Aviation Administration( FAA) National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems for 2017 – 2021 categorized it as a non-hub primary commercial service facility.
5. The airport was served by Northwest Airlink, as a reliever for Pittsburgh International Airport on the other side of the Pittsburgh metropolitan area.
6. The airport had regional service by US Airways to Pittsburgh International Airport, until the company's bankruptcy.
7. Northwest/ Delta ended its service to Detroit on July 31, 2009.
8. In February 2011 Spirit Airlines launched seasonal service to Fort Lauderdale and Myrtle Beach; in January 2012 Spirit announced they would start service to Orlando on May 17.
9. The airline currently serves the airport year- round.
10. Spirit now serves 5 cities from Arnold Palmer Regional Airport and has increased passenger traffic from 6,978 in 2010 to 355,910 in 2015.
11. Southern Airways Express released a statement showing interest in operating a Pittsburgh to Latrobe flight; no start date given.

chunks.title: Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport
chunks.chunk:
Title: Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport
0. Luis Muñoz Marín International Airport( also known as Isla Verde International Airport/ Aeropuerto Internacional de Isla Verde) is a joint civil- military international airport named for Puerto Rico's first democratically elected governor and located in suburban Carolina, Puerto Rico, southeast of San Juan.
1. It is the busiest airport in the Caribbean region by passenger traffic.
2. Over 4 million passengers board a plane at the airport per year according to the Federal Aviation Administration.
3. The airport is owned by the Puerto Rico Ports Authority and managed by Aerostar Airport Holdings, a public – private partnership which was awarded a lease by the government of Puerto Rico to operate and manage the airport for 40 years beginning in 2013.
4. SJU is the second international airport to be privatized in the United States or its territories, and, as of 2013, is the only currently privatized airport in the nation.
5. Taxis and rental cars can transport travelers to and from the airport.
6. The airport serves as a gateway to the Caribbean islands.
7. SJU covers 1,600 acres( 647 ha) of land.

0. Vishal Bhardwaj (born 4 August 1965) is an Indian film director, screenwriter, producer, music composer and playback singer.
1. He is known for his work in Hindi cinema, and is the recipient of seven National Film Awards in four categories.
2. Bhardwaj made his debut as a music composer with the children's film "Abhay (The Fearless)"
3. (1995), and received wider recognition with his compositions in Gulzar's "Maachis" (1996).
4. He received the Filmfare RD Burman Award for New Music Talent for the latter.
5. He went on to compose music for the films "Satya" (1998) and "Godmother" (1999).
6. For the latter, he garnered the National Film Award for Best Music Direction.
7. Bhardwaj made his directorial debut with the children's film "Makdee" (2002), for which he also composed the music.
8. He garnered critical acclaim and several accolades for writing and directing the Indian adaptations of three tragedies by William Shakespeare: "Maqbool" (2003) from "MacbethOmkara" (2006) from "Othello", and "Haider" (2014) from "Hamlet".
9. He has also directed the caper thriller "Kaminey", the black comedy "7 Khoon Maaf" (2011), and the satire "Matru Ki Bijlee Ka Mandola" (2013).
10. In addition, Bhardwaj produces films under his banner VB Pictures.
11. He has co-written and produced the films "Ishqiya" (2010), its sequel "Dedh Ishqiya" (2014), and the crime drama "Talvar" (2015), among others.
12. He has composed the musical score for each of his directorial and production ventures, and frequently collaborates with the lyricist Gulzar.
13. He is married to playback singer Rekha Bhardwaj.

chunks.title: Henry C. Lord
chunks.chunk:
Title: Henry C. Lord
0. Henry Clark Lord (October 2, 1824 – March 23, 1884) was the fourth president of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway.
1. He was born in Amherst, Massachusetts, the son of Dartmouth College president Nathan Lord.
2. In 1837, Henry enrolled at Dartmouth.
3. He graduated in 1843 and began working as a tutor in Virginia.
4. After studying law, he was admitted to the Suffolk Bar in Boston.
5. He married Eliza Burret Wright of Cincinnati, and he moved there in the 1850s.
6. In Ohio, Lord developed a reputation as a rehabilitator of railroad lines.
7. In the 1850s, he served as president of the Indianapolis and Cincinnati Railroad.
8. He succeeded William F. Nast as president of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway on September 24, 1868.
9. In August 1873, Henry Lord became the founding president of the Indianapolis Belt Railroad.
10. Although he was not a member, Henry Lord was a strong supporter of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and a frequent contributor to the labor union's monthly journal.
11. In November 1883, he developed throat cancer.
12. Henry Lord died at his home in Riverside, Ohio, on March 23, 1884.

2. He was admitted at Peterhouse, Cambridge on 6 March 1618.

5. Paulet married Lucy Philpot, daughter of Sir George Philpot.

chunks.title: Nathan Lord
chunks.chunk:
Title: Nathan Lord
0. Nathan Lord (November 28, 1793 – September 9, 1870) was a U.S. Congregational clergyman and educator who served as president of Dartmouth College for more than three decades.
1. He graduated from Bowdoin College in 1809, attended Andover Theological Seminary.
2. He served as president of Dartmouth College from 1828 to 1863.
3. Lord was able to bring the college out of debt, improve the overall curriculum, and raise admission levels.
4. He was a founding member of the American Anti-Slavery Society, and in 1833 was its Vice President.
5. But his views on slavery changed dramatically; he came to see it as "not a moral evil", but "an ordinance of...God", which "providentially found a settlement in this country".
6. These views and his opposition to the Civil War, which he blamed on abolitionists,brought a storm of controversy, earning him the enmity of several members of the Dartmouth Board of Trustees, including Amos Tuck (1835), a founding member of the Republican Party and close friend of Abraham Lincoln.
7. Matters came to a head in 1863 when the Trustees were deadlocked on awarding an honorary degree to President Lincoln, and Lord broke the tie by voting against it.
8. The Trustees issued a statement: "Neither the trustees nor the Faculty coincide with the president of the College in the views which he has published, touching slavery and the war; and it has been our hope that the College would not be judged a partisan institution by reason of such publications."
9. Lord tendered his resignation.
10. He continued as an active member of the Dartmouth College community, in Hanover, New Hampshire, until his death in 1870.

supporting_facts.chunk: He graduated from Bowdoin College in 1809, attended Andover Theological Seminary.

chunks.title: Gus Van Sant
chunks.chunk:
Title: Gus Van Sant
0. Gus Green Van Sant Jr. (born July 24, 1952) is an American film director, screenwriter, painter, photographer, musician, and author who has earned acclaim as both an independent and mainstream filmmaker.
1. His films typically deal with themes of marginalized subcultures, in particular homosexuality; as such, Van Sant is considered one of the most prominent auteurs of the New Queer Cinema movement.
2. Van Sant's early career was devoted to directing television commercials in the Pacific Northwest.
3. He made his feature-length cinematic directorial debut with "Mala Noche" (1985).
4. His second feature "Drugstore Cowboy" (1989) was highly acclaimed, and earned Van Sant screenwriting awards from the Los Angeles Film Critics Association and New York Film Critics Circle and the award for Best Director from the National Society of Film Critics.
5. His following film, "My Own Private Idaho" (1991), was similarly praised, as was the black comedy "To Die For" (1995), the drama "Good Will Hunting" (1997), and the biographical film "Milk" (2008); for the latter two, Van Sant was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Director and both films received Best Picture nominations.
6. In 2003, Van Sant's film about the Columbine High School massacre, "Elephant", won the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival.
7. Van Sant also received the festival's Best Director Award that same year, making him one of only two filmmakers—the other being Joel Coen—to win both accolades at the festival in the same year.
8. Though most of Van Sant's other films received favourable reviews, such as "Finding Forrester" (2000) and "Paranoid Park" (2007), some of his efforts, such as the art house production "Last Days" (2005) and the environmental drama "Promised Land" (2012), have received more mixed reviews from critics, while his adaptation of Tom Robbins's "Even Cowgirls Get the Blues" (1994), his 1998 remake of Alfred Hitchcock's "Psycho", and "The Sea of Trees" (2015), were critical and commercial failures.
9. In addition to directing, Van Sant has written the screenplays for several of his earlier works, and is the author of a novel entitled "Pink".
10. A book of his photography, called "108 Portraits", has also been published, and he has released two musical albums.
11. He is openly gay and currently lives in Los Feliz, California.

chunks.title: My Own Private Idaho
chunks.chunk:
Title: My Own Private Idaho
0. My Own Private Idaho is a 1991 American independent adventure drama film written and directed by Gus Van Sant, loosely based on Shakespeare's" Henry IV, Part 1 Henry IV, Part 2", and" Henry V", and starring River Phoenix and Keanu Reeves.
1. The story follows two friends, Mike and Scott, as they embark on a journey of personal discovery that takes them from Portland, Oregon to Mike's hometown in Idaho, and then to Rome in search of Mike's mother.
2. Van Sant originally wrote the screenplay in the 1970s, but discarded it after reading John Rechy's 1963 novel" City of Night" and concluding that Rechy's treatment of the subject of street hustlers was better than his own.
3. Over the years, Van Sant rewrote the script, which comprised two stories: that of Mike and the search for his mother, and Scott's story as a modern update of the" Henry IV" plays.
4. Van Sant had difficulty getting Hollywood financing, and at one point considered making the film on a minuscule budget with a cast of actual street kids.
5. After he sent copies of his script to Reeves, and Reeves then showed it to Phoenix, both agreed to star in the film on each other's behalf.
6. " My Own Private Idaho" had its premiere at the 48th Venice International Film Festival, and received largely positive reviews from critics including Roger Ebert and those of" The New York Times" and" Entertainment Weekly".
7. The film was a moderate financial success, grossing over$ 6.4 million in North America, above its estimated budget of$ 2.5 million.
8. Phoenix received several awards for his performance in the film, including the Volpi Cup for Best Actor at the 1991 Venice Film Festival, Best Male Lead from the Independent Spirit Awards, and Best Actor from the National Society of Film Critics.
9. " My Own Private Idaho" is considered a landmark film in the New Queer Cinema movement, an early 1990s movement in queer- themed independent filmmaking.
10. Since its 1991 release, the film has grown in popularity and been deemed as a cult classic, especially among LGBT audiences.
11. The film is notable for its then- taboo subject matter and avant- garde style.

8. Annette then acquired the courtesy title" Her Highness, Princess of Orange- Nassau, van Vollenhoven" due to her status as the wife of a Prince of Orange- Nassau.
9. Since 2002, Princess Annette has worked as a counsellor at the AGO foundation in Amsterdam.
10. Princess Annette and Prince Bernhard have three children:

question: Are the bands The Catheters and Dark At Dawn, from the same country?

chunks.title: Dark at Dawn
chunks.chunk:
Title: Dark at Dawn
0. Dark at Dawn is a power metal band from Germany, formed in 1993.

chunks.title: The Catheters
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Catheters
0. The Catheters were a punk rock band from Bellevue, Washington, which formed in 1995 as a 4- piece with singer Brian Standeford, guitarist Derek Mason, bassist Paul Waude, and drummer James Lysons( who was soon replaced by Davey Borozowski of the band Damaged Goods).
1. They originally played hardcore punk in the vein of bands such as Black Flag and The Circle Jerks.
2. In 1998 they added second guitarist Lars Swenson and began cultivating a dirtier' 70s glam- rock sound, as heard on their eMpTy Records releases.
3. The records sold fairly well and gained them the attention of larger labels such as DreamWorks and Sub Pop, the latter of whom signed the band to a recording contract in 1999.
4. Over the course of their career they did extensive roadwork, touring North America and Europe with bands such as Sparta, Mudhoney, Run Run Run, Division of Laura Lee, and, often, the Murder City Devils.
5. Waude and Swenson left the band in 2001 for other projects, and the Catheters continued as a 4- piece with longtime roadie Leo Gebhardt joining as bassist.
6. In 2002, with the help of a popular music video, they scored an indie hit with the song" Nothing", from their album" Static Delusions and Stone- Still Days"( Sub Pop, 2002).
7. After releasing more singles and touring heavily in 2002 and 2003, the band released the acclaimed album" Howling ... It Grows and Grows !!!"
8. ( Sub Pop, 2004), which infused their earlier sound with elements of classic rock.
9. The Catheters played their final show on October 15, 2004 at Seattle's Sunset Tavern, joined by friends the Vells and blackbelt( who played some old- school Catheters covers), ending the show with a mass sing- along to their song'" Fake ID" which degenerated into instrument destruction and a minor brawl.
10. The band dissolved amicably, with Brian Standeford and Davey Borozowski forming the group Tall Birds( later joined by Leo Gebhardt), while Derek Mason went on to play keyboards in the Girls and bass in Sunday Night Blackout.
11. After Tall Birds disbanded, Standeford started Idle Times, while Borozowski went on to form the band Black Whales.
12. Borozowski also tours with the popular indy rock band Modest Mouse as their percussionist/ second drummer, alongside Jeremiah Green.
13. Idle times has released two seven- inches, and Black Whales have an EP on Mt Fuji Records and a self- released full- length album.
14. Mason's band the Girls are on Dirtnap Records.
15. The Catheters reunited to play a birthday party in January 2013, and the Sub Pop Jubilee in June 2013.

chunks.title: The Battle of the Bands
chunks.chunk:

chunks.title: Tales of Conan
chunks.chunk:
Title: Tales of Conan
0. Tales of Conan is a 1955 collection of four fantasy short stories by American writers Robert E. Howard and L. Sprague de Camp, featuring Howard's sword and sorcery hero Conan the Barbarian.
1. The tales as originally written by Howard were adventure yarns mostly set in the Middle Ages; they were rewritten as Conan stories by de Camp, who also added the fantastic element.
2. Three of the stories also appeared in the fantasy magazine" Fantastic Universe", two of them before publication of the collection and the other one after.
3. The book has also been translated into Japanese.
4. The collection never saw publication in paperback; instead, its component stories were split up and distributed among other" Conan" collections.
5. " The Flame Knife" was later also published as an independent paperback.
6. Chronologically, the four short stories collected as" Tales of Conan" represent an add- on to Gnome's Conan series, coming between stories published in the remaining volumes.
7. The first" tale" would fall within the collection" The Coming of Conan", the second between that volume and the collection" Conan the Barbarian", the third within" Conan the Barbarian", and the fourth between that volume and the collection" The Sword of Conan".

chunks.title: Robert E. Howard
chunks.chunk:
Title: Robert E. Howard
0. Robert Ervin Howard (January 22, 1906 – June 11, 1936) was an American author who wrote pulp fiction in a diverse range of genres.
1. He is well known for his character Conan the Barbarian and is regarded as the father of the sword and sorcery subgenre.
2. Howard was born and raised in Texas.
3. He spent most of his life in the town of Cross Plains, with some time spent in nearby Brownwood.
4. A bookish and intellectual child, he was also a fan of boxing and spent some time in his late teens bodybuilding, eventually taking up amateur boxing.
5. From the age of nine he dreamed of becoming a writer of adventure fiction but did not have real success until he was 23.
6. Thereafter, until his death by suicide at age 30, Howard's writings were published in a wide selection of magazines, journals, and newspapers, and he became proficient in several subgenres.
7. His greatest success occurred after his death.
8. Although a Conan novel was nearly published in 1934, Howard's stories were never collected during his lifetime.
9. The main outlet for his stories was "Weird Tales", where Howard created Conan the Barbarian.
10. With Conan and his other heroes, Howard helped fashion the genre now known as sword and sorcery, spawning many imitators and giving him a large influence in the fantasy field.
11. Howard remains a highly-read author, with his best works still reprinted.
12. Howard's suicide and the circumstances surrounding it have led to speculation about his mental health.
13. His mother had been ill with tuberculosis his entire life, and upon learning she had entered a coma from which she was not expected to wake, he walked out to his car and shot himself in the head.

Title: Conan the Adventurer (1992 TV series)
0. Conan the Adventurer is an American-French-Canadian animated television series adaptation of Conan the Barbarian, the literary character created by Robert E. Howard in the 1930s.
1. Produced by Jetlag Productions and Sunbow Productions, the series debuted on September 13, 1992, ran for 65 episodes and concluded on November 22, 1993.
2. The series was developed by Christy Marx who served as the sole story editor.
3. The series was produced in association with Graz Entertainment for the first 13-episode season; AB Productions and Jean Chalopin's Créativité et Développement for the remaining episodes.
4. The series also spawned a small toyline in 1992 created by Hasbro.
5. This first incarnation of Conan in cartoon form performed much better than its follow-up cartoon, "Conan and the Young Warriors", which lasted only 13 episodes.

chunks.title: The Man Who Knew Too Much (1956 film)
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Man Who Knew Too Much (1956 film)
0. The Man Who Knew Too Much is a 1956 American suspense thriller film directed and produced by Alfred Hitchcock, starring James Stewart and Doris Day.
1. The film is Hitchcock's second film using this title following his own 1934 film of the same name featuring a significantly different plot and script.
2. In the book- length interview" Hitchcock/ Truffaut"( 1967), in response to fellow filmmaker François Truffaut's assertion that aspects of the remake were by far superior, Hitchcock replied" Let's say the first version is the work of a talented amateur and the second was made by a professional."
3. The film won an Academy Award for Best Original Song for" Que Sera, Sera( Whatever Will Be, Will Be)", sung by Doris Day.
4. It premiered at the 1956 Cannes Film Festival on April 29.

chunks.title: The Girl Who Knew Too Much (1963 film)
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Girl Who Knew Too Much (1963 film)
0. The Girl Who Knew Too Much is a 1963 Italian giallo film.
1. Directed by Italian filmmaker Mario Bava, the film stars John Saxon as Dr. Marcello Bassi and Letícia Román as Nora Davis.
2. The plot revolves around a young woman named Nora, who travels to Rome and witnesses a murder.
3. The police and Dr. Bassi do n't believe her since a corpse ca n't be found.
4. Several more murders follow, tied to a decade- long string of killings of victims chosen in alphabetical order.
5. " The Girl Who Knew Too Much" is considered to be the first giallo film, a film genre with a mixture of thriller, sexploitation and horror conventions.
6. An alternative cut titled" Evil Eye" was released in the United States by American International Pictures; this version features a score by Les Baxter, deletes several scenes, and adds others which place a greater emphasis on comedy compared to the Italian release.

chunks.title: The Girl Who Knew Too Much (1969 film)
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Girl Who Knew Too Much (1969 film)
0. The Girl Who Knew Too Much is a 1969 neo noir film starring Adam West as Johnny Cain, a nightclub owner and former freelance adventurer who is forced out of retirement when a crime syndicate boss is murdered in his nightclub and investigations lead into unexpected areas.
1. It was the final film of director Francis D. Lyon and United Pictures Corporation.
2. The film co-stars Nancy Kwan, Nehemiah Persoff, Robert Alda, Patricia Smith, David Brian, and noted jazz musician Buddy Greco as nightclub entertainer Albert" Lucky" Jones.
3. The melodramatic promotional tagline of" The Girl Who Knew Too Much" was:" You have to be crazy or in love — to take on the syndicate!"
4. The film was intended to be a vehicle for Adam West to escape his Batman stereotype by playing a cynical, hard- edged tough guy.
5. The movie's dialogue is typified by a scene between West's Cain and the boozy Mrs. Grinaldi played by Smith:" The Girl Who Knew Too Much" was not a box office success in theatrical release, but became a staple of late- night showings on WCBS- TV and other television stations in the early 1970s.
6. It then disappeared from sight for decades and was in danger of becoming a lost film.
7. However, it finally appeared in a home video release that came on May 28, 2013, on Blu-ray and DVD.

chunks.title: Man on Wire
chunks.chunk:
Title: Man on Wire
0. Man on Wire is a 2008 British- American biographical documentary film directed by James Marsh.
1. The film chronicles Philippe Petit's 1974 high- wire walk between the Twin Towers of New York's World Trade Center.
2. It is based on Petit's book," To Reach the Clouds", released in paperback with the title" Man on Wire".
3. The title of the film is taken from the police report that led to the arrest( and later release) of Petit, whose performance had lasted for almost one hour.
4. The film is crafted like a heist film, presenting rare footage of the preparations for the event and still photographs of the walk, alongside re-enactments( with Paul McGill as the young Petit) and present- day interviews with the participants, including Barry Greenhouse, an insurance executive who served as the inside man.
5. " Man on Wire" competed in the World Cinema Documentary Competition at the 2008 Sundance Film Festival, where it won the Grand Jury Prize: World Cinema Documentary and the World Cinema Audience Award: Documentary.
6. In February 2009, the film won the BAFTA for Outstanding British Film, the Independent Spirit Awards, and the Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature.

chunks.title: The Man Who Knew Too Much (1934 film)
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Man Who Knew Too Much (1934 film)
0. The Man Who Knew Too Much is a 1934 British thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock, featuring Peter Lorre, and released by Gaumont British.
1. It was one of the most successful and critically acclaimed films of Hitchcock's British period.
2. The film is Hitchcock's first film using this title and was followed later with his own 1956 film using the same name featuring a significantly different plot and script.
3. The second film featured James Stewart and Doris Day, and was made for Paramount Pictures.
4. The two films are very different in tone.
5. In the book- length interview" Hitchcock/ Truffaut"( 1967), in response to filmmaker François Truffaut's assertion that aspects of the remake were by far superior, Hitchcock replied," Let's say the first version is the work of a talented amateur and the second was made by a professional."
6. However, it's been claimed this statement can not be taken at face value.
7. The 1934 film has nothing except the title in common with G. K. Chesterton's 1922 book of detective stories of the same name.
8. Hitchcock decided to use the title because he held the film rights for some of the stories in the book.
