chunks.chunk:
Title: John III, Duke of Cleves
0. John III "the Peaceful", Duke of Cleves and Count of Mark
1. (John III, Duke of Cleves;
2. John I, Duke of Jülich-Berg; ; 10 November 1490 – 6 February 1538 or 1539) was a son of John II, Duke of Cleves and Mathilde of Hesse, daughter of Henry III, Landgrave of Upper Hesse.
3. John III became Regent of the United Duchies of Jülich-Cleves-Berg in 1521, and Lord of Ravensberg in 1528.
4. John represented a compensatory attitude, which strove for a , a middle way, between the two confessions during the Protestant Reformation.
5. Despite what others may have thought, not all Germanic princely houses were Lutheran Protestant.
6. In fact the real influence at the court of Cleves was Erasmus.
7. Many of his men were friends and followers of this well-educated Dutch scholar and theologian.
8. When Duke John decided to write up a list of church regulations, Erasmus was the first person the Duke went to personally for consultation and approval.
9. Duke John had an instinct for balance as was shown when he married his eldest daughter Sybille to John Frederick of Saxony.
10. John Frederick would go on to later head the Schmalkaldic League.
11. In many ways John of Cleves' court was ideal for raising a Queen.
12. It was fundamentally liberal, but serious-minded, theologically inclined, profoundly Erasmian; as the court of Catherine of Aragon had once been.
13. It was from this court that his daughter Anne would be raised.
14. Anne would go on to marry King Henry VIII of England as his fourth wife.

1. He was educated at Harrow School and Trinity College, Cambridge, where he was a member of the University Pitt Club and graduated as MA in 1845.
2. After being ordained priest in 1850, he became successively parish Rector of Willey, Shropshire 1850-53; Blymhill, Staffordshire in 1853-64 (besides Rural Dean of Brewood in 1863); and of Wigan, Lancashire from 1864 until his death.
3. While at Wigan he also became Honorary Canon of Chester Cathedral in 1872, then of Liverpool Cathedral following the creation of the latter diocese in 1880, which incorporated his parish.
4. He was also chaplain to Queen Victoria from 1872.
5. He was JP for the counties of Shropshire and Staffordshire and an early trustee of the William Salt Library, Stafford.
6. He began to study his family history, and contributed several articles to "Archaeologia Cambrensis".
7. The outcome of his research into genealogy was "History of the Princes of South Wales" (1876).
8. He died at The Hall, Wigan, in 1895, aged seventy-two.

chunks.title: Qianlong Emperor
chunks.chunk:
Title: Qianlong Emperor
0. The Qianlong Emperor (25 September 1711 – 7 February 1799) was the sixth Emperor of the Qing dynasty, and the fourth Qing emperor to rule over China proper, reigned from 1735 to 1796.
1. Born Hongli, the fourth son of the Yongzheng Emperor, he reigned officially from 11 October 1735 to 8 February 1796.
2. On 8 February, he abdicated in favour of his son, the Jiaqing Emperor—a filial act in order not to reign longer than his grandfather, the illustrious Kangxi Emperor.
3. Despite his retirement, however, he retained ultimate power as the Retired Emperor until his death in 1799; he thus was one of the longest-reigning "de facto" rulers in the history of the world, and dying at the age of 87, one of the longest-lived.
4. As a capable and cultured ruler inheriting a thriving empire, during his long reign the Qing Empire reached its most splendid and prosperous era, boasting a large population and economy.
5. As a military leader, he led military campaigns expanding the dynastic territory to the largest extent by conquering and sometimes destroying Central Asian kingdoms.
6. This turned around in his late years: the Qing empire began to decline with corruption and wastefulness in his court and a stagnating civil society.
7. A British valet who accompanied his diplomat master to the Qing court in 1793 described the emperor:
8. The Emperor is about five feet ten inches in height, and of a slender but elegant form; his complexion is comparatively fair, though his eyes are dark; his nose is rather aquiline, and the whole of his countenance presents a perfect regularity of feature, which, by no means, announce the great age he is said to have attained; his person is attracting, and his deportment accompanied by an affability, which, without lessening the dignity of the prince, evinces the amiable character of the man.
9. His dress consisted of a loose robe of yellow silk, a cap of black velvet with a red ball on the top, and adorned with a peacock's feather, which is the peculiar distinction of mandarins of the first class.
10. He wore silk boots embroidered with gold, and a sash of blue girded his waist.

chunks.title: Jeanne de Salzmann
chunks.chunk:
Title: Jeanne de Salzmann
0. Jeanne de Salzmann born Jeanne- Marie Allemand often addressed as Madame de Salzmann( January 26, 1889, Reims – May 24, 1990, Paris) was the daughter of the famous Swiss architect Jules Louis Allemand and of Marie Louise Matignon.
1. She was a French- Swiss dance teacher and a close pupil of the spiritual teacher G. I. Gurdjieff, recognized as his deputy by many of Gurdjieff's other pupils.
2. She was responsible for transmitting the movements and his teaching through the Gurdjieff Institute of Paris, the Gurdjieff Foundation of New York City, the Gurdjieff Society in London and the Fundación Gurdjieff of Caracas, which she founded or helped founding, as well as other formal and informal groups throughout the world.
3. Madame de Salzmann began her career at the Conservatory of Geneva, studying piano.
4. Later a student of Émile Jaques- Dalcroze in Germany from 1912, she taught dance and rhythmic movements.
5. She met her husband Alexandre de Salzmann in Hellerau at Dalcroze's Institute.
6. They married on September 6 in Geneva.
7. With him she had a daughter, Nathalie de Salzmann( 1919- 2007).
8. The First World
9. War caused the closure of Dalcroze's Institute and Jeanne and her husband Alexandre moved to Tiflis, Georgia where she continued to teach.
10. In 1919, Thomas de Hartmann introduced the de Salzmanns to George Gurdjieff, a relationship that would last until Gurdjieff's death in 1949.
11. She worked with Gurdjieff for nearly 30 years.
12. She led the Gurdjieff Institute of Paris and continued Gurdjieff's teachings, emphasizing work with the movements, until she died, 101 years old, in 1990.
13. Jeanne de Salzmann played a major role in realizing the 1977 movie" Meetings with Remarkable Men" by Peter Brook.
14. She was buried at Cimetière de Plainpalais in Geneva.
15. After her death, her son Michel de Salzmann( 1923- 2001) took over the leadership of the organization and a book," The Reality of Being", was made, faithful to the notebooks she kept for 40 years, witnessing her work and teaching after Gurdjieff died

chunks.title: Anthemiolus
chunks.chunk:
Title: Anthemiolus
0. Anthemiolus (died c. 471 AD) was the son of the Western Roman Emperor Anthemius (467–472) and Marcia Euphemia, daughter of the Eastern Roman emperor Marcian.
1. His name means "little Anthemius" and is a diminutive of his and his father's name Anthemius, in order to distinguish them both.
2. His life is known only from the "Chronica Gallica of 511".
3. He was sent by his father to Gaul with a powerful army, accompanied by three generals — Thorisarius, Everdingus, and Hermianus — in order to oppose the Visigoths then occupying Provence and threatening to conquer the Auvergne.
4. He and his generals were defeated by the Visigothic king Euric near Arles and all four of them lost their lives.
5. The "Chronica", in entry 649, states:
6. Antimolus a patre Anthemio imperatore cum Thorisario, Everdingo et Hermiano com.
7. stabuli Arelate directus est, quibus rex Euricus trans
8. Rhodanum occurrit occisisque ducibus omnia vastavit
9. Antimolus was sent by his father, Emperor Anthemius, to Arles, with Thorisarius, Everdingus and Hermanius, "comes" [or "comitesstabuli":
10. King Euric met them on the far side of the Rhone and, having killed the "duces", laid everything waste.
11. According to the "Chronica", this event falls between the succession of Euric (467) and the war between Anthemius and Ricimer (471–472).
12. It can probably be further narrowed to the period when Anthemius is known to have been organising a concerted effort to remove the Visigoths from Gaul between 468 and 471, a period during which an army led by the Briton Riothamus was defeated near Déols.
13. It is not impossible that Anthemiolus' army was sent to reinforce Riothamus and that Euric defeated both forces in turn, probably in either 470 or 471.

chunks.title: Anthemius
chunks.chunk:
Title: Anthemius
0. Anthemius (– 11 July 472) was Western Roman Emperor from 467 to 472.
1. Perhaps the last capable Western Roman Emperor, Anthemius attempted to solve the two primary military challenges facing the remains of the Western Roman Empire: the resurgent Visigoths, under Euric, whose domain straddled the Pyrenees; and the unvanquished Vandals, under Geiseric, in undisputed control of North Africa.
2. Anthemius was killed by Ricimer, his own general of Gothic descent, who contested power with him.

chunks.title: Rumbold of Mechelen
chunks.chunk:
Title: Rumbold of Mechelen
0. Saint Rumbold( or" RumoldRomuold") was an Irish or Scottish Christian missionary, although his true nationality is not known for certain.
1. He was martyred near Mechelen by two men, whom he had denounced for their evil ways.
2. Saint Rumbold's feast day is celebrated by the Roman Catholic Church, and Western Rite Orthodox Churches, on 24 June; and it is celebrated in Ireland on 3 July.
3. He is the patron saint of Mechelen, where St. Rumbold's Cathedral possesses an elaborate golden shrine on its high altar, containing relics attributed to the saint.
4. It is rumoured that his remains are buried inside the cathedral.
5. Twenty- five paintings in the choir illustrate his life.

chunks.title: Waylon Jennings
chunks.chunk:
Title: Waylon Jennings
0. Waylon Arnold Jennings (June 15, 1937 – February 13, 2002) was an American singer, songwriter, and musician.
1. Jennings began playing guitar at age eight and began performing at age twelve on KVOW radio, after which he formed his first band, The Texas Longhorns.
2. Jennings left high school at age sixteen, determined to become a musician, and bounced around as a performer and DJ on KVOW, KDAV, KYTI, KLLL, in Coolidge, Arizona, and Phoenix.
3. In 1958, Buddy Holly arranged Jennings's first recording session, and hired him to play bass.
4. Jennings gave up his seat on the ill-fated flight in 1959 that crashed and killed Holly, J. P. "
5. The Big Bopper" Richardson and Ritchie Valens.
6. Jennings formed a rockabilly club band, The Waylors, which became the house band at "JD's", a club in Scottsdale, Arizona.
7. He recorded for independent label Trend Records and A&M Records, but did not achieve success until moving to RCA Victor, taking on Neil Reshen as a manager, who negotiated significantly better touring and recording contracts for him.
8. After finally wresting creative control from RCA Victor, his career turning point became the critically acclaimed albums "Lonesome, On'ry and Mean" and "Honky Tonk Heroes", followed by hit LPs "Dreaming My Dreams" and "Are You Ready for the Country".
9. During the 1970s, Jennings was instrumental in the inception of outlaw country and with Willie Nelson, Tompall Glaser, and Jessi Colter recorded country music's first platinum album, "Wanted!
10. The Outlaws".
11. It was followed by "Ol' Waylon" and the hit song "Luckenbach, Texas".
12. Jennings was featured in the 1978 album "White Mansions", performed by various artists documenting the lives of people in the Confederacy during the Civil War.
13. Jennings also appeared in films and television series, including Sesame Street, and a stint as the balladeer for "The Dukes of Hazzard", composing and singing the show's theme song and providing narration for the show.
14. By the early 1980s, Jennings struggled with a cocaine addiction, which he overcame in 1984.
15. Later, he joined the country supergroup The Highwaymen with Willie Nelson, Kris Kristofferson, and Johnny Cash, which released three albums between 1985 and 1995.
16. During that period, Jennings released the successful album "Will the Wolf Survive".
17. He toured less after 1997 to spend more time with his family.
18. Between 1999 and 2001, his appearances were limited by health problems.
19. In 2001, he was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame.
20. In 2007, he was posthumously awarded the Cliffie Stone Pioneer Award by the Academy of Country Music.

question: Who is Charles D'Orléans, Duke Of Penthièvre's paternal grandfather?
answer: Louis Philippe II, Duke of Orléans

chunks.title: Louis Philippe I
chunks.chunk:
Title: Louis Philippe I
0. Louis Philippe I( 6 October 1773 – 26 August 1850) was King of the French from 1830 to 1848.
1. As Duke of Chartres he distinguished himself commanding troops during the Revolutionary Wars but broke with the Republic over its decision to execute King Louis XVI.
2. He fled to Switzerland in 1793 after being connected with a plot to restore France's monarchy.
3. His father Louis Philippe II, Duke of Orléans( Philippe Égalité) fell under suspicion and was executed, and Louis Philippe remained in exile for 21 years until the Bourbon Restoration.
4. He was proclaimed king in 1830 after his cousin Charles X was forced to abdicate by the July Revolution.
5. The reign of Louis Philippe is known as the July Monarchy and was dominated by wealthy industrialists and bankers.
6. He followed conservative policies, especially under the influence of French statesman François Guizot during the period 1840 – 48.
7. He also promoted friendship with Britain and sponsored colonial expansion, notably the French conquest of Algeria.
8. His popularity faded as economic conditions in France deteriorated in 1847, and he was forced to abdicate after the outbreak of the French Revolution of 1848.
9. He lived out his life in exile in the United Kingdom.
10. His supporters were known as Orléanists, as opposed to Legitimists who supported the main line of the House of Bourbon.

He was the son of François de Luxembourg and Charlotte de Brosse, daughter of René de Brosse. 2. Nephew of Jean de Brosse, duc d'Étampes, he was allowed to inherit his uncle's taken estates and was subsequently created the 1st Duke of Penthièvre. 3. He participated at the Siege of Leith in 1560, but was killed on November 19 1569 at the Siege of Saint- Jean- d'Angely .
4. His only daughter and heiress Marie de Luxembourg married Philippe- Emmanuel de Lorraine, duc de Mercœur, the rebel in Brittany.

chunks.title: John, Prince of Portugal (1451)
chunks.chunk:
Title: John, Prince of Portugal (1451)
0. John, Prince of Portugal was a Portuguese infante, son of Afonso V and Isabella of Coimbra.
1. He was born heir to the throne in 1451, but he died young during the same year.
2. The title of Prince of Portugal then passed again to Infante Ferdinand, Duke of Viseu, his uncle.

chunks.title: João de Lencastre, 1st Duke of Aveiro
chunks.chunk:
Title: João de Lencastre, 1st Duke of Aveiro
0. João de Lencastre(?, 1501 – Coimbra, 1571), was the older son of Infante George, Duke of Coimbra and of his wife" Dona" Beatriz of Vilhena.
1. Through his father, John was a grandchild of King John II of Portugal and a 3rd cousin to King Manuel I of Portugal.
2. Through his mother, daughter of Álvaro of Braganza( 4th male son of Fernando I, 2nd Duke of Braganza), John of Lencastre was close related to the most prestigious aristocratic families of the Kingdom( namely the Duke of Braganza, the Marquis of Ferreira, the Marquis of Vila Real, the Count of Vimioso, the Count of Portalegre).
3. When he was 12 years old, he served crown prince John( who became later King John III of Portugal) and King Manuel I granted him the title of Marquis of Torres Novas by a royal decree issued on March 27, 1520.
4. In that time, the royal house announced the marriage of Infante Ferdinand, Duke of Guarda( King Manuel I younger son) to the richest and prestigious heir" Dona" Guiomar Coutinho, 5th Countess of Marialva and the 3rd Countess of Loulé.
5. However, John of Lencastre declared he had secretly married the richest bride.
6. The scandal in the Court ended when King John III ordered the Marquis imprisonment in the Castle of São Jorge, in Lisbon, allowing the celebration of the Infante Ferdinand's marriage.
7. After nine years, when he was released, he went to live in Setúbal, maybe ashamed for the situation, and he only returned to the Court in 1535, to escort Infante Luis, Duke of Beja, who was leading the Portuguese fleet in Charles V ’s crusade against Tunis.
8. In that year King John III granted him the title of Duke of Aveiro.
9. After his return from Madrid, in 1537( where he was sent by King John III to present formal condolences to Charles V, when his wife, Empress Isabel of Portugal, died) John of Lencastre, 1st Duke of Aveiro, decided to marry to" Dona" Juliana de Lara, daughter of the 3rd Marquis of Vila Real.
10. In 1552, he was again chosen by the King to escort, from the border to Lisbon, the Infanta Joan of Spain, who would marry John, Crown Prince of Portugal( John III only surviving son).
11. John of Lencastre and Juliana de Lara had two sons: John of Lencastre wrote several books and built a magnificent convent in Arrábida, near Setúbal, where an annual music festival takes place.

Germany, Year Zero is a 1948 film directed by Roberto Rossellini, and is the final film in Rossellini's unofficial war film trilogy, following" Rome, Open City" and" Pais à Germany Year Zero" takes place in Allied- occupied Germany, unlike the others, which take place in German- occupied Rome and during the Allied invasion of Italy, respectively.
1. As in many neorealist films, Rossellini used mainly local, non-professional actors.
2. He filmed on locations in Berlin and intended to convey the reality in Germany the year after its near total destruction in World War II.
3. It contains dramatic images of bombed out Berlin and of the human struggle for survival following the destruction of Nazi Germany.
4. When explaining his ideas about realism in an interview, he said," realism is nothing other than the artistic form of truth."

chunks.title: Emperor Zhang of Han
chunks.chunk:
Title: Emperor Zhang of Han
0. Emperor Zhang of Han (57 – 9 April 88) was an emperor of the Chinese Han dynasty from 75 to 88.
1. He was the third emperor of the Eastern Han.
2. Emperor Zhang was a hardworking and diligent emperor.
3. He reduced taxes and paid close attention to all affairs of state.
4. Zhang also reduced government spending as well as promoted Confucianism.
5. As a result, Han society prospered and its culture flourished during this period.
6. Along with his father Emperor Ming, Emperor Zhang's reign has been highly praised and was regarded as the golden age of the Eastern Han period, and their reigns are collectively known as the Rule of Ming and Zhang.
7. During his reign, Chinese troops under the leadership of General Ban Chao, progressed far west while in pursuit of Xiongnu insurgents harassing the trade routes now collectively known as the Silk Road.
8. The Eastern Han dynasty, after Emperor Zhang, would be plagued with internal strife between royal factions and eunuchs struggling for power.
9. The people for the coming century and a half would yearn for the good days of Emperors Ming and Zhang.
10. (However, part of the strife came from the power obtained by consort clans – and the precedent was set by Emperor Zhang's bestowing of power on both his adoptive mother Empress Dowager Ma's clan and his wife Empress Dou's clan.)

0. The Ancient Egyptian artisan Sennedjem lived in Set Maat( translated as" The Place of Truth"), contemporary Deir el- Medina, on the west bank of the Nile, opposite Thebes, during the reigns of Seti I and Ramesses II.
1. Sennedjem had the title" Servant in the Place of Truth".
2. He was buried along with his wife, Iyneferti, and family in a tomb in the village necropolis.
3. His tomb was discovered January 31, 1886.
4. When Sennedjem's tomb was found, in it there was regular furniture from his home, including a stool and a bed, which he actually used when he was alive.
5. His titles included Servant in the Place of Truth, meaning that he worked on the excavation and decoration of the nearby royal tombs.

chunks.title: Saparmurat Niyazov
chunks.chunk:
Title: Saparmurat Niyazov
0. Saparmurat Atayevich Niyazov (Cyrillic: Сапармырат Атаевич Ныязов; 19 February 1940 – 21 December 2006; also known as Türkmenbaşy (Head of the Turkmen) or Beýik Türkmenbaşy (Great Head of the Turkmen) was a Turkmen politician who served as the leader of Turkmenistan from 1985 until his death in 2006.
1. He was First Secretary of the Turkmen Communist Party from 1985 until 1991 and supported the 1991 Soviet coup d'état attempt.
2. He continued to lead Turkmenistan for 15 years after independence from the Soviet Union in 1991.
3. Turkmen media referred to him using the title "His Excellency Saparmurat Türkmenbaşy, President of Turkmenistan and Chairman of the Cabinet of Ministers".
4. His self-given title Türkmenbaşy, meaning "Head of the Turkmen"
5. , referred to his position as the founder and president of the Association of Turkmens of the World.
6. In 1999, the Assembly of Turkmenistan declared Niyazov President for Life of Turkmenistan.
7. In his time, he was one of the world's most totalitarian, despotic and repressive dictators.
8. He promoted a cult of personality around himself and imposed his personal eccentricities upon the country, such as renaming Turkmen months and days of the week to references of his autobiography the "Ruhnama".
9. He made it mandatory to read the "Ruhnama" in schools, universities and governmental organizations, new governmental employees were tested on the book at job interviews and
10. an exam on its teachings was a part of the driving test in Turkmenistan.
11. In 2005, he closed down all rural libraries and hospitals outside of the capital city Ashgabat, in a country where at that time more than half the population lived in rural areas, once stating that, "If people are ill, they can come to Ashgabat."
12. Under his rule, Turkmenistan had the lowest life expectancy in Central Asia.
13. Global Witness, a London-based human rights organisation, reported that money under Niyazov's control and held overseas may be in excess of US$3 billion, of which between $1.8–$2.6 billion was allegedly situated in the Foreign Exchange Reserve Fund at Deutsche Bank in Germany.

0. In Switzerland, the place of origin( literally" home place" or" citizen place") denotes where a Swiss citizen has their municipal citizenship.
1. It is not to be confused with the place of birth or place of residence, although two or all three of these locations may be identical depending on the person's circumstances.

chunks.title: Place of birth
chunks.chunk:
Title: Place of birth
0. The place of birth( POB) or birthplace is the place where a person was born.
1. This place is often used in legal documents, together with name and date of birth, to uniquely identify a person.
2. As a general rule with respect to passports, the place of birth is determined to be the country that currently has" sovereignty" over the actual place of birth, regardless of when the birth actually occurred.
3. The place of birth is not necessarily the place where the parents of the new baby live.
4. If the baby is born in a hospital in another place, that place is the place of birth.
5. In many countries, this also means that the government requires that the birth of the new baby is registered in the place of birth.
6. Some countries place less or no importance on the place of birth, instead using alternative geographical characteristics for the purpose of identity documents.
7. For example, Sweden has used the concept of" födelsehemortdomicile of birth") since 1947.
8. This means that the domicile of the baby's mother is the registered place of birth.
9. The location of the maternity ward or other physical birthplace is considered unimportant.
10. Similarly, Switzerland uses the concept of" Heimatortlieu d'origineluogo d'origineplace of origin" in German, French and Italian respectively).
11. A child born to Swiss parents is automatically assigned the place of origin of the parent with the same last name, so the child either gets their mother's or father's place of origin.
12. A child born to one Swiss parent and one foreign parent acquires the place of origin of their Swiss parent.
13. In a Swiss passport and identity card, the holder's place of origin is stated, not their place of birth.
14. In some countries( primarily in the Americas), the place of birth automatically determines the nationality of the baby, a practice often referred to by the Latin phrase" jus soli".
15. Almost all countries outside the Americas instead attribute nationality based on the nationality( ies) of the baby's parents( referred to as" jus sanguinis").
16. There can be some confusion regarding the place of birth if the birth takes place in an unusual way: when babies are born on an airplane or at sea, difficulties can arise.
17. The place of birth of such a person depends on the law of the countries involved, which include the nationality of the plane or ship, the nationality( ies) of the parents and/ or the location of the plane or ship( if the birth occurs in the territorial waters or airspace of a country).
18. Some administrative forms may request the applicant's" country of birth".
19. It is important to determine from the requester whether the information requested refers to the applicant's" place of birth" or" nationality at birth".
20. For US citizens born abroad who under the US Constitution acquire US citizenship at the time of birth, the nationality at birth will be USA( American), while the place of birth would be the country in which the actual birth takes place.

chunks.title: Alexander (grandson of Herod the Great)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Alexander (grandson of Herod the Great)
0. Alexander, also known by his Roman name Gaius Julius Alexander( 15 BC- probably between 26- 28 AD) was a Herodian Prince.
1. Alexander was the second born son of Alexander and Glaphyra.
2. His oldest brother was called Tigranes and had a younger unnamed sister.
3. His father Alexander was a Judean Prince, of Jewish, Nabataean and Edomite descent and was a son of King of Judea, Herod the Great and his wife Mariamne.
4. His mother Glaphyra was a Cappadocian Princess, who was of Greek, Armenian and Persian descent.
5. She was the daughter of the King Archelaus of Cappadocia and her mother was an unnamed Princess from Armenia, possibly a relation of the Artaxiad Dynasty.
6. Alexander was the namesake of his father.
7. His name reflects his Hasmonean and Hellenic lineage.
8. Alexander was born and raised in Herod's court in Jerusalem.
9. After the death and burial of his father in 7 BC, Herod acted in an extreme and brutal manner returning his mother to Cappadocia, forcing her to leave her children under the sole custody of Herod in Jerusalem.
10. Alexander and his brother remained under Herod's guardianship so he could be able to control their fates.
11. Another son of Herod's Antipater, was concerned for Alexander and his brother as he expected them to attain higher station than their own late fathers, because of the assistance Antipater considered likely from their maternal grandfather Archelaus.
12. In the time Alexander lived in Herod's court, he was betrothed to the daughter of Pheroras.
13. Pheroras was Alexander's paternal great- uncle and was Herod's brother.
14. Antipater persuaded Herod to call off Alexander's betrothal to Pheroras ’ daughter because Antipater convinced his father that closer ties between Pheroras and Archelaus of Cappadocia were liable to develop into a plot against Herod.
15. Herod died in 4 BC in Jericho.
16. After the death of Herod, Alexander and his brother decided to leave Jerusalem and to live with their mother and her family in the Cappadocian Royal Court.
17. After Alexander and his brother arrived in Cappadocia, they disavowed their Jewish descent, deserted their Jewish religion and embraced their Greek descent, including the religion.
18. However the family connections to the Herodian Dynasty were n't wholly broken.
19. After Alexander and his brother disavowed their Jewish descent, they were considered among fellow Jews as gentiles.
20. There is a possibility that his maternal grandfather sent Alexander to be educated in Rome.
21. Little is known of the adult life of Alexander.
22. He appeared to an administrator for the extensive land estates in Egypt that were owned by the Imperial family of Rome and he was a wealthy landowner, owing two estates in the Egyptian town of Euhemeria.
23. Alexander married an unnamed noblewoman who flourished in the reigns of the first two Roman Emperors Augustus and Tiberius.
24. His wife bore him a son called Tigranes.
25. Alexander named his son in honor of his brother.
26. Tigranes later served as a Roman Client King of Armenia under the reign of Roman Emperor Nero( reigned 54- 68).
27. Roman Empress Livia Drusilla and her daughter- in- law Antonia Minor were mentioned in Alexander's will.

chunks.title: Anil Biswas (composer)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Anil Biswas (composer)
0. Anil Krishna Biswas (अनिल कृष्ण विश्वास / অনিল বিশ্বাস; 7 July 1914 – 31 May 2003) was an noted Indian film music director and playback singer from 1935 to 1965, who apart from being one of pioneers of playback singing, is also credited for the first Indian orchestra of twelve pieces and introducing orchestral music and full-blooded choral effects, into Indian cinema.
1. A master in western symphonic music was known for the Indian classical or folk elements, especially Baul and Bhatiyali in his music.
2. Out of his over 90 films, most memorable were, "Roti" (1942), "Kismet" (1943), "Anokha Pyaar" (1948), "Taraana" (1951), "Waaris" (1954), "Pardesi" (1957) and "Char Dil Char Rahen" (1959).
3. He was also the pioneer in using the counter melody in film scores, employing technique of western music, ‘cantala’, where one line overlaps the other in contra-melody, recitative prose songs as in "Roti" (1942), besides he was the first one to start extensively using the Ragmala.
4. Another important element that he introduced was western orchestration, using indigenous instruments both in the songs as well as in their melodic interludes, a trend that soon caught on and paved way for the musicals of Indian cinema today.
5. He was awarded the Sangeet Natak Akademi Award in 1986, given by the Sangeet Natak Akademi, India's National Academy of Music, Dance & Drama.

0. Louis III( d. August 12? 1189), Count of Chiny, son of Albert, Count of Chiny, and his spouse Agnes of Bar.

chunks.title: Louis IV, Count of Chiny
chunks.chunk:
Title: Louis IV, Count of Chiny
0. Louis IV the Young (1173-7 October 1226), Count of Chiny from 1189 to 1226, son of Louis III, Count of Chiny, and Sophie.
1. Louis was the last of the first dynasty of Counts of Chiny.
2. Having no son, he prepared his eldest daughter Jeanne as his successor.
3. Louis marked his reign by issuing the first postage stamp in the county.
4. He succeeded as count in 1189 when his father died on the Third Crusade, but was under the supervision of his mother and uncle Thierry, Lord of Mellier, because of his young age.
5. He likely participated in the Albigensian Crusade, where he died in Cahors.
6. He married Matilda of Avesnes, widow of Nicolas IV, Lord of Rumigny, and daughter of James, Lord of Avesnes and Conde, and Adele, Lady of Guise.
7. They had three children:
8. Isabelle was referred to as Madame de Florenville during the in 1285, hosted by Louis' grandson Louis V, successor Count of Chiny,
Upon Louis’ death, his daughter Jeanne became Countess of Chiny until her marriage to Arnold IV, when he became the first Count of Chiny of the second dynasty as Arnold II.
9. Louis IV was also a direct paternal descendant of Charlemagne.

chunks.title: Dodo of Cons
chunks.chunk:
Title: Dodo of Cons
0. Dodo of Cons( Dudo of Konz- Saarburg)( fl. 1096), lord of Cons- la- Grandville, a nobleman from the Lotharingian territories, son of Adelon( Adelo) de Cons.
1. Dodo was originally from Konz, above Trier at the confluence of the Moselle and Sauer rivers.
2. Dodo had taken the cross and joined in the First Crusade and was lucky enough to return unscathed along with his wife, a countess of Chiny.
3. Cons- la- Grandville was a commune of Meurthe- et- Moselle in what is now northeastern France on the river Chiers.
4. Dodo was a benefactor of the abbey of Saint- Hubert to which he donated the priory of St Michael.
5. His father, Adelo was master of the castle of Dun on the Meuse which had been given to the church of Verdun by Emperor Henry IV.
6. On Adelo's death his lands were divided between his sons Walter, who received Dun, and Dodo who received Cons.
7. Dodo was a crusader who was one of the many leading knights from Walloon and the Lotharingian territories that joined the army of Godfrey of Bouillon in the First Crusade.
8. These included Godfrey's brothers and their cousin Baldwin of Le Bourg, Baldwin II, Count of Hainaut, Rainald( or Reinhard), Count of Toul, Warner, Count of Grez, Baldwin of Stavelot, Peter of Stenay, and the brothers Henry and Godfrey of Esch.
9. Dodo was known to have been at the siege of Nicaea in 1097.
10. Dodo married Hadvide of Chiny, daughter of Arnold I, Count of Chiny.
11. Murray identifies her as" Hadwida, daughter of Arnulf II of Chiny" but such different spellings are common in historical documents.
12. The confusion about the numbering is rampant among the counts of Chiny and Looz, especially once the countships merged.
13. Even before that, Arnold I and Arnold II, who were counts of Looz before the merger with the counts of Chiny, were often confused with each other.
14. Dodo and Hadvide are not known to have had any children, although a son named Quino has been attributed to Dodo.
15. Hadvide accompanied her husband on the First Crusade.
16. It is unclear what her role was during the crusade, but she did procure a complete set of vestments in black cloth and gold trim, and a chalice made of gold and adorned with jewels.
17. These were donated to the monks of St. Hubert- en- Ardenne, named in honor of Hubert, Bishop of Liege, patron of archers, dogs, mathematicians and metal workers.
18. Many of the original places of worship still exist at St. Hubert.
19. The relic, which dates to the twelfth century, may include elements of this chalice.
20. The vestments are not known to have survived.

chunks.title: Louis, Count of Verdun
chunks.chunk:
Title: Louis, Count of Verdun
0. Louis I (murdered September 29, 1025), Count of Chiny (987-1025) and Count of Verdun (as Louis) (1024-1025), son of Otto I, Count of Chiny, and an unknown mother.
Upon Otto’s death, Louis became the second Count of Chiny.
1. Virtually nothing is known about his rule in Chiny.
2. In 1024, Reginbert, the Bishop of Verdun, appointed Louis as Count of Verdun when Count Herman of Ename, son of Godfrey the Prisoner, retired to a monastery.
3. Herman's nephew, Godfrey the Bearded, coveted the position, and Gothelo (Herman’s brother and Godfrey’s father) invaded the city and murdered Louis.
4. Louis married Adelaide (d. after 1025), of unknown parentage.
5. They had two children:
Louis’ son Louis II assumed the position of Count of Chiny after his father’s death, and Godfrey the Bearded was appointed Count of Verdun.

1. He succeeded his father in 1272 or 1273, as the Count of Looz and Chiny.
2. Virtually nothing is known about his reign.
3. He first married, in 1258, Matilda, daughter of William IV, Count of Jülich, and Matilda of Gelderland.
4. Their children were:
5. Widowed, he married secondly, in 1269, Isabelle de Conde (d. after 1280), daughter of Jacques, Seigneur of Conde and Bailleul, and his wife Agnes of Rœulx.
6. Their children were::
Upon his death, he was succeeded as Count of Chiny by his brother Louis, and as Count of Looz by his son Arnold.

chunks.title: Louis V, Count of Chiny
chunks.chunk:
Title: Louis V, Count of Chiny
0. Louis V (1235-1299), Count of Chiny (1268-1299), the youngest son of Arnold IV, Count of Looz and Chiny, and Jeanne, Countess of Chiny.
1. He became Count of Chiny in 1268 when his parents entrusted him with the county before their death.
2. In 1285, he brought to Chauvency-le-Château one of the most famous jousting tournaments (a “tournament of chivalry”) of the Middle Ages, which pitted knights from the Empire, France, Lotharingia, Hainault, Flanders, and England, against each other in two days of solo-contest jousting and a final day of massed mêlée fighting.
3. The Tournament of Chauvency  was described in verse by the French poet Jacques Bretel.
4. A list of the participants at the tournament, which includes nearly 100 named individuals, can be found here.
5. Before 22 July 1257, he married Jeanne de Bar (1225-1299), widow of Frederick de (d. 1255/6) and daughter of Henry II, Count of Bar, and Philippa de Dreux.
6. Her dowry was the castle of Salm.
7. Jeanne already had three children from her first marriage: Henry (d.1331) sire de Blâmont and seneschal of Lorraine, Joffroi (mentioned in 1253) and Thomas ("princier" of Verdun and subsequently Bishop, d.1305).
8. Until she became Countess of Chiny in spring 1268 she was styled as 'dame de Blâmont' and used her own seal.
9. Louis and Jeanne had no children and, after his death, Chiny reverted to his nephew Arnold V of Looz.

Title: Otto II, Count of Chiny
0. Otto II( 1065- after 1131), Count of Chiny, son of Arnold I, Count of Chiny, and Adélaïs.
1. He succeeded his father in 1106 and completed the construction of the Abbey of Orval that his father had started in 1070, installing the canons in 1124.
2. The installation of a Cistercian community in Orval in 1131 marked his last appearance in any proceedings.
3. He married Adelaide( Alix)( 1068- 1124), daughter of Albert III, Count of Namur and Ida of Saxony( widow of Frederick of Lower Lorraine), who gave birth to: Ida( also known as Ida of Namur) and Godfrey( also known as Godfrey the Bearded, not to be confused with the uncle of his father Henry II, Godfrey) were parents of Adeliza of Louvain, wife of Henry I, King of England.
4. Oda ’s husband Gislebert was son of Otto, Count of Duras and therefore the grandson of Giselbert, the first Count of Looz, whose family would eventually be merged with the Counts of Chiny with the marriage of Otto's great- great granddaughter Jeanne, Countess of Chiny, with Arnold IV, Count of Looz.
5. After his death, Otto was succeeded as Count of Chiny by his son Albert.

chunks.title: Charles II, Duke of Parma
chunks.chunk:
Title: Charles II, Duke of Parma
0. Charles Louis( 22 December 1799 – 16 April 1883) was King of Etruria( 1803 – 1807; reigned as Louis II), Duke of Lucca( 1824 – 1847; reigned as Charles I), and Duke of Parma( 1847 – 1849; reigned as Charles II).
1. He was the only son of Louis, Prince of Piacenza, and his wife Infanta Maria Luisa of Spain.
2. Born at the Royal Palace of Madrid at the court of his maternal grandfather King Charles IV of Spain, he spent his first years living at the Spanish court.
3. In 1801, by the Treaty of Aranjuez, Charles became Crown Prince of Etruria, a newly created kingdom formed from territories of the Grand Duchy of Tuscany.
4. Charles moved to Italy with his parents and in 1803, not yet four years old, he succeeded his father as King of Etruria under the name Charles Louis I. His mother Infanta Maria Luisa assumed the regency while Charles Louis' minority lasted.
5. In 1807 Napoleon Bonaparte dissolved the kingdom of Etruria and Charles Louis and his mother took refuge in Spain.
6. In May 1808 they were forced to leave Spain by Napoleon who arrested Charles Louis' mother in a convent in Rome.
7. Between 1811 and 1814 Charles Louis was placed under the care of his grandfather, the deposed King Charles IV of Spain.
8. After Napoleon's fall, in 1817, Infanta Maria Luisa became Duchess of Lucca in her own right and Charles Louis, age sixteen, became hereditary Prince of Lucca.
9. In 1820 he married Princess Maria Teresa of Savoy.
10. They were a mismatched couple and had only one surviving son.
11. At his mother's death in 1824, Charles Louis became the reigning Duke of Lucca as Charles I.
12. He had little interest in ruling.
13. He left the duchy in the hands of his ministers and spent most of his time traveling around Europe.
14. A liberal movement led him to abdicate Lucca in favor of the Grand Duke of Tuscany in October 1847 in exchange for financial compensation, as he wanted to retire to private life.
15. Two months later, in December 1847, at the death of the former Empress Marie Louise, he succeeded her as the reigning Duke of Parma according to what had been stipulated by the Congress of Vienna.
16. His reign in Parma as Duke Charles II was brief.
17. He was ill- received by his new subjects and within a few months he was ousted by a revolution.
18. He regained control of Parma under the protection of Austrian troops, but finally abdicated in favor of his son Charles III on 14 March 1849.
19. His son was assassinated in 1854 and his grandson Robert I, the last reigning Duke of Parma, was deposed in 1860.
20. In exile Charles Louis assumed the title of count of Villafranca.
21. He spent the last years of his life mostly in France, dying at Nice on 16 April 1883.

question: Where was the place of burial of Ælfgar, Earl Of Mercia's mother?

chunks.title: Place of birth
chunks.chunk:
Title: Place of birth
0. The place of birth( POB) or birthplace is the place where a person was born.
1. This place is often used in legal documents, together with name and date of birth, to uniquely identify a person.
2. As a general rule with respect to passports, the place of birth is determined to be the country that currently has" sovereignty" over the actual place of birth, regardless of when the birth actually occurred.
3. The place of birth is not necessarily the place where the parents of the new baby live.
4. If the baby is born in a hospital in another place, that place is the place of birth.
5. In many countries, this also means that the government requires that the birth of the new baby is registered in the place of birth.
6. Some countries place less or no importance on the place of birth, instead using alternative geographical characteristics for the purpose of identity documents.
7. For example, Sweden has used the concept of" födelsehemortdomicile of birth") since 1947.
8. This means that the domicile of the baby's mother is the registered place of birth.
9. The location of the maternity ward or other physical birthplace is considered unimportant.
10. Similarly, Switzerland uses the concept of" Heimatortlieu d'origineluogo d'origineplace of origin" in German, French and Italian respectively).
11. A child born to Swiss parents is automatically assigned the place of origin of the parent with the same last name, so the child either gets their mother's or father's place of origin.
12. A child born to one Swiss parent and one foreign parent acquires the place of origin of their Swiss parent.
13. In a Swiss passport and identity card, the holder's place of origin is stated, not their place of birth.
14. In some countries( primarily in the Americas), the place of birth automatically determines the nationality of the baby, a practice often referred to by the Latin phrase" jus soli".
15. Almost all countries outside the Americas instead attribute nationality based on the nationality( ies) of the baby's parents( referred to as" jus sanguinis").
16. There can be some confusion regarding the place of birth if the birth takes place in an unusual way: when babies are born on an airplane or at sea, difficulties can arise.
17. The place of birth of such a person depends on the law of the countries involved, which include the nationality of the plane or ship, the nationality( ies) of the parents and/ or the location of the plane or ship( if the birth occurs in the territorial waters or airspace of a country).
18. Some administrative forms may request the applicant's" country of birth".
19. It is important to determine from the requester whether the information requested refers to the applicant's" place of birth" or" nationality at birth".
20. For US citizens born abroad who under the US Constitution acquire US citizenship at the time of birth, the nationality at birth will be USA( American), while the place of birth would be the country in which the actual birth takes place.

chunks.title: Lady Godiva

Title: Lady Godiva

Godiva, Countess of Mercia (died between 1066 and 1086), in Old English Godgifu, was an English noblewoman who, according to a legend dating at least to the 13th century, rode naked – covered only in her long hair – through the streets of Coventry to gain a remission of the oppressive taxation that her husband, Leofric, Earl of Mercia, imposed on his tenants.
1. The name "Peeping Tom" for a voyeur originates from later versions of this legend in which a man named Thomas watched her ride and was struck blind or dead.

Title: Sennedjem
0. The Ancient Egyptian artisan Sennedjem lived in Set Maat( translated as" The Place of Truth"), contemporary Deir el- Medina, on the west bank of the Nile, opposite Thebes, during the reigns of Seti I and Ramesses II.
1. Sennedjem had the title" Servant in the Place of Truth".
2. He was buried along with his wife, Iyneferti, and family in a tomb in the village necropolis.
3. His tomb was discovered January 31, 1886.
4. When Sennedjem's tomb was found, in it there was regular furniture from his home, including a stool and a bed, which he actually used when he was alive.
5. His titles included Servant in the Place of Truth, meaning that he worked on the excavation and decoration of the nearby royal tombs.

0. Connie Chan Po-chu was born in 1947 to impoverished parents, one of at least nine siblings, in Guangdong, China.

chunks.title: Eva Dahlgren

Title: Eva Dahlgren

2. som bryr sej om" was released the same year.
3. In 1979 she placed third in Melodifestivalen (the tryout competition for the Eurovision Song Contest in Sweden).
4. She toured Sweden in 1987 with Swedish pop duo Roxette, a tour that was attended for more than 100,000 people.
5. Dahlgren's career grew steadily with several album releases during the 1980s but her definite breakthrough in Sweden came in 1991 with the hit album "En blekt blondins hjärta" which sold over half a million copies and netted the singer five Grammis awards.
6. In 1996 Dahlgren made headlines in the Swedish press when she came out as a lesbian through her civil union with jewellery designer Efva Attling.
7. In connection with the civil union, Dahlgren changed her surname to Dahlgren-Attling.
8. In 2009 they got married, after Sweden passed its gender neutral marriage law.
9. Eva Dahlgren toured July – August 2008 together with Peter Jöback in Sweden, Norway and Finland.
10. The tour was called "Himlen är inget tak", and a single with the same title was released.

chunks.title: Thomas Stafford, 3rd Earl of Stafford
chunks.chunk:
Title: Thomas Stafford, 3rd Earl of Stafford
0. Thomas Stafford, 3rd Earl of Stafford (c. 1368–4 July 1392) was the second son—but the senior surviving heir—of Hugh Stafford, 2nd Earl of Stafford and Philippa de Beauchamp, daughter of Thomas de Beauchamp, 11th Earl of Warwick.
1. His elder brother, his father's heir, Sir Ralph Stafford, was murdered by Richard II's half-brother, the earl of Huntingdon whilst they were campaigning in Scotland in July 1385.
2. As a result, Thomas became heir to the earldom of Stafford, and in 1390 he was knighted.
3. He gained livery of his estates in 1391 and paid homage to the king for them on 20 October that year.
4. He spent his short career campaigning in France alongside the duke of Gloucester.
5. Thomas Stafford married Anne, daughter of Thomas, Duke of Gloucester around 1390.
6. He died on 4 July 1392 in Westminster, and was interred in Stone, with his father; his widow, Anne, with whom he had had no children, married his youngest brother Edmund Stafford, 5th Earl of Stafford.

chunks.title: Hanns Schwarz
chunks.chunk:
Title: Hanns Schwarz
0. Hanns Schwarz was an Austrian film director.
1. He was born in Vienna on 11 February 1888.
2. He directed twenty four films between 1924 and 1937 in both English and German.
3. During the late silent and early sound eras, he was a leading director at the large German studio UFA.
4. In the early 1930s he worked on several multi-language version films for UFA, producing the same films in distinct German and foreign- language versions.
5. Schwarz was Jewish and was therefore forced to leave Germany in 1933 when the Nazis took over, going into exile in Britain.
6. His last film was the 1937 British thriller" Return of the Scarlet Pimpernel".
7. He died in California on 27 October 1945.

chunks.title: Amar Akbar Anthony
chunks.chunk:
Title: Amar Akbar Anthony
0. Amar Akbar
1. Anthony is a 1977 Indian action comedy film, directed and produced by Manmohan Desai, and written by Kader Khan.
2. The film stars Vinod Khanna, Amitabh Bachchan and Rishi Kapoor opposite Shabana Azmi, Parveen Babi and Neetu Singh in the lead roles.
3. The plot focuses on three brothers who are separated in childhood and adopted by three families of different faiths Hinduism, Islam and Christianity.
4. One grows up to be a policeman, another a singer, and the third the owner of a country liquor bar.
5. The soundtrack album was composed by Laxmikant- Pyarelal and the lyrics were written by Anand Bakshi.
6. The film had been released on 27 May 1977, in which it earned 155 million in India, and became the highest- grossing Indian film of that year, alongside" Dharam Veer" and" Hum Kisise Kum Naheen".
7. The film about religious tolerance became a landmark for Bollywood masala films, building on the masala formula pioneered several years earlier with Nasir Hussain's" Yaadon Ki Baarat"( 1973).
8. " Amar Akbar Anthony" also had a lasting impact on pop culture, with its catchy songs, one- liners and the character of Anthony Gonsalves played by Amitabh Bachchan.
9. It won several awards at 25th Filmfare Awards including Best Actor, Best Music Director and Best Editing.
10. It was later remade in Tamil as" Shankar Salim Simon"( 1978), in Telugu as" Ram Robert Rahim"( 1980) and in Malayalam as" John Jaffer Janardhanan"( 1982).

chunks.title: Juliana Freire
chunks.chunk:
Title: Juliana Freire
0. Juliana Freire de Lima e Silva is a Brazilian computer scientist who works as a professor of computer science and engineering at the New York University Polytechnic School of Engineering.
1. She is known for her research in information visualization, data provenance, and computerized assistance for scientific reproducibility.
2. Freire did her undergraduate studies at the Federal University of Ceará in Brazil, and earned her doctorate from Stony Brook University.
3. Prior to joining NYU-Poly in 2011, she was a researcher at Bell Laboratories, and a faculty member at the Oregon Health & Science University and the University of Utah.
4. Freire's research projects include the VisTrails scientific workflow management system, and the DeepPeep search engine for web database content.
5. Freire was the program co-chair of the WWW2010 conference.
6. In 2014, Freire was elected as a Fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery "for contributions to provenance management research and technology, and computational reproducibility."

2. He co-developed the open-source data-exploration system VisTrails with his wife Juliana Freire and many other collaborators.
3. He currently serves as chair of the executive committee for the IEEE Computer Society Technical Committee on Visualization and Graphics.

chunks.title: Gustaf Molander
chunks.chunk:
Title: Gustaf Molander
0. Gustaf Harald August Molander (18 November 1888 – 19 June 1973) was a Swedish actor and film director.
1. His parents were director Harald Molander, Sr.
2. (1858–1900) and singer and actress Lydia Molander, "née" Wessler, and his brother was director Olof Molander (1892–1966).
3. He was the father of director and producer Harald Molander from his first marriage to actress Karin Molander and father to actor Jan Molander from his second marriage to Elsa Fahlberg (1892-1977).
4. Gustaf Molander was born in Helsingfors (now Helsinki) in the Grand Duchy of Finland (in the Russian Empire), where his father was working at the Swedish Theatre.
5. He studied in the school of the Royal Dramatic Theatre in Stockholm 1907–1909, acted at the Swedish theatre in Helsingfors 1909–1913, and then at the Royal Dramatic Theatre from 1913–1926.
6. The last years there he headed the school; his students included Greta Garbo.
7. Molander wrote several screenplays for Victor Sjöström and Mauritz Stiller, and was helped by the latter to get employment as a director for Svensk Filmindustri, where he worked 1923–1956.
8. All in all, he directed sixty-two films.
9. He often worked with Gösta Ekman, and his films include "Intermezzo" (1936), which became Ingrid Bergman's breakthrough and paved her way to America, where she starred in the 1939 Hollywood remake of the film.

question: Who is Richard Burke, 4Th Earl Of Clanricarde's paternal grandfather?

chunks.title: Henry de Burgh, 1st Marquess of Clanricarde
chunks.chunk:
Title: Henry de Burgh, 1st Marquess of Clanricarde
0. Henry de Burgh, 1st Marquess of Clanricarde KP, PC( Ire)( 8 January 1742 – 8 December 1797), styled Lord Dunkellin from birth to 1782, was an Irish peer and politician.
1. He was the son of John Smith de Burgh, 11th Earl of Clanricarde and from 1753 to 1758 was educated at Eton College.
2. In 1768 he was a Member of Parliament in the Irish House of Commons representing Galway County.
3. He succeeded his father as Earl of Clanricarde( among other titles) on 21 April 1782, became a Knight of the Order of St Patrick on 5 February 1783 and on 6 March of the same year was invested as a member of the Privy Council of Ireland.
4. On 17 March 1785, he married Lady Urania Anne Paulet, daughter of George Paulet, 12th Marquess of Winchester, but they had no children.
5. He was made Marquess of Clanricarde in 1785, and from 1792 until his death on 8 December 1797 he was Governor and Custos Rotulorum of County Galway.

chunks.title: Edward Bermingham, 13th Baron Athenry
chunks.chunk:
Title: Edward Bermingham, 13th Baron Athenry
0. Edward de Bermingham, Anglo- Irish lord of Athenry and Dunmore, County Galway, died 1709, was the son of Francis de Bermingham, 12th Baron Athenry and Bridget, daughter of Sir Lucas Dillon.
1. He succeeded as 13th Baron Athenry in 1677.
2. During the Williamite War in Ireland he was a supporter of James II of England.
3. He served under Richard Burke, 8th Earl of Clanricarde as an infantry captain.
4. After the failure of James' cause he was outlawed and attainted, but the attainder was reversed in 1698.
5. In later years he conformed to the Church of Ireland.
6. He married firstly Lady Mary Bourke, daughter of Richard Burke, 6th Earl of Clanricarde and secondly Bridget, daughter of Colonel John Browne and Maud Bourke.
7. He had three daughters and one son, Francis, who succeeded as 14th Baron Athenry.

chunks.title: Ulick Burke, 3rd Earl of Clanricarde
chunks.chunk:
Title: Ulick Burke, 3rd Earl of Clanricarde
0. Ulick Burke, 3rd Earl of Clanricarde, Irish peer, died 1601.
1. He was the son of Richard Burke, 2nd Earl of Clanricarde and Margaret O'Brien.
2. He married Honora Burke, daughter of John Burke, on 25 November 1564 at Athenry, County Galway, Ireland.
3. He had long been a rebel against the English Crown, and since the 1560s had instigated the "Mac an Iarla" wars in Connaught and Thomond, devastating much of the area, against his father, who was a staunch supporter of Elizabeth I.
4. On his father's death in 1582 it was uncertain who would inherit the title, Ulick or his brother, John.
5. Ulick gained the succession by murdering John and acknowledging the supremacy of the Crown.
6. He remained a loyal subject till his death.
7. Children of Ulick Burke and Honora Burke:
Child of Ulick Burke and Martha Frannas:

1. Lord Clanricarde was a Catholic Royalist, who had overall command of the Irish forces during the later stages of the Cromwellian conquest of Ireland.
2. He was created Marquess of Clanricarde in 1646.

chunks.title: Sir Henry Lynch, 1st Baronet
chunks.chunk:
Title: Sir Henry Lynch, 1st Baronet
0. Sir Henry Lynch, 1st Baronet( died 1635) was an Irish knight and land agent.
1. Lynch was the eldest of the 12 sons of Nicholas Lynch fitz Stephen( Mayor 1584 – 1585) and great- grandson of Mayor Arthur Lynch( died 1539).
2. He was a land agent for Richard Burke, 4th Earl of Clanricarde; their surviving correspondence from c.1617 to c.1632 was published in 1996.
3. He was a mentor to his stepson Patrick D'Arcy and his nephew Richard Martyn, later senior political figures of Confederate Ireland.
4. He was among the first of his family to become a lawyer, and several of his younger sons followed him into this profession, as did, under his influence, D' Arcy, Martyn, Geoffrey Browne and subsequent generations of The Tribes of Galway.
5. The baronetcy was created for Henry Lynch on 8 June 1622.
6. Lynch is said by some to have been knighted in 1627.
7. He married Elizabeth, the daughter of Richard Martyn and the widow of James D'Arcy.
8. They had 3 sons and 3 daughters and was succeeded by Sir Robuck Lynch, 2nd Baronet, Mayor of Galway for 1638 – 39.
9. His descendants included:

chunks.title: Frances Walsingham, Countess of Essex
chunks.chunk:
Title: Frances Walsingham, Countess of Essex
0. Frances Walsingham, Dowager Countess of Essex and Countess of Clanricarde( 1567 – 17 February 1633) was an English noblewoman.
1. The daughter of Sir Francis Walsingham, Elizabeth I's Secretary of State, she became the wife of Sir Philip Sidney at age 16.
2. Her second husband was Queen Elizabeth's favourite, Robert Devereaux Earl of Essex, with whom she had five children.
3. Two years after his execution in 1601, she married Richard Burke, Earl of Clanricarde, and went to live with him in Ireland.

chunks.title: Richard Burke, 4th Earl of Clanricarde
chunks.chunk:
Title: Richard Burke, 4th Earl of Clanricarde
0. Richard Burke, 4th Earl of Clanricarde (also Richard de Burgh) (1572 – 12 November 1635) was an Irish nobleman and politician.
1. He was the son of Ulick Burke, 3rd Earl of Clanricarde and Honora Burke.
2. Knighted in 1602 for his exploits as leader of the English cavalry during the Battle of Kinsale, he would later serve as Governor of Connaught from 1604 to 1616, and as a member of the Privy Council of Ireland.
3. Having established himself as the largest and most influential landowner in Connacht, his later life was characterized by animosity between him and an increasingly hostile and acquisitive Dublin government.
4. He actively served Queen Elizabeth I against the rebel Irish lordships and their Spanish allies during the Nine Years' War.
5. He was appointed governor of Connaught, member of the privy council in Ireland, and, in 1624, created Viscount Tunbridge and Baron of Somerhill, a manor which he owned in Kent.
6. The titles of Viscount Galway and Earl of St. Albans were conferred on him in 1628.
7. By 1633 he was not only one of the principal landowners in Ireland, but virtually all powerful in County Galway.
8. This aroused the resentment of the Dublin Government, which decided to use the method of empanelling juries to "find" defective titles, in order to recover the lands in question for the English Crown.
9. The treatment which Lord Clanricarde experienced from the Lord Deputy of Ireland, Thomas Wentworth, was said to have accelerated his death in November 1635:
10. Wentworth however pointed to the Earl's advancing years and asked sarcastically if he was to blame for a man being over sixty.
11. The feud, which was continued by Clanricarde's son and heir, was in the long run very damaging to Strafford, who apparently did not reflect on the close connections Clanricarde, through his wife, had with just that faction of the English nobility, the Rich-Devereux clan, who were most hostile to Strafford.
12. In 1603, he married Frances Walsingham, the widow of Robert Devereux, 2nd Earl of Essex.
13. They had one son, Ulick, and two daughters, Honora, who married John Paulet, 5th Marquis of Winchester, and Mary, wife of Hon.
14. Edward Butler of Ballinahinch.
15. He was succeeded by his son and heir, Ulick, as 5th Earl of Clanricarde, who in 1622 had married Lady Anne Compton, only daughter of William Compton, 1st Earl of Northampton.

chunks.title: Ralph Neville, 3rd Earl of Westmorland
chunks.chunk:
Title: Ralph Neville, 3rd Earl of Westmorland
0. Ralph Neville, 3rd Earl of Westmorland( c. 1456 – 6 February 1499) was an English peer.
1. He was the grandfather of Ralph Neville, 4th Earl of Westmorland.

chunks.title: William Burke, 7th Earl of Clanricarde
chunks.chunk:
Title: William Burke, 7th Earl of Clanricarde
0. William Burke, 7th Earl of Clanricarde( died 1687), Irish peer, was the son of Sir William Burke, younger son of Ulick Burke, 3rd Earl of Clanricarde, and Joan O'Shaughnessy.
1. Burke had served with his brother Richard, the 6th Earl under their cousin, Ulick Burke, 5th Earl of Clanricarde, during the Irish Confederate Wars and they each succeeded to his title.
2. He became Lord Lieutenant of County Galway in 1680 and its Chief Governor in 1687.
3. His first wife was Lettice Shirley, daughter of Sir Henry Shirley and Lady Dorothy Devereux and granddaughter of Robert Devereux, 2nd Earl of Essex.
4. By her he had three sons including his heir, Richard.
5. His second wife was Helen, daughter of Donough MacCarty, 1st Earl of Clancarty, by whom he had two sons and two daughters.

chunks.title: Jorge Brum do Canto
chunks.chunk:
Title: Jorge Brum do Canto
0. Jorge Brum do Canto( February 10, 1910 – February 7, 1994) was a Portuguese film director and actor.
1. His career spanned over a half- century, from 1929 to 1984.

chunks.title: Monte Hellman
chunks.chunk:
Title: Monte Hellman
0. Monte Hellman( born July 12, 1932) is an American film director, producer, writer, and editor.
1. Hellman began his career as an editor's apprentice at ABC TV, and made his directorial debut with the horror film" Beast from Haunted Cave"( 1959), produced by Roger Corman.
2. He would later gain critical recognition for the Westerns" The Shooting" and" Ride in the Whirlwind"( both 1966) starring Jack Nicholson, and the independent road movie" Two- Lane Blacktop"( 1971) starring James Taylor and Dennis Wilson.
3. His later directorial work has included the 1989 slasher film and the independent thriller" Road to Nowhere"( 2010).

chunks.title: The Shooting
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Shooting
0. The Shooting is a 1966 western film directed by Monte Hellman, with a screenplay by Carole Eastman( using the pseudonym" Adrien Joyce").
1. It stars Warren Oates, Millie Perkins, Will Hutchins, and Jack Nicholson, and was produced by Nicholson and Hellman.
2. The story is about two men who are hired by a mysterious woman to accompany her to a town located many miles across the desert.
3. During their journey, they are closely tracked by a black- clad gunslinger who seems intent on killing all of them.
4. The film was shot in 1965 in the Utah desert, back- to- back with Hellman's similar western," Ride in the Whirlwind", which also starred Nicholson and Perkins.
5. Both films were shown at several international film festivals but it was not until 1968 that the U.S. distribution rights were purchased by the Walter Reade Organization.
6. No other domestic distributor had expressed any interest in the films.
7. Walter Reade decided to bypass a theatrical release, and the two titles were sold directly to television.

chunks.title: Fernando Gonçalves Namora
chunks.chunk:
Title: Fernando Gonçalves Namora
0. Fernando Namora( 15 April 1919 – 31 January 1989), with the full name Fernando Gonçalves Namora was a Portuguese writer and medical doctor.
1. Namora was born in Condeixa- a- Nova, Coimbra District and died in Lisbon, Portugal.
2. He received his medical degree at 1942, by the University of Coimbra.
3. Those years as student would have influenced him as a man( and writer) as well his experience as a country doctor, in remote regions as Beira Baixa and Alentejo, till the year of 1950, when he moved to Lisbon, invited to be medical assistant at the Instituto Português de Oncologia.
4. His early book was" Relevos", poetry, in( 1937), published at the age of 18.
5. In( 1938) appeared his first romance" As Sete Partidas do Mundo" that won the Almeida Garrett Prize, and, three years later, with some other colleagues at Coimbra, was involved in the literary project of" Novo Cancioneiro",( 1941), with 10 volumes, which the first one was his poem named" Terra"- for many specialists the advent of neorealism movement, a milestone in the Portuguese literature.
6. All the early age lyrics are in the anthology" As Frias Madrugadas", by 1959.
7. Nevertheless, his youth, Coimbra's student atmosphere romance is" Fogo na Noite Escura"( 1943), at the collection" Novos Prosadores"( 1943), by" Coimbra Editora".
8. Besides over 30 titles, along his fifty years of intensive literary life, not only wrote “ neo-realistic ” novels, as" Casa da Malta"( 1945)," Minas de S. Francisco"( 1946)," Retalhos da Vida de um Médico"( 1949 and 1963)," A Noite e a Madrugada"( 1950)," O Trigo e o Joio"( 1954), but also “ urban themes ”, contemporary fiction, as in" O Homem Disfarçado"( 1957)," Cidade Solitária"( 1959)," Domingo à Tarde"( 1961, José Lins do Rego Prize)," Os Clandestinos"( 1972)," Resposta a Matilde"( 1980) or" O Rio Triste"( 1982, Fernando Chinaglia Prize, Fialho de Almeida Prize and D. Dinis Prize).
9. Another cicle was the" cadernos de um escritor" narratives, a sort of analytic, critic testimonials, regarding “ social themes ” and the emergence of a new time, specially during the 1960s and 1970s, related with the Geneve International Encounters and the many travels abroad( including Scandinavia), expressed in" Diálogo em Setembro"( 1966)," Um Sino na Montanha"( 1968)," Os Adoradores do Sol"( 1971)," Estamos no Vento"( 1974)," A Nave de Pedra"( 1975)," Cavalgada Cinzenta"( 1977)," URSS, Mal Amada, Bem Amada" and" Sentados na Relva", from( 1986).
10. Namora was suggested for the Nobel Prize in 1981.

0. Maui Nō Ka Oi Magazine is a bi-monthly regional magazine published by the Haynes Publishing Group in Wailuku, Hawaii.
1. The phrase "Maui nō ka oi" means "Maui is the best" in the Hawaiian language. "
2. Maui Nō Ka Oi Magazine" features stories relating to the culture, art, dining, environmental issues, current events, recreational activities, and local businesses within Maui County.
3. The magazine is marketed at newsstands across the United States and by subscription, and is distributed as an in-room amenity in resorts.
4. Since 2002 the magazine has sponsored the Aipono Awards, an annual award in which readers select their favorite restaurants in 25 categories.
5. In 2003 they began celebrating the winners at an annual banquet.
6. Proceeds from the banquet go to the Maui Community College's Culinary Academy.
7. "Maui Nō Ka Oi" has a circulation of 25,000 and an estimated readership of 1.44 annually.
8. The magazine has received several Pai awards, which are given out by the Hawaii Publishers Association.

chunks.title: Second Motion Records

Title: Second Motion Records
0. Second Motion
1. Records is part of Second Motion Entertainment based in Carrboro, North Carolina.
2. The Label was founded in Chapel Hill, NC by Stephen Judge, who is the former manager of the rock band Athenaeum( who released two albums on Atlantic Records in the mid to late 1990s) as well as the former General Manager/ A&R Director of Redeye Distribution and Yep Roc Records.
3. Judge has also worked with such artists as: Liam Finn, Bell X1, John Doe, Paul Weller, Public Enemy, Daniel Lanois, Martin Sexton, Sloan, Concrete Blonde, The Supersuckers and others.
4. In 2010 Second Motion Entertainment( the label's parent company) purchased the assets of Blurt Magazine and is the publisher of the highly respected Magazine and On- line media outlet.
5. Blurt has often been called the" Mojo Magazine of the United States".
6. In Feb 2012 Second Motion announced that both Blurt Magazine and the label would be relocating their offices to Raleigh, NC and that they had more" big news" forthcoming in April 2012.

chunks.title: Blurt (magazine)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Blurt (magazine)
0. Blurt is a music print magazine and online outlet originally based in Silver Spring, MD.
1. The magazine was originally known as "Harp Magazine" for over 10 years, also based in Silver Spring, and was considered one of the best music magazines of the decade in the early 2000s.
2. After "Harp" folded in March 2008 (at the behest of its parent company, which also owned JazzTimes, it declared bankruptcy), "Blurt" was founded by "Harp" owner Scott Crawford.
3. Some of the main writers and editors for "Harp" also started "Blurt" with Crawford, including managing editor Fred Mills (of Asheville, NC, and also a contributing editor to "StereophileMagnet" and other music industry publications and alternative weeklies), senior editor Randy Harward (also an editor for the Salt Lake City weekly paper), and senior editor Andy Tennille (a journalist and photographer, currently the photographer for Tom Petty & the Heartbreakers).
4. "Blurt"s tag line is "Real Music, Real Artists, Real OpinionsBlurt" is a highly respected outlet within the music industry and has often been cited by critics and fans as the "Mojo" magazine of the United States.
5. It initially launched as an all-digital, downloadable online magazine, publishing five issues in that format before moving to print for the next nine issues while also posting each issue online, frequently with expanded content, at BlurtOnline.com.
6. In early 2010, Crawford sold the "Blurt" assets to Stephen Judge of Second Motion Entertainment and the company moved to the label's home of Carrboro, NC.
7. Second Motion Entertainment also owns the record label Second Motion Records which works with such artists as Australia's The Church, Bettie Serveert, Swervedriver, Parson Red Heads and Tommy Keene.
8. "Blurt" magazine announced in February 2012 that it would be relocating its offices (along with Second Motion) to Raleigh, NC, where Judge had purchased long-tenured independent record store Schoolkids Records.
9. Editor Mills also relocated to Raleigh, assisting Judge in both running the store and publishing the magazine.
10. As of April 2017, Schoolkids also operates locations in Durham, NC, and Carrboro, NC, and the Second Motion Records name has been changed to Schoolkids Records.
11. The magazine, label and stores are increasingly integrated, operationally.
12. "Blurt" is updated daily with new music interviews, essays and features; music news, record release announcements (vinyl is a specialty), and tour dates; exclusive videos, audio streams and bootleg MP3s; record, DVD, book and concert reviews; and blog entries by Judge, Mills, John B. Moore, Michael Toland, and Bill Kopp.
13. Tim Hinely, founder of "Dagger", a punk and indie zine first published in 1987 and still in print, and recognized by "Pitchfork" as "one of the best," is also a contributor.
14. As a print magazine it was distributed throughout the United States and internationally.
15. The final print issue was #14, published at the end of 2013 and featuring Artist of the Year Jason Isbell on the cover, along with features on The Beatles, Big Star, The Replacements, Megafaun, Tommy Keene and King Khan.
16. At that point the magazine decided to revert to publishing online in the face of declining advertising revenue.
17. While operating as a print publication, covers were devoted to artists such as: Sonic Youth, The Avett Brothers, PJ Harvey, Of Montreal, Janelle Monáe, Spiritualized Grizzly Bear and Wilco.
18. From 2010 to 2016 the magazine also hosted an annual day party each March in Austin at the SXSW Music Festival at the Ginger Man Pub, and photo galleries and descriptions of those parties can be viewed at the Blurtonline.com website.

question: Who is the paternal grandfather of John Ii Of Baden?

chunks.title: Jacob, Margrave of Baden-Baden
chunks.chunk:
Title: Jacob, Margrave of Baden-Baden
0. Jacob I of Baden (15 March 1407, Hachberg – 13 October 1453, Mühlburg), was Margrave of Baden-Baden from 1431 to 1453.
1. He was the elder son of Bernard I, Margrave of Baden-Baden and his second wife Anna of Oettingen.
2. Jacob
3. I was a man of deep religious beliefs, well known as a founder of churches.
4. He founded the monastery at Fremersberg and was a major benefactor of the Stiftskirche at Baden-Baden.
5. According to his father's precepts, only two of his sons were to be considered heirs of the margravate.
6. Therefore, only Charles and Bernard received a secular education; the other children had a strict religious upbringing.
7. George, after taking a religious profession in his youth, returned briefly to the world, but in 1454 reverted to
holy orders and later became Bishop of Metz.
8. Jacob
9. I was the opposite of his father; Enea Silvio de Piccolomini (Pope Pius II) characterized him as "famous among the Germans for his justice and intelligence".
10. In his early years he was ruler of the family possessions in Hohenberg, until at the age of 24 he succeeded to the government of Baden.
11. He was described as a pugnacious knight and a frugal father of the state and was popular among the princes as a mediator.
12. Both Emperor Sigismund and Emperor Frederick III, under whom he served, thought highly of him.
13. When as the result of a miscarriage his sister Agnes fled in the middle of a conflict about inheritance, the Margrave lost his claim to the Duchy of Schleswig.
14. He was so angry that he confined Agnes for the rest of her life in Eberstein Castle in Ebersteinburg.
15. (The incident is remembered as the "Double Disaster of Gottorf").
16. When in 1427 the Treaty of Sponheim came into force, he gained possessions on the Moselle.
17. In 1442 he bought for 30,000 guilders from the descendants of Walter von Geroldseck half the lordship of Lahr and Mahlberg.

chunks.title: Bonne of Berry
chunks.chunk:
Title: Bonne of Berry
0. Bonne of Berry( 1362/1365 – 30 December 1435) was the daughter of John, Duke of Berry, and Joanna of Armagnac.
1. Through her father, she was a granddaughter of John II of France.

chunks.title: Gilbert Talbot, 3rd Baron Talbot
chunks.chunk:
Title: Gilbert Talbot, 3rd Baron Talbot
0. Gilbert Talbot, 3rd Baron Talbot( c. 1332–1387) was an English nobleman and soldier.
1. He was the grandfather of John Talbot, 1st Earl of Shrewsbury.

chunks.title: John Westley
chunks.chunk:
Title: John Westley
0. Rev. John Westley( 1636 – 78) was an English nonconformist minister.
1. He was the grandfather of John Wesley( founder of Methodism).

chunks.title: John II of Baden
chunks.chunk:
Title: John II of Baden
0. John II of Baden (1434 at Hohenbaden Castle in Baden-Baden – 9 February 1503 in Ehrenbreitstein) was a titular Margrave of Baden and was Archbishop and Elector of Trier as "John II of Baden" from 1456 until his death in 1503.
1. John II of Baden was the third son of Margrave Jacob I of Baden-Baden and his wife Catherine de Lorraine.
2. John was given a strict religious upbringing, as he was destined from an early age for an ecclesiastical career.
3. At the urging of his father, most of his siblings also followed a religious career, the exceptions being his two oldest brothers Charles I and Bernard II and his sister Margaret.
4. He studied in Erfurt, Pavia and Cologne from 1452 to 1456, together with his younger brothers George and Mark.
5. On 21 June 1456, at the age of 22, he was elected Archbishop of Trier as "John II of Baden".
6. His mother was from Lorraine and had connections with Trier.
7. Pope Calixtus III confirmed him as administrator of Trier, because he had not yet reached the minimum age of 35 for consecration as bishop.
8. When he reached that age in 1465, he was consecrated by his suffragan bishop Hubertis Agrippina and the bishops of Metz and Worms.
9. In 1459, Diether von Isenburg was elected Archbishop of Mainz, ahead of Adolph II of Nassau by a narrow margin.
10. However, the Pope did not confirm Dieter's election.
11. This led to the Baden-Palatinate War, in which John II and his brothers participated on the side of Adolph II of Nassau.
12. John II of Baden supported reform in the Benedictine monasteries and encouraged them to join the Bursfelde Congregation.
13. In 1469, he sent Johann Fart, the prior of the St. Mary monastery in Trier to the Maria Laach Abbey, where Johann acted as a reformer abbot.
14. Johann was the 21st abbott, his tenure lasted from 1470 to 1491.
15. By appointing Johann, John II thwarted the intentions of Archbishop Rupert of Cologne, who had a different reform candidate in mind.
16. During John II's reign, the long-anticipated University of Trier was founded on 16 March 1473.
17. The University provided coursed in theology, philosophy, medicine and law.
18. In 1477, he officiated in the wedding of Maximilian of Habsburg and Mary of Burgundy.
19. On 16 January 1500, he appointed his great-nephew Jakob as co-adjutor with the right to succeed  and from 1501, Jakob led the government of the Electorate.
20. John II died in 1503 in Ehrenbreitstein (now part of Koblenz), after a tenure of 46 years, 7 months and 18 days, the longest of any bishop of Trier.
21. He was buried in the Cathedral of Trier in a magnificent grave that he had built during his lifetime.

Title: Herman II, Margrave of Baden
0. Hermann II of Baden( c. 1060 – 7 October 1130) was the first to use the title Margrave of Baden, after the family seat at Castle Hohenbaden.
