chunks.title: Fernando Cortés
chunks.chunk:
Title: Fernando Cortés
0. Fernando "Papi" Cortés (October 4, 1909 – 1979) was a Puerto Rican film actor, writer and director.
1. He was born in San Juan, Puerto Rico, but he spent most of his adult life in Mexico City, where he died.
2. On 1932, while in New York City, Fernando Cortés married Puerto Rican childhood friend María del Pilar Cordero, who adopted the stage name of Mapy Cortés.
3. The couple soon traveled to Spain with a Cuban theatrical troupe.
4. They worked on the Spanish stage, radio and film until the outbreak of the Civil War in 1936.
5. Fernando progressively began to take a backseat as actor and baritone and focused on promoting the career of his wife Mapy, who became a noted "vedette" (showgirl with star status) in Barcelona.
6. After the Spanish Civil War interrupted their careers, the couple worked in New York, San Juan, Buenos Aires, Havana and Caracas, occasionally starring in movies.
7. They arrived to Mexico City in late 1940 and made their stage debut at the Teatro Follies, in a show headlined by the popular Mexican comedian Cantinflas.
8. Despite early struggles to become household names, Mapy achieved Mexican film stardom in late 1941 and the couple settled in Mexico City.
9. Initially, Fernando Cortés played supporting roles in his wife's films.
10. He then made a successful debut as director with "La pícara Susana" (1945) a comedy vehicle for his wife.
11. On March 1954, Fernando and Mapy Cortés returned to Puerto Rico to help launch local television.
12. Cortés became the first director at WKAQ-TV, Channel 2, and the couple co-starred in "Mapy y Papi", the first Puerto Rican sitcom.
13. Despite their success on local TV, the couple returned the following year to Mexico City, which offered more opportunities.
14. The couple starred in a Mexican version of their Puerto Rican sitcom and Mapy returned to the stage.
15. Fernando Cortés became known as a reliable director of Mexican comedies on stage, television and film.
16. After writing and directing star vehicles for his wife Mapy in the 1940s and comedians like Resortes and Tin-Tan in the 1950s, Fernando Cortés produced and directed Puerto Rican co-productions in the 1960s and launched the film career of La India María in the 1970s.

chunks.title: Meritaten
chunks.chunk:
Title: Meritaten
0. Meritaten, also spelled Merytaten or Meryetaten (14th century BC), was an ancient Egyptian royal woman of the Eighteenth dynasty.
1. Her name means "She who is beloved of Aten"; Aten being the sun-deity whom her father, Pharaoh Akhenaten, worshipped.
2. She held several titles, performing official roles for her father and becoming the Great Royal Wife to Pharaoh Smenkhkare, who may have been a brother or son of Akhenaten.
3. Meritaten also may have served as pharaoh in her own right under the name, Ankhkheperure Neferneferuaten.

chunks.title: Meritaten Tasherit
chunks.chunk:
Title: Meritaten Tasherit
0. Meritaten Tasherit, which means" Meritaten the Younger" was an ancient Egyptian princess of the 18th dynasty.
1. She is likely to have been the daughter of Meritaten, eldest daughter of Pharaoh Akhenaten.
2. The father of this child remains under debate.
3. Many assume it to be none other than Meritaten's father, Akhenaten, or possibly her husband Smenkhkare.
4. Since both Meritaten Tasherit and another princess, Ankhesenpaaten Tasherit appear only in texts that once mentioned Akhenaten's second wife Kiya, it is also possible that they were children of Akhenaten and Kiya, or that they were fictional, replacing the name of Kiya's daughter, who might have been Beketaten, more commonly thought to be Tiye's child.
5. The fate of this child is uncertain.
6. The mention of the god Aten in her name suggests that she was indeed a daughter of Akhenaten, since his successors reverted his religious reforms, and reverted to the worship of Egypt's traditional gods.
7. Meanwhile, the name Aten was dropped from popular use during this time.

Title: Sennedjem
0. The Ancient Egyptian artisan Sennedjem lived in Set Maat( translated as" The Place of Truth"), contemporary Deir el- Medina, on the west bank of the Nile, opposite Thebes, during the reigns of Seti I and Ramesses II.
1. Sennedjem had the title" Servant in the Place of Truth".
2. He was buried along with his wife, Iyneferti, and family in a tomb in the village necropolis.
3. His tomb was discovered January 31, 1886.
4. When Sennedjem's tomb was found, in it there was regular furniture from his home, including a stool and a bed, which he actually used when he was alive.
5. His titles included Servant in the Place of Truth, meaning that he worked on the excavation and decoration of the nearby royal tombs.

1. It is not to be confused with the place of birth or place of residence, although two or all three of these locations may be identical depending on the person's circumstances.

chunks.title: Place of birth
chunks.chunk:
Title: Place of birth
0. The place of birth( POB) or birthplace is the place where a person was born.
1. This place is often used in legal documents, together with name and date of birth, to uniquely identify a person.
2. As a general rule with respect to passports, the place of birth is determined to be the country that currently has" sovereignty" over the actual place of birth, regardless of when the birth actually occurred.
3. The place of birth is not necessarily the place where the parents of the new baby live.
4. If the baby is born in a hospital in another place, that place is the place of birth.
5. In many countries, this also means that the government requires that the birth of the new baby is registered in the place of birth.
6. Some countries place less or no importance on the place of birth, instead using alternative geographical characteristics for the purpose of identity documents.
7. For example, Sweden has used the concept of" födelsehemortdomicile of birth") since 1947.
8. This means that the domicile of the baby's mother is the registered place of birth.
9. The location of the maternity ward or other physical birthplace is considered unimportant.
10. Similarly, Switzerland uses the concept of" Heimatortlieu d'origineluogo d'origineplace of origin" in German, French and Italian respectively).
11. A child born to Swiss parents is automatically assigned the place of origin of the parent with the same last name, so the child either gets their mother's or father's place of origin.
12. A child born to one Swiss parent and one foreign parent acquires the place of origin of their Swiss parent.
13. In a Swiss passport and identity card, the holder's place of origin is stated, not their place of birth.
14. In some countries( primarily in the Americas), the place of birth automatically determines the nationality of the baby, a practice often referred to by the Latin phrase" jus soli".
15. Almost all countries outside the Americas instead attribute nationality based on the nationality( ies) of the baby's parents( referred to as" jus sanguinis").
16. There can be some confusion regarding the place of birth if the birth takes place in an unusual way: when babies are born on an airplane or at sea, difficulties can arise.
17. The place of birth of such a person depends on the law of the countries involved, which include the nationality of the plane or ship, the nationality( ies) of the parents and/ or the location of the plane or ship( if the birth occurs in the territorial waters or airspace of a country).
18. Some administrative forms may request the applicant's" country of birth".
19. It is important to determine from the requester whether the information requested refers to the applicant's" place of birth" or" nationality at birth".
20. For US citizens born abroad who under the US Constitution acquire US citizenship at the time of birth, the nationality at birth will be USA( American), while the place of birth would be the country in which the actual birth takes place.

chunks.title: Akhenaten
chunks.chunk:
Title: Akhenaten
0. Akhenaten (also spelled Echnaton, Akhenaton, Ikhnaton, and Khuenaten; meaning "Effective for Aten"), known before the fifth year of his reign as Amenhotep IV
1. (sometimes given its Greek form, "Amenophis IV", and meaning "Amun Is Satisfied"), was an ancient Egyptian pharaoh of the 18th Dynasty, who ruled for 17 years and died perhaps in 1336 BC or 1334 BC.
2. He is noted for abandoning traditional Egyptian polytheism and introducing worship centered on the Aten (notably instead of Amun the temples of which he destroyed, the name of whom he rubbed off and the priests of whom he left without resources), which is sometimes described as monolatristic, henotheistic, or even quasi-monotheistic.
3. An early inscription likens the Aten to the sun as compared to stars, and later official language avoids calling the Aten a god, giving the solar deity a status above mere gods.
4. Akhenaten tried to shift his culture from Egypt's traditional religion, but the shifts were not widely accepted.
5. After his death, his monuments were dismantled and hidden, his statues were destroyed, and his name excluded from the king lists.
6. Traditional religious practice was gradually restored, and when some dozen years later rulers without clear rights of succession from the 18th Dynasty founded a new dynasty, they discredited Akhenaten and his immediate successors, referring to Akhenaten himself as "the enemy" or "that criminal" in archival records.
7. The stele of Merneptah, on the one hand, values Amun who is represented giving the cemetery of victory to Ramses III (Merneptah), on the other hand, is written on the back of a stele of Akhenaten stolen from one of his temples in Karnak.
8. He was all but lost from history until the discovery during the 19th century of the site of Akhetaten, the city he built and designed for the worship of Aten, at Amarna.
9. Early excavations at Amarna by Flinders
10. Petrie sparked interest in the enigmatic pharaoh, and a mummy found in the tomb KV55, which was unearthed in 1907 in a dig led by Edward R. Ayrton, is likely that of Akhenaten.
11. DNA analysis has determined that the man buried in KV55 is the father of King Tutankhamun, but its identification as Akhenaten has been questioned.
12. Modern interest in Akhenaten and his queen Nefertiti comes partly from his connection with Tutankhamun (even though Tutankhamun's mother was not Nefertiti, but a woman named by archaeologists The Younger Lady), partly from the unique style and high quality of the pictorial arts he patronized, and partly from ongoing interest in the religion he attempted to establish.

chunks.title: Edward I of England
chunks.chunk:
Title: Edward I of England
0. Edward I (17/18 June 1239 – 7 July 1307), also known as Edward Longshanks and the Hammer of the Scots , was King of England from 1272 to 1307.
1. Before his accession to the throne, he was commonly referred to as The Lord Edward.
2. The first son of Henry III, Edward was involved from an early age in the political intrigues of his father's reign, which included an outright rebellion by the English barons.
3. In 1259, he briefly sided with a baronial reform movement, supporting the Provisions of Oxford.
4. After reconciliation with his father, however, he remained loyal throughout the subsequent armed conflict, known as the Second Barons' War.
5. After the Battle of Lewes, Edward was hostage to the rebellious barons, but escaped after a few months and defeated the baronial leader Simon de Montfort at the Battle of Evesham in 1265.
6. Within two years the rebellion was extinguished and, with England pacified, Edward joined the Ninth Crusade to the Holy Land.
7. Edward was on his way home in 1272 when he was informed that his father had died.
8. Making a slow return, he reached England in 1274 and was crowned at Westminster Abbey on 19 August.
9. Edward spent much of his reign reforming royal administration and common law.
10. Through an extensive legal inquiry, he investigated the tenure of various feudal liberties, while the law was reformed through a series of statutes regulating criminal and property law.
11. Increasingly, however, Edward's attention was drawn towards military affairs.
12. After suppressing a minor rebellion in Wales in 1276–77, Edward responded to a second rebellion in 1282–83 with a full-scale war of conquest.
13. After a successful campaign, he subjected Wales to English rule, built a series of castles and towns in the countryside and settled them with English people.
14. Next, his efforts were directed towards Scotland.
15. Initially invited to arbitrate a succession dispute, Edward claimed feudal suzerainty over the kingdom.
16. The war that followed continued after Edward's death, even though the English seemed victorious at several points.
17. Simultaneously, Edward found himself at war with France (a Scottish ally) after the French king Philip IV had confiscated the Duchy of Gascony, which until then had been held in personal union with the Kingdom of England.
18. Although Edward recovered his duchy, this conflict relieved English military pressure against Scotland.
19. At the same time there were problems at home.
20. In the mid-1290s, extensive military campaigns required high levels of taxation, and Edward met with both lay and ecclesiastical opposition.
21. These crises were initially averted, but issues remained unsettled.
22. When the King died in 1307, he left to his son Edward II an ongoing war with Scotland and many financial and political problems.
23. Edward
24. I was a tall man (6'2") for his era, hence the nickname "Longshanks".
25. He was temperamental, and this, along with his height, made him an intimidating man, and he often instilled fear in his contemporaries.
26. Nevertheless, he held the respect of his subjects for the way he embodied the medieval ideal of kingship, as a soldier, an administrator and a man of faith.
27. Modern historians are divided on their assessment of Edward
28. I: while some have praised him for his contribution to the law and administration, others have criticised him for his uncompromising attitude towards his nobility.
29. Currently, Edward I is credited with many accomplishments during his reign, including restoring royal authority after the reign of Henry III, establishing Parliament as a permanent institution and thereby also a functional system for raising taxes, and reforming the law through statutes.
30. At the same time, he is also often criticised for other actions, such as his brutal conduct towards the Welsh and Scots, and issuing the Edict of Expulsion in 1290, by which the Jews were expelled from England.
31. The Edict remained in effect for the rest of the Middle Ages, and it was over 350 years until it was formally overturned under Oliver Cromwell in 1657.

chunks.title: Henry III of England
chunks.chunk:
Title: Henry III of England
0. Henry III (1 October 1207 – 16 November 1272), also known as Henry of Winchester, was King of England, Lord of Ireland, and Duke of Aquitaine from 1216 until his death.
1. The son of King John and Isabella of Angoulême, Henry assumed the throne when he was only nine in the middle of the First Barons' War.
2. Cardinal Guala declared the war against the rebel barons to be a religious crusade and Henry's forces, led by William Marshal, defeated the rebels at the battles of Lincoln and Sandwich in 1217.
3. Henry promised to abide by the Great Charter of 1225, which limited royal power and protected the rights of the major barons.
4. His early rule was dominated first by Hubert de Burgh and then Peter des Roches, who re-established royal authority after the war.
5. In 1230, the King attempted to reconquer the provinces of France that had once belonged to his father, but the invasion was a debacle.
6. A revolt led by William Marshal's son, Richard Marshal, broke out in 1232, ending in a peace settlement negotiated by the Church.
7. Following the revolt, Henry ruled England personally, rather than governing through senior ministers.
8. He travelled less than previous monarchs, investing heavily in a handful of his favourite palaces and castles.
9. He married Eleanor of Provence, with whom he had five children.
10. Henry was known for his piety, holding lavish religious ceremonies and giving generously to charities; the King was particularly devoted to the figure of Edward the Confessor, whom he adopted as his patron saint.
11. He extracted huge sums of money from the Jews in England, ultimately crippling their ability to do business, and as attitudes towards the Jews hardened, he introduced the Statute of Jewry, attempting to segregate the community.
12. In a fresh attempt to reclaim his family's lands in France, he invaded Poitou in 1242, leading to the disastrous Battle of Taillebourg.
13. After this, Henry relied on diplomacy, cultivating an alliance with Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor.
14. Henry supported his brother Richard of Cornwall in his bid to become King of the Romans in 1256, but was unable to place his own son Edmund Crouchback on the throne of Sicily, despite investing large amounts of money.
15. He planned to go on crusade to the Levant, but was prevented from doing so by rebellions in Gascony.
16. By 1258, Henry's rule was increasingly unpopular, the result of the failure of his expensive foreign policies and the notoriety of his Poitevin half-brothers, the Lusignans, as well as the role of his local officials in collecting taxes and debts.
17. A coalition of his barons, initially probably backed by Eleanor, seized power in a coup d'état and expelled the Poitevins from England, reforming the royal government through a process called the Provisions of Oxford.
18. Henry and the baronial government enacted a peace with France in 1259, under which Henry gave up his rights to his other lands in France in return for King Louis IX recognising him as the rightful ruler of Gascony.
19. The baronial regime collapsed but Henry was unable to reform a stable government and instability across England continued.
20. In 1263, one of the more radical barons, Simon de Montfort, seized power, resulting in the Second Barons' War.
21. Henry persuaded Louis to support his cause and mobilised an army.
22. The Battle of Lewes occurred in 1264, where Henry was defeated and taken prisoner.
23. Henry's eldest son, Edward, escaped from captivity to defeat de Montfort at the Battle of Evesham the following year and freed his father.
24. Henry initially enacted a harsh revenge on the remaining rebels, but was persuaded by the Church to mollify his policies through the Dictum of Kenilworth.
25. Reconstruction was slow and Henry had to acquiesce to various measures, including further suppression of the Jews, to maintain baronial and popular support.
26. Henry died in 1272, leaving Edward as his successor.
27. He was buried in Westminster Abbey, which he had rebuilt in the second half of his reign, and was moved to his current tomb in 1290.
28. Some miracles were declared after his death; however, he was not canonised.

chunks.title: Gaston II, Count of Foix
chunks.chunk:
Title: Gaston II, Count of Foix
0. Gaston II of Foix-Béarn
1. ( 1308 – September 1343), son of Gaston I of Foix- Béarn and Jeanne of Artois, was the 10th Count of Foix.
2. In 1315, after the death of his father Gaston I, he became Count of Foix, and Viscount of Béarn, Marsan, Gabardan, Nébouzan and Lautrec under the regency of his mother, Jeanne of Artois.
3. Count Gaston II imprisoned his mother Jeanne d'Artois in 1331 at the Château of Foix, being later moved in turn to Orthez, Lourdes and Carbonne.
4. Gaston II married his cousin Eleanore de Comminges, daughter of Bernard VII of Comminges and Laura de Montfort.
5. Eleanore de Comminges brought, as a dowry, her rights to the County of Bigorre.
6. They had one son: Gaston III Febus, who succeeded his father as Count of Foix.
7. Gaston II had several illegitimate children:
8. His actions in 1339 during the conquest of the castle of Tartas resulted in him receiving the title of Viscount of Lautrec.
9. He was at the Siege of Algeciras( 1342 – 44) in southern Spain, which was led by King Alfonso XI of Castile.
10. He died of the plague at Seville in 1343.

1. Born in Mazères, County of Foix, he was the second child but only son of John of Foix, Viscount of Narbonne and Marie d'Orléans.
2. His older sister was Germaine of Foix, Queen consort of Aragon as the second wife of Ferdinand II.
3. His paternal grandparents were Gaston IV of Foix- Grailly and Queen regnant Eleanor of Navarre.
4. His maternal grandparents were Charles, Duke of Orléans and Marie of Cleves.
5. His only maternal uncle was Louis XII of France.

chunks.title: Etan Boritzer
chunks.chunk:
Title: Etan Boritzer
0. Etan Boritzer( born 1950) is an American writer of children ’s literature who is best known for his book" What is God?" first published in 1989.
1. His best selling" What is?" illustrated children's book series on character education and difficult subjects for children is a popular teaching guide for parents, teachers and child- life professionals.
2. Boritzer gained national critical acclaim after" What is God?" was published in 1989 although the book has caused controversy from religious fundamentalists for its universalist views.
3. The other current books in the" What is?" series include
4. What is Love?,
5. What is Death?,
6. What is Beautiful?,
7. What is Funny?,
8. What is Right?,
9. What is Peace?,
10. What is Money?,
11. What is Dreaming?,
12. What is a Friend?,
13. What is True?,
14. What is a Family?,
15. What is a Feeling?"
16. The series is now also translated into 15 languages.
17. Boritzer was first published in 1963 at the age of 13 when he wrote an essay in his English class at Wade Junior High School in the Bronx, New York on the assassination of John F. Kennedy.
18. His essay was included in a special anthology by New York City public school children compiled and published by the New York City Department of Education.
19. Boritzer now lives in Venice, California and maintains his publishing office there also.
20. He has helped numerous other authors to get published through" How to Get Your Book Published!" programs.
21. Boritzer is also a yoga teacher who teaches regular classes locally and guest- teaches nationally.
22. He is also recognized nationally as an erudite speaker on" The Teachings of the Buddha."

chunks.title: All of Me (Boy Oh Boy)
chunks.chunk:
Title: All of Me (Boy Oh Boy)
0. " All Of Me( Boy Oh Boy)" was the fifth international single release by Italian popstar Sabrina.
1. It was released in Italy in July 1988 as the first single from her second album" Super Sabrina".
2. It is written and produced by Stock Aitken& Waterman and followed her previous single" Hot Girl" in Europe, while it was her second single release in the UK, following" Boys( Summertime Love)".
3. Entering the charts in mid-summer 1988, the single became Sabrina's third major international hit.
4. It followed" Boys( Summertime Love)" and" Hot Girl" into the Top 10 or Top 20 in practically every country in the European continent, and made the Top 30 in the UK.
5. For example, in France it reached number 15, but spent 18 weeks in the Top 50.
6. It made Top 30 in the overall Eurochart, and would probably have peaked even higher had it been released in the UK at the same time as in the rest of Europe.
7. Its estimated worldwide sales are around 400,000- 500,000 copies.

4. The song peaked at# 55 at the Hot R&B/ Hip- Hop Singles& Tracks.

chunks.title: When You're Strange
chunks.chunk:
Title: When You're Strange
0. When You're Strange is a 2009 music documentary film about the American rock band the Doors.
1. It was written and directed by Tom DiCillo and narrated by Johnny Depp.
2. The film begins with the band's formation in 1965, its development over the next two years, release of their debut album and subsequent albums and Jim Morrison's use of alcohol and drugs and subsequent death in Paris in July 1971.
3. The film features archival footage of rehearsals, TV and concert performances, private cine- film and the background to Morrison's arrest at a 1969 Miami concert and later trial.
4. The film also includes the first public release of material from Morrison's 1969 film.
5. Doors' keyboardist Ray Manzarek stated that" This will be the true story of the Doors," and that the film will be" the anti-Oliver Stone," referring to the 1991 film about the group that Stone directed, and which drew criticism from many Doors fans and several people who knew Morrison.

1. It is a 50- minute experimental film in Direct Cinema style.
2. It was shot during the spring and summer of 1969 in the Mojave Desert and in Los Angeles.
3. In the informal 1971 interview Morrison gave to Ben Fong Torres, Morrison states the film" ... was more of an exercise for me and a warm- up for something bigger."
4. Apart from select excerpts used in the 2009 documentary" When You're Strange", the complete 35 mm movie has yet to be released commercially.

chunks.title: Frederick I, Holy Roman Emperor
chunks.chunk:
Title: Frederick I, Holy Roman Emperor
0. Frederick Barbarossa (1122 – 10 June 1190), also known as Frederick I, was the Holy Roman Emperor from 2 January 1155 until his death.
1. He was elected King of Germany at Frankfurt on 4 March 1152 and crowned in Aachen on 9 March 1152.
2. He was crowned King of Italy on 24 April 1155 in Pavia and emperor by Pope Adrian IV on 18 June 1155 in Rome.
3. Two years later, the term ' ("holy") first appeared in a document in connection with his empire.
4. He was later formally crowned King of Burgundy, at Arles on 30 June 1178.
5. He was named ' by the northern Italian cities which he attempted to rule: Barbarossa means "red beard" in Italian; in German, he was known as ", which has the same meaning.
6. Before his imperial election, Frederick was by inheritance Duke of Swabia (1147–1152, as Frederick III).
7. He was the son of Duke Frederick II of the Hohenstaufen dynasty and Judith, daughter of Henry IX, Duke of Bavaria, from the rival House of Welf.
8. Frederick, therefore, descended from the two leading families in Germany, making him an acceptable choice for the Empire's prince-electors.
9. Historians consider him among the Holy Roman Empire's greatest medieval emperors.
10. He combined qualities that made him appear almost superhuman to his contemporaries: his longevity, his ambition, his extraordinary skills at organization, his battlefield acumen and his political perspicacity.
11. His contributions to Central European society and culture include the reestablishment of the ", or the Roman rule of law, which counterbalanced the papal power that dominated the German states since the conclusion of the Investiture Controversy.
12. Frederick died in 1190 in Asia Minor while leading an army in the Third Crusade.

chunks.title: Matilda II, Countess of Nevers
chunks.chunk:
Title: Matilda II, Countess of Nevers
0. Matilda II, Countess of Nevers( 1234/35–1262), also known as Maud of Dampierre or Mathilda II of Bourbon, was a sovereign Countess of Nevers, Countess of Auxerre, Countess of Tonnerre and Lady of Bourbon.
1. She was a daughter of Archambaud IX of Bourbon and Yolande de Châtillon, Countess of Nevers.
2. As heiress to the counties of Nevers, Auxerre and Tonnerre, she was married off to Odo, Count of Nevers, the son and heir of Hugh IV, Duke of Burgundy.
3. By this marriage Odo reunited two important areas that had previously been united as the Duchy of Burgundy, but he died leaving no male heirs, and so the united territory passed to his brother Robert II, Duke of Burgundy.
4. After her father's death Matilda also became Lady of Bourbon.
5. With Odo she had three children:

chunks.title: Taxi zum Klo
chunks.chunk:
Title: Taxi zum Klo
0. Taxi zum Klo is a 1981 film written by, directed by, and starring Frank Ripploh.
1. The film is a dark comedy of manners that wryly explores the life of a Berlin school teacher and the contrasts between his public and private lives.
2. It was sexually explicit for general audiences of the day and for some time afterwards.
3. So, for example, the film was not passed uncut by the British Board of Film Classification until 2011, though it was widely shown in club cinemas.
4. Taxi zum Klo was considered groundbreaking for its subject matter and achieved a cult status among audiences of the time.
5. Shot on location with many characters appearing as themselves, the film documents gay culture in West Berlin in the brief moment post gay liberation and before the onset of AIDS, around 1980.
6. Ripploh has stated that much of the film was autobiographical.
7. The name literally means Taxi to the Toilet( or" Cab to the Cottage", etc.), that being a place for casual gay sex.

Title: Taxi nach Kairo

1. The film is about a love triangle between Frank, Klara, an actress posing as Frank's wife in order to appease his mother, and their neighbor, Eugen.
2. The title translates to Taxi to Cairo.

chunks.title: Sackville Lane-Fox, 12th Baron Conyers
chunks.chunk:
Title: Sackville Lane-Fox, 12th Baron Conyers
0. Sackville George Lane-Fox, 12th Baron Conyers and "de jure" 15th Baron Darcy de Knayth (14 September 1827 – 24 August 1888) was a British peer and soldier.

chunks.title: George Fox-Lane, 1st Baron Bingley
chunks.chunk:
Title: George Fox-Lane, 1st Baron Bingley
0. George Fox- Lane, 1st Baron Bingley( circa 1697 – 22 February 1773) was a British peer and Tory politician.
1. Born George Fox, he was the first son and heir of Henry Fox and his second wife, Hon. Frances" née" Lane, the daughter of George Lane, 1st Viscount Lanesborough and his third wife Lady Frances Sackville.
2. From 1734 to 1741, he was Member of Parliament for Hindon and then for the City of York from 1742 to 1761.
3. In 1750, he took the additional name of Lane by an Act of Parliament in 1750, on succeeding to the estates of his maternal half- uncle, James Lane, 2nd Viscount Lanesborough.
4. On 12 July 1731, he had married Hon. Harriet Benson( c.1705-1771), the only child of Robert Benson, 1st Baron Bingley; their only child was Robert Fox- Lane( died 1768).
5. He was Lord Mayor of York for 1757.
6. On 13 May 1762, Lane- Fox's father- in- law's extinct title was re-created, when he was created Baron Bingley, of Bingley in the County of York, with remainder only to his heirs male with his wife, Harriet.
7. As his only son died in 1768 and his wife in 1771, the title became extinct on his own death in 1773.

chunks.title: George Lane Parker
chunks.chunk:
Title: George Lane Parker
0. Hon. George Lane Parker( 1724–1791) was a British Army officer and politician who sat in the House of Commons between 1769 and 1780.

chunks.title: Sackville Lane-Fox
chunks.chunk:
Title: Sackville Lane-Fox
0. Sackville Walter Lane- Fox( 24 March 1797 – 18 August 1874), was a British Conservative Party politician.

chunks.title: James Fox-Lane
chunks.chunk:
Title: James Fox-Lane
0. James Fox-Lane (August 1756 – 7 April 1821), known as James Fox until 1773, was an English landed gentleman, who represented Horsham in Parliament for six years.
1. He was the oldest son of Sackville Fox of East Horsley, Surrey, and his wife Ann Holloway.
2. His father died in 1760 and left him his estate in Surrey, worth about £1,300 per year.
3. Educated at Marylebone School, he was admitted to Christ's College, Cambridge in 1771 and studied there until 1774.
4. On 22 February 1773, he inherited the Bramham Park, Yorkshire estate of his paternal uncle George Fox-Lane, 1st Baron Bingley, and subsequently took the name of Fox-Lane.
5. Through extravagance as a youth he became indebted to the moneylender Robert Mackreth.
6. Mackreth bought Fox-Lane's Surrey estate very shortly after James came of age in 1777 and resold it for a handsome profit.
7. He attempted to buy the Yorkshire estate as well, but the sale was cancelled by the Court of Chancery.
8. Fox-Lane subsequently retained John Scott as counsel and sued Mackreth, alleging that Mackreth had defrauded him, and that the transactions had begun while Fox-Lane was still a minor.
9. His suit was successful, and he was awarded the purchase money of the Surrey estate with interest and costs, totaling about £20,000.
10. Mackreth appealed, but the verdict was upheld by the Lord Chancellor and, in 1791, the House of Lords.
11. On 23 July 1789, Fox-Lane married Hon.
12. Marcia Lucy Pitt (1756–1822), the daughter of George Pitt, 1st Baron Rivers.
13. They had four sons and one daughter:
14. On 5 May 1790, Fox-Lane was commissioned a lieutenant in the Dorsetshire Militia, of which his father-in-law was colonel.
15. Although he had joined Brooks's Club, famously a society of Whigs, Fox-Lane had little interest in politics.
16. Frances, the Dowager Viscountess of Irvine, was one of his Yorkshire neighbours, and in the 1796 election, returned him for one of the seats she controlled at Horsham.
17. No known speech or vote on his part survives, and he did not stand at the 1802 election.
18. He died on 7 April 1821, his health having declined for some time, and left an estate worth £120,000.

chunks.title: Felicity Lane-Fox, Baroness Lane-Fox
chunks.chunk:
Title: Felicity Lane-Fox, Baroness Lane-Fox
0. Felicity Lane- Fox, Baroness Lane- Fox, OBE( 22 June 1918 – 17 April 1988) was a Conservative member of the House of Lords and champion of disability issues.
1. She was born in Tadcaster, Yorkshire, the daughter of Edward Lane- Fox, who was brother of George Lane- Fox, 1st Baron Bingley.
2. At the age of 12 she was paralysed by an attack of poliomyelitis.
3. In 1963 she became a member of the executive of the National Union of Conservative and Unionist Associations.
4. In the 1976 New Year Honours list she was appointed OBE for services to disabled people.
5. In 1981 she was made a life peer, as Baroness Lane- Fox, of Bramham in the County of West Yorkshire.
6. Using an electric wheelchair, she was an active member of the House of Lords until her death.
7. She was the aunt of Robin Lane Fox and great- aunt of his daughter Martha Lane Fox, Baroness Lane- Fox of Soho.

chunks.title: Kenneth Hargreaves
chunks.chunk:
Title: Kenneth Hargreaves
0. Brigadier Kenneth Hargreaves( 23 February 1903 – 27 March 1990) was a British soldier and industrialist who held several local offices in Yorkshire.
1. He was commissioned into the Leeds Rifles, a Territorial Army battalion of the West Yorkshire Regiment, in 1922 but later transferred to the Royal Artillery when the Leeds Rifles became 66th Anti-Aircraft Regiment, RA.
2. He was appointed Commander of the Order of the British Empire( CBE) in 1956.
3. He married Else Markenstam( d. 1968) in 1958, and adopted his stepchildren by that marriage, Ingrid Mary and Peter Hargreaves- Allen.
4. He subsequently married Hon. Margaret Lane- Fox, the daughter of George Lane- Fox, 1st Baron Bingley, on 15 February 1969.
5. Hargreaves served as High Sheriff of Yorkshire in 1962, Lord Lieutenant of the West Riding of Yorkshire from 1970 until 1974, when, as a result of the reorganization of county governments, he became Lord Lieutenant of West Yorkshire until 1978.
6. He was appointed a Deputy Lieutenant of West Yorkshire on 4 May 1978.

chunks.title: Martha Lane Fox
chunks.chunk:
Title: Martha Lane Fox
0. Martha Lane Fox, Baroness Lane- Fox of Soho, CBE( born 10 February 1973) is a British businesswoman, philanthropist and public servant.
1. She co-founded Last Minute during the dotcom boom of the early 2000s and has subsequently served on public service digital projects.
2. She sits on the boards of Twitter, Donmar Warehouse and Chanel, as well as being a trustee of The Queens Commonwealth Trust.
3. She previously served on the board of Channel 4.
4. She entered the House of Lords as a crossbencher on 26 March 2013, becoming its youngest female member, and was appointed Chancellor of the Open University on 12 March 2014.
5. In November 2019, Lane Fox was named as the most influential woman in Britain's digital sector from the past quarter of a century ..

chunks.title: George Lane-Fox (MP)
chunks.chunk:
Title: George Lane-Fox (MP)
0. George Lane-Fox (4 May 1793 – 15 November 1848), of Bramham Park, Yorkshire, was a British landowner and Tory politician.
1. Lane-Fox was the son of James Fox-Lane, of Bramham Park, Yorkshire, by the Honourable Mary Lucy, daughter of George Pitt, 1st Baron Rivers.
2. He was the brother of Sackville Lane-Fox and the uncle of Sackville Lane-Fox, 12th Baron Conyers, and Augustus Pitt Rivers.
3. He inherited Bramham Park, near Wetherby but moved to Bowcliffe Hall after Bramham Hall was severely damaged by fire in 1828.
4. Lane-Fox was returned to parliament for Beverley in 1820, a seat he held until 1826 and again between 1837 and 1840.
5. His brother Sackville Lane-Fox succeeded him in 1840.
6. Lane-Fox died in November 1848, aged 55.
7. He had married Georgiana Henrietta, daughter of Edward Percy Buckley, of Minestead Lodge, Hampshire, in 1814.
8. They had one son and two daughters.
9. His only son George Lane-Fox (d. 1896), High Sheriff of Leitrim and of Yorkshire, was the grandfather of George Lane-Fox, 1st Baron Bingley.

chunks.title: Joseph Andrews (British politician)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Joseph Andrews (British politician)
0. Joseph Ormond Andrews( 1873 – 26 January 1909) was a Liberal Party politician in the United Kingdom.
1. Andrews was educated at the Ripon Cathedral Choir School.
2. A barrister by profession, Andrews was called to the Bar at the Inner Temple in 1898 and practised on the North Eastern circuit.
3. A Freemason, he was a member of the Zetland Lodge in Leeds.
4. A keen sportsman, he was a follower of the Bramham Moor Hounds, and ran horses at the Wetherby Steeplechase.
5. Andrews was elected as Member of Parliament( MP) for Barkston Ash at a by-election in October 1905 following the death of Sir Robert Gunter, defeating the Conservative candidate George Lane- Fox by 228 votes.
6. The seat had never been won by the Liberals before.
7. However, as Parliament was not sitting at the time, Andrews was unable to take his seat.
8. Andrews lost the seat only three months later at the 1906 general election to the Conservative Party candidate, again George Lane- Fox( later 1st Baron Bingley), losing by 548 votes.
9. His defeat was one of the few Liberal losses at an election which saw the party win a landslide majority in the House of Commons.
10. Andrews thus became one of the shortest- serving Members of Parliament, and one of only a handful never to take their seats.
11. Andrews died, in 1909, at Boston Spa, Leeds.
12. after two operations for appendicitis.
13. He was 36 years old and left a widow and two children.

chunks.title: Sennedjem
chunks.chunk:
Title: Sennedjem
0. The Ancient Egyptian artisan Sennedjem lived in Set Maat( translated as" The Place of Truth"), contemporary Deir el- Medina, on the west bank of the Nile, opposite Thebes, during the reigns of Seti I and Ramesses II.
1. Sennedjem had the title" Servant in the Place of Truth".
2. He was buried along with his wife, Iyneferti, and family in a tomb in the village necropolis.
3. His tomb was discovered January 31, 1886.
4. When Sennedjem's tomb was found, in it there was regular furniture from his home, including a stool and a bed, which he actually used when he was alive.
5. His titles included Servant in the Place of Truth, meaning that he worked on the excavation and decoration of the nearby royal tombs.

chunks.title: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
chunks.chunk:
Title: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
0. Johann Wolfgang von Goethe (28 August 1749 – 22 March 1832) was a German writer and statesman.
1. His works include: four novels; epic and lyric poetry; prose and verse dramas; memoirs; an autobiography; literary and aesthetic criticism; and treatises on botany, anatomy, and colour.
2. In addition, numerous literary and scientific fragments, more than 10,000 letters, and nearly 3,000 drawings by him have survived.
3. A literary celebrity by the age of 25
4. , Goethe was ennobled by the Duke of Saxe-Weimar, Karl August, in 1782 after taking up residence in Weimar in November 1775 following the success of his first novel, "The Sorrows of Young Werther" (1774).
5. He was an early participant in the "Sturm und Drang" literary movement.
6. During his first ten years in Weimar, Goethe became a member of the Duke's privy council, sat on the war and highway commissions, oversaw the reopening of silver mines in nearby Ilmenau, and implemented a series of administrative reforms at the University of Jena.
7. He also contributed to the planning of Weimar's botanical park and the rebuilding of its Ducal Palace.
8. Goethe's first major scientific work, the "Metamorphosis of Plants", was published after he returned from a 1788 tour of Italy.
9. In 1791 he was made managing director of the theatre at Weimar, and in 1794 he began a friendship with the dramatist, historian, and philosopher Friedrich Schiller, whose plays he premiered until Schiller's death in 1805.
10. During this period Goethe published his second novel, "Wilhelm Meister's Apprenticeship"; the verse epic "Hermann and Dorothea", and, in 1808, the first part of his most celebrated drama, "Faust".
11. His conversations and various shared undertakings throughout the 1790s with Schiller, Johann Gottlieb Fichte, Johann Gottfried Herder, Alexander von Humboldt, Wilhelm von Humboldt, and August and Friedrich Schlegel have come to be collectively termed Weimar Classicism.
12. The German philosopher Arthur Schopenhauer named "Wilhelm Meister's Apprenticeship" one of the four greatest novels ever written, while the American philosopher and essayist Ralph Waldo Emerson selected Goethe as one of six "representative men" in his work of the same name (along with Plato, Emanuel Swedenborg, Montaigne, Napoleon, and Shakespeare).
13. Goethe's comments and observations form the basis of several biographical works, notably Johann Peter Eckermann's "Conversations with Goethe" (1836).

chunks.title: Place of birth
chunks.chunk:
Title: Place of birth
0. The place of birth( POB) or birthplace is the place where a person was born.
1. This place is often used in legal documents, together with name and date of birth, to uniquely identify a person.
2. As a general rule with respect to passports, the place of birth is determined to be the country that currently has" sovereignty" over the actual place of birth, regardless of when the birth actually occurred.
3. The place of birth is not necessarily the place where the parents of the new baby live.
4. If the baby is born in a hospital in another place, that place is the place of birth.
5. In many countries, this also means that the government requires that the birth of the new baby is registered in the place of birth.
6. Some countries place less or no importance on the place of birth, instead using alternative geographical characteristics for the purpose of identity documents.
7. For example, Sweden has used the concept of" födelsehemortdomicile of birth") since 1947.
8. This means that the domicile of the baby's mother is the registered place of birth.
9. The location of the maternity ward or other physical birthplace is considered unimportant.
10. Similarly, Switzerland uses the concept of" Heimatortlieu d'origineluogo d'origineplace of origin" in German, French and Italian respectively).
11. A child born to Swiss parents is automatically assigned the place of origin of the parent with the same last name, so the child either gets their mother's or father's place of origin.
12. A child born to one Swiss parent and one foreign parent acquires the place of origin of their Swiss parent.
13. In a Swiss passport and identity card, the holder's place of origin is stated, not their place of birth.
14. In some countries( primarily in the Americas), the place of birth automatically determines the nationality of the baby, a practice often referred to by the Latin phrase" jus soli".
15. Almost all countries outside the Americas instead attribute nationality based on the nationality( ies) of the baby's parents( referred to as" jus sanguinis").
16. There can be some confusion regarding the place of birth if the birth takes place in an unusual way: when babies are born on an airplane or at sea, difficulties can arise.
17. The place of birth of such a person depends on the law of the countries involved, which include the nationality of the plane or ship, the nationality( ies) of the parents and/ or the location of the plane or ship( if the birth occurs in the territorial waters or airspace of a country).
18. Some administrative forms may request the applicant's" country of birth".
19. It is important to determine from the requester whether the information requested refers to the applicant's" place of birth" or" nationality at birth".
20. For US citizens born abroad who under the US Constitution acquire US citizenship at the time of birth, the nationality at birth will be USA( American), while the place of birth would be the country in which the actual birth takes place.

2. He was also an hereditary Knight of the Golden Spur/ Eques Auratus and Papal Count Palatine of the Lateran.

Rodolph Fane De Salis,( Fringford, 10.12.1854- 26.11.1931( buried Virginia Water), FGS, AMICE, civil engineer who was a director and then chairman of the Singer Motor Company of Coventry; President of the Canal Association; the last chairman of the Grand Junction Canal Co.; and director of the North Staffordshire Railway, the Great Central Railway, and of the Coventry Canal.
1. A nephew of William Fane de Salis and the eldest son of Rev. Henry- Jerome Fane De Salis, of Fringford and then Portnall Park, Virginia Water, the seventh son of the 4th Count de Salis, he was educated at Eton and( Trinity Hall, Cantab).
2. Sir Cecil Fane De Salis and Charles De Salis, Bishop of Taunton were two of his three brothers.
3. He was also a sometime Lieutenant in the Surrey Volunteer Regiment.
4. Lived in Acton, Westminster and Barkeston gardens, Kensington.
5. He inherited Portnall Park, Virginia
6. Water from his father in 1915 and sold it in 1924.
7. He lived subsequently at Finmere house, county Buckingham, which was within five miles of where he was born.
8. His recreations were listed in" Who's Who" as motoring and golfing.
9. A member of United University Club and Garrick Club.
10. His cars had number plates DU 4726 and DU 6765.

Title: George De Salis

1. He was born on Darbalara Station near Gundagai to pastoralist Leopold Fane De Salis and Charlotte Macdonald.
2. He received a private education and then farmed at Tharwa and Michelago.
3. On 28 February 1878 he married Mary Galliard-Smith, with whom he had eight children.
4. He was elected to the New South Wales Legislative Assembly for Queanbeyan in 1882, but did not re-contest in 1885.
5. De Salis died at Michelago in 1931.

0. Leopold William Jerome Fane De Salis( 12 June 1845 – 3 August 1930) was an Australian politician.

2. He was elected to the New South Wales Legislative Assembly for Queanbeyan in 1872, but did not re-contest in 1874.
3. He managed the family estates in Queensland until 1892, when they were lost in the economic crash.
4. In 1895 he married Jeanette Armstrong.
5. De Salis moved to England in 1910 and died in 1930 at Laleham.

1. De Salis was the third son of Jerome, 4th Count de Salis-Soglio (d. 1836), by his third wife, Henrietta Foster (d. 1856).
2. Peter John Fane, Count de Salis was an elder half-brother.
3. William Foster Stawell was a first cousin, and the poet Lord De Tabley was a nephew.
4. Colonel Bisse-Challoner was a brother-in-law.
5. General Rodolph de Salis was an elder brother and the Rev. Henry Jerome de Salis
6. was his youngest brother and Rodolph, Cecil and Charles were nephews.
7. Born in St. Marylebone, Westminster, brought up in County Louth he was educated at Eton (1824–27); Heidelberg University (1828–29); and Oriel College, Oxford (1830–1834, Classics, 4th class).
8. He was called to the Bar, 30 January 1836; and was at 3 Brick Court, Inner Temple, by 1840.
9. He was appointed a revising barrister for Northamptonshire (1839), Nottingham and East Retford.

chunks.title: Leopold Fane De Salis
chunks.chunk:
Title: Leopold Fane De Salis
0. Leopold Fabius Dietegen Fane de Salis, (26 April 1816 – 20 November 1898) was a Tuscan-born Australian pastoralist and politician.
1. Born in Florence to Jerome, 4th Count de Salis-Soglio and Henrietta Foster, he attended Eton College and studied sheep farming at Jedburgh in Scotland.
2. In 1840 he migrated to Sydney, where he formed a partnership to run a station at Junee.
3. In the same decade, in 1842, 1844 and 1848, his highly capable next elder brother William also sailed to Australia.
4. They did much business together.
5. In 1844 he married Charlotte Macdonald, with whom he had four children, two of whom
6. (George and Leopold) would later become politicians themselves.
7. In 1855 he sold out and bought the Cuppacumbalong station at Tharwa, later purchasing further property on the Murrumbidgee River.
8. In 1864 he was elected to the New South Wales Legislative Assembly for Queanbeyan, but he did not re-contest in 1869.
9. In 1872 he was appointed to the New South Wales Legislative Council.
10. Around this time he also acquired property in Queensland, all of which he lost in the 1890s depression.
11. His daughter Nina married William Farrer in 1882 and they lived at Lambrigg, Tharwa, a property given them by De Salis.
12. In 1898 he left the Council bankrupt with significant debts.
13. He died at Tharwa later that year.

question: What is the date of death of Catherine Of Guelders's father?

chunks.title: Reginald III, Duke of Guelders
chunks.chunk:
Title: Reginald III, Duke of Guelders
0. Reginald III of Guelders( or" Renaud", known as" The Fat")( 13 May 1333 – 4 December 1371) was Duke of Guelders and Count of Zutphen from 1343 to 1361, and again in 1371.
1. He was the son of Reginald II of Guelders and of Eleanor of Woodstock, daughter of Edward II of England.
2. With the death of his father in 1343, his mother held the regency until 1344.
3. From 1350, his brother Edward asserted his rights and a quarrel of succession broke out between the two brothers until 1361.
4. Reginald was overcome in Tiel and was imprisoned in the castle of Nijenbeek.
5. There he became so large that he could not have left, even if the door had remained open—hence his appellation" The Fat".
6. Edward died on 24 August 1371, having been mortally wounded in the Battle of Baesweiler, and Reginald was released( according to the legend, the walls had to be cut away so he could leave); he held the ducal throne for only a short period, dying a few months later.
7. He was buried at Graefenthal Abbey.
8. As he did not have a legitimate child, the succession passed to his sisters: Mathilde( also, Machteld), who was married to John II, Count of Blois, and Maria, wife of William II of Jülich and mother to William I of Guelders and Jülich, on whose behalf she claimed the throne of Guelders.
9. The sisters and their respective followers( the" Heeckerens", from the party led by families of Van Heeckeren and their relatives, the Van Rechterens, supported Mathilde, while the faction known as the" Bronkhorsters" followed Maria) fought for the duchy of Guelders in the War of the Succession of Guelders.

chunks.title: Reginald II, Duke of Guelders
chunks.chunk:
Title: Reginald II, Duke of Guelders
0. Reginald II of Guelders, called" the Black"( c. 1295 – 12 October 1343), was Count of Guelders, and from 1339 onwards Duke of Guelders, and Zutphen, in the Low Countries, from 1326 to 1343.
1. He was the son of Reginald I of Guelders and Marguerite of Flanders.

chunks.title: Otto I, Count of Guelders
chunks.chunk:
Title: Otto I, Count of Guelders
0. Otto I of Guelders( 1150 – 1207) was a Count of Guelders and Zutphen from 1182 until his death in 1207.
1. He was a son of Duke Hendrik of Guelders and Agnes of Arnstein.
2. He married Richardis of Bavaria in 1184.
3. Richardis was a daughter of Otto I Wittelsbach, Duke of Bavaria.

chunks.title: Catherine of Guelders
chunks.chunk:
Title: Catherine of Guelders 0. Catherine of Guelders (ca. 1440 – Guelders, January 25, 1497), was regent of the Duchy of Guelders between 1477 and 1492. 1. Catherine of Guelders was the fourth and youngest child of Arnold, Duke of Guelders (1410-1473) and Catherine of Cleves (1417–1479).
3. Until 1477, she led an inconspicuous life, in the shadow of her brother Adolf, at war with his father, and her sisters Mary, married to King James II of Scotland and Margaret, married to Frederick I, Count Palatine of Simmern.
5. Despite efforts by her father, no suitable husband was found for Catherine.
6. 17th century theories that she was secretly married with Louis de Bourbon, Bishop of Liège, are now believed to be false. 7. Everything changed for Catherine in 1477, when Charles the Bold was killed in the Battle of Nancy. 8. Guelders had been under control of Charles the Bold since 1473, and now saw the chance to regain its independence. 9. As her brother Adolf was in Flanders, the States of Guelders convinced him to appoint his sister Catherine as regent, pending his return. 10. Catherine reluctantly agreed. 11. But the regency lasted much longer than expected because Adolf was killed in battle on June 27, 1477. 12. She then continued to rule as regent for his son Charles II, who was held with his sister Philippa by the Burgundians. 13. Catherine became involved in the Guelderian War of Independence with Maximilian of Austria. 14. In 1482, she was forced to conclude peace with Maximilian and to retire from politics. 15. In 1492, she witnessed the regained independence of Guelders under her nephew Charles II, Duke of Guelders.
17. Catherine died in 1497 and was buried in the church of Geldern, where her grave can still be seen.

chunks.title: Gerard III, Count of Guelders
chunks.chunk:
Title: Gerard III, Count of Guelders
0. Gerard III of Guelders( 1185 – 22 October 1229) was the Count of Guelders and Zutphen from 1207 until his death in 1229.
1. He was a son of Count Otto I of Guelders, and is sometimes called Gerard IV or Gerard V.
2. He married Margaretha of Brabant, the daughter of Duke Hendrik I of Brabant, in 1206.

chunks.title: Margaret of Guelders (1436–1486)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Margaret of Guelders (1436–1486)
0. Margaret of Guelders( 11 August 1436, Grave, North Brabant – 2 November 1486, Simmern) was a noblewoman from what is now the Netherlands.
1. She was the daughter of Arnold of Egmond, Duke of Guelders, and Catherine of Cleves( 1417 – 1479).
2. Via her mother she was a granddaughter of Adolph I, Duke of Cleves.
3. In Lobith on 6 August 1454 she married Frederick I, Count Palatine of Simmern- they had ten children:

chunks.title: Catherine of Cleves (1417–1479)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Catherine of Cleves (1417–1479)
0. Catherine of Cleves (25 May 1417 – 10 February 1479) was Duchess of Guelders by marriage to Arnold, Duke of Guelders.
1. She acted as regent of Guelders during the absence of her spouse in 1450.
2. The Hours of Catherine of Cleves was commissioned for her.

chunks.title: Maria, Duchess of Guelders
chunks.chunk:
Title: Maria, Duchess of Guelders
0. Marie of Guelders( † May 12, 1405) was one of two pretenders to the title of Duchess of Guelders and Countess of Zutphen on behalf of her son during the War of the Guelderian Succession from 1371 to 1379.
1. The war began after the deaths of her brothers, Reginald III of Guelders and Edward of Guelders.
2. Edward died from wounds received at the Battle of Baesweiler, and Reginald, who was known as the fat, died months later.
3. Succession was also claimed by Marie's sister, Mathilda, whose side was called the" Heeckerens" and were led by Frederik van Heeckeren van der Eze( 1320- 1386).
4. Her party was called the" Bronckhorsters" and was led by Gijsbert V van Bronckhorst( 1328- 1356).
5. Upon victory of her party, the title of Duke of Guelders went to her son, William.
6. Marie was daughter of Reginald II, Duke of Guelders and Sophie Berthout, lady of Malines.
7. On December 25, 1362, she married William II, Duke of Jülich( † 1393).
8. They had three children:

chunks.title: Maarten van Rossum
chunks.chunk:
Title: Maarten van Rossum
0. Maarten van Rossum( c. 1478 – June 7, 1555) was a military tactician of the duchy of Guelders who became field marshal in the service of Charles, Duke of Guelders.
1. He was greatly feared outside his home country for the ruthless manner in which he waged war.
2. In a long career, he often put his motto Blaken en branden is het sieraad van de oorlogBurning and torching is the jewel of war") into practice.
3. His way of waging war was quite similar to that of his Italian colleagues, the condottieri, and was characterized by guerrilla- like tactics, in which the civilian population was spared even less than was usual in his time.
4. For thirty years he served the interests of the Dukes of Guelders in their struggle to safeguard the independence of the Duchy of Guelders against the Habsburg Netherlands of Charles V. Van Rossum had a number of military successes obtained through his use of ruses, daring and the indiscriminate destruction of civilian lives and property.
5. After the collapse of the Duchy of Guelders, he fought the last years of his life in the service of his old enemy Emperor Charles V against France.

chunks.title: Arnold, Duke of Guelders
chunks.chunk:
Title: Arnold, Duke of Guelders
0. Arnold of Egmond (14 July 1410 – 23 February 1473) was Duke of Guelders, Count of Zutphen.
1. Arnold was born in Egmond-Binnen, North Holland, the son of John II of Egmond and Maria van Arkel.
2. On 11 July 1423, Arnold, still a boy, succeeded Duke Reinald IV.
3. Arnold was the grandson of Reinald's sister, Johanna.
4. Although the Emperor Sigismund had invested the Duke of Berg with the duchy of Gelders, Arnold retained the confidence of the Estates by enlarging their privileges, and enjoyed the support of Duke Philip of Burgundy.
5. Arnold was betrothed, and afterwards united in marriage to Catherine of Cleves, a niece of Philip of Burgundy.
6. Subsequently, however, Duke Arnold fell out with his ally as to the succession to the see of Utrecht, whereupon Philip joined with the four chief towns of Guelders in the successful attempt of Arnold's son Adolf to substitute his own for his father's authority.
7. Arnold gave up his claim on Jűlich only after his defeat in 1444 by Gerhard VII, Duke of Jülich-Berg.
8. When Charles the Bold became Duke of Burgundy in 1467, after rejecting a compromise, Adolph was thrown into prison.
9. Arnold, against the will of the towns and the law of the land, pledged his duchy to Charles for 300,000 Rhenish florins (1471).
10. Upon Arnold's death two years later at Grave, Charles took possession of the duchy, starting a series of wars that would last more than 70 years.

supporting_facts.chunk: Catherine of Guelders was the fourth and youngest child of Arnold, Duke of Guelders (1410-1473) and Catherine of Cleves (1417–1479).<br

chunks.title: Miley Cyrus
chunks.chunk:
Title: Miley Cyrus
0. Miley Ray Hemsworth (née Cyrus, born Destiny Hope Cyrus; November 23, 1992) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and philanthropist.
1. Her music has spanned a range of styles, including pop, country pop, and hip hop.
2. Cyrus' personal life, public image, and
3. performances have often sparked controversy and received widespread media coverage.
4. She is widely considered to be one of the most successful entertainers in adulthood that originated as a child star.
5. Among numerous awards and nominations, Cyrus was included on the "Time" 100 list in both 2008 and 2014, named MTV's Artist of the Year in 2013, and was ranked 62nd on "Billboard"s Top 125 Artists of All Time list in 2019.

chunks.title: Place of birth
chunks.chunk:
Title: Place of birth
0. The place of birth( POB) or birthplace is the place where a person was born.
1. This place is often used in legal documents, together with name and date of birth, to uniquely identify a person.
2. As a general rule with respect to passports, the place of birth is determined to be the country that currently has" sovereignty" over the actual place of birth, regardless of when the birth actually occurred.
3. The place of birth is not necessarily the place where the parents of the new baby live.
4. If the baby is born in a hospital in another place, that place is the place of birth.
5. In many countries, this also means that the government requires that the birth of the new baby is registered in the place of birth.
6. Some countries place less or no importance on the place of birth, instead using alternative geographical characteristics for the purpose of identity documents.
7. For example, Sweden has used the concept of" födelsehemortdomicile of birth") since 1947.
8. This means that the domicile of the baby's mother is the registered place of birth.
9. The location of the maternity ward or other physical birthplace is considered unimportant.
10. Similarly, Switzerland uses the concept of" Heimatortlieu d'origineluogo d'origineplace of origin" in German, French and Italian respectively).
11. A child born to Swiss parents is automatically assigned the place of origin of the parent with the same last name, so the child either gets their mother's or father's place of origin.
12. A child born to one Swiss parent and one foreign parent acquires the place of origin of their Swiss parent.
13. In a Swiss passport and identity card, the holder's place of origin is stated, not their place of birth.
14. In some countries( primarily in the Americas), the place of birth automatically determines the nationality of the baby, a practice often referred to by the Latin phrase" jus soli".
15. Almost all countries outside the Americas instead attribute nationality based on the nationality( ies) of the baby's parents( referred to as" jus sanguinis").
16. There can be some confusion regarding the place of birth if the birth takes place in an unusual way: when babies are born on an airplane or at sea, difficulties can arise.
17. The place of birth of such a person depends on the law of the countries involved, which include the nationality of the plane or ship, the nationality( ies) of the parents and/ or the location of the plane or ship( if the birth occurs in the territorial waters or airspace of a country).
18. Some administrative forms may request the applicant's" country of birth".
19. It is important to determine from the requester whether the information requested refers to the applicant's" place of birth" or" nationality at birth".
20. For US citizens born abroad who under the US Constitution acquire US citizenship at the time of birth, the nationality at birth will be USA( American), while the place of birth would be the country in which the actual birth takes place.

0. Prince Michael Imeretinsky AFC ("Mikheil ImeretinskiMikhail Georgyevich Imeretinsky")
1. (27 January 1900 – 14 April 1975) was a British military officer of Georgian royal descent.
2. He belonged to the Bagrationi dynasty and directly descended from the Kings of Imereti.
3. Michael Imeretinsky was born to a Georgian father, "Serene Prince" George Imeretinsky (1872–1932), and a Russian mother, Lidya Nikolayevna Klimova (1880–1956), in St. Petersburg.
4. He descended from the royal dynasty of the western Georgian kingdom of Imereti, which had been conquered by the Russian Empire in 1810.
5. Like his elder brother, George, Michael Imeretinsky received his early education at the Lancing College in the United Kingdom and enlisted in the Royal Flying Corps as a sub-lieutenant in 1918.
6. He fought in both World War I and World War II, serving as a squadron commander of the Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve on the latter occasion.
7. He was decorated with the Air Force Cross.
8. After his retirement from the military, Imeretinsky lived in the United Kingdom and France.
9. He devoted himself to agriculture, being—as his obituary put it—"a prominent member of the Soil Association and a well-known horticulturist in France."
10. In 1975, he died, aged 75, in Nice, being the last direct male descendant of the kings of Imereti.
11. Prince Imeretinsky married Margaret Stella Wright (born 1899) in 1925.
12. They had three daughters:

chunks.title: Hermann Friedrich Graebe
chunks.chunk:
Title: Hermann Friedrich Graebe
0. Herman Friedrich Graebe or Gräbe,( June 19, 1900 – April 17, 1986) was a German manager and engineer in charge of a German building firm in Ukraine, who witnessed mass executions of the Jews of Dubno on October 5, 1942 by Nazis.
1. Following the war he wrote a famous and horrifying testimony.
2. Graebe gave the following eyewitness account:
3. My foreman and I went directly to the pits.
4. Nobody bothered us.
5. Now I heard rifle shots in quick succession from behind one of the earth mounds.
6. The people who had got off the trucks- men, women and children of all ages- had to undress upon the order of an SS man who carried a riding or dog whip.
7. They had to put down their clothes in fixed places, sorted according to shoes, top clothing and undergarments.
8. I saw heaps of shoes of about 800 to 1000 pairs, great piles of under -linen and clothing.
9. Without screaming or weeping these people undressed, stood around in family groups, kissed each other, said farewells, and waited for a sign from another SS man, who stood near the pit, also with a whip in his hand.
10. During the fifteen minutes I stood near, I heard no complaint or plea for mercy.
11. I watched a family of about eight persons, a man and a woman both of about fifty, with their children of about twenty to twenty- four, and two grown- up daughters about twenty- eight or twenty- nine.
12. An old woman with snow white hair was holding a one- year- old child in her arms and singing to it and tickling it.
13. The child was cooing with delight.
14. The parents were looking on with tears in their eyes.
15. The father was holding the hand of a boy about ten years old and speaking to him softly; the boy was fighting his tears.
16. The father pointed to the sky, stroked his head and seemed to explain something to him.
17. At that moment the SS man at the pit started shouting something to his comrade.
18. The latter counted off about twenty persons and instructed them to go behind the earth mound.
19. Among them was the family I have just mentioned.
20. I well remember a girl, slim with black hair, who, as she passed me, pointed to herself and said," twenty- three years old."
21. I walked around the mound and found myself confronted by a tremendous grave.
22. People were closely wedged together and lying on top of each other so that only their heads were visible.
23. Nearly all had blood running over their shoulders from their heads.
24. Some of the people shot were still moving.
25. Some were lifting their arms and turning their heads to show that they were still alive.
26. The pit was nearly two- thirds full.
27. I estimated that it already contained about a thousand people.
28. I looked for the man who did the shooting.
29. He was an SS man, who sat at the edge of the narrow end of the pit, his feet dangling into the pit.
30. He had a tommy- gun on his knees and was smoking a cigarette.
31. The people, completely naked, went down some steps which were cut in the clay wall of the pit and clambered over the heads of the people lying there to the place to which the SS man directed them.
32. They lay down in front of the dead or wounded people; some caressed those who were still alive and spoke to them in a low voice.
33. Then I heard a series of shots.
34. I looked into the pit and saw that the bodies were twitching or the heads lying already motionless on top of the bodies that lay beneath them.
35. Blood was running from their necks.
36. The next batch was approaching already.
37. They went down into the pit, lined themselves up against the previous victims and were shot.
38. He later provided vital testimony in the Einsatzgruppen Trial, one of the Subsequent Nuremberg Trials, invoking bitter persecution from many of his countrymen.
39. To escape the hostility, Graebe moved his family to San Francisco in 1948, where he lived until his death in 1986.
40. Hermann Graebe was honoured as a' Righteous Among the Nations' by Yad Vashem.
41. Another witness of the mass executions of October 1942 in Dubno was the German officer Axel von dem Bussche who, traumatised by what he had seen, in 1943 joined the German resistance around Claus von Stauffenberg and unsuccessfully tried to kill Adolf Hitler in a suicide attack in November 1943.

chunks.title: William Adam (architect)
chunks.chunk:
Title: William Adam (architect)
0. William Adam (1689 – 24 June 1748) was a Scottish architect, mason, and entrepreneur.
1. He was the foremost architect of his time in Scotland, designing and building numerous country houses and public buildings, and often acting as contractor as well as architect.
2. Among his best known works are Hopetoun House near Edinburgh, and Duff House in Banff.
3. His individual, exuberant style built on the Palladian style, but with Baroque details inspired by Vanbrugh and Continental architecture.
4. In the 18th century, Adam was considered Scotland's "Universal Architect".
5. However, since the early 20th century, architectural critics have taken a more measured view, Colin McWilliam, for instance, finding the quality of his work "varied to an extreme degree".
6. As well as being an architect, Adam was involved in several industrial ventures and improvement schemes, including coal mining, salt panning, stone quarries and mills.
7. In 1731 he began to build up his own estate in Kinross-shire, which he named Blair Adam.
8. He was the father of three architects; John, Robert and James, the last two were the developers of the "Adam style".

chunks.title: James Adam, Lord Adam
chunks.chunk:
Title: James Adam, Lord Adam
0. James Adam, Lord Adam( 31 October 1824–27 August 1914) was a Scottish judge and Senator of the College of Justice.

chunks.title: James Bede
chunks.chunk:
Title: James Bede
0. James Adam Bede( January 13, 1856 – April 11, 1942) was an American politician who served as U.S. Representative from Minnesota.

chunks.title: James Adam (architect)
chunks.chunk:
Title: James Adam (architect)
0. James Adam (21 July 1732 – 20 October 1794) was a Scottish architect and furniture designer, but was often overshadowed by his older brother and business partner, Robert Adam.
1. They were sons of architect William Adam.
2. In 1755 James worked on Gunsgreen House in the Berwickshire town of Eyemouth.
3. In 1758, Robert, James, and their younger brother William Adam started their business in London (living in Lower Grosvenor Street), focusing on designing complete schemes for the decoration and furnishing of houses.
4. Palladian design was popular, but Robert had evolved a new, more flexible style incorporating elements of classic Roman design alongside influences from Greek, Byzantine and Baroque styles.
5. The Adam brothers' success can also be attributed to a desire to design everything down to the smallest detail, ensuring a sense of unity in their designs.
6. He then followed in Robert's footsteps by undertaking the "Grand Tour", leaving in May 1760 to October 1763, when he arrive back in London.
7. James succeeded Robert as Architect of the King's Works in 1768 just before work on the brothers' Adelphi project (1768–1772) almost bankrupted the firm (the business employed other notable architects including Joseph Bonomi (1739–1808) who, from 1768, remained with the Adams until 1781).
8. From 1771–5 he was engaged with his brother in the design and building of Wedderburn Castle near Duns, Berwickshire.
9. James emerged from his brother's shadow after Robert's death in 1792, designing several notable buildings in Glasgow, including the old Infirmary (1792; demolished 1907), Assembly Rooms (1794; demolished in 1890) and the Tron Kirk (1794).
10. He also designed Portland Place in central London.
11. However, his glory was short-lived — he died at his home in London's Albermarle Street in October 1794.
12. During their lifetime Robert and James Adam published two volumes of their designs, "Works in Architecture of Robert and James Adam" (in 1773–1778 and 1779; a third volume was published posthumously, in 1822).

Title: Lady Katherine Percy

chunks.title: Edmund Tudor, 1st Earl of Richmond
chunks.chunk:
Title: Edmund Tudor, 1st Earl of Richmond
0. Edmund Tudor, 1st Earl of Richmond
1. (Welsh: "Edmwnd Tudur", 11 June 1430 – 3 November 1456, also known as Edmund of Hadham), was the father of King Henry VII of England and a member of the Tudor family of Penmynydd, North Wales.
2. Born to Owen Tudor and the dowager queen Catherine of Valois, Edmund was half-brother to Henry VI of England.
3. Edmund was raised for several years by Katherine de la Pole, and Henry took an interest in Edmund's upbringing, granting him a title and lands once he came of age.
4. Both Edmund and his brother, Jasper, were made advisers to the King as they were his remaining blood relatives.
5. The brothers were made the senior earls in the royal court and had influential positions in the Parliament of England.
6. Edmund was also granted Baynard's Castle, London and ran a successful estate.
7. He was married to Margaret Beaufort, Countess of Richmond and Derby, after her first marriage was annulled.
8. Prior to the start of the Wars of the Roses, Edmund liaised with Richard of York and supported him when the King fell ill during 1453 and 1454.
9. After war began in 1455, York sent Edmund to uphold the authority of the King in South Wales.
10. While he was there, York was overthrown by the King and in retaliation, Yorkist forces were sent to engage those of Tudor's in South Wales.
11. Edmund was captured at Carmarthen Castle, and died there of the bubonic plague on 3 November 1456.

chunks.title: Ae Dil Hai Mushkil

3. It also features cameo appearances by Shah Rukh Khan and Alia Bhatt.
4. The film was released on 28 October 2016 during the Diwali festival.
5. Made with a budget of , "Ae Dil Hai Mushkil" was commercially successful, grossing over worldwide.
6. It received mixed reviews, with criticism towards its direction, screenplay, dialogues and length, while Kapoor's performance and the soundtrack received praise.
7. The film became one of the highest-grossing Hindi films of 2016 and Kapoor's first commercial success since his 2013 romantic comedy film "Yeh Jawaani Hai Deewani".
8. It received seven nominations at the 62nd Filmfare Awards, including Best Director (Johar), Best Actor (Kapoor) and Best Actress for Sharma, winning four of them for its soundtrack.
9. The film is inspired by the lives of Kaushik Koppula and his friend with Ranbir Kapoor and Anushka Sharma reprising their roles while roles of Shah Rukh Khan and Aishwarya Rai were based on lives of his friend Kalyan and his love interest repestively.

chunks.chunk:
Title: Fernando Cortés
0. Fernando "Papi" Cortés (October 4, 1909 – 1979) was a Puerto Rican film actor, writer and director.
1. He was born in San Juan, Puerto Rico, but he spent most of his adult life in Mexico City, where he died.
2. On 1932, while in New York City, Fernando Cortés married Puerto Rican childhood friend María del Pilar Cordero, who adopted the stage name of Mapy Cortés.
3. The couple soon traveled to Spain with a Cuban theatrical troupe.
4. They worked on the Spanish stage, radio and film until the outbreak of the Civil War in 1936.
5. Fernando progressively began to take a backseat as actor and baritone and focused on promoting the career of his wife Mapy, who became a noted "vedette" (showgirl with star status) in Barcelona.
6. After the Spanish Civil War interrupted their careers, the couple worked in New York, San Juan, Buenos Aires, Havana and Caracas, occasionally starring in movies.
7. They arrived to Mexico City in late 1940 and made their stage debut at the Teatro Follies, in a show headlined by the popular Mexican comedian Cantinflas.
8. Despite early struggles to become household names, Mapy achieved Mexican film stardom in late 1941 and the couple settled in Mexico City.
9. Initially, Fernando Cortés played supporting roles in his wife's films.
10. He then made a successful debut as director with "La pícara Susana" (1945) a comedy vehicle for his wife.
11. On March 1954, Fernando and Mapy Cortés returned to Puerto Rico to help launch local television.
12. Cortés became the first director at WKAQ-TV, Channel 2, and the couple co-starred in "Mapy y Papi", the first Puerto Rican sitcom.
13. Despite their success on local TV, the couple returned the following year to Mexico City, which offered more opportunities.
14. The couple starred in a Mexican version of their Puerto Rican sitcom and Mapy returned to the stage.
15. Fernando Cortés became known as a reliable director of Mexican comedies on stage, television and film.
16. After writing and directing star vehicles for his wife Mapy in the 1940s and comedians like Resortes and Tin-Tan in the 1950s, Fernando Cortés produced and directed Puerto Rican co-productions in the 1960s and launched the film career of La India María in the 1970s.
