chunks.title: Björk
chunks.chunk:
Title: Björk
0. Björk Guðmundsdóttir (born 21 November 1965) is an Icelandic singer, songwriter, record producer, actress, and DJ.
1. Over her four-decade career, she has developed an eclectic musical style that draws on a range of influences and genres spanning electronic, pop, experimental, classical, trip hop, IDM, and avant-garde music.
2. Born and raised in Reykjavík, Björk began her music career at the age of 11 and first gained international recognition as the lead singer of the alternative rock band
3. The Sugarcubes, whose 1987 single "Birthday" was a hit on UK and US indie stations and a favourite among music critics.
4. After the band's breakup, Björk embarked on a solo career in 1993, coming to prominence as a solo artist with albums such as "Debut" (1993), "Post" (1995), and "Homogenic" (1997), while collaborating with a range of artists and exploring a variety of multimedia projects.
5. Several of Björk's albums have reached the top 20 on the US "Billboard" 200 chart, the most recent being "Vulnicura" (2015).
6. Björk’s fourth studio album, "Vespertine", was released in August 2001.
7. She has had 31 singles reach the top 40 on pop charts around the world, with 22 top 40 hits in the UK, including the top 10 hits
8. "It's Oh
9. So QuietArmy of Me", and "Hyperballad".
10. In 2004, Björk released her fifth studio album, "Medúlla", followed by her sixth studio album, "Volta", in May 2007.
11. Björk is reported to have sold between 20 and 40 million records worldwide .
12. She has won the 2010 Polar Music Prize from the Royal Swedish Academy of Music in recognition of her "deeply personal music and lyrics, her precise arrangements, and her unique voice.
13. "
14. Björk was included in "Time"'s 2015 list of the 100 most influential people in the world.
15. She was ranked both sixtieth and eighty-first in "Rolling Stone"
16. 's 100 greatest singers and songwriters lists respectively.
17. She has also won five BRIT Awards and has been nominated for 15 Grammy Awards.
18. Björk's ninth studio album, "Utopia", was released in November 2017 through One Little Indian Records.
19. Outside her music career, Björk starred in the 2000 Lars von Trier film "Dancer in the Dark", for which she won the Best Actress Award at the 2000 Cannes Film Festival, and was nominated for Academy Award for Best Original Song for
20. "I've Seen It All".
21. Her 2011 album "Biophilia" was marketed as an interactive app album with its own education program.
22. Björk has also been an advocate for environmental causes in her home country Iceland.
23. A full-scale retrospective exhibition dedicated to Björk was held at the New York Museum of Modern Art in 2015.

chunks.title: XXXTentacion
chunks.chunk:
Title: XXXTentacion
0. Jahseh Dwayne Ricardo Onfroy (January 23, 1998 – June 18, 2018), known professionally as XXXTentacion , was an American rapper, singer, songwriter and musician.
1. Although a controversial figure within the music industry, XXXTentacion has been regarded to have left behind "a huge musical footprint" due to his impact on his young fanbase and his popularity during his short career.
2. He was often credited by critics and fans for his musical-versatility, with his music primarily exploring trap, R&B, rock and emo.
3. Born in Plantation, Florida, XXXTentacion spent most of his childhood in Lauderhill.
4. He began writing music after being released from a juvenile detention center and started his music career on SoundCloud in 2013, where he soon became a popular figure in SoundCloud rap, a trap scene that takes elements of lo-fi music and harsh 808s.
5. XXXTentacion rose to mainstream fame with the single "Look at Me".
6. His debut album, "17" (2017), debuted at number two on the "Billboard" 200 and his second album,  (2018), debuted at number one on the "Billboard" 200.
7. Both albums have been certified Platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA).
8. In the week following his death, XXXTentacion's highest-charting single, "Sad!", went from number 52 to number one on the "Billboard" Hot 100, making him the first artist to top the "Billboard" Hot 100 posthumously since 1997.
9. On June 18, 2018, XXXTentacion was fatally shot at the age of 20, in a robbery at a motorcycle dealership in Deerfield Beach, Florida.
10. The attackers fled the scene in an SUV after stealing a Louis Vuitton bag containing $50,000 from him; four suspects were arrested and are currently awaiting trial.

1. The song premiered on December 30, 2015, on the SoundCloud account of Rojas, the song's co-producer, before initially being released for digital download as a single on January 29, 2016, becoming a sleeper hit in January 2017, in which the single was later re-released for digital download again with a remastered and clean version of the single on February 20, 2017, by Empire Distribution.
2. The song serves as the lead single from his debut commercial mixtape "Revenge".
3. The track was produced by Rojas and Jimmy Duval, and heavily samples the song "Changes" by British dubstep DJ and record producer Mala.
4. The song was met with critical acclaim due to its production and XXXTentacion's style of rapping, and peaked at number 34 on the US "Billboard" Hot 100.
5. It currently has 161.1 million plays since its addition on SoundCloud, as well as over 281 million views on YouTube.
6. "Look at Me" was certified Platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) on August 14, 2017, with over one million single-equivalent units.

1. On 8 November 1273, Anna married Andronikos II Palaiologos.
2. According to George Pachymeres, the couple had two children:
3. Anna died before her husband became senior emperor in 1282.
4. However every Palaiologos emperor to the Fall of Constantinople in 1453 descended from her through her son Michael.

1. Her husband would become the last Emperor of the Eastern Roman Empire.

chunks.title: Constantine Palaiologos (son of Andronikos II)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Constantine Palaiologos (son of Andronikos II)
0. Constantine Doukas Komnenos Palaiologos (1278/81–1334/35) was a Byzantine prince of the Palaiologos dynasty, who received the supreme title of Despot and served as provincial governor.
1. Constantine was the second son of Emperor Andronikos II Palaiologos (r. 1282–1328) and his first wife, Empress Anna of Hungary.
2. He was born sometime between 1278 and 1281.
3. As his father was already a reigning co-emperor alongside Michael VIII Palaiologos, he was styled a "porphyrogennetospurple-born"), as attested on his seals.
4. In 1294 he was named Despot, the highest court rank in the Byzantine Empire, on the occasion of his first marriage to Eudokia, the daughter of Theodore Mouzalon.
5. In 1305, he fought in the disastrous Battle of Apros against the Catalan Company.
6. In 1317, he intercepted his half-sister Simonida, the queen-consort of Serbia, who wished to retire to a monastery after the death of her mother, Irene of Montferrat, and handed her over to the Serbs.
7. At about this time he married a second time, again to a Eudokia, but both his marriages were childless.
8. He had one illegitimate son, Michael Katharos.
9. In 1319 he served as governor of Avlona, and in 1321–1322 as governor of Thessalonica.
10. It was in this position that the outbreak of the Byzantine civil war of 1321–1328 found him; in 1322 he was imprisoned by his nephew, Andronikos III Palaiologos, at Didymoteichon.
11. Constantine then became a monk, under the monastic name Kallistos.
12. He died in 1334/35.

Title: Miss Seventeen
0. Miss Seventeen is a reality television show on MTV that aired from October 17, 2005 to December 19, 2005.
1. The show consisted of 17 young women competing for an internship at and a college scholarship.
2. Atoosa Rubenstein was the main judge, she was the youngest editor-in-chief ever to run "Seventeen magazine".
3. They picked 17 girls from around the United States who were not only photogenic but also had been at the top of their class, to provide a role model for young women.
4. The girls were flown to New York, where they would take part in a contest similar in format to The Apprentice — they would be given tasks to be done by Atoosa, and in each episode one of the girls would be eliminated from the competition.
5. The winner would get her face on the cover of "Seventeen magazine", a college scholarship and would be offered an internship job on the magazine.
6. The criteria for elimination were not only performing poorly — Atoosa was watchful of how the girls talked when no one else was in the room, via cameras set up around the house.
7. In this manner, she could watch the girls with their guards down and see what their real motivations and dreams were.
8. In one elimination, for example, Atoosa sat down with the girl and explained that she didn't feel that the girl was in the contest for the 'right' reasons — video clips were shown to the viewers which showed the girl talking to her other roommates and explaining that she was more interested in the face-time she would get for being part of an MTV show.
9. Where the format differed from other shows was in the first elimination round and in how the contestants found out who was eliminated.
10. In the first episode, all 17 girls sat around the dinner table with Atoosa and had to describe in brief who they were and what they hoped they would get out of the experience.
11. Based on this conversation, Atoosa eliminated 7 of the girls from the contest.
12. The way the girls would generally find out who was eliminated was by sitting around a TV as Atoosa would talk to them, telling them the results of the tasks they were given.
13. The TV screen would then display the names of the girls who would be staying in the house, written in cursive form.
14. The girl whose name didn't appear on 'The List' was eliminated, and met with Atoosa to hear her reasoning for why she was eliminated.
15. In the final episode, Jennifer Steele was declared the winner, with her magazine cover unveiled in Times Square.
16. It was also revealed that Brianne Burrowes, who voluntarily left the show in an early episode of the series, was offered a job by Atoosa and will be working with Jennifer in their respective internships at the magazine.

chunks.title: Meritites I
chunks.chunk:
Title: Meritites I
0. Meritites
1. I was an ancient Egyptian queen of the 4th dynasty.
2. Her name means "Beloved of her Father".
3. Several of her titles are known from a stela found at Giza.
4. She was buried in the middle Queen’s Pyramid in Giza ("Pyramid G 1b").
5. Meritites was a daughter of King Sneferu and his consort of unknown name.
6. Meritites married her (half?)brother, King Khufu.
7. With Khufu, she was the mother of the Crown Prince Kawab, and possibly Djedefre.
8. Both Queen Hetepheres II and Pharaoh Khafra have been suggested as children of Meretites I and Khufu as well, and it is possible that Meritites II was a daughter of Meritites
9. I as well.
10. Auguste Mariette recorded a stela at Giza in which Meritites is said to be a favorite of both Sneferu and Khufu:
11. "King’s wife, his beloved, devoted to Horus, Mertitytes.
12. King’s wife, his beloved, Mertitytes; beloved of the Favorite of the Two Goddesses; she who says anything whatsoever and it is done for her.
13. Great in the favor of Snefr[u]; great in the favor of Khuf[u], devoted to Horus, honored under Khafre.
14. Merti[tyt]es."
15. [Breasted]
16. Meritites held the titles:
17. "great one of the hetes-sceptre of Khufuwrt-hetes-nt-khwfw"), great one of the "hetes"-sceptre of Snofru ("wrt-hetes-nt-snfrw"), king’s wife, his beloved ("hmt-nisw meryt.f"), attendant of Horus ("kht-hrw") and consort and beloved of the Two Ladiessm3yt-mry-nbty").

chunks.title: Sennedjem
chunks.chunk:
Title: Sennedjem
0. The Ancient Egyptian artisan Sennedjem lived in Set Maat( translated as" The Place of Truth"), contemporary Deir el- Medina, on the west bank of the Nile, opposite Thebes, during the reigns of Seti I and Ramesses II.
1. Sennedjem had the title" Servant in the Place of Truth".
2. He was buried along with his wife, Iyneferti, and family in a tomb in the village necropolis.
3. His tomb was discovered January 31, 1886.
4. When Sennedjem's tomb was found, in it there was regular furniture from his home, including a stool and a bed, which he actually used when he was alive.
5. His titles included Servant in the Place of Truth, meaning that he worked on the excavation and decoration of the nearby royal tombs.

chunks.title: Where Was I
chunks.chunk:
Title: Where Was I
0. " Where Was I?" may refer to:

chunks.title: Place of birth
chunks.chunk:
Title: Place of birth
0. The place of birth( POB) or birthplace is the place where a person was born.
1. This place is often used in legal documents, together with name and date of birth, to uniquely identify a person.
2. As a general rule with respect to passports, the place of birth is determined to be the country that currently has" sovereignty" over the actual place of birth, regardless of when the birth actually occurred.
3. The place of birth is not necessarily the place where the parents of the new baby live.
4. If the baby is born in a hospital in another place, that place is the place of birth.
5. In many countries, this also means that the government requires that the birth of the new baby is registered in the place of birth.
6. Some countries place less or no importance on the place of birth, instead using alternative geographical characteristics for the purpose of identity documents.
7. For example, Sweden has used the concept of" födelsehemortdomicile of birth") since 1947.
8. This means that the domicile of the baby's mother is the registered place of birth.
9. The location of the maternity ward or other physical birthplace is considered unimportant.
10. Similarly, Switzerland uses the concept of" Heimatortlieu d'origineluogo d'origineplace of origin" in German, French and Italian respectively).
11. A child born to Swiss parents is automatically assigned the place of origin of the parent with the same last name, so the child either gets their mother's or father's place of origin.
12. A child born to one Swiss parent and one foreign parent acquires the place of origin of their Swiss parent.
13. In a Swiss passport and identity card, the holder's place of origin is stated, not their place of birth.
14. In some countries( primarily in the Americas), the place of birth automatically determines the nationality of the baby, a practice often referred to by the Latin phrase" jus soli".
15. Almost all countries outside the Americas instead attribute nationality based on the nationality( ies) of the baby's parents( referred to as" jus sanguinis").
16. There can be some confusion regarding the place of birth if the birth takes place in an unusual way: when babies are born on an airplane or at sea, difficulties can arise.
17. The place of birth of such a person depends on the law of the countries involved, which include the nationality of the plane or ship, the nationality( ies) of the parents and/ or the location of the plane or ship( if the birth occurs in the territorial waters or airspace of a country).
18. Some administrative forms may request the applicant's" country of birth".
19. It is important to determine from the requester whether the information requested refers to the applicant's" place of birth" or" nationality at birth".
20. For US citizens born abroad who under the US Constitution acquire US citizenship at the time of birth, the nationality at birth will be USA( American), while the place of birth would be the country in which the actual birth takes place.

chunks.title: Khufu
chunks.chunk:
Title: Khufu
0. Khufu (full name Khnum Khufu , known to the ancient Greeks as Cheops, was an ancient Egyptian monarch who was the second pharaoh of the Fourth Dynasty, in the first half of the Old Kingdom period (26th century BC).
1. Khufu succeeded his father Sneferu as king.
2. He is generally accepted as having commissioned the Great Pyramid of Giza, one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, but many other aspects of his reign are poorly documented.
3. The only completely preserved portrait of the king is a three-inch high ivory figurine found in a temple ruin of a later period at Abydos in 1903.
4. All other reliefs and statues were found in fragments, and many buildings of Khufu are lost.
5. Everything known about Khufu comes from inscriptions in his necropolis at Giza and later documents.
6. For example, Khufu is the main character noted in the Westcar Papyrus from the 13th dynasty.
7. Most documents that mention king Khufu were written by ancient Egyptian and Greek historians around 300 BC.
8. Khufu's obituary is presented there in a conflicting way: while the king enjoyed a long-lasting cultural heritage preservation during the period of the Old Kingdom and the New Kingdom, the ancient historians Manetho, Diodorus and Herodotus hand down a very negative depiction of Khufu's character.
9. Thanks to these documents, an obscure and critical picture of Khufu's personality persists.

chunks.title: Meritites II
chunks.chunk:
Title: Meritites II
0. Meritites II( Merytiotes, Meritetes) or Meritites A(" beloved of her father") was a 4th dynasty Princess of Ancient Egypt, and probably a daughter of King Khufu.
1. She may have been a daughter of Meritites I based on the fact that this queen is mentioned in mastaba G 7650.
2. She married the Director of the Palace Akhethotep( a non-royal court official) and she had several children with her husband.
3. Meritites and her husband shared a mastaba( G 7650) in Giza.

chunks.title: Voi Voi
chunks.chunk:
Title: Voi Voi

1. Hey Hey", , a supposed Sami expression) was the Norwegian entry in the Eurovision Song Contest 1960, performed in Norwegian by Nora Brockstedt.
2. This was Norway's debut at the Eurovision Song Contest, and consequently the first occasion on which the Norwegian language was used at the Contest.
3. The title being in Sami was also the first use of the language in the Contest, the next entry being Sámiid Ædnan in 1980.
4. The song is in the "chanson" style popular in the early years of the Contest.
5. Brockstedt begins by telling her listeners that she once heard the song of a Sami girl in the north of the country, before repeating the lyrics of the song in question.
6. This song-within-a-song is a love ballad from the girl to her lover, telling him how much she looks forward to spending time with him on Saturday.
7. The song was performed sixth on the night, following Belgium's Fud Leclerc with "Mon amour pour toi" and preceding Austria's Harry Winter with "Du hast mich so fasziniert".
8. At the close of voting, it had received 11 points, placing 4th in a field of 13.
9. It was succeeded as Norwegian representative at the 1961 Contest by Brockstedt, this time with "Sommer i Palma".
10. Following the death of Georg Elgaaen in 2005, the royalties of the song goes to the Norwegian Humanist Association, of which he was a member.

chunks.title: Michael Curtiz
chunks.chunk:
Title: Michael Curtiz
0. Michael Curtiz (born Manó Kaminer(1886-1905)
1. Mihály Kertész (1905); December 24, 1886 April 11, 1962) was a Hungarian-born American film director, recognized as one of the most prolific directors in history.
2. He directed classic films from the silent era and numerous others during Hollywood's Golden Age, when the studio system was prevalent.
3. Curtiz was already a well-known director in Europe when Warner Bros. invited him to Hollywood in 1926, when he was 39 years of age.
4. He had already directed 64 films in Europe, and soon helped Warner Bros. become the fastest-growing movie studio.
5. He directed 102 films during his Hollywood career, mostly at Warners, where he directed ten actors to Oscar nominations.
6. James Cagney and Joan Crawford won their only Academy Awards under Curtiz's direction.
7. He put Doris Day and John Garfield on screen for the first time, and he made stars of Errol Flynn, Olivia de Havilland, and Bette Davis.
8. He himself was nominated five times and won twice, once for Best Short Subject for "Sons of Liberty" and once as Best Director for "Casablanca".
9. Curtiz introduced to Hollywood a unique visual style using artistic lighting, extensive and fluid camera movement, high crane shots, and unusual camera angles.
10. He was versatile and could handle any kind of picture: melodrama, comedy, love story, film noir, musical, war story, Western, or historical epic.
11. He always paid attention to the human-interest aspect of every story, stating that the "human and fundamental problems of real people" were the basis of all good drama.
12. Curtiz helped popularize the classic swashbuckler with films such as "Captain Blood" (1935) and "The Adventures of Robin Hood" (1938).
13. He directed many dramas which today are also considered classics, "Angels with Dirty Faces" (1938), "The Sea Wolf" (1941), "Casablanca" (1942), and "Mildred Pierce" (1945).
14. He directed leading musicals, including "Yankee Doodle Dandy" (1942), "
15. This Is the Army" (1943), and "White Christmas", and he made comedies with "Life With Father" (1947) and "We're No Angels" (1955).

5. In 2019, he co-produced and co-directed" Breslin and Hamill: Deadline Artists," a documentary about the columnists Jimmy Breslin and Pete Hamill, which is available on HBO.
6. Alter is the author of" The Defining Moment: FDR's Hundred Days and the Triumph of Hope", a national bestseller published by Simon& Schuster in 2006, and, a collection of twenty years' worth of his columns published by Borders Books.
7. His 2010 book is, published by Simon& Schuster, a behind- the- scenes look at Obama's eventful debut.
8. " The Promise" was a" New York Times" Best Seller, reaching# 3 on the list at its peak.
9. Alter's new book on President Obama," The Center Holds: Obama and His Enemies", was released on June 4, 2013.
10. " The Center Holds" debuted on the" New York Times" Best Sellers list on June 23, 2013.
11. A veteran of Chicago politics, Alter has known President Obama and his closest confidantes for as long as nearly any national columnist, having published the first national magazine cover story on Obama in" Newsweek's" 2004" Who's Next Issue."
12. Alter currently hosts a radio show with his children, one of whom is a writer for" Time" and one who is a producer for" The Nightly Show with Larry Wilmore" on SIRIUS channel 102 called" Alter Family Politics".
13. The show is part of Andy Cohen's new 24- hour network, Radio Andy.

5. Eberhard also participated in the alliance against the Electorate of Cologne and gained the independence of the County of Mark from the Archbishop of Cologne after the victory in the Battle of Worringen in 1288.

chunks.title: Bad Day at Black Rock
chunks.chunk:
Title: Bad Day at Black Rock
0. Bad Day at Black Rock is a 1955 American thriller film, directed by John Sturges and starring Spencer Tracy and Robert Ryan, that combines elements of the western genre with those of film noir.
1. The supporting cast includes Anne Francis, Dean Jagger, Walter Brennan, Lee Marvin, and Ernest Borgnine.
2. The film tells the story of a mysterious stranger who arrives at a tiny isolated town in a desert of the southwest United States in search of a man.
3. The film was adapted by Don McGuire and Millard Kaufman from the short story" Bad Time at Honda" by Howard Breslin.
4. The original story had appeared in" The American Magazine" in January 1947, with full- color illustrations by Robert Fawcett.
5. In 2018, the film was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry by the Library of Congress as being" culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant."

chunks.chunk:
Title: Millard Kaufman
0. Millard Kaufman( March 12, 1917 – March 14, 2009) was an American screenwriter and novelist.
1. His works include the Academy Award- nominated" Bad Day at Black Rock"( 1955).
2. He was also one of the creators of Mr. Magoo.

chunks.title: Conspiracy (2008 film)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Conspiracy (2008 film)
0. Conspiracy is a 2008 American action thriller film written and directed by Adam Marcus and stars Val Kilmer and Jennifer Esposito.
1. The film is influenced by the classic western film noir thriller" Bad Day at Black Rock"( 1955), which itself was an adaptation of a short story" Bad Time at Honda" by Howard Breslin.
2. The film was released on direct- to- DVD in the United States on March 18, 2008.
3. Whilst" Bad Day at Black Rock" tells the story of wounded World War II vet John J. MacReedy," Conspiracy" revolves around William" Spooky" MacPherson, a disabled special operations marine wounded during combat operations in Iraq.
4. When MacPherson decides to visit a friend on a ranch in the southwest, he discovers that his friend has disappeared, and no one will acknowledge that he ever lived there.
5. The film was shot in Galisteo, New Mexico in 30 days on April 19 and May 19, 2007.

0. John Eliot Sturges( January 3, 1910 – August 18, 1992) was an American film director.
1. His movies include" Bad Day at Black Rock"( 1955)," Gunfight at the O.K. Corral"( 1957)," The Magnificent Seven"( 1960)," The Great Escape"( 1963), and" Ice Station Zebra"( 1968).
2. In 2013," The Magnificent Seven" was selected for preservation in the United States National Film Registry by the Library of Congress as being" culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant".
3. He was not related to director Preston Sturges.

chunks.title: Joe D'Amato
chunks.chunk:
Title: Joe D'Amato
0. Aristide Massaccesi( 15 December 1936 – 23 January 1999), known professionally as Joe D'Amato, was an Italian film producer, director and cinematographer, who worked in many genres( westerns, decamerotici, peplum, war films, swashbuckler, comedy, fantasy, postapocalyptic film, and erotic thriller) but is best known for his horror, erotic and adult films.
1. D' Amato worked in the 1950s as electric and set photographer, in the 1960s as camera operator, and from 1969 onwards as cinematographer.
2. Starting in 1972, he directed and co-directed around 200 films under numerous pseudonyms, regularly acting as cinematographer as well.
3. Starting in the early 1980s, D'Amato produced many of his own and other directors' genre films through the companies he founded or co-founded, the best known being Filmirage.
4. From 1979 to 1982 and from 1993 to 1999, D'Amato also produced and directed about 120 adult films.
5. Among his best known erotic films are his five entries into the Black Emanuelle series of films starring Laura Gemser( 1976 – 1978) and his horror/ pornography crossover films" Erotic Nights of the Living Dead" and" Porno Holocaust"( both shot in Santo Domingo in 1979).
6. In the horror genre, he is above all remembered for his films" Beyond the Darkness"( 1979) and" Antropophagus"( 1980), which have gained cult status, as well as" Absurd"( 1981).

1. ( It: Un dollaro per 7 vigliacchi, Sp: El Millón de Madigan) is a 1968 Italian- Spanish comedy crime film directed by Stanley Prager and produced by Sidney W. Pink.
2. The movie was shot in 1966 but was not released for two years.
3. It stars Dustin Hoffman, in his first movie role, as Jason Fister, a young U.S. Treasury Dept. official sent to Rome to recover a large sum of money owed to the United States government by a deceased mobster.
4. The film is in the lowbrow comedy genre, with comic stop- action chase scenes, as well as many scenes involving spaghetti western- style gunplay on the streets of Rome.
5. Hoffman's Fister is a seemingly naive and mild- mannered bureaucrat with a sense for sniffing out phonies.
6. The interiors of the film were shot largely in Spain, with exteriors in Rome.

chunks.title: Paul L. Stein
chunks.chunk:
Title: Paul L. Stein
0. Paul Ludwig Stein( 4 February 1892 – 2 May 1951) was an Austrian- born film director with 67 films to his credit.
1. Stein began his career in Berlin in 1918 and worked exclusively in the German silent film industry until 1926, when he first went to Hollywood, and spent the next five years commuting between Germany and the U.S., where he worked with stars such as Jeanette MacDonald, Lillian Gish and Constance Bennett.
2. In 1931, Stein relocated to England after gaining a contract with British International Pictures, where he was assigned a number of big- name prestige productions, including some of the popular operetta films of the mid-1930s.
3. These included" Blossom Time" and" Heart's Desire" starring his boyhood friend Richard Tauber, who also made cameo appearances in two of his post-war films" Waltz Time" and" Lisbon Story".
4. For most his career, Stein's credits tended to be films primarily aimed at female audiences, although later he also directed crime and spy thrillers.
5. Stein remained in England for the rest of his life and career, becoming a British citizen in 1938.

chunks.title: Woody Guthrie
chunks.chunk:
Title: Woody Guthrie
0. Woodrow Wilson Guthrie (July 14, 1912 – October 3, 1967) was an American singer-songwriter, one of the most significant figures in American western folk music; his music, including songs, such as "
1. This Land Is Your Land", has inspired several generations both politically and musically.
2. He wrote hundreds of country, folk, and children's songs, along with ballads and improvised works.
3. His album of songs about the Dust Bowl period, "Dust Bowl Ballads", is included on "Mojo" magazine's list of 100 Records That Changed The World.
4. Many of his recorded songs are archived in the Library of Congress.
5. Songwriters such as Bob Dylan, Phil Ochs, Johnny Cash, Bruce Springsteen, Robert Hunter, Harry Chapin, John Mellencamp, Pete Seeger, Andy Irvine, Joe Strummer, Billy Bragg, Jerry Garcia, Jay Farrar, Bob Weir, Jeff Tweedy, Bob Childers, Sammy Walker, Tom Paxton, AJJ, Brian Fallon, and Sixto Rodríguez have acknowledged Guthrie as a major influence.
6. He frequently performed with the slogan "This machine kills fascists" displayed on his guitar.
7. Guthrie was brought up by middle-class parents in Okemah, Oklahoma, until he was 14, when his mother Mary was hospitalized as a consequence of Huntington's disease, a fatal hereditary neurological disorder.
8. His father moved to Pampa, Texas, to repay debts from unsuccessful real estate deals.
9. During his early teens, Guthrie learned folk and blues songs from his parents' friends.
10. He married at 19, but with the advent of the dust storms that marked the Dust Bowl period, he left his wife and three children to join the thousands of Okies who were migrating to California looking for employment.
11. He worked at Los Angeles radio station KFVD, achieving some fame from playing hillbilly music; made friends with Will Geer and John Steinbeck; and wrote a column for the communist newspaper "People's World" from May 1939 to January 1940.
12. Throughout his life, Guthrie was associated with United States communist groups, although he did not appear to belong to any.
13. With the outbreak of World War II and the non-aggression pact the Soviet Union had signed with Germany in 1939, the owners of KFVD radio were not comfortable with Guthrie's political leanings.
14. He left the station, ending up in New York where he wrote and recorded his 1940 album "Dust Bowl Ballads", based on his experiences during the 1930s, which earned him the nickname the "Dust Bowl Troubadour".
15. In February 1940 he wrote his most famous song, "
16. This Land Is Your Land".
17. He said it was a response to what he felt was the overplaying of Irving Berlin's "God Bless America" on the radio.
18. Guthrie was married three times and fathered eight children.
19. His son Arlo Guthrie became nationally known as a musician.
20. Guthrie died in 1967 from complications of Huntington's disease.
21. His first two daughters also died of the disease.
22. During his later years, in spite of his illness, Guthrie served as a figurehead in the folk movement, providing inspiration to a generation of new folk and country musicians, including mentoring Ramblin' Jack Elliott and Bob Dylan.

Title: Harald Kesja
0. Harald Kesja, "Harald the Spear", (1080–1135) was the son of Eric
1. I of Denmark and anti-king of Denmark.
2. He acted as regent 1103-1104 for his father while he was on pilgrimage to Jerusalem alongside Archbishop Asser of Lund.
3. As regent, he was courageous, but violent, cruel and debauched.
4. Harald plundered far and wide from his stronghold Haraldsborg at Roskilde, which greatly contributed to him not being elected king after his father died in 1103.
5. Instead, his uncle Niels of Denmark was elected king in 1104.
6. In 1132, he allied with his half-brother Eric Emune in order to avenge his third brother Canute Lavard, but he later turned to the murderer
7. Magnus I of Sweden because he had desires for the Danish throne himself.
8. He tried to gain recognition as king by the name of Harald IV and was successful in receiving the homage of Jutland, but he was defeated along with Magnus Nilsson at the Battle of Fotevik in Skåne, 1134.
9. He fled after the defeat but he was taken captive near Vejle on Jutland and decapitated together with eight of his sons.
10. Harald Kesja had married to Ragnild Magnusdotter, the daughter of King Magnus III of Norway.
11. They had four or six sons:

chunks.title: Olaf (II) Haraldsen
chunks.chunk:
Title: Olaf (II) Haraldsen
0. Olaf Haraldsen (died) was a Danish anti-king who ruled Scania for a few years from 1139.
1. He never won control over the rest of Denmark, and he is not included in the list of Danish monarchs used by the Danish monarchy or "Den Store Danske Encyklopædi".
2. He is sometimes called "Olaf II" even though there was a later Olaf II of Denmark.
3. He was the son of Harald Kesja and thus nephew of King Eric II of Denmark.
4. He seems to have been the only who escaped Eric II's murder of Harald and his sons in 1135.
5. After trying in vain to regain his heritage, Olaf proclaimed himself king in Scania in 1139, fighting his cousin King Eric III of Denmark.
6. The civil war mostly consisted of alternating raids, during which Olaf killed Bishop Rike of Roskilde, an act that saw him excommunicated by the Pope.
7. He was at last defeated by Eric III and was killed in a battle in Middle Scania around 1143.
8. Harald Skrænk, the leader of a peasant rebellion in Scania about 1182, is said to have been Olaf's illegitimate son, but their connection is unsure.

3. Engilbert is mentioned only sporadically in the sources: in 1297, when he accompanied Princess Isabella of Villehardouin to Nesi near Kalamata; in 1301 among the Moreote barons who ratified the proclamation of Philip of Savoy as Prince; in early 1304 as one of the witnesses to the marriage of John I Orsini to Maria Komnene Doukaina, and in the act of donation of the fortresses of Karytaina and Araklovon to Isabella's daughter Matilda of Hainaut; and finally in an act of December 1305 signed at Thebes.

chunks.title: Matilda of Hainaut
chunks.chunk:
Title: Matilda of Hainaut
0. Matilda of Hainaut( 29 November 1293 – 1331) was the Princess of Achaea from 1313 to 1318.
1. She was the daughter of Isabella of Villehardouin and her husband Florent of Hainaut.
2. In 1299, while still a child, she had been married to Guy II de la Roche, Duke of Athens.
3. Widowed in 1308, she was engaged to Charles of Taranto until 1313, when she remarried to Louis of Burgundy, who held the titular dignity of the long- extinct Kingdom of Thessalonica.
4. The marriage was intended to unite the Angevin and Burgundian houses.
5. So was the betrothal of the Empress Catherine II to Hugh V of Burgundy, Louis's elder brother.
6. However, Charles of Valois, Catherine's father, nixed the marriage and instead married her to Philip of Taranto.
7. It was in an effort to compensate the Burgundians that Philip renounced his claim to Achaea in favour of Matilda and gave her hand to Louis.
8. From 1307, when Philip of Savoy relinquished his claim, to 1312, when Isabella of Villehardouin died, Achaea was disputed between two claimants: Isabella and Philip I of Taranto.
9. In 1313, Philip granted it to Matilda, daughter of Isabella and her first husband Florent of Hainaut.
10. On Isabella's death, however, Ferdinand of Majorca laid claim to the principality in right of his wife, Isabella of Sabran, the daughter of Isabella's younger sister Margaret of Villehardouin.
11. The new couple quickly left for Greece to take possession of their fief, which was then occupied by their rival Ferdinand.
12. At the Battle of Manolada on 5 July 1316, Ferdinand was vanquished and killed and Louis took control of the Elis.
13. However, he was poisoned soon after, leaving a twice- widowed 23- year- old in charge of the Morea.
14. It was soon disputed by the varying claimants and Matilda was solidly dispossessed of her fief by 1318, in which year John, Duke of Durazzo, an Angevin, abducted the princess and forced her to marry him.
15. She did not give him children, however, and he repudiated her in 1321.
16. Matilda married yet again to Hugh de La Palice and retired to Aversa, where she died in 1331.

chunks.title: Helena Angelina Komnene
chunks.chunk:
Title: Helena Angelina Komnene
0. Helena Angelina Komnene  was a daughter of the Greek "sebastokrator" John I Doukas, ruler of Thessaly in ca. 1268–1289, and a Greek princess of Aromanian Greek origin, known only by her monastic name, Hypomone.
1. In 1275, the Byzantine Emperor Michael VIII Palaiologos sent a large army to subdue her recalcitrant father.
2. The Byzantine army besieged John's capital of Neopatras, but he managed to flee and seek the aid of the Duke of Athens, John I de la Roche (r. 1263–1280).
3. John I gave the necessary aid to the "sebastokrator", in exchange for the marriage of Helena to his brother, William I de la Roche, the future Duke of Athens (r. 1280–1287).
4. The Duchy also acquired the towns of Siderokastron, Zeitounion, Gravia, and Gardiki as her dowry.
5. The couple had a son, Guy II de la Roche (r. 1287–1308).
6. Following William's death, Helena served as regent for her underage son until his coming of age.
7. In 1289, she refused to recognize the suzerainty of the new Prince of Achaea, Florent of Hainaut, and the Angevin King of Naples, Charles II, as the common liege-lord of all Frankish states in Greece, had to force her to submit.
8. In 1291 she married Hugh of Brienne, Count of Lecce, who became the "bailli" of the Athenian duchy.
9. This allowed Helena once again to challenge Achaen suzerainty, and insist on her right to do homage directly to the King of Naples.
10. Charles II vacillated, but in the end Florent of Hainaut prevailed, and when Guy II of Athens came of age in 1296, he recognized Florent and his wife, Isabella of Villehardouin, as his liege-lords.

chunks.title: Florent of Hainaut
chunks.chunk:
Title: Florent of Hainaut
0. Florent of Hainaut (also "Floris" or "Florence"; Hainaut, also spelled "Hainault")
1. (c. 1255 – 23 January 1297) was Prince of Achaea from 1289 to his death, in right of his wife, Isabella of Villehardouin.
2. He was the son of John I of Avesnes and Adelaide of Holland.
3. From his father he received the stadholdership (government) of Zeeland.
4. After he left Zeeland, he took up service with Charles II of Naples, who made him constable of the Kingdom of Naples.
5. After his marriage with Isabella (16 September 1289), he had one daughter: Matilda.
6. She would succeed him and her mother as princess.
7. Florent settled with his wife in Morea.
8. He negotiated the Treaty of Glarentsa with the Byzantine Empire in 1290.
9. The situation for the Franks in Greece was hopeless by this time, however.
10. The fall of the Angevins in Sicily meant that they were preoccupied with recouping territory there and few Western governments would send troops to defend Morea.
11. Florent thus made peace and maintained it until 1293, when the Greeks retook Kalamata.
12. Florent did not despair and did not reopen the war which had been ongoing until his succession: he instead sent an embassy in protest to Andronikos II Palaiologos, and the emperor returned Kalamata.
13. In 1296, the Greeks retook the castle of Saint George in Arcadia.
14. Florent besieged the castle, but died before it could be taken.

0. Adelaide of Holland (– buried 9 April 1284), Countess of Hainaut, was a Dutch regent.
1. She was a daughter of Floris IV, Count of Holland and Matilda of Brabant.

chunks.chunk:
Title: The Devil's Pass Key
0. The Devil's Pass Key( or The Devil's Passkey) was a 1920 silent drama film directed by Erich von Stroheim.
1. The film was produced by Universal Pictures and distributed under their" Jewel" banner.
2. The film was von Stroheim's second directorial effort, and considered one of the best screen exhibitions of August 1920, with" The New York Times" later calling it" One of the best photodramatic productions of the year".
3. The production was shot from September 1919 through December 1919 and premiered on 8 August 1920 at the Capitol Theatre in New York City, New York.

chunks.title: Mario Missiroli
chunks.chunk:
Title: Mario Missiroli
0. Mario Missiroli( 13 March 1934 – 19 May 2014) was an Italian stage, television and film director.
1. Born in Bergamo, at a young age Missiroli moved to Milan with his family.
2. Later. he graduated in direction from the Accademia d' Arte Drammatica in Rome.
3. In the 1950s Missiroli worked at the Piccolo Teatro in Milan as assistant director of Giorgio Strehler and in cinema he debuted as assistant director of Valerio Zurlini.
4. In 1963 he directed his first and only film," La bella di Lodi", based on a novel by Alberto Arbasino and starring Stefania Sandrelli.
5. In later years Missiroli focused his activities on theatre, in which he was regarded as having been one of the most innovative and nonconformist directors as well as being one of the fathers of Italian modern theatre.
6. From 1976 to 1985 he was director of the Teatro Stabile di Torino.
7. He was also active as a television director, mainly of literary adaptations.

chunks.title: Erich von Stroheim
chunks.chunk:
Title: Erich von Stroheim
0. Erich Oswald Hans Carl Maria von Stroheim( born Erich Oswald Stroheim; September 22, 1885 – May 12, 1957) was an Austrian- American director, actor and producer, most noted as a film star and avant garde, visionary director of the silent era.
1. His masterpiece adaptation of Frank Norris's" McTeague" titled" Greed" is considered one of the finest and most important films ever made.
2. After clashes with Hollywood studio bosses over budget and workers' rights issues, Stroheim was banned for life as a director and subsequently became a well- respected character actor, particularly in French cinema.
3. For his early innovations as a director, Stroheim is still celebrated as one of the first of the auteur directors.
4. He helped introduce more sophisticated plots and noirish sexual and psychological undercurrents into cinema.
5. He died in 1957 in France of prostate cancer at the age of 71.
6. Beloved by Parisian neo-Surrealists known as Letterists, he was honored by Letterist Maurice Lemaitre with a 70- minute 1979 film entitled" Erich von Stroheim."

question: Where did the composer of film Henry V (1944 Film) die?

chunks.title: William Walton
chunks.chunk:
Title: William Walton
0. Sir William Turner Walton, OM (29 March 19028 March 1983) was an English composer.
1. During a 60 year career, he wrote music in several classical genres and styles, from film scores to opera.
2. His best-known works include "Façade", the cantata "Belshazzar's Feast", the Viola Concerto, the First Symphony, and the British coronation anthems "Crown Imperial" and "Orb and Sceptre".
3. Born in Oldham, Lancashire, the son of a musician, Walton was a chorister and then an undergraduate at Christ Church, Oxford.
4. On leaving the university, he was taken up by the literary Sitwell siblings, who provided him with a home and a cultural education.
5. His earliest work of note was a collaboration with Edith Sitwell, "Façade", which at first brought him notoriety as a modernist, but later became a popular ballet score.
6. In middle age, Walton left Britain and set up home with his young wife Susana on the Italian island of Ischia.
7. By this time, he had ceased to be regarded as a modernist, and some of his compositions of the 1950s were criticised as old-fashioned.
8. His only full-length opera, "Troilus and Cressida", was among the works to be so labelled and has made little impact in opera houses.
9. In his last years, his works came back into critical fashion; his later compositions, dismissed by critics at the time of their premieres, were revalued and regarded alongside his earlier works.
10. Walton was a slow worker, painstakingly perfectionist, and his complete body of work across his long career is not large.
11. His most popular compositions continue to be frequently performed in the 21st century, and by 2010 almost all his works had been released on CD.

chunks.title: Henry V (1944 film)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Henry V (1944 film)
0. Henry V is a 1944 British Technicolor film adaptation of William Shakespeare's play of the same name.
1. The on-screen title is The Chronicle History of King Henry the Fift with His Battell Fought at Agincourt in France (derived from the title of the 1600 quarto edition of the play, though changing the spelling from "Agin Court").
2. It stars Laurence Olivier, who also directed.
3. The play was adapted for the screen by Olivier, Dallas Bower, and Alan Dent.
4. The score is by William Walton.
5. The film was made near the end of World War II and was intended as a morale booster for Britain.
6. Consequently, it was partly funded by the British government.
7. The film was originally "dedicated to the ‘Commandos and Airborne Troops of Great Britain the spirit of whose ancestors it has been humbly attempted to recapture.’
8. "
9. The film won Olivier an Academy Honorary Award for "his Outstanding achievement as actor, producer and director in bringing Henry V to the screen."

chunks.title: Elmer Clifton
chunks.chunk:
Title: Elmer Clifton
0. Elmer Clifton( March 14, 1890 – October 15, 1949) was an American writer, director and actor from the early silent days.
1. A collaborator of D.W. Griffith, he appeared in" The Birth of a Nation"( 1915) and" Intolerance"( 1916) before giving up acting in 1917 to concentrate on work behind the camera, with Griffith and Joseph Henabery as his mentors.
2. His first feature- length solo effort as a director was" The Flame of Youth" with Jack Mulhall.
3. Clifton honed his talents during the late 1910s, directing vehicles for Mulhall and Herbert Rawlinson at Universal and then for Dorothy Gish for Famous Players- Lasky.
4. Two of his projects with Gish," Nobody Home" and" Nugget Nell", featured performances from pre-stardom Rudolph Valentino.
5. Most of this early output has been lost.
6. He was the first filmmaker to discover the talents of Clara Bow, whom he cast in" Down to the Sea in Ships", released on March 4, 1923.
7. The independently produced film was well reviewed for its visual authenticity.
8. During the 1920s, Clifton directed films for several different studios.
9. During the filming of" The Warrens of Virginia"( 1924) for Fox Film Corporation, lead actress Martha Mansfield suffered a fatal accident from burns when her costume caught fire.
10. Clifton directed" The Wreck of the Hesperus" for Cecil B. deMille's production company, and filmed on location in the Grand Canyon for" The Bride of the Colorado".
11. He also directed some Technicolor short films, including" Manchu Love" with an all- Asian cast.
12. In the sound era, Clifton wrote and directed many poverty row Westerns and" exploitation" classics, among them the anti-marijuana polemic" Assassin of Youth"( 1937).
13. He also directed the vice films" Gambling with Souls"( 1936)," Slaves in Bondage"( 1937) and" City of Missing Girls"( 1941), all of which portrayed addiction and white slavery to some degree.
14. His last film was" Not Wanted"( 1949), which was finished by producer Ida Lupino when Clifton became ill and was unable to work anymore.
15. He died in 1949 of a cerebral hemorrhage shortly after the film's release.

chunks.title: Namie Amuro
chunks.chunk:
Title: Namie Amuro
0. Born in Naha, Okinawa, Japan, Amuro debuted as the lead singer of the idol group Super Monkey's when she was 14 years old.
1. Despite early sales disappointments, she ventured into modeling and acting, attracting domestic attention with the group's best-selling single
2. "Try Me (Watashi o Shinjite)".
3. She signed to Avex Trax in 1995 and debuted as a solo artist with the single "Body Feels Exit".
4. Her 1996 studio album, "Sweet 19 Blues," sold over 3 million copies, setting the record at the time for the biggest selling album by a female artist in Japan and the highest selling album debut in the world (currently ranked #15 in the world's largest first week album sales).
5. One of the singles from her album "Concentration 20" (1997), "Can You Celebrate?", is the best-selling single by a solo female artist in Japanese music history.
6. From 1999, Amuro partnered with international musicians and producers on her records, beginning with "Genius 2000" (2000).
7. In the early 2000s, Amuro's music evolved from pop to R&B, and Amuro saw a decline in sales.
8. "Play" (2007), her eighth studio album, heralded a period of commercial resurgence.
9. She continued to experiment musically, moving to electronic dance music and English language songs with follow-up records "Uncontrolled" (2012) and "Feel" (2013).
10. She subsequently released her eleventh studio album, "Genic" (2015) and a compilation album, "Finally" (2017).
11. Amuro is noted within the Japanese entertainment industry, and the wider Western music industry, for "producing" and managing her own career.
12. Aside from music, she has appeared in various advertisement campaigns in Japan and founded her own management company, Stella88, and her own record label, Dimension Point.
13. Having sold more than 36 million records in Japan, Amuro is recognized as one of the best-selling artists in Japan by Oricon.
14. Since her solo debut, she has top 10 singles for 23 consecutive years (#1 for solo artist).
15. All of her albums are at least certified Platinum, and her debut solo album, "Sweet 19 Blues", was the best selling album in Japan.
16. She is the only artist in Japan selling million albums in her teens, 20s, 30s and 40s.
17. Furthermore, her last album, "Finally", topped the Year-End album charts of both Oricon and Billboard Japan for two consecutive years (The first and only artist in the Japanese Music Industry to do so).
18. Amuro has frequently been noted for her live performances at music award ceremonies and she is the recipient of World Music Awards, Japan Record Awards, Japan Gold Disc Awards, and MTV Video Music Awards Japan among many others.
19. On September 16, 2018, Amuro officially retired from the music and entertainment business.

chunks.title: Place of birth
chunks.chunk:
Title: Place of birth
0. The place of birth( POB) or birthplace is the place where a person was born.
1. This place is often used in legal documents, together with name and date of birth, to uniquely identify a person.
2. As a general rule with respect to passports, the place of birth is determined to be the country that currently has" sovereignty" over the actual place of birth, regardless of when the birth actually occurred.
3. The place of birth is not necessarily the place where the parents of the new baby live.
4. If the baby is born in a hospital in another place, that place is the place of birth.
5. In many countries, this also means that the government requires that the birth of the new baby is registered in the place of birth.
6. Some countries place less or no importance on the place of birth, instead using alternative geographical characteristics for the purpose of identity documents.
7. For example, Sweden has used the concept of" födelsehemortdomicile of birth") since 1947.
8. This means that the domicile of the baby's mother is the registered place of birth.
9. The location of the maternity ward or other physical birthplace is considered unimportant.
10. Similarly, Switzerland uses the concept of" Heimatortlieu d'origineluogo d'origineplace of origin" in German, French and Italian respectively).
11. A child born to Swiss parents is automatically assigned the place of origin of the parent with the same last name, so the child either gets their mother's or father's place of origin.
12. A child born to one Swiss parent and one foreign parent acquires the place of origin of their Swiss parent.
13. In a Swiss passport and identity card, the holder's place of origin is stated, not their place of birth.
14. In some countries( primarily in the Americas), the place of birth automatically determines the nationality of the baby, a practice often referred to by the Latin phrase" jus soli".
15. Almost all countries outside the Americas instead attribute nationality based on the nationality( ies) of the baby's parents( referred to as" jus sanguinis").
16. There can be some confusion regarding the place of birth if the birth takes place in an unusual way: when babies are born on an airplane or at sea, difficulties can arise.
17. The place of birth of such a person depends on the law of the countries involved, which include the nationality of the plane or ship, the nationality( ies) of the parents and/ or the location of the plane or ship( if the birth occurs in the territorial waters or airspace of a country).
18. Some administrative forms may request the applicant's" country of birth".
19. It is important to determine from the requester whether the information requested refers to the applicant's" place of birth" or" nationality at birth".
20. For US citizens born abroad who under the US Constitution acquire US citizenship at the time of birth, the nationality at birth will be USA( American), while the place of birth would be the country in which the actual birth takes place.

chunks.title: Sennedjem

Title: Sennedjem
0. The Ancient Egyptian artisan Sennedjem lived in Set Maat( translated as" The Place of Truth"), contemporary Deir el- Medina, on the west bank of the Nile, opposite Thebes, during the reigns of Seti I and Ramesses II.
1. Sennedjem had the title" Servant in the Place of Truth".
2. He was buried along with his wife, Iyneferti, and family in a tomb in the village necropolis.
3. His tomb was discovered January 31, 1886.
4. When Sennedjem's tomb was found, in it there was regular furniture from his home, including a stool and a bed, which he actually used when he was alive.
5. His titles included Servant in the Place of Truth, meaning that he worked on the excavation and decoration of the nearby royal tombs.

chunks.title: Afif Abdul Wahab
chunks.chunk:
Title: Afif Abdul Wahab
0. Afif Abdul Wahab( 1915–2003) was a Lebanese doctor, general surgeon and urologist, businessman and philanthropist, born and raised in El Mina.
1. After receiving his Medical Doctorate from the American University of Beirut in 1941, he opened up a hospital in his hometown of El- Mina in 1946 in partnership with Dr. Joseph Yamine and Dr. Richard Jebara, for a short period before moving to Saudi Arabia in 1949.
2. Again with Drs Yamine and Jebara, Abdul Wahab opened up the first Arab- owned hospital in Jeddah, The Lebanese Hospital in Jeddah, and was one of the first medical doctors to live and work in Saudi Arabia.
3. In 1953 Abdul Wahab received the Saudi Citizenship from King Saud Bin Abdul Aziz, In 1962 all three partners opened another hospital in the eastern province of Saudi Arabia, Ash- Sharq Hospital which was a medical contractor for ARAMCO.
4. Abdul Wahab, along with Dr. Yamine received the National Cedars Medal from Lebanese president Suleiman Frangieh, which is the highest honor given to a Lebanese citizen.
5. He died in January 2003, aged 87.

chunks.title: Abdul Wahab Khan
chunks.chunk:
Title: Abdul Wahab Khan
0. Abdul Wahab Khan was the 3rd speaker of the National Assembly of Pakistan.
1. He was preceded and succeeded by Maulvi Tamizuddin Khan.
2. He was born into a middle- class Muslim family in East Pakistan.
3. In later years, he became a Bengali Nationalist.
4. He is the grandfather of Salman Khan, founder of the Khan Academy.

chunks.title: Abdullah Khan Tarzi
chunks.chunk:
Title: Abdullah Khan Tarzi
0. Sardar Abdullah Khan Tarzi"( died 1970)" was a twentieth century Afghan Statesman from Kandahar province in Afghanistan.
1. As a country" elder," he participated in the national Loya Jirga( loya means" great" or" grand" and jirga means" council" or" assembly"), specifically the one in 1964 that was called by Mohammed Zahir Shah, which acted as a constitutional convention.
2. In and out of office, he was always a key decision maker, as he was a tribal and Pashtun leader in southern Afghanistan.
3. Abdullah Khan Tarzi was a soldier in the Third Anglo- Afghan War in 1919, which led to Afghan independence from the British.
4. He would fight in that war for over two years.
5. This led to his first role in Afghan politics, as Abdullah Khan Tarzi would become mayor of Kandahar at the age of 18 years.
6. He would rise from being the Mayor of the city to representative of Kandahar province in the Wolesi Jirga, the lower house of the Afghan parliament.
7. After one term, he then took the position of being the governor of the province.
8. Soon after, Abdullah Khan Tarzi reached the Afghan Senate, known as the House of Elders, representing Kandahar province for two terms, he was the leader of the Senate during his final two years.
9. Abdullah Khan Tarzi was one of the few members of the Tarzi's family, since Ghulam Muhammad Tarzi to lead within Afghanistan; traditionally, most notable Tarzi's have served Afghanistan on the international stage.
10. Abdullah Khan Tarzi died in 1970, leaving behind his wife, four sons and three daughters.

chunks.title: Habibullah Khan Tarzi
chunks.chunk:
Title: Habibullah Khan Tarzi
0. Ambassador Habibullah Khan Tarzi( born 1896) was head of the Afghan Delegation to Paris from 1923 to 1924.
1. He served in that post to increase diplomatic/ economic relations between France and Afghanistan.
2. Tarzi would go on to play critical roles in the Afghan foreign affairs as the Temporary Representative to France from 1928 to 1929, and Japan from 1933 to 1939.
3. Habibullah Khan Tarzi became the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs for Afghanistan from 1932 to 1933.
4. He took a few years off after that, however, and stayed with his family.
5. It was not until 1946, when he was named as a Temporary Representative to China, that Habibullah Khan Tarzi would return to international politics.
6. After less than a year in China, he would present his credentials to President Harry S. Truman as Afghanistan's Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary to the United States of America.
7. After developing a very friendly relationship with President Truman, Habibullah Khan Tarzi would stay at that post in Washington, D.C. from 1946 to 1953.
8. Shortly after President Dwight D. Eisenhower came to office, Habibullah Khan Tarzi left the United States and returned to Kabul.
9. Habibullah Khan Tarzi and his wife Shahira Begum Tarzi had four sons along with three daughters.

chunks.title: Samuel Arthur Saunder
chunks.chunk:
Title: Samuel Arthur Saunder
0. Samuel Arthur Saunder (1852 – December 8, 1912) was a British mathematician and selenographer who taught at Wellington College, Berkshire.
1. In 1894 he became a fellow of the Royal Astronomical Society, and in 1908 he was made Gresham Professor of Astronomy giving public lectures on the subject.
2. Saunder was one of the first to use photography of the Moon to measure and triangulate its features.

Prior to his accession in 1944, Osmeña served as Governor of Cebu from 1906 to 1907, Member and first Speaker of the Philippine House of Representatives from 1907 to 1922, and Senator from the 10th Senatorial District for thirteen years, in which capacity he served as Senate President pro tempore.

7. The duo were overwhelmingly re-elected in 1941.
8. He was the patriarch of the prominent Osmeña family, which includes his son, former Senator Sergio Osmeña Jr., and his grandsons, senators Sergio Osmeña III and John Henry Osmeña, ex-governor Lito Osmeña and Cebu City mayor Tomas Osmeña.

chunks.title: John Ramon III, Count of Cardona
chunks.chunk:
Title: John Ramon III, Count of Cardona
0. John Ramon III Folch de Cardona i de Prades, (9 January 1418 – 1485), was a Catalan nobleman.
1. John Ramon's titles included Count of Prades, Count of Cardona, Viscount of Vilamur, Baron of Entenza, Admiral of Aragon, Captain-general of Catalonia as well as Viceroy of Sicily from 1477-79.
2. His parents were John Ramon II, 3rd Count of Cardona (14 June 14001471) and Joana de Prades, heiress of Prades and Entenza.
3. John Ramon III became the sixth count of Prades and viscount of Vilamur upon the resignation of his father in 1445.
4. Upon the death of his father in 1471, he inherited the County of Cardona.
=
5. Biography=
6. John Ramon III was ambassador to the pope for Alfonso V of Aragon and actively participated in the Cortes from 1449 to 1455.
7. Shortly before beginning of the Catalan Civil War, John Ramon joined King John II of Aragon's army and was made Captain-General.
8. For his service he was awarded the Sicilian town of Alì Terme in 1463.
9. After the Catalan war, John Ramon accompanied Ferran, Prince of Girona to the campaign of Roussillon.
10. He went on to fight against French troops in the Ampurdan area at battle of Besós.
11. As Viceroy of Sicily (1477-79), John Ramon moved to Italy accompanied by the infanta Joana, where he repressed the revolt of Leonard de Alagon and Arborea in Sardinia.
12. In 1479, John Ramon returned to Catalonia and was the trusted advisor of the new king Ferdinand II of Aragon, whom he counseled for years.
13. In 1484 the king entrusted him as Captain-general of the campaigns against the count of Pallars and against the serfs of Pere Joan Sala.
14. John Ramon III died in 1485.

chunks.title: Thomas Hanbury-Tracy, 2nd Baron Sudeley
chunks.chunk:
Title: Thomas Hanbury-Tracy, 2nd Baron Sudeley
0. Thomas Charles Hanbury-Tracy, 2nd Baron Sudeley (5 February 1801 – 19 February 1863), known as Thomas Leigh between 1806 and 1838 and styled The Honourable Thomas Leigh between 1838 and 1839 and The Honourable Thomas Hanbury-Tracy between 1839 and 1858, was a British colliery owner and politician.
1. Hanbury-Tracy was the son of Charles Hanbury-Tracy, 1st Baron Sudeley, and the Honourable Henrietta Susanna Tracy, daughter of Henry Tracy, 8th Viscount Tracy.
2. The Hanbury family derived its wealth from its ownership of the Pontypool Ironworks.
3. In 1806 he assumed by Royal licence the surname of Leigh in lieu of his patronymic.
4. However, in 1839 he discontinued the use of this surname and resumed by Royal licence his original surname of Hanbury-Tracy.
5. He was returned to Parliament for Wallingford in 1831, a seat he held until 1832.
6. On 10 February 1852, his father appointed him a deputy lieutenant of Montgomeryshire.
7. He succeeded his father in the barony in 1858 and also succeeded him as Lord Lieutenant of Montgomeryshire, which he remained until his death five years later.
8. Lord Sudeley married Emma Elizabeth Alicia Pennant, daughter of George Hay Dawkins-Pennant, in 1831.
9. Lord Sudeley died in February 1863, aged 62, and was succeeded in the barony by his son, Sudeley.
10. Lady Sudeley died in July 1888.

1. Hanbury-Tracy was the son of Thomas Hanbury-Tracy, 2nd Baron Sudeley, and Emma Elizabeth Alicia Pennant, daughter of George Hay Dawkins-Pennant.
2. He succeeded his father in the barony in February 1863, aged 25.
3. He also succeeded his father as Lord-Lieutenant of Montgomeryshire, a post he held until his death.
4. Lord Sudeley died unmarried in April 1877, aged 40, and was succeeded in the barony by his younger brother, Charles, who became a prominent Liberal politician.

0. The Honourable Henry Hanbury- Tracy( 11 April 1802 – 6 April 1889) was a British Whig politician.
1. He sat in the House of Commons from 1837 to 1838.
2. Hanbury- Tracy was born at Toddington, Gloucestershire, a younger son of Charles Hanbury- Tracy, 1st Baron Sudeley, by the Honourable Henrietta Susanna, only child and heiress of Henry Tracy, 8th Viscount Tracy.
3. Thomas Hanbury- Tracy, 2nd Baron Sudeley, was his elder brother.
4. He was elected at the 1837 general election as a Member of Parliament( MP) for Bridgnorth, but resigned from Parliament the following year by becoming Steward of the Chiltern Hundreds Hanbury- Tracy married Rosamond Ann Myrtle, daughter of Robert William Shirley, Viscount Tamworth, in 1841.
5. On 2 September 1852, he was appointed a deputy lieutenant of Montgomeryshire by his brother, and was promoted by him to major of the Montgomeryshire Militia on 3 September.
6. Hanbury- Tracy was appointed lieutenant- colonel commandant of that regiment on 1 May 1854, succeeding Sir John Conroy, 1st Baronet.
7. However, he resigned his militia commission on 25 June 1855.
8. He died in April 1889 at age 86.

2. A member of the Conservative Party all his adult life, he was sometime President and also Chairman of the Conservative Monday Club for seventeen years.

1. Mathis also tackled recent easy listening fare on this album(" A Taste of HoneyQuiet Nights of Quiet Stars( Corcovado)") in addition to show tunes from" On a Clear Day You Can See Forever" and" West Side Story".
2. The first single from the album," On a Clear Day You Can See Forever", debuted on" Billboard" magazine's list of the 40 most popular Easy Listening songs in the US a few months before the album's release, in the issue dated November 6, 1965, and made it to number 6 during a 15- week chart run.
3. In the meantime it also spent two weeks on" Billboard"'s Hot 100 that began in the December 18 issue and included a peak position at number 98.
4. " The Shadow of Your Smile" had its first appearance on the magazine's Top LP's chart in the issue dated April 2, 1966, and began a run of 45 weeks there, where it got as high as number nine.
5. This was the most number of weeks that an album of his stayed on their list since" Johnny's Mood" in 1960 and the highest chart position an album of his achieved since 1960's" The Rhythms and Ballads of Broadway".
6. " The Shadow of Your Smile" was released for the first time on compact disc on November 6, 2012, as one of two albums on one CD, the second of the two being his previous LP," The Sweetheart Tree".
7. Both were also included in Sony's Mathis box set" The Complete Global Albums Collection", which was released on November 17, 2014.

chunks.title: On a Clear Day You Can See Forever (soundtrack)
chunks.chunk:
Title: On a Clear Day You Can See Forever (soundtrack)
0. On a Clear Day You Can See Forever is the soundtrack album to the 1970 American film of the same name.
1. It was released by Columbia Records on July 1, 1970 and features singing by Barbra Streisand and Yves Montand, in addition to choral arrangements and live orchestration.
2. No commercial singles were released from the soundtrack, but the reprise version of the title track was released as a promotional single on 7" vinyl by Columbia.
3. Executively and solely produced by Wally Gold, the album's ten tracks were written by Alan Jay Lerner while the music was written by Burton Lane.
4. The album was reissued on compact disc in 2008.
5. Music critics highlighted the compilation's title track and Streisand's singing ability.
6. Commercially, the soundtrack was once Streisand's lowest- performing entry on the" Billboard" 200, peaking at number 108 in September 1970.
7. However, her other 1970 soundtrack album," The Owl and the Pussycat", would later take its place as Streisand's lowest- peaking album.
8. Nonetheless," On a Clear Day You Can See Forever" served as Montand's only charting effort in the United States.

1. It was subsequently performed by American actress and vocalist Barbra Streisand in the 1970 film adaptation of the musical.
2. Three variations of the song appear in the film and on the accompanying soundtrack album produced by Wally Gold: the initial version sung by co-star Yves Montand, a reprise version sung by Streisand, and an orchestral version performed alongside a live chorus.
3. The Streisand rendition was released by Columbia Records as a promotional single on 7" vinyl( with a stereo mix on one side and mono on the other) in July 1970.
4. The track received positive reviews from music critics, with many of them listing it as a highlight of the soundtrack.

0. Curtis Bernhardt( 15 April 1899 – 22 February 1981) was a German film director born in Worms, Germany, under the name Kurt Bernhardt.
1. He trained as an actor in Germany, and performed on the stage, before starting as a film director in 1924, with" Nameless Heroes".
2. Other films include" A Stolen Life"( 1946) and" Sirocco"( 1951).
3. Bernhardt made films in Germany from 1925 until 1933, when he was forced to flee the Nazi regime — who briefly had him arrested — because he was Jewish.
4. Bernhardt directed films in France and England before moving on to Hollywood to work for Warner Brothers in 1940.
5. He produced and directed his last Hollywood picture," Kisses for My President"( 1964), about the nation's first female Chief Executive starring Polly Bergen and Fred MacMurray.
6. He is interred at Glendale's Forest Lawn Memorial Park Cemetery, near his wife, Pearl Argyle Wellman Bernhardt.

1. It stars Jennifer Grey as Frances" Baby" Houseman, a young woman who falls in love with dance instructor Johnny Castle( Patrick Swayze) at a holiday resort.
2. The film was based on screenwriter Eleanor Bergstein's own childhood.
3. She originally wrote a screenplay for the Michael Douglas film" It's My Turn", but ultimately ended up conceiving a story for a film which became" Dirty Dancing".
4. She finished the script in 1985, but management changes at MGM put the film in development hell.
5. The production company was changed to Vestron Pictures with Emile Ardolino as director and Linda Gottlieb as producer.
6. Filming took place in Lake Lure, North Carolina, and Mountain Lake, Virginia, with the film's score composed by John Morris and dance choreography by Kenny Ortega.
7. " Dirty Dancing" premiered at the 1987 Cannes Film Festival on May 12, 1987, and was released on August 21, 1987, in the United States, earning over$ 214 million worldwide.
8. It was the first film to sell more than a million copies for home video, and its soundtrack created by Jimmy Ienner generating two multi-platinum albums and multiple singles, including"( I've Had) The Time of My Life", which won both the Golden Globe and Academy Award for Best Original Song, and a Grammy Award for best duet.
9. The film's popularity led to a 2004 prequel,, and a stage version which has had sellout performances in Australia, Europe, and North America.
10. A made- for- TV remake was also released in 2017.

question: Where did the director of film Music In Darkness die?

chunks.title: Ingmar Bergman
chunks.chunk:
Title: Ingmar Bergman
0. Ernst Ingmar Bergman (14 July 1918 – 30 July 2007) was a Swedish director, writer, and producer who worked in film, television, theatre and radio.
1. Considered to be among the most accomplished and influential filmmakers of all time, Bergman's films include "Smiles of a Summer Night" (1955),
2. "The Seventh Seal" (1957)
3. , "Wild Strawberries" (1957), "Persona" (1966), "Cries and Whispers" (1972),
4. "Scenes from a Marriage" (1973), and "Fanny and Alexander" (1982); the last two exist in extended television versions.
5. Bergman directed over sixty films and documentaries for cinematic release and for television screenings, most of which he also wrote.
6. He also directed over 170 plays.
7. He eventually forged a creative partnership with his cinematographers Gunnar Fischer and Sven Nykvist.
8. Among his company of actors were Harriet and Bibi Andersson, Liv Ullmann, Gunnar Björnstrand, Erland Josephson, Ingrid Thulin and Max von Sydow.
9. Most of his films were set in Sweden, and many films from "Through a Glass Darkly" (1961)
10. onward were filmed on the island of Fårö.
11. Philip French referred to Bergman as "one of the greatest artists of the 20th century ...
12. he found in literature and the performing arts a way of both recreating and questioning the human condition."
13. Director Martin Scorsese commented; "If you were alive in the 50s and the 60s and of a certain age, a teenager on your way to becoming an adult, and you wanted to make movies
14. , I don't see how you couldn't be influenced by Bergman ...
15. It's impossible to overestimate the effect that those films had on people."

Title: Aleksander Koniecpolski (1555–1609)

1. He was the son of Stanisław Przedbór Koniecpolski and Elżbieta Ligzianka( relative of hetman Jan Tarnowski).

chunks.title: Stanisław Koniecpolski
chunks.chunk:
Title: Stanisław Koniecpolski
0. Stanisław Koniecpolski (1591 – 11 March 1646) was a Polish military commander, regarded as one of the most talented and capable in the history of the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth.
1. He was also a magnate, a royal official ("starosta"), a castellan, a member of the Polish nobility ("szlachta"), and the "voivode" (governor) of Sandomierz from 1625 until his death.
2. He led many successful military campaigns against rebelling Cossacks and invading Tatars.
3. From 1618 he held the rank of Field Crown Hetman before becoming the Grand Crown Hetman, the military commander second only to the King, in 1632.
4. Koniecpolski's life was one of almost constant warfare.
5. Before he had reached the age of 20, he had fought in the Dymitriads and the Moldavian Magnate Wars.
6. Later, in 1620, he took part in the Battle of Cecora, during which he was captured by Ottoman forces.
7. After his release in 1623, he defeated the Ottomans' Tatar vassals several times between 1624 and 1626.
8. With inferior numbers, during the Polish–Swedish War (1626–29), Koniecpolski stopped the Swedish forces of Gustavus Adolphus from conquering Prussia and Pomerania before the war was concluded with the Truce of Altmark.
9. In 1634, he defeated a major Turkish invasion at Kamianets-Podilskyi (Kamieniec Podolski), in modern Ukraine, while in 1644, his victory against the Tatars at the Battle of Ochmatów brought him international fame and recognition.

1. He was the only son of Archibald Acheson, 2nd Earl of Gosford of Gosford Castle, County Armagh and educated at Harrow School and Christ Church, Oxford.
2. He succeeded to his father's Irish titles and estates in 1849.

0. Archibald John Primrose, 4th Earl of Rosebery, KT, PC, FRS( 14 October 1783 – 4 March 1868), styled Viscount Primrose until 1814, was a British politician.
1. He was the eldest son of Neil Primrose, 3rd Earl of Rosebery, and his second wife, Mary Vincent.
2. Primrose was educated at Pembroke College, Cambridge, gaining his MA in 1804.
3. He was Member of Parliament for Helston from 1805 to 1806 and Cashel from 1806 to 1807.
4. He succeeded to the earldom in 1814, and was created Baron Rosebery, of Rosebery in the County of Edinburgh, in the Peerage of the United Kingdom, in 1828.
5. He was appointed a Privy Counsellor in 1831 and a Knight of the Thistle in 1840.
6. He was a Fellow of the Royal Society.
7. He was the grandfather of Archibald Primrose, 5th Earl of Rosebery, who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 1894 to 1895.

chunks.title: Archibald Acheson, 4th Earl of Gosford
chunks.chunk:
Title: Archibald Acheson, 4th Earl of Gosford
0. Archibald Brabazon Sparrow Acheson, 4th Earl of Gosford, (2 August 1841 – 11 April 1922) was a British peer.
1. The son of Archibald Acheson, 3rd Earl of Gosford, he was born at Worlingham Hall, Suffolk, in 1841, and succeeded to the earldom upon the death of his father in 1864.
2. Since there are two United Kingdom peerages (e.g. Baron Worlingham) subsumed in that Irish Earldom, he was entitled to an automatic seat in the House of Lords.
3. He was Lord Lieutenant of Armagh from 1883 to 1920, and served as Vice-Chamberlain of the Household of Queen Alexandra from 1901.
4. He was Honorary Colonel of the 3rd Battalion of the Royal Irish Fusiliers from 1899, and Vice-Admiral of Ulster.
5. Gosford died in London in 1922, aged 80, and was cremated at Golders Green Crematorium.

chunks.title: William de Warenne, 3rd Earl of Surrey
chunks.chunk:
Title: William de Warenne, 3rd Earl of Surrey
0. William de Warenne, 3rd Earl of Surrey( 11196 January 1148) was an Anglo- Norman nobleman who fought in England during the Anarchy and generally remained loyal to King Stephen.
1. He participated in the Second Crusade.

chunks.title: Waleran de Beaumont, 4th Earl of Warwick
chunks.chunk:
Title: Waleran de Beaumont, 4th Earl of Warwick
0. Waleran de Beaumont, 4th Earl of Warwick (1153 – 12 December 1204) was the younger son of Roger de Beaumont, 2nd Earl of Warwick and Gundred de Warenne, daughter of William de Warenne, 2nd Earl of Surrey and Elizabeth de Vermandois.
1. He was also known as Walerian de Newburg.
2. After the death of his brother, William de Beaumont, 3rd Earl of Warwick, an impostor arose, claiming to be the deceased Earl; he gave Waleran a great deal of trouble in maintaining his claim.
3. He does not appear to have been a great soldier, for he paid scutage money to escape military service in Wales.
4. His position in the Court is attested by his bearing the right hand Sword of State at the Coronation of John, King of England, 27 May 1199.
5. He liberally supported the hospital of St Michael's Hospital, Warwick and gave to the nuns of Pinley land at Claverdon, and land at Brailes to the nuns at Wroxall, Warwickshire.

chunks.title: William de Warenne, 2nd Earl of Surrey
