Title: William de Warenne, 2nd Earl of Surrey
0. William de Warenne, 2nd Earl of Surrey (died 11 May 1138) was the son of William de Warenne, 1st Earl of Surrey and his first wife Gundred.
1. He was more often referred to as "Earl Warenne" or "Earl of Warenne" than as Earl of Surrey.

chunks.title: William de Warenne, 1st Earl of Surrey
chunks.chunk:
Title: William de Warenne, 1st Earl of Surrey
0. William de Warenne, 1st Earl of Surrey, Lord of Lewes, Seigneur de Varennes (died 1088), was a Norman nobleman created Earl of Surrey under William II Rufus.
1. He is among the few who are documented as having fought for William the Conqueror at the Battle of Hastings in 1066.
2. At the time of the Domesday Survey, he held extensive lands in 13 counties, including the Rape of Lewes in Sussex, which is now divided between the ceremonial counties of East Sussex and West Sussex.

chunks.title: Ada de Warenne
chunks.chunk:
Title: Ada de Warenne
0. Ada de Warenne( or Adeline de Varenne)( 1120 – 1178) was a Scottish princess, the Anglo- Norman wife of Henry of Scotland, Earl of Northumbria and Earl of Huntingdon.
1. She was the daughter of William de Warenne, 2nd Earl of Surrey by Elizabeth of Vermandois, and a great- granddaughter of Henry I of France.
2. She became mother to two Kings of Scots, Malcolm the Maiden and William the Lion.

chunks.title: William de Warenne, 5th Earl of Surrey
chunks.chunk:
Title: William de Warenne, 5th Earl of Surrey
0. William de Warenne, 5th Earl of Surrey( died 27 May 1240) was the son of Hamelin de Warenne and Isabel, daughter of William de Warenne, 3rd Earl of Surrey.
1. His father Hamelin granted him the manor of Appleby, North Lincolnshire.
2. De Warenne was present at the coronation of John, King of England on 27 May 1199.
3. When Normandy was lost to the French in 1204 he lost his Norman holdings( in 1202 he was lieutenant of Gascony), but John recompensed him with Grantham and Stamford.
4. His first tenure of office as Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports began in 1204, and lasted until 1206; he was again appointed as Warden in 1214.
5. He was also a Warden of the Welsh Marches between 1208 and 1213.
6. Between the years 1200 and 1208, and between 1217 and 1226 he was to serve as the High Sheriff of Surrey.
7. William was one of the few barons who remained loyal to King John( who was his cousin.
8. In 1212, when a general rebellion was feared, John committed to him the custody of the northern shires.
9. During the king's difficulties with the barons, when they sought for the French prince to assume the English throne, William is listed as one of those who advised John to accede to" Magna Carta".
10. His allegiance only faltered a few times when the king's cause looked hopeless; shortly before the death of John, he made terms with Prince Louis.
11. In March 1217 he again demonstrated his loyalty to England by supporting the young King Henry III, and he was also responsible for the establishment of Salisbury Cathedral.
12. However, he disliked the royal favourites who came into power after 1227, and used his influence to protect Hubert de Burgh when the latter had been removed from office by their efforts in 1232.
13. Warenne's relations with the king became strained in course of time.
14. In 1238 he was evidently regarded as a leader of the baronial opposition, for the Great Council appointed him as one of the treasurers who were to prevent the king from squandering the subsidy voted in that year.
15. William married Maud Marshal, on 13 October 1225.
16. They had a son and a daughter.
17. The son John( 1231–1304) succeeded his father as earl, while the daughter, Isabel de Warenne( c. 1228–1282), married Hugh d' Aubigny, 5th Earl of Arundel.
18. William may also have had an earlier, childless marriage to another Matilda, daughter of William d'Aubigny, 2nd Earl of Arundel.

Title: Isabel de Warenne, Countess of Surrey
0. Isabel de Warenne, 4th Countess of Surrey( c. 1137 c. 1203) was an English peer.
1. She was the only surviving heir of William de Warenne, 3rd Earl of Surrey and his wife, Adela, the daughter of William III of Ponthieu.

chunks.title: William Peverel the Younger
chunks.chunk:
Title: William Peverel the Younger
0. William" the Younger" Peverel( c. 1080 – 1155) was the son of William Peverel.
1. He lived in Nottingham, England.
2. He married Avicia de Lancaster( 1088 – c. 1150) in La Marche, Normandy, France.
3. She was the daughter of William de Lancaster I and Countess Gundred de Warenne, daughter of William de Warenne, 2nd Earl of Surrey.
4. In 1114, she bore a daughter, Margaret Peverel.
5. Another member of his family, Maude Peverel( a sister or daughter) was- by 1120- the first wife of Robert fitz Martin.
6. William inherited the Honour of Peverel.
7. He was a principal supporter of King Stephen, and a commander in the Battle of the Standard.
8. He was captured at The Battle of Lincoln.
9. King Henry II dispossessed William of the Honour in 1153, for conspiring to poison the Earl of Chester- though historians speculate that the King wished to punish him for his' wickedness and treason' in supporting King Stephen.
10. The Earl died before he took possession of the Honour, and it stayed in the Crown for about a half century.

chunks.title: François Girard
chunks.chunk:
Title: François Girard
0. François Girard( born January 12, 1963) is a French- Canadian director and screenwriter.
1. Born in Quebec, Girard's career began on the Montreal art video circuit.
2. In 1990, he produced his first feature film," Cargo"; he attained international recognition following his 1993" Thirty Two Short Films About Glenn Gould", a series of vignettes about the life of piano prodigy Glenn Gould.
3. In 1998, he wrote and directed" The Red Violin", which follows the ownership of a red violin over several centuries.
4. " The Red Violin" won an Academy Award for Best Original Score, thirteen Genie Awards and nine Jutra Awards.
5. He has also directed various works for the stage, including Stravinsky's" Symphony of PsalmsOedipus Rex" and" Novencento" at the Edinburgh International Festival; Kafka's" The Trial", adapted for the stage by Serge Lamothe at the National Arts Centre, Ottawa; the oratorio" Lost Objects" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music;" Siegfried" in Toronto; and" The Lindbergh Flight" and" The Seven Deadly Sins", first in Lyon and then in Edinburgh.
6. Girard has also produced a residency show for Cirque du Soleil," Zed", in Tokyo and" Zarkana", which opened at Radio City Music Hall in New York in the summer of 2011.
7. In 2013 the Metropolitan Opera in New York opened a new production of Richard Wagner's" Parsifal" directed by Girard.
8. The production received near universal acclaim from critics and audiences alike.
9. His television credits include" Le dortoirPeter Gabriel's Secret World" and" The Sound of the Carceri", one of the six episodes of" Yo Yo Ma Inspired by Bach".

chunks.title: Hochelaga, Land of Souls
chunks.chunk:
Title: Hochelaga, Land of Souls
0. Hochelaga, Land of Souls is a 2017 Canadian historical drama film directed and written by François Girard and starring Gilles Renaud, Samian and Tanaya Beatty.
1. Dramatizing several centuries of Quebec history and the local history of Montreal in particular, the story depicts Quebec archaeology revealing the past of indigenous peoples, explorers and 1837 rebels.
2. Girard had previously used an anthology approach in his films such as" The Red Violin", and was interested in another project that would depict Montreal.
3. It was shot in Montreal, with performances in numerous languages.
4. The film was screened in the Gala Presentations section at the 2017 Toronto International Film Festival.
5. It won four Canadian Screen Awards, including Best Cinematography for Nicolas Bolduc, and was Canada's submission for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film.

chunks.title: Leona Lewis
chunks.chunk:
Title: Leona Lewis
0. Leona Louise Lewis (born 3 April 1985) is a British singer, songwriter, actress, model and activist.
1. She was born and raised in the London Borough of Islington in London, where she attended the BRIT School for Performing Arts and Technology.
2. Lewis achieved national recognition when she won the third series of "The X Factor" in 2006, winning a £1 million recording contract with Simon Cowell's record label, Syco Music.
3. Her winner's single, a cover of Kelly Clarkson's "A Moment Like This", peaked at number one for four weeks on the UK Singles Chart and broke a world record for reaching 50,000 digital downloads within 30 minutes.
4. In February 2007, Lewis signed a five-album contract in the United States with Clive Davis's record label, J Records.
5. Lewis's success continued with the release of her debut album, "Spirit", in 2007; it was certified 10× platinum in the United Kingdom and became the fourth best-selling album of the 2000s.
6. It is one of the best-selling albums in UK chart history.
7. In the US, Lewis became the first UK solo artist to debut at number one with a debut album, with "Spirit".
8. The lead single,
9. "Bleeding Love", spent seven weeks at number one in the UK where it became the best-selling single of 2007.
10. She achieved international recognition with the album in 2008 when it topped charts around the world.
11. "
12. Spirit" has sold more than eight million copies worldwide, and "Bleeding Love" peaked at number one in over 30 countries, including the US "Billboard" Hot 100, becoming the best-selling single of 2008.
13. As a result, she was proclaimed Top New Artist by "Billboard" in 2008.
14. Under the guidance of Cowell and Davis, Lewis released her second UK number-one album "Echo" and recorded the theme song for the film "Avatar" in 2009.
15. She embarked on her first UK arena tour, The Labyrinth, in 2010.
16. In 2011, Lewis released the non-album single "Collide", a collaboration with Swedish DJ Avicii, and her first extended play, .
17. Her third album, "Glassheart", was released in 2012.
18. It marked a new creative direction for Lewis, drawing inspiration from dubstep and electronic music.
19. However, it failed to match the commercial performance of her two previous albums, peaking at number three in the UK and becoming her first to not be certified platinum.
20. Lewis began to record material for her first Christmas album during her Glassheart Tour, which took place in mid 2013. "
21. Christmas, with Love" was released later that year.
22. Its lead single, "One More Sleep", peaked at number three in the UK.
23. With this chart entry, Lewis became the first British female solo artist to reach the top five with eight singles, surpassing Olivia Newton-John's record of seven.
24. In 2014, Lewis made her film debut in the supporting role of Elena in the romantic comedy musical, "Walking on Sunshine".
25. Her fourth studio album, "I Am", was released the following year.
26. In 2016, Lewis made her Broadway debut as Grizabella in the revival of Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical "Cats".
27. A year later, she signed a modelling contract with Wilhelmina Models.
28. She then collaborated with Calum Scott on the single
29. "You Are The Reason" (2018) which achieved worldwide chart success, and had a recurring role in the American television series "The Oath" (2019).
30. As of 2015, Lewis is the second best-selling act from "The X Factor" franchise in the UK, behind One Direction, having sold over 30 million records worldwide.
31. The OCC recognises Lewis as the most successful winner from the UK's "The X Factor".
32. Lewis has won two MOBO Awards, an MTV Europe Music Award, and two World Music Awards.
33. She is also a six-time Brit Award and three-time Grammy Award nominee.
34. Lewis is known for her expansive four-octave vocal range, power, technical control and, in particular, her frequent use of the falsetto register.
35. Aside from her musical career, Lewis is a philanthropist and an animal welfare campaigner for World Animal Protection and is a supporter of other animal rights charities and organisations; she is also vegan.

0. Princess Stéphanie Windisch- Graetz( 17 July 1939 – 12 July 2019) was the daughter of Prince Franz Joseph zu Windisch- Graetz and granddaughter of Archduchess Elisabeth Marie of Austria.
1. Archduchess Elisabeth was the daughter of Rudolf, Crown Prince of Austria and granddaughter of Emperor Franz Joseph I of Austria.
2. She became an artist, known for her photographic portraits using only candles as a source of light, and for her sensual images from the animal world.

chunks.title: Hubba bint Hulail

chunks.title: Zita of Bourbon-Parma
chunks.chunk:
Title: Zita of Bourbon-Parma
0. Zita of Bourbon-Parma ("Zita Maria delle Grazie Adelgonda Micaela Raffaela Gabriella Giuseppina Antonia Luisa Agnese"; 9 May 1892 – 14 March 1989) was the wife of Charles, the last monarch of Austria-Hungary.
1. As such, she was the last Empress of Austria and Queen of Hungary, in addition to other titles.
2. Born as the seventeenth child of the dispossessed Robert I, Duke of Parma, and his second wife, Infanta Maria Antonia of Portugal, Zita married the then Archduke Charles of Austria in 1911.
3. Charles became heir presumptive to the Emperor Franz Joseph
4. I of Austria in 1914 after the assassination of his uncle Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria, and acceded to the throne in 1916 after the old emperor's death.
5. After the end of World War I in 1918, the Habsburgs were deposed and the empire became four independent countries, Austria, Hungary, and the newly formed Czechoslovakia and State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs.
6. Charles and Zita left for exile in Switzerland and were subsequently removed from Hungary by the Allies to Madeira, where Charles died in 1922.
7. After her husband's death, Zita and her son Otto served as symbols of unity for the exiled dynasty.
8. A devout Catholic, she raised a large family after being widowed at the age of 29, and never remarried.

chunks.title: Sebastián Iradier
chunks.chunk:
Title: Sebastián Iradier
0. Sebastián Iradier Salaverri( Salaberri)( 20 January 18096 December 1865), or Sebastián Yradier, was a Spanish Basque composer.
1. Iradier was born in Lanciego, in the province of Álava.
2. His publisher in Paris urged him to" universalize" his name, from Iradier to Yradier.
3. He is known primarily for his habaneras, especially the one titled" La Paloma", written around 1860 after a visit to Cuba.
4. " La Paloma" was extremely popular in both Spain and the Americas( especially Mexico), where it was responsible for the great popularity achieved by the habanera.
5. Radio Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México( UNAM) has estimated that there are more than one thousand versions of" La Paloma", and said that, together with" Yesterday" by The Beatles, it is one of the most recorded songs in the history of music.
6. Another of Iradier's compositions is" El Arreglito", a habanera used by Georges Bizet in his opera" Carmen".
7. Bizet, thinking it was a folk song, was inspired by the melody, and recomposed it as the aria" L'amour est un oiseau rebelle", also known as the" Habanera".
8. When he discovered his mistake, Bizet added a note to the vocal score of the opera, acknowledging its source.
9. Iradier died in obscurity in 1865.

chunks.title: Aminatou Haidar
chunks.chunk:
Title: Aminatou Haidar
0. Aminatou Ali Ahmed Haidar( born 24 July 1966), sometimes known as" Aminetou"," Aminatu" or" Aminetu", is a Sahrawi human rights activist and an advocate of the independence of Western Sahara.
1. She is often called the" Sahrawi Gandhi" or" Sahrawi Pasionaria" for her nonviolent protests.
2. She is the president of the Collective of Sahrawi Human Rights Defenders( CODESA).
3. She was imprisoned from 1987 to 1991 and from 2005 to 2006 on charges related to her independence advocacy.
4. In 2009, she attracted international attention when she staged a hunger strike in Lanzarote Airport after being denied re-entry into Moroccan Western Sahara.
5. Haidar has won several international human rights awards for her work, including the 2008 Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights Award and the 2009 Civil Courage Prize.

0. Red Sparrow is a 2018 American spy thriller film directed by Francis Lawrence and written by Justin Haythe, based on the 2013 novel of the same name by Jason Matthews.

2. It tells the story of a Russian intelligence officer, who is sent to make contact with a CIA officer in the hope of discovering the identity of a mole.
3. Matthews, a former member of the CIA, advised the production on the depiction of spying.
4. Based on historic Soviet sexpionage and contemporary Russian use of kompromat, filming took place in Hungary, Slovakia and Austria.
5. " Red Sparrow" premiered at the Newseum in Washington, D.C. on February 15, 2018, and was released in the United States on March 2, 2018.
6. The film grossed$ 151 million worldwide, becoming a modest box- office success, and received mixed reviews from critics, who described it as having" more style than substance", and criticized the film's length and over-reliance on graphic violence and sex, while praising Jennifer Lawrence's performance.

chunks.title: The Cemetery Club (2006 film)
chunks.chunk:
Title: The Cemetery Club (2006 film)
0. The Cemetery Club( Hebrew: מועדו ן בית הקברות," Mo'adon Beit Hakvarot") is a 2006 Israeli documentary film, directed by Tali Shemesh.
1. The film opened the 2006 DocAviv film festival, to rave reviews and several awards.
2. It then went on to screenings at many international festivals, including the Cannes Film Festival, and won the White Dove award at Dok Leipzig.
3. It is considered the most successful Israeli documentary ever.

chunks.title: Toussaint L'Overture County Cemetery
chunks.chunk:
Title: Toussaint L'Overture County Cemetery
0. The Toussaint L'Ouverture County Cemetery is an historical African- American cemetery located in Franklin, Tennessee.
1. It was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1995.
2. It is named for Toussaint Louverture, the leader of the Haitian Revolution.
3. The earliest recorded burials date from 1869, but it was n't officially incorporated until 1884.
4. It is" the oldest African American institution in continuous use" in Williamson County.
5. The cemetery corporation which originally purchased the land and established the cemetery failed during the Great Depression in the United States.
6. After the failure of the cemetery corporation, no entity was named successor and all the members of the original board of trustees have died.
7. Consequently, ownership of the cemetery is unclear and no entity is legally responsible for its maintenance.
8. Care of the cemetery has been support by the Toussaint L'Ouverture Cemetery Club hosted by the First Missionary Baptist Church in Franklin, TN.
9. The club is a volunteer organization funded by donations and headed by Mattie B. Reeves.
10. Starting in 2013, when the cemetery was added to the Historic Franklin Parks Cell Phone Tour, community support for the cemetery has expanded.
11. On September 11, 2014, in cooperation with the United Way's Days of Caring program, about 150 community volunteers, many from the local Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, cleaned the grounds of the cemetery and headstones.
12. On October 24, 2015, the Cemetery Club held another clean- up day.
13. No Burial Register exists for the cemetery.
14. Consequently, volunteers have photographed and transcribed many of headstones in the cemetery to the Billion Graves website.

Title: Old Jewish cemetery, Cieszyn
0. Old Jewish Cemetery is one of two Jewish cemeteries in Cieszyn, Poland; together with New Jewish Cemetery.
1. Situated on Hażlaska Street 39, it is the oldest of them.
2. Land for the cemetery was purchased in 1647 and has since belonged to the Singer family.
3. In 1785, the cemetery was ceased to be private property and was sold to the Jewish community in Cieszyn.
4. The last burial at the cemetery took place in 1928.
5. In 1986, the cemetery was added to the register of monuments.
6. The cemetery now belongs to the Jewish Community in Bielsko-Biała.
7. As of 2009, the cemetery has more than 1,500 graves.
8. The cemetery has an area of 1.9 hectares and is surrounded by a brick fence.
9. It is claimed by local authors that the cemetery was established in the Middle Ages.

chunks.title: Linwood Cemetery (Dubuque)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Linwood Cemetery (Dubuque)
0. Linwood Cemetery is located in Dubuque, Iowa.
1. It is located on Windsor Avenue in the north end of Dubuque.
2. The cemetery is one of the main cemeteries in Dubuque.
3. Originally established for the Protestants of the city, the cemetery now serves members of all faiths.
4. If current burial procedures are followed in the future, the cemetery is estimated to have enough room for the next 1,200 years.
5. The cemetery is noted for the large gates at the entrance to the cemetery.
6. The gates were given in memory of a local businessman and banker.
7. It is also noted for the well cared for grounds, part of which sit on a bluff overlooking the Mississippi River.
8. A number of famous people have been interred at Linwood Cemetery.
9. These include Iowa Governor Stephen P. Hempstead, for whom Hempstead High School is named, a U.S. Senator William Boyd Allison, and former Speaker of the US House David Bremner Henderson.
10. Other notable local people buried at the cemetery include local tailor Rocco Buda, and former city councilman Donald Deich.
11. Oran Pape- the only member of the Iowa State Patrol to have been murdered in the line of duty, as well as the first State Trooper to die in the line of duty- is also buried at Linwood.
12. Major Stuart Anderson- a member of the U.S. Army Reserve who died in the January 7, 2006 UH- 60 Black Hawk near Tal Afar, Iraq was also recently buried at Linwood.
13. Len Kruse, a forty- year veteran of the US Postal Service turned Local Historian is also interred here.
14. Len's writings appeared in numerous local publications, including the Telegraph Herald and Julien's Journal.
15. The cemetery is owned and operated by the Linwood Cemetery Association.
16. They have operated the cemetery since 1875.
17. Prior to that, the cemetery was owned by the city.
18. However the city had not done a good job maintaining the cemetery, which resulted in the cemetery being in poor condition.
19. This led to a number of citizens voting to turn over control to the Association.
20. Recently, the cemetery has built a mausoleum that also includes a number of columbarium niches.
21. The cemetery plans to build several more similar mausoleums.

chunks.title: Riverside Cemetery (Pawtucket, Rhode Island)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Riverside Cemetery (Pawtucket, Rhode Island)
0. Riverside Cemetery is an historic cemetery at 752 Pleasant Street in Pawtucket, Rhode Island.
1. It occupies a parcel of land about in size between Pleasant Street and the Seekonk River, and just north of the much larger Swan Point Cemetery in neighboring Providence.
2. The cemetery was established in 1874, and is Pawtucket's instance of a rural cemetery.
3. The cemetery's creation was championed by John W. Davis, a local politician who later served two terms as Governor of Rhode Island, and was for many years the cemetery's resident manager, living in the cemetery manager's house, which was built around the time of the cemetery's founding.
4. The cemetery has been run by descendants of John W. Davis since its inception in 1874.
5. The cemetery was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1983.

chunks.title: Evergreen Cemetery (Southgate, Kentucky)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Evergreen Cemetery (Southgate, Kentucky)
0. Evergreen Cemetery( Southgate, Kentucky) is the largest cemetery in Campbell County, Kentucky.
1. It is still in operation and is located at 25 Alexandria Pike in Southgate, Kentucky.
2. The Cemetery was begun in the 1840s, to replace the Newport, Cemetery.
3. The cemetery was located a few miles south of Newport, in a rural area, which is now the City of Southgate, Kentucky.
4. General James Taylor Jr. considered the founder of Newport, Kentucky is buried here, as well as Congressman Brent Spence.
5. The cemetery also contains a Soldiers and Sailors section.
6. Notable is William H. Horsfall, one of the youngest men to receive the Medal of Honor during the American Civil War.
7. A defensive earthwork named Shaler Battery, built as part of the Defense of Cincinnati, remains preserved within the cemetery and is located adjacent to the cemetery bandstand.
8. It was one of the 28 artillery batteries that were built on northern Kentucky hilltops from 1861 to 1863.
9. A residence for the sexton of the cemetery was constructed in 1872.
10. Seven years later, in 1879, the name of the cemetery was officially acknowledged as Evergreen.
11. By 1902, a chapel had been constructed on the cemetery grounds and was used for funeral services and layouts.
12. The cemetery was used as the cemetery in the 1988 film" Rain Man".
13. Today, the cemetery contains and accepts burials from throughout the region.

0. Hans Barthold Andresen Butenschøn( 27 December 1877 – 28 November 1971) was a Norwegian businessperson.

2. Together with Mabel Anette Plahte( 1877 – 1973, a daughter of Frithjof M. Plahte) he had the son Hans Barthold Andresen Butenschøn Jr. and was through him the father- in- law of Ragnhild Butenschøn and grandfather of Peter Butenschøn.
3. Through his daughter Marie Claudine he was the father- in- law of Joakim Lehmkuhl, through his daughter Mabel Anette he was the father- in- law of Harald Astrup( a son of Sigurd Astrup) and through his daughter Nini Augusta he was the father- in- law of Ernst Torp.
4. He took commerce school and agricultural school.
5. He was hired in the family company N. A. Andresen& Co, and became a co-owner in 1910.
6. He eventually became chief executive officer.
7. The bank changed its name to Andresens Bank in 1913 and merged with Bergens Kreditbank in 1920.
8. The merger was dissolved later in the 1920s.
9. He was also a landowner, owning Nedre Skøyen farm and a lot of land in Enebakk.
10. He chaired the board of Nydalens Compagnie from 1926, having not been a board member before that.
11. He also chaired the supervisory council of Forsikringsselskapet Viking and Nedre Glommen salgsforening, and was a supervisory council member of Filharmonisk Selskap.
12. He was a member of the gentlemen's club SK Fram since 1890, and was proclaimed a lifetime member in 1964.
13. He was buried in Enebakk.

chunks.title: Tracy Flannigan
chunks.chunk:
Title: Tracy Flannigan
0. Tracy Flannigan is an award winning independent filmmaker residing in the Echo Park area of Los Angeles who began making movies when she was seventeen years old.
1. She has worked professionally for the last fifteen years in the film business and has created numerous short films and music videos.
2. Her work has been screened at many film festivals throughout the United States.
3. Tracy’s feature-length screenplay, "The Late Great W.J.", won a fellowship at the Squaw Valley Community of Writers.
4. marks Tracy Flannigan’s
5. documentary feature debut.
6. The film was made over a five-year period in which Tracy dedicated herself to capturing the lives and performances of the all women queercore band, Tribe 8. "
7. Rise Above" has screened internationally and garnered the July Award for Best Documentary at Frameline, the San Francisco Gay and Lesbian Film Festival and earned Ms. Flannigan the Kodak Emerging Talent Award at Outfest, the Los Angeles Gay and Lesbian Film Festival.
8. Currently, Ms. Flannigan is in pre-production on a second feature-length documentary on the experiences of poverty-stricken illegal immigrants, who on a daily basis must find work outside stores like Home Depot.

chunks.title: Rise Above: The Tribe 8 Documentary
chunks.chunk:
Title: Rise Above: The Tribe 8 Documentary
0. Rise Above:
1. The Tribe 8 Documentary is a feature film about the all women queercore punk band Tribe 8 directed and produced by Tracy Flannigan.
2. The film chronicles live performances, candid moments of their lives at work and on the road, and the controversy at the Michigan Womyn's Music Festival, an all women's music festival, that landed them in a quagmire of protest and praise from a fiercely divided crowd.
3. It also captures the truly funny and warm people behind the music and the politics.
4. Starting with their controversial gig at the 1994 Michigan Womyn's Music Festival, the film chronicles four years of the band.
5. The images presented on stage of blow jobs, sadomasochistic acts and mock castrations are not shocking the audience for shock's sake, for example
6. Lynn Breedlove, the lead singer wore a strap-on didlo.
7. Lyn often got young men up from the audience to 'service' her, this act was to break the taboo of straight male penetration.
8. The documentary portrays on a deeper level through the band members' intense personal disclosures.

chunks.title: Gilduin of Le Puiset
chunks.chunk:
Title: Gilduin of Le Puiset
0. Gilduin of Le Puiset( d. between 1130 and 1135) was the son of Hugh I of Le Puiset and Alice of Monthléry, daughter of Guy I of Montlhéry.
1. Monk at St. Martin- des- Champs, prior at Cluny Abbey, prior at Lurey- le- Bourg, abbot of St. Mary of the Valley of Jehosaphat.
2. It is unclear when Gilduin became abbot of St. Mary, but he was in this position when his cousin Baldwin II confirmed the privileges of the abbey, the chief Marian shrine in Jerusalem, on 31 January 1120.
3. In that same year, Gilduin and Baldwin II travelled to Edessa, joining with Gilduin ’s brother Waleran.
4. There they met Hugh, Archbishop of Edessa.
5. Hugh, in possession of two sacred relics — a finger of St. Stephen and a tooth of John the Baptist- was concerned about keeping the relics in a place that could be overrun by Moslems.
6. He gave the relics to Gilduin for transfer to Cluny, now under Pons of Melgueil, a mission which he completed.
7. Gilduin may have been associated with Barisan the Old.
8. " Les Lignages d’ Outremer" identified Balian[ Barisan] as the brother of a Count Guilduin of Chartres.
9. Riley- Smith speculates that Barisan may have been the illegitimate brother or brother- in- law of Gilduin, but there is little evidence to support this.
10. It is not known who succeeded Gilduin as abbot of St. Mary.

chunks.title: Hugh I of Le Puiset
chunks.chunk:
Title: Hugh I of Le Puiset
0. Hugh I of Le Puiset( died 23 December 1096), son of Everard I of Breteuil and his wife Humberge.
1. In 1067, taking advantage of the weakness of Philip I of France, he seized the royal castle of Puiset and settled there.
2. In 1073, Theobald III, Count of Blois, became Count of Chartres and did not hesitate to defy royal order, defeating the royal army in 1079 at Le Puiset.
3. He took as prisoner Ivo, Bishop of Chartres, and kept him confined for two years.
4. Hugh married Alice of Monthléry, daughter of Guy I, lord of Monthléry, and Hodierna de Gometz.
5. The family of Montlhéry was also part of the turbulent nobility that King Louis VI would have to put down a generation later.
6. The alliances of the Montlhéry Clan formed a broad network of nobles who engaged heavily in the Crusades.
7. Hugh and Alice had at least nine children:
8. Hugh established a priory of Marmountier at Le Puiset.
9. See also the Houses of Montlhéry and Le Puiset.

chunks.title: Guy I of Dampierre
chunks.chunk:
Title: Guy I of Dampierre
0. Guy I of Dampierre( died 1151), son of Thibaut of Dampierre- sur- l’ Aube and Elizabeth of Montlhéry, daughter of Milo I of Montlhéry, Viscount of Troyes.
1. Seigneur of Dampierre, Saint- Dizier, and Moëlain.
2. Guy travelled with Hugh I of Troyes on his pilgrimage to the Holy Land in 1125.
3. It is not known whether Guy became a Knight Templar, although his son William approved the donation of property to the Templars at Provins.
4. Guy was associated with Barisan the Old, who travelled in the Holy Land with Hugh II of Le Puiset, as well as Hugh ’s uncle Guy of Le Puiset.
5. Guy married Helvide of Baudémont, daughter of Andre of Baudémont, Seneschal of Bourgogne, and his wife Agnes.
6. Helvide was the widow of Hugh of Chacenay, Seigneur de Montréal.
7. After Guy ’s death, Helvide became a nun at Jully- les- Nonnains.
8. Guy and Helvide had seven children:

chunks.title: Walo II of Chaumont-en-Vexin
chunks.chunk:
Title: Walo II of Chaumont-en-Vexin
0. Walo II( Galon II de Beaumont)(* 1060; † 1098) was a viscount of Chaumont- en- Vexin and a constable of King Philip I of France.
1. He was son of Odo( Eudes) de Beaumont, viscount of Chaumont- en- Vexin.
2. He took a part at the First Crusade as part of the army of Hugh the Great that attempted to capture the Holy Lands, called by Pope Urban II in 1095.
3. Walo was killed by the Turks during the Siege of Antioch on 20 May 1098.
4. Walo was married to Humberge of Le Puiset, a sister of Everard of Le Puiset, both from the prominent Île- de- France family of Hugh I of Le Puiset.
5. Walo and Humberge had three children:
6. Drogo was the ancestor of the later counts of Dammartin, his great- grandson Jean, Châtelain de Trie, marrying Alix de Dammartin, daughter of Alberic III, Count of Dammartin.

chunks.title: Hugh I of Jaffa
chunks.chunk:
Title: Hugh I of Jaffa
0. Hugh I( died between 1112 and 1118) was the Lord of Le Puiset( as Hugh II) from 1097 and Count of Jaffa from 1106.
1. He was the son of Hugh I of Le Puiset and Alice of Montlhéry.
2. He is often confused with his son, who was also known as Hugh II of Le Puiset, though he was actually only Hugh II of Jaffa.
3. Through his mother he was a cousin of Baldwin of Le Bourg and Joscelin of Courtenay, who were lords in Outremer.
4. Hugh acted as lord of Le Puiset until 1106 as tutor to his young nephew Hugh III.
5. After his tenure was up, he went to the Holy Land in the company of Bohemond of Taranto and there received the county of Jaffa.
6. By his wife Mabel, daughter of Ebles II of Roucy and Sybil of Hauteville, he had one son, Hugh, who succeeded to Jaffa following the regency of his mother's second husband, Albert of Namur.

chunks.title: Guy I of Montlhéry
chunks.chunk:
Title: Guy I of Montlhéry
0. Guy I( died 1095) was the second lord of Bray and the second lord of Montlhéry( Latin:" Monte Leterico").
1. He was probably the son of Thibaud of Montmorency, but some sources say that his father was named Milo.
2. Thibaud may instead have been his grandfather.
3. He married Hodierna of Gometz, daughter of William, lord of Gometz.
4. They had seven children:
5. Guy died in 1095, the same year Pope Urban II launched the First Crusade.
6. Many of his descendants had illustrious careers in the Holy Land, through the Montlhéry, Courtenay, and Le Puiset branches of his family.
7. See the Houses of Montlhéry and Le Puiset.

chunks.title: Éric Rohmer
chunks.chunk:
Title: Éric Rohmer
0. Jean Marie Maurice Schérer or Maurice Henri Joseph Schérer, known as Éric Rohmer (21 March 192011 January 2010), was a French film director, film critic, journalist, novelist, screenwriter, and teacher.
1. Rohmer was the last of the post-World War II French New Wave directors to become established.
2. He edited the influential film journal, "Cahiers du cinéma", from 1957 to 1963, while most of his colleagues—among them Jean-Luc Godard and François Truffaut—were making the transition from film critics to filmmakers and gaining international attention.
3. Rohmer gained international acclaim around 1969 when his film "My Night at Maud's" was nominated at the Academy Awards.
4. He won the San Sebastián International Film Festival with "Claire's Knee" in 1971 and the Golden Lion at the Venice Film Festival for "The Green Ray" in 1986.
5. Rohmer went on to receive the Venice Film Festival's Career Golden Lion in 2001.
6. After Rohmer's death in 2010, his obituary in "The Daily Telegraph" described him as "the most durable filmmaker of the French New Wave", outlasting his peers and "still making movies the public wanted to see" late in his career.

2. He was born to Portuguese settler parents.
3. His father emigrated from Ponte de Lima in Northern Portugal in 1898 and owned a cattle ranch.

chunks.title: Emmanuel de Rohan-Polduc
chunks.chunk:
Title: Emmanuel de Rohan-Polduc
0. Fra' Emmanuel Marie des Neiges de Rohan- Polduc( 18 April 1725, in la Mancha, Spain – 14 July 1797, in Valletta, Malta) was a member of the wealthy and influential Rohan family of France, and 70th Prince and Grand Master of the Order of St. John from 1775 to 1797.
1. De Rohan was born in la Mancha, Spain on 18 April 1725.
2. His father was French, but had been banished to Spain.
3. He served in the courts of Madrid and Parma, before becoming an ambassador to Francis I.
4. He eventually joined the Order of St. John, and served in several posts.
5. He was considered as a potential successor to Grand Master Manuel Pinto da Fonseca following his death in 1773, but Francisco Ximenes de Texada was elected instead.
6. Ximenes' magistracy was unpopular due to the Order's bankruptcy.
7. He died in 1775, and was succeeded by De Rohan.
8. De Rohan sought to win the respect of the people, and he became a popular Grand Master.
9. On 21 June 1777, he elevated the village of Żebbuġ to the status of city, naming it Città Rohan.
10. An archway commemorating this event was constructed in 1798.
11. The coat of arms of Żebbuġ contains the arms of the House of Rohan, in honour of the Grand Master.
12. De Rohan authored the" Code de Rohan", a constitutional law book published in two volumes titled" Saint John of Jerusalem of Rhodes of Malta" in 1782.
13. This Grand Master was also responsible for the publication of the Diritto Municipale in 1784.
14. De Rohan instituted the Anglo- Bavarian langue, which was housed in the former Palazzo Carniero.
15. In 1797, he established the Russian Grand Priory, which later evolved into the Russian tradition of the Knights Hospitaller.
16. In 1792, he commissioned and partially financed the construction of Fort Tigné.
17. St. Lucian Tower& Battery were also upgraded during De Rohan's magistracy, and the complex was renamed Fort Rohan in 1795 after the Grand Master.
18. It was rebuilt as Fort San Lucian in the 1870s, but it still retains De Rohan's coat of arms on the façade.
19. The last few years of De Rohan's magistracy were troublesome, due to the decline of the Order because of the French Revolution.
20. De Rohan suffered a stroke in 1792, and his health began to deteriorate.
21. He died on 14 July 1797, and was buried at St. John's Co- Cathedral in Valletta.
22. His last words were" I, at any rate, am the last grandmaster, at least of an order illustrious and independent."
23. He was proven correct, since less than a year after his death, the French invaded Malta and expelled the Order from the island.

5. He produced and directed his last Hollywood picture, "Kisses for My President" (1964), about the nation's first female Chief Executive starring Polly Bergen and Fred MacMurray.

2. A versatile film director, Hawks explored many genres such as comedies, dramas, gangster films, science fiction, film noir, and westerns.
3. His most popular films include" Scarface"( 1932)," Bringing Up Baby"( 1938)," Only Angels Have Wings"( 1939)," His Girl Friday"( 1940)," To Have and Have Not"( 1944)," The Big Sleep"( 1946)," Red River"( 1948)," The Thing from Another World"( 1951)," Gentlemen Prefer Blondes"( 1953), and" Rio Bravo"( 1959).
4. His frequent portrayals of strong, tough- talking female characters came to define the" Hawksian woman".
5. In 1942, Hawks was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Director for" Sergeant York".
6. In 1974, he was awarded an Honorary Academy Award as" a master American filmmaker whose creative efforts hold a distinguished place in world cinema."
7. His work has influenced various popular and respected directors such as Martin Scorsese, Robert Altman, Jean- Luc Godard, John Carpenter, and Quentin Tarantino.

question: Where was the place of burial of Gjon Kastrioti Ii's father?

chunks.title: Skenderbeg Crnojević
chunks.chunk:
Title: Skenderbeg Crnojević
0. Staniša" Stanko" Crnojević( Serbian Cyrillic: Станиша „ Станко “ Црнојевић; 1457 – 1528) was a member of the Crnojević noble family that held the Lordship of Zeta; Stanko was the heir to Ivan I Crnojević, who ruled from 1465 to 1490.
1. In 1485 his Grandfather Ndrek son of Gjon Kastrioti sent him to the Ottoman sultan to guarantee his loyalty, as an Ottoman vassal.
2. Stanko converted into Islam and received the name" Skender", hence he is also known as Skenderbeg Crnojević, and became the Ottoman sanjakbey of the Sanjak of Montenegro in 1514 – 1528.
3. He is enumerated in Serbian and Montenegrin epic poetry, in which he is sometimes known as Maksim.

chunks.title: Dhimitër Jonima
chunks.chunk:
Title: Dhimitër Jonima
0. Dhimitër Jonima(? – 1409) was an Albanian nobleman from the Jonima family.
1. Together with other Albanian noblemen he is mentioned as a participant of the Battle of Kosovo in 1389.
2. He suffered another defeat from the Ottoman Empire shortly after the Ottoman forces captured Shkodër in 1393.
3. Then he acted as a mediator between them and Marco Barbadigo, the husband of Helena Thopia who was at that period in possession of Krujë castle.
4. In 1402, as an Ottoman vassal, together with other Albanian noblemen, he fought alongside Bayezid I's forces in the Battle of Ankara.
5. After the Ottoman defeat, he accepted the suzerainty of the Venetian Republic as a vassal of Koja Zaharia.
6. He is last mentioned in the sources in 1409 and is supposed to have died the same year.
7. After his death, Gjon Kastrioti took possession of the Jonima dominions, which became a part of the Principality of Kastrioti.
8. Other members of the Jonima family are mentioned in Shkodër region later, however they never reached the fame of Dhimitër Jonima.
9. Even long after his death, in 1431, upon the defeat of Gjon Kastrioti by Ottoman forces, the lands taken from him and once belonging to Jonima family, were registered by Ottomans as the vilayet of Dhimitër Jonima.

chunks.title: Gjon Kastrioti II
chunks.chunk:
Title: Gjon Kastrioti II
0. John Castriot II (1456–1502), was the son of Skanderbeg, the Albanian national hero, and of Donika Kastrioti, daughter of Gjergj Arianiti.
1. He was for a short time Lord of Kruja after his father death, Duke of San Pietro in Galatina (1485), Count of Soleto, Signore of Monte Sant'Angelo and San Giovanni Rotondo.
2. In 1495 Ferdinand I of Naples gave the title of the Signore of Gagliano del Capo and Oria.
3. While in his teens he was forced to leave the country after the death of his father in 1468.
4. He is known also for his role in the Albanian uprising of 1481, when, after reaching the Albanian coast from Italy settling in Himara, he tried to struggle against the Ottomans.
5. In June 1481 he supported forces of Ivan Crnojević to successfully recapture Zeta from Ottomans.
6. He was unable to re-establish the Kastriot principality and liberate Albania from the Ottomans, and he retired in Italy after three years of war in 1484.

chunks.title: Skanderbeg
chunks.chunk:
Title: Skanderbeg
0. Gjergj Kastrioti (6 May 1405 – 17 January 1468), known as Skanderbeg (or "Skënderbeu" from), was an Albanian nobleman and military commander who led a rebellion against the Ottoman Empire in what is today Albania, North Macedonia, Kosovo, Montenegro and Serbia.
1. A member of the noble Kastrioti family, he was sent to the Ottoman court as hostage, where he was educated and entered the service of the Ottoman sultan for the next twenty years.
2. He rose through the ranks, culminating in the appointment as "sanjakbey" (governor) of the Sanjak of Dibra in 1440.
3. In 1443, he deserted the Ottomans during the Battle of Niš and became the ruler of Krujë, Svetigrad, and Modrič.
4. In 1444, he was appointed the chief commander of the short-lived League of Lezhë that consolidated nobility throughout what is today Northern Albania.
5. Thus, for the first time Albania was united under a single leader.
6. Skanderbeg's rebellion was not a general uprising of Albanians, because he did not gain support in the Venetian-controlled north or in the Ottoman-controlled south.
7. His followers included, apart from Albanians, also Slavs, Vlachs, and Greeks.
8. Despite this military valor he was not able to do more than to hold his own possessions within the very small area in nowadays northern Albania where almost all of his victories against the Ottomans took place.
9. His rebellion was a national rebellion.
10. The resistance led by him brought Albanians of different regions and dialects together in a common cause, helping define the ethnic identity of the Albanians.
11. Skanderbeg's military skills presented a major obstacle to Ottoman expansion, and he was considered by many in western Europe to be a model of Christian resistance against Muslims.
12. For 25 years, from 1443 to 1468, Skanderbeg's 10,000 man army marched through Ottoman territory winning against consistently larger and better supplied Ottoman forces, for which he was admired.
13. Skanderbeg always signed himself in ("Lord of Albania"), and claimed no other titles but that in documents.
14. In 1451, he recognized "de jure" the sovereignty of the Kingdom of Naples over Albania through the Treaty of Gaeta, to ensure a protective alliance, although he remained a "de facto" independent ruler.
15. In 1460–61, he participated in Italy's civil wars in support of Ferdinand I of Naples.
16. In 1463, he became the chief commander of the crusading forces of Pope Pius II, but the Pope died while the armies were still gathering.
17. Together with Venetians he fought against the Ottomans during the Ottoman–Venetian War (1463–1479) until his death in January 1468.
18. He ranks high in that military history, as the most persistent opponent of the Ottoman Empire in its heyday who was also ever-victorious.

Title: Jerina Branković (wife of Gjon Kastrioti II)

2. She had two sisters, Helen (Mary), wife of King Stephen Tomašević of Bosnia, and Milica, wife of Leonardo III Tocco of Epirus.
3. Gjon Kastrioti II was the "conte di Spoleto" in 1485, and "duca di San Pietro" in Galatina in 1495.
4. They had the following issue:

chunks.title: Emperor Daigo
chunks.chunk:
Title: Emperor Daigo
0. Daigo's reign spanned the years from 897 through 930.
1. He is named after his place of burial.

chunks.title: Voisava
chunks.chunk:
Title: Voisava
0. Voisava( 1402 – 05) was the wife of Gjon Kastrioti( 1386 – d. 1437), a nobleman with whom she had nine children, one of whom was the most powerful Albanian nobleman in history, regarded a national hero, George Kastrioti" Skanderbeg"( 1405 – 1468).
1. She is mentioned in passing in two sources from the start of the 16th century.
2. The first source, a biography on her son, mentions her as the daughter of a" Triballian nobleman", which is interpreted as her being Serbian, modern scholars pointing to the Branković dynasty.
3. Her name is Slavic, as are several of her children's names.

chunks.title: Milica Branković
chunks.chunk:
Title: Milica Branković
0. Milica Branković (d. 1464) was Serbian princess and the first wife of Leonardo III Tocco, whom she married on 1 May 1463.
1. She was a daughter of despot Lazar Branković of Serbia and Helena Palaiologina.
2. Milica died in childbirth in 1464, while giving birth to Carlo III Tocco.
3. Carlo III Tocco succeeded his father as titular ruler of Epirus (Arta) and Zakynthos.
4. Her siblings were Maria, wife of King Stephen Tomašević of Bosnia and Jerina, wife of Gjon Kastrioti II.

chunks.title: Kastrioti (kephale)
chunks.chunk:
Title: Kastrioti (kephale)
0. Kastrioti or Castriot of Kanina was a kephale of Kanina in 1368.
1. He was probably the first member of the Kastrioti family mentioned in historical documents.
2. If so, he was the father of Pal Kastrioti, grandfather of Gjon Kastrioti and great- grandfather of Skanderbeg.
3. Some scholars believe that his first name was Branilo, while other scholars suggest that this belief is the result of misreading a historical document.

chunks.title: Barthold A. Butenschøn Sr.
chunks.chunk:
Title: Barthold A. Butenschøn Sr.
0. Hans Barthold Andresen Butenschøn( 27 December 1877 – 28 November 1971) was a Norwegian businessperson.
1. He was born in Kristiania as a son of Nils August Andresen Butenschøn and Hanna Butenschøn, and grandson of Nicolay Andresen.
2. Together with Mabel Anette Plahte( 1877 – 1973, a daughter of Frithjof M. Plahte) he had the son Hans Barthold Andresen Butenschøn Jr. and was through him the father- in- law of Ragnhild Butenschøn and grandfather of Peter Butenschøn.
3. Through his daughter Marie Claudine he was the father- in- law of Joakim Lehmkuhl, through his daughter Mabel Anette he was the father- in- law of Harald Astrup( a son of Sigurd Astrup) and through his daughter Nini Augusta he was the father- in- law of Ernst Torp.
4. He took commerce school and agricultural school.
5. He was hired in the family company N. A. Andresen& Co, and became a co-owner in 1910.
6. He eventually became chief executive officer.
7. The bank changed its name to Andresens Bank in 1913 and merged with Bergens Kreditbank in 1920.
8. The merger was dissolved later in the 1920s.
9. He was also a landowner, owning Nedre Skøyen farm and a lot of land in Enebakk.
10. He chaired the board of Nydalens Compagnie from 1926, having not been a board member before that.
11. He also chaired the supervisory council of Forsikringsselskapet Viking and Nedre Glommen salgsforening, and was a supervisory council member of Filharmonisk Selskap.
12. He was a member of the gentlemen's club SK Fram since 1890, and was proclaimed a lifetime member in 1964.
13. He was buried in Enebakk.

chunks.title: Ruth Hanna McCormick
chunks.chunk:
Title: Ruth Hanna McCormick
0. Ruth Hanna McCormick (née Ruth Hanna, also known as Ruth Hanna McCormick Simms; March 27, 1880 – December 31, 1944), was an American politician, activist, and publisher.
1. She served one term in the United States House of Representatives, winning an at-large seat in Illinois in 1928.
2. She gave up the chance to run for re-election to seek a United States Senate seat from Illinois.
3. She defeated the incumbent, Senator Charles S. Deneen, in the Republican primary, becoming the first female Senate candidate for a major party.
4. McCormick lost the general election.
5. A decade later, she became the first woman to manage a presidential campaign, although her candidate, Thomas E. Dewey, failed to capture his party's nomination.
6. Politics was a part of McCormick's life from an early age.
7. She was the daughter of Mark Hanna, a Senator and politician who was instrumental in the election of President William McKinley.
8. McCormick learned politics by watching her father, and put those lessons to use fighting for causes such as women's suffrage and improved working conditions for women.
9. McCormick was instrumental in passing a partial suffrage law in Illinois in 1913, allowing women to vote in municipal and Presidential elections.
10. She also married two politicians, Senator Joseph Medill McCormick and Congressman Albert Gallatin Simms.
11. McCormick's endeavors were not limited to politics.
12. Throughout her life, she maintained an interest in agriculture.
13. She owned and operated ranches in Illinois, New Mexico, and Colorado.
14. She also owned several newspapers, founding the Rockford Consolidated Newspapers in Rockford, Illinois.

chunks.title: Albert G. Simms
chunks.chunk:
Title: Albert G. Simms
0. Albert Gallatin Simms (October 8, 1882 – December 29, 1964) was a United States Representative from New Mexico.
1. He was the husband of Ruth Hanna McCormick, who served as a United States Representative from Illinois.
2. He was born in Washington, Arkansas, where he attended private schools.
3. He attended the University of Arkansas at Fayetteville.
4. He moved to Monterrey, Mexico in 1906 and was employed as an accountant.
5. In 1912, he moved to Silver City, New Mexico.
6. He studied law, was admitted to the bar in 1915, and practiced law at Albuquerque, New Mexico until 1919.
7. Simms was a member of the city council 1920–1922.
8. He was also a member and chairman of the board of county commissioners of Bernalillo County, New Mexico 1920–1922.
9. He engaged in banking, serving as president of a national bank in Albuquerque, 1920–1924, and as president of a mortgage company in 1924.
10. He served as a member of the New Mexico House of Representatives 1925-1927 and was elected as a Republican to the Seventy-first Congress (March 4, 1929 – March 3, 1931).
11. He married the widowed Ruth Hanna McCormick, also a member of Congress at the time, in 1931.
12. He was an unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1930 to the Seventy-second Congress due to a Democratic takeover.
13. The couple returned to New Mexico and established Los Poblanos, a successful farm and ranch.
14. After leaving Congress, he was member of the Republican National Committee 1932-1934 as well as a banker, farmer, and rancher.
15. He helped found Albuquerque Academy.
16. He died as a resident of Albuquerque, New Mexico in 1964 and was buried in Fairview Park Cemetery.
